headline: RJR Nabisco Q2 intl tobacco profits rise.
text:
RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp on Tuesday reported that international tobacco sales and operating profits were stronger than the first quarter while domestic tobacco earnings held steady.
Domestic tobacco operating profit rose to $395 million from $390 million in the second quarter of 1996.
International tobacco operating profit rose to $179 million from $162 million in the second quarter of 1996.  
"Sales, volumes and operating profit growth strengthened versus the first quarter. International tobacco showed strong volume and operating profit advances and domestic tobacco's earnings held steady," said Chief Executive Steven Goldstone.
Excluding a one-time restructuring charge and related expenses at Nabisco in the 1996 second quarter, net income of $243 million or $0.71 per fully diluted common share for the second quarter of 1997 represents an 11 percent gain compared to the $219 million or $0.64 fully diluted common share of net income reported in the comparable 1996 quarter.  
Excluding a negative impact of currency translation due to the strengthening of the dollar, operating company contribution would have increased $37 million over 1996.
The company also said that if exchange rates continue at the same level for the remainder of the year, second-half results will also reflect a negative translation.
Internationally, overall volume was up during the quarter 13 percent. The company said the most significant volume gains were drawn from Central European markets as well as from markets in the former Soviet Union.  
Domestically, the company said the Camel brand remained the strongest performer with shipment increases of 8 percent for the quarter.
In its food group, the company said its gains reflect the growth of core biscuit brands, productivity improvements and strong growth in nuts and confections.
Partially offsetting this performance was a "significant" profit decline in Brazil, soft earnings in some domestic product lines and the transition effects of a domestic sales force reorganization.
Domestic food group's net sales were $1.55 billion.

headline: CME cattle and pork complex pre-opening calls.
text:
CME cattle and pork complex pre-opening calls as of 0815 CDT.
LIVE CATTLE - steady to 0.10 cent lower - Market still on defensive after Friday's bearish USDA cattle-on-feed report. Rising product values, however, should underpin the market.
FEEDER CATTLE - 0.10 to 0.15 cent lower. Modest overnight gains in CBOT corn may weigh on the market. The latest CME feeder cattle index, for July 18, was up $0.21 per cwt at $82.14, its highest level since March 16, 1994.
LEAN HOGS - steady to 0.10 cent lower. Weaker product prices may weigh on the market, while cash hogs look set to be around steady, contrary to some expectations late Monday that they could have a slightly firmer tone.
PORK BELLIES - 0.25 to 0.50 cent lower. Followthrough selling possible after limit decline in key August contract on Monday. Some talk that cash fresh pork belly market may be poised to weaken.
((Nigel Hunt 312-408-8720))

headline: BEFORE THE BELL - IBM eases.
text:
Shares in International Business Machines Corp eased before the markets' opening Tuesday after the computer maker released second quarter earnings.
Markets were quiet, and one trader said, "There's really not a lot of trading.  People are focusing on earnings, and (Federal Reserve chairman Alan) Greenspan's testimony today" before Congress on economic and monetary policy.  
IBM shares were trading at 101-1/2, down from a Monday close of 103-11/16.  The company reported its quarterly results of $1.46 per share, $0.04 above analysts' views, after the markets' close Monday.
Among other active shares, McAfee Associates Inc was traded at 76-3/4 versus a close of 77-4/16.  The Santa Clara, Calif., software company reported earnings of $0.44 a share after the markets' close Monday against $0.18 a year before.  
PepsiCo Inc was slightly higher, trading at 35-3/4 versus a closing price of 35-8/16.  The company reported second-quarter earnings per share of $0.42 against $0.36 for the same period a year before.
((--Ian Simpson, Wall Street desk, (212) 859-1879))

headline: Texaco Q2 down as oil, U.S. refining weak.
text:
Texaco Inc reported second quarter unadjusted earnings per share of $2.14, down from $2.59 a year ago as weaker oil prices and weak West Coast refining margins ate into its profits.
Total net income was $571 million, including a one-time gain of $131 million, compared with $689 million a year ago, which included a one-time gain of $224 million.
Before special items, net income per share was $440 million, $1.64 per share, against $465 million or $1.73 per share a year ago.
Analysts had been looking for $1.53 per share.  
Revenues were $11.5 billion versus $11.3 billion.
Second quarter operating income before special items for the U.S. upstream slid to $232 million from $243 million, but were higher on a six month basis, $543 million versus $510 million.
Average realized crude oil for the second quarter were $16.95 per barrel and $2.02 per thousand cubic feet (mcf) or $0.35 per barrel and $0.05 per mcf lower than a year ago.
Texaco's U.S. refining, marketing and distribution operating earnings before special items were were $87 million in the quarter, down from $144 million a year ago and $93 million in the first half compared with $148 million.  
"Throughout the first half of 1997 branded gasoline sales volumes increased; however, surplus supplies led to a squeeze on West Coast gasoline margins," said Texaco chief executive Peter Bijur.
In the international upstream, an 11 percent increase in output year-on-year in the second quarter offset a $1.50 fall in crude oil prices.
The quarter included special gains of $161 million from the sales of a 15 percent interest in UK North Sea Captain Field, an interest in Canadian natgas properties and a stake in an Australian pipeline system.  
The division made $79 million operating income before special items compared with $103 million a year ago, due to an aggressive exploration program and lower natural gas trading prices in the UK.
Year-to-date capital and exploratory expenditures grew 25 percent to $1.8 billion from a year ago.
In the international downstream sector, operating income before special items rose to $132 million from $80 million as refining margins in the UK and Panama improved.
Lower expenses at all refineries coupled with improved marketing margins and increased sales volumes in Latin America and the UK also boosted earnings, although lower results at its Caltex Asia Pacific venture offset some of the gains, Texaco said. ((-- David Chance, New York Newsroom 212 859 1902))

headline: Clinton seen restating importance of budget deal.
text:
President Bill Clinton was expected to make a public statement on Tuesday reiterating the importance of enacting legislation to balance the U.S. federal budget, an administration official said.
The official, who asked not to be identified, said White House advisers had decided to recommend that Clinton make the statement, adding that the president was expected to accept the recommendation.
"The president will reiterate the importance of a balanced budget," said the official. "He will call on the congressional leadership to make a major push to bring this to closure."
The official said the statement was tentatively scheduled for 1100 EDT (1500 GMT), although this could change.
Clinton, a Democrat, and the Republicans who control both houses of Congress in May reached an agreement aiming to balance the U.S. federal budget by 2002 while providing a net $85 billion tax cut over the five-year period.
However, White House and congressional negotiators seeking to hammer out legislation to enact that agreement disagree on many points, notably on the distribution of the tax cut.
On Monday administration officials said there would be two objectives to Clinton making such a public statement: seeking tactical advantage in the tax negotiations with Congress and generally seeking to give a push to the legislative process.
"We think we can both win an argument (on taxes) and we would also increase pressure on them to hold to the deal," said one official on Monday evening. "We would press them publicly because it helps get a deal at the end of the day and we think it substantively (would be) a better deal."

headline: Wall St's latest invention - century bond strips.
text:
Wall Street's financial wizards have created securities with unusual cash-flow characteristics, by stripping 100-year corporate bonds also known as "century bonds."
Market sources said investment banks such as Salomon Brothers Inc, Merrill Lynch & Co Inc and other banks have in recent months created strips from century bonds issued by IBM Corp, JC Penney & Co Inc and US West Inc.  
A recent $500 million issue from Chrysler Corp also was expected to be stripped because of its large size, analysts said.
Stripped century bonds are in some ways similar to much-discussed collateralized bond obligations (CBOs) and collaterlized mortgage obligations (CMOs) because they are created from a trust containing outstanding bonds.
"The concept is the same whether it's a CBO, a CMO or a strip," said Dennis Adler, corporate bond strategist at Salomon Brothers Inc. "You can sell the pieces for more than the whole."  
Unlike CBOs, where securities with different credit ratings are created from a diverse pool of debt, strips are securities with different interest-rate characteristics which are created of a single type of corporate bond.
In a typical transaction, dealers create two different securities by carving out the principal and interest payments from 100-year debt bought in the secondary market and placed in a trust.  
Owners of the first security receive the first 20 years of interest payments from the 100-year bonds. The cash flows are synthetically divided into regularly scheduled interest payments as well as principal payments which ammortize over the 20-year life of the security.
These ammortizing bonds currently offer a higher return than bullet bonds with the same average life of around 12.5 years, said Salomon's Adler.  
Owners of the second security, known as zero-to-full coupon bonds, or ZTFs, get no payments for the first 20 years (similar to a generic zero coupon bond), and then receive the remaining 80 years of interest as well as the final principal payment of the 100-year bonds.
Analysts noted that ZTFs offer about three times the duration of a 100-year bond, meaning their prices are far more sensitive to changes in interest rates. Duration refers to the average maturity of a series of cash flows and is used to calculate exposure to interest-rate risk.  
The ZTFs also have around four times the convexity of a 100-year bond, meaning their price sensitivity increases dramatically as interest rates fall. This makes them an efficient hedge for mortgage portfolios which tend to underperform in a bullish interest rate environment, analysts said.
ZTF's have been especially popular with insurance companies and pension funds that look for assets to match long-term liabilites which do not mature for many years in the future.
Analysts noted other factors contributing to demand for stripped century bonds in addition to their unique cash-flow structures.
"This is a function, in part, of yield compression and the fact that everyone is looking for a different angle to pick up a bit extra," said Adler.
Another factor which has led to their development is that the raw material for strips, specifically century bonds, may be selling at fundamentally cheap levels, analysts said.
Analysts noted that, in some cases, the spread between 100-year bonds and 30-year bonds with comparable ratings have tightened from about 20 basis points to around 10 basis points in recent months as the investor base for these securities has grown.
One analyst said the spread is likely to tighten even further if demand for stripped products continues to increase.
Finally, the creation of century bond strips may be indicative of an growing trend of chopping up cash flows from corporate bonds, Adler said.
"Whether it's 100-year bonds or anything else, you will see more trust structures that take corporates bought in the secondary market and carve up their cash flows," he added.
(( -- U.S. Corporate Bond Unit, 212-859-1662 ))

headline: SPX on target to meet objectives for year.
text:
SPX Corp said Tuesday its restructuring and cost reduction programs helped improve second quarter earnings and the company is on track to meet its full year objectives.
John Blystone, chairman, president and chief executive of SPX, said the company has its new financial strategy in place and is now focusing on growth.  
SPX on Tuesday reported second quarter operating earnings of $0.88 a share versus $0.72 a share, excluding a second quarter 1996 restructuring charge and an extraordinary loss.
"Halfway through the year we are on target to achieve our full year commitment," Blystone said in a statement.
Revenues for the quarter were $230.3 million, compared to $310.6 million last year. SPX said the decrease reflects the sale of the Sealed Power and Hy-Lift divisions, and non-recurring dealer equipment sales in second quarter 1996.
SPX provides vehicle service solutions.
((--Chicago newsdesk, 312-408-8787))

headline: Amax Gold sees record gold production in 97.
text:
Amax Gold Inc's CEO said on Tuesday the company expects record production of about 700,000 ounces in 1997 and cash costs in the low $200 per ounce range.
Milton Ward, chairman and chief executive officer, said, "Amax Gold expects record production of about 700,000 ounces in 1997 with cash costs in the low $200 per ounce range."
Amax Gold's average realized price for the second quarter and the first six months of 1997 was $374 per ounce and $379 per ounce, respectively, compared with $412 per ounce for the comparable 1996 periods.  
This compares with an average spot gold price of $343 per ounce and $348 per ounce for the second quarter and first six months of 1997.
In June 1997, the company had record production of 75,390 ounces of gold at an average cash cost of $182 per ounce.
Gold production was a record 192,493 ounces for the second quarter of 1997, more than triple the 62,023 ounces produced in the 1996 second quarter.  In June 1997, the company had record production of 75,390 ounces of gold at an average cash cost of $182 per ounce.  
The company's second quarter 1997 cost of sales as a percentage of revenue decreased to 59 percent compared with 77 percent for the prior year's second quarter, reflecting lower average cash costs.  Average total cash costs were reduced by nearly 28 percent to $194 per ounce for the second quarter of 1997 from $268 per ounce in the second quarter of 1996.
Ward said that commercial production at Kubaka, the company's new mine in Russia, was achieved by June 1, earlier than anticipated this year, and the ramp-up of the mine toward full production is progressing ahead of schedule.
"Kubaka's first month of commercial operations produced 17,432 ounces for the company's account at a cash cost of $160 per ounce, which is better than expected," added Ward.
Amax Gold explores for and develops gold and silver properties in the western United States, New Zealand, Chile and Russia.

headline: Tenneco says paperboard conditions improve.
text:
Tenneco Inc said Tuesday it believes it has "turned the corner" in its paperboard business because of improvements in containerboard industry conditions, including its pricing.
It also said its strict cost-control measures have contributed to improvements in that business.
Paperboard packaging operations, however, recorded an operating earnings decline because of what the company said were weaker containerboard prices than a year earlier.  
The second quarter loss in the division was $6 million on revenues of $372 million.  Second quarter 1996 earnings were $35 million, excluding a $50 million gain on a joint venture, on revenues of $442 million.
Although containerboard prices weakened early in the quarter, paperboard earnings for the second quarter remained unchanged compared with first quarter results, excluding the one-time portion of a mill lease refinancing gain in the earlier quarter.  
The company said this is due to improved mill performance, cost reduction initiatives and strong performance from corrugated products.
The company also said that in the second quarter, two of its businesses, automotive and specialty packaging, set records for both earnings and revenue and exceeded its expectations.
The company said its automotive operating income was up 26 percent, and its revenues were up 12 percent.  Specialty packaging operating income was up 35 percent.  
The company said it expects to continue to generate record quarterly results for the automotive equipment business for the second half of 1997.
The company reported net earnings per share of $0.61 compared with $0.93 after a gain.  Before the gain, the 1996 quarter's earnings per share were $0.52.
All results are restated to reflect a restructured Tenneco formed in December 1996 following the spinoff of Newport News Shipbuilding Inc and the merger of Tenneco Energy with El Paso Energy Corp.

headline: Bell Atlantic posts solid Q2 rev, EPS growth.
text:
Bell Atlantic Corp reported second quarter earnings that were slightly ahead of expectations, before taking account of a $15 million charge to cover the writedown in value of a wireless cable venture.
The company reported adjusted second quarter earnings of $1.17 per share, up 11.4 percent from the 1996 second quarter, excluding a charge of $15 million, or $0.03, for the writedown of its investment in CAI Wireless Systems Inc.
Second quarter earnings were a penny ahead of Wall Street's consensus projection of $1.16 per share before the CAI Wireless writedown charge, according to First Call.  
Bell Atlantic's second quarter revenues rose 6.7 percent over the year earlier period, and by 7.7 percent including its proportionate share of domestic cellular revenues.
Bell Atlantic and NYNEX Corp are co-owners of a cellular phone venture. The two companies are slated to merge as soon as they receive a go-ahead from federal regulators, which is expected shortly.
"The story for our second quarter performance is straightforward and simple," said Bell Atlantic Chairman and CEO Raymond W. Smith.  "The beat goes on."  
"In the face of increasing competition in our core businesses, revenues are rising, expenses are in check and operating income is increasing at double-digit rates," Smith said in a statement accompanying the earnings report.
"We have never been more confident in our ability to capitalize on the tremendous opportunities open to us," he added.
Bell Atlantic's local phone business revenues grew 5.6 percent during the second quarter, buoyed by growth in basic access lines and enhanced phone features. Local access lines grew 4.0 percent to 21 million during the quarter.  
The increase included 10.9 percent growth in Centrex lines year over year for its business customers.
Call volumes, measured by the number of minutes of customer network use, grew 7.8 percent from the second quarter of last year, it said.
Secondary residential lines increased 228,000 in the second quarter compared to a year ago, a 7.6 percent rise.
Enhanced calling features like home voice mail, Caller ID and call waiting were up 20 percent year-to-year.
Network operating expenses of $2.5 billion were 2.7 percent higher than in the 1996 second quarter.  
In its wireless business, the company said operating revenues rose 16 percent to $714.2 million and operating cash flow was up 19.6 percent to $282.4 million, with an operating cash flow margin of 45 percent versus 43 percent a year ago.
Second quarter directory publishing revenues grew to $265 million from $253 million last year.
In its local phone opertions, second quarter toll services revenues declined to $328 million from $350 million in the 1996 second quarter.
Total headcount at Bell Atlantic at June 30, 1997 rose to 66,900 from 60,800 in the same date a year ago.
"It looks like a pretty quarter," Bear Stearns analyst Bette Massick Columbo said in an initial reaction to the results. "Revenues were a bit stronger than expected and access line growth of 4 percent was solid," she said.
-- Eric Auchard, New York newsdesk, 212-859-1712

headline: Allen CDC, Texas, won by Smith Barney.
text: Smith Barney Inc. said it won $5.35 million of Allen Community Development Corporation, Texas, sales tax revenue bonds, Series 1997, with a net interest cost of 5.11 percent.

headline: No sightings of Versace suspect in Florida - mayor.
text:
The mayor of South Florida's Dade County said on Tuesday there has not been a credible sighting of Andrew Cunanan in the area since last week's murder of fashion designer Gianni Versace in Miami.
But the manhunt for Cunanan, so far the only publicly suspected killer of Versace, will continue in south Florida until he is positively identified elsewhere, Alex Penelas, mayor of Dade County, added.
"There has not been a credible sighting of Andrew Cunanan in south Florida since the murder (of Versace)," the mayor told NBC's "Today" programme.
"In fact, there has not been a credible sighting of Andrew Cunanan outside of south Florida since the murder, that's why we continue to assume he is in the south Florida area."
The search for Cunanan continues amid fears he may be changing his appearance to elude a police dragnet. He has a history of adroitly using costumes and makeup, Penelas said.
Investigators said he also may be wearing eyeglasses or contact lenses.
"Andrew Cunanan may not appear right now as he does in pictures. Apparently this gentleman changes appearances on a regular basis. He may be very difficult to identify."
Investigators were still concentrating the manhunt on the south Florida area but tips were flooding in from all over the United States, Penelas said.
Newsweek magazine reported that a Brazilian woman told investigators she had photographs and videotape of Cunanan inside Versace's gated mansion a week ago, two days before the 50-year-old designer was killed after a visit to a newsstand.
CNN reported that Brazilian police had concluded the people shown were not Versace and Cunanan though.
But Mayor Penelas, in the NBC interview, said: "We are following up on literally thousands of tips that we've been receiving locally, individuals who believe they have sighted Andrew Cunanan somewhere in south Florida."
"Law enforcement officials are wading through those tips determining which in fact are credible and following up on those that warrant following up on," he said.
Cunanan is also being sought as a suspect in the murders of four other men in a cross-country killing spree before the Versace slaying. One of the four was reportedly a former gay lover of Cunanan's.

headline: Boeing, McDonnell may face delay on vote--report.
text:
Boeing Co and McDonnell Douglas Corp may be forced to delay this week's shareholder votes on their $14 billion merger if, as many expect, European regulators fail to approve the deal, the Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday.
Quoting people familiar with the deliberations, the newspaper said attorneys for the aerospace companies are concerned about the effect of holding shareholder votes, scheduled for Friday, before the European Union grants antitrust approval for the merger.
No one was available for comment at Boeing or McDonnell.  
The Journal quoted a spokeswoman for Boeing as saying the company would hold its shareholder meeting as scheduled but that EU rejection "could trigger a chain of events including an adjournment of the meeting."
A McDonnell Douglas spokeswoman was quoted as saying the company plans to hold its shareholder meeting as scheduled.
According to the newspaper, the companies' attorneys are said to be worried that the validity of any shareholder vote taken before the EU gives approval could be challenged later by shareholders, regulators and banks.

headline: S&P AFFIRMS MORTGAGE GUARANTY INSURANCE.
text:
NEW YORK, July 21 - Standard & Poor's today has affirmed its double-'A'-plus issuer credit and claims-paying ability rating of Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corp. (MGIC). The triple-'A' issuer credit and claims-paying ability rating of subsidiary MGIC Mortgage Insurance Corp. (MMIC) also has been affirmed.
MGIC's rating is based on its leading market position, which has led the company to produce a high-quality book of business and excellent capital adequacy. MGIC's strong name recognition and distribution system have resulted in its holding a leading market share of new premiums written since it restructured its operations in 1985.
For the year ended Dec. 31, 1996, the company's market share of new insurance written was 25.4%.
MMIC is no longer writing new business, but its triple-'A' rating is affirmed based on a 100%-reinsurance arrangement with triple-'A' rated reinsurers.
Insurance is ceded to MMIC by MGIC, and subsequently retroceded to the reinsurance syndicate. European Reinsurance Co. of Zurich (claims-paying ability rating of triple-'A') is the leader of this syndicate.
RATING FACTORS:
-- Superior claim incidence experience and loss ratios relative to peers. To date, MGIC has reported a loss ratio lower than the active industry for each book originated since 1988 and a lower claims incidence for each book since 1985.
Management has consistently demonstrated an ability to manage exposures geographically and across product categories that exhibit favorable loss development characteristics. For the year ending Dec. 31, 1996 the company reported an excellent 37.9% loss ratio.
-- Excellent profitability. In 1996, MGIC reported, on a consolidated basis, pretax return on assets of 17.2% and return on equity of 24.3% relative to an industry average of 14.5% and 19.6%, respectively.
The company's performance has consistently been in the top quartile of the industry and reflects greater earnings stability than its peers.
-- Capital adequacy, as indicated by risk to capital, has improved despite the company's reassumption of some of the old Wisconsin Mortgage Assurance Corp. book of insured risk. Excellent profitability and the additions to retained earnings lowered risk to capital to 18.4 to 1 at Dec. 31, 1996. MGIC's capital adequacy is excellent and survives the revised Standard & Poor's stress test, which models the company's insured risk through a 10-year regional recession.
-- MGIC reserving practices are amongst the most conservative in the industry. At March 31, 1997 MGIC's case reserves stood at $473 million and represented the second-highest average reserve within the mortgage insurance industry at $18,410 per case.
EXPECTATIONS:
Standard & Poor's believes that recent performance is at an industry peak, although MGIC's earnings of $80.6 million for the six months ending June 30, 1997 indicate that a strong economy is continuing to drive demand for housing and improve the credit fundamentals of home ownership.
Standard & Poor's believes that further growth of MGIC's risk in force will likely be funded from earnings, with some further strengthening of capital adequacy expected over the next few years. Monday, 21 July 1997 18:58:18 ENDS  nN21247582

headline: AMERICAN EAGLE POSTPONES ANNUAL MEETING.
text:
American Eagle Group Inc said Monday it placed its aviation insurance unit in conservatorship, and it has postponed its annual meeting set for July 30 as a result of a delay in the unit's sale.
The company said Great American Insurance Co has informed the Texas Department of Insurance it would not proceed with the acquisition of the unit on the terms previously announced.
The department has informed American Eagle that in its role as conservator, it will seek to maximize value and preserve assets of American Eagle and to finalize a transaction with protection for policyholders of the unit.
The department has informed the unit it has reached an agreement in principle with Great American under which Great American will continue to write new and renewal aviation business.
As a result of these events, the company postponed the annual meeting of stockholders that had been scheduled for July 30. A new date for the annual meeting will be announced in the future. Monday, 21 July 1997 19:11:39 ENDS  nN21254635

headline: Burlington lands bigger Rockwell con.
text:
Burlington Air Express said Rockwell International has awarded it a new five-year contract for international heavyweight shipping and logistics.
The new contract is a global extension of the carrier's exclusive domestic heavyweight shipping contract with Rockwell in effect for the last five years.
It covers domestic and international air freight, ocean services, customs brokerage, warehousing information systems integration and logistics management. - Air Cargo Newsroom Tel +44 171 542 7706 Fax +5017
www.racs.com

headline: AMERICAN RE SAYS UPGRADED BY A.M. BEST.
text:
American Re said on Monday that A.M. Best Company has upgraded its rating of the American Re Corp Group to A++ (Superior) from A+.
The group consists of American Re-Insurance Company, the nation's second-largest writer of property-casualty reinsurance, and American Alternative Insurance Corporation, a primary property-casualty insurance company, the company said.
American Re is a unit of Munich Re.

headline: Arrow Air name GSAs for ex-Asia, Canada, Europe.
text:
All-cargo airline Arrow Air has appointed new general sales agents in Asia and Canada.
The carrier said Pacific Express Co Ltd is assigned to develop new traffic from Asia to the South America and the Caribbean, with emphasis on Taiwan and Hong Kong as origin markets.
JAMP Interfreight Inc, will serve as GSA for Canada and will ship via truck to Miami to access the carrier's Caribbean and Latin American network.
Taipei-based Pacific Express will move goods to Arrow in Miami and Atlanta via interline arrangements with China Airlines and Northwest and via Panama City using EVA Air. - Air Cargo Newsroom Tel +44 171 542 7706 Fax +44 171 542 5017 dg

headline: Boston airport begins work on new cargo terminal.
text:
Construction has started on a new cargo terminal to replace cargo space lost due to expansion of the city's expressway system around Logan International Airport, the Massport authority, which operates Logan, said in a statement.
The building will contain 61,000 sq ft of which 14,600 sq ft will be office space for tenants.
Massport said the building's location will provide trucks with immediate access to the surrounding highway system.
Massport said the building will be ready for next June. No tenants have been confirmed to date. - Reuters Air Cargo Service Tel+ 44 171 542 7706 Fax +5017 - www.racs.com

headline: News Corp seeks access to NYC cable - WSJ.
text:
News Corp is seeking an agreement with Time Warner that could give News Corp's Fox News Channel a crucial boost by providing it with space on New York City cable, The Wall Street Journal said.
In Tuesday's electronic edition, the paper cited "executives familiar with the negotiations" who said Rupert Murdoch's News Corp is trying to end a bitter lawsuit against Time Warner that has ensnared New York's leading media and political personalities while keeping Fox News at a money-losing 22 million subscribers.
Under the broad framework being discussed, News Corp would drop its federal antitrust lawsuit against Time Warner in exchange for a spot on Time Warner's 1.1 million New York cable system, the paper said.
Under the proposed settlement, the channel capacity would be freed up by the city of New York turning over to Time Warner one of its public access channels in exchange for Time Warner dropping a separate lawsuit against the city, the paper said.
Time Warner seems willing to discuss a deal, the article said.

headline: U.S. lawmakers try to pre-empt EU on Boeing merger.
text:
Members of Congress said they would stage a last-ditch effort on Tuesday to stop the European Union from blocking the merger of Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp.
Representative Jack Metcalf, a Republican from Washington state, said he and more than 100 lawmakers would send a letter to European Commission President Jacques Santer condemning the expected action.
The commission is expected to block the merger at a regular meeting Wednesday.
"Any disapproval by the European Commission of the merger of Boeing Company and McDonnell Douglas would constitute an unwarranted and uprecedented interference in a United States business transaction," Metcalf said in a resolution he planned to introduce in the House of Representatives on Tuesday.
Metcalf is a member of the House Transportation Committee and his district covers Boeing's biggest production facility in Everett, Washington.
In the letter to Santer, the lawmakers complained that the commission was motivated by the interests of European aerospace consortium Airbus Industrie, rather than concerns over competition.
"The domination of the review by Airbus Industries and its member nations are threatening the U.S.-European relationship and will have damaging effects now and in the future," the letter said.

headline: U.S. assails China over religious freedom - report.
text:
A U.S. State Department report to be released on Tuesday assails China over the suppression of religious life and urges Russian President Boris Yeltsin to veto legislation restricting worship there, the New York Times said.
The Times said in its Tuesday edition that the report, which it calls a "comprehensive review of persecution of Christian groups around the world," was prepared at the behest of Congress.
The report covers 78 countries and also touches on religious persecution faced by non-Christians, such as Tibetans in China.
The report said constitutional promises of religious freedom were regularly violated in China, the Times said.
In Russia, it said, there was concern over new legislation that would restrict religious freedom for the first time since the break-up of the Soviet Union.
The legislation, which is awaiting Yeltsin's signature, would restrict religions not registered 15 years ago, in the Soviet era, the Times said.

headline: Miss America contestants can choose two-piece suits.
text:
A skimpier -- but not too racy -- swimsuit is coming to the Miss America pageant.
Contestants in the biggest beauty contest in the United States this September will have the option of trading in their traditional one-piece bathing suits for two-piece suits, as long as certain standards of modesty are maintained, pageant officials said on Monday.
In revamping the annual event, officials for the first time will also have a yet-to-be-named professional journalist interview each of the five finalists live as part of the selection process.
"This year's telecast will focus on maximizing each contestant's ability to express her individuality," Leonard Horn, president of the Miss America organisation, said in a news release.
This year's contest will be broadcast on Sept. 13.
It will be the first time in the 77-year history of the pageant that contestants will be allowed to choose their own one- or two-piece swimsuits, instead of wearing the one-piece model selected by organisers.
"There will be certain parameters," Horn told a news conference in Pasadena. "No thongs or bikinis. It's not supposed to be sexual or sexy and it won't be."
He said two-piece suits will have to have "a full bottom" and be "no more than an inch below the belly button."
In 1995, pageant television viewers were allowed to vote on whether they wanted to keep the swimsuit portion of the competition. Although some critics derided the swimsuit portion as sexist, viewers overwhelmingly supported it.
This year the women will wear sandals, also of their own choosing, with their swimsuits. The pageant dropped the wearing of high heels with swimsuits in 1994.

headline: Document says Vatican hid fascist gold.
text:
The Vatican stored 200 million Swiss francs, mostly in gold coins, for Croatian fascists just after the Second World War to keep the money out of Allied hands, according to a previously classified U.S. document released on Monday.
The October 1946 document, released by A&E Television Networks, marks the first time in a more than a year-long hunt of U.S. national archives by researchers that the Vatican has been mentioned in connection with gold looted by the Nazis or their allies.
A&E, the cable television network, said it came across the document during research for a two-hour documentary, "Blood Money: Switzerland's Nazi Gold," that it will broadcast on Saturday.
Sources close to a probe launched by Jewish organisations trying to trace looting by the Nazis and their allies during the war called the document "important and reliable."
In it, Treasury Department official Emerson Bigelow writes the department's director of monetary research that pro-Nazi Croatian fascists removed about 350 million Swiss francs from Yugoslavia at the end of the war but the British managed to capture about 150 million.
He said that a reliable source in Italy told him that the Vatican held the rest and rumours were rife that a considerable amount of that was later taken through a Vatican pipeline to Spain and Argentina.
Croatian fascist leader Ante Pavelic took refuge in those two countries after the war and was assassinated in Spain in 1957.
But Bigelow said he thought the rumours were a smokescreen and that the funds remained at the Vatican.
