headline: FEATURE - Washington is a capital with two faces.
text:
Forget the tax-cut debate, the fund-raising scandal and the posturing over whether to torpedo government spending on the arts. The deepest divide in Washington is the Anacostia River.
The river, which runs into the much more famous Potomac on its way to Chesapeake Bay, divides Washington into the capital of the only remaining world superpower on one side and what is sometimes called the murder capital of the world on the other.
Across the river from the Washington of broad boulevards and monuments is Southeast Washington, a place some of its residents call a Third World country where a vicious cycle of poverty, drugs and violence belies the image of America as a shining city on a hill.
In the city where Martin Luther King Jr. once spoke of his dream of one nation no longer divided by race, the District of Columbia's two extremes are sadly separated.
"You've got a black city and a white city," African American building contractor and community activist Cardell Shelton told Reuters. "When you look at every black community in this city it's a crime haven, decrepit, abused, misused and neglected. There's no economic development, no investment."
Two-thirds of Washington residents are African American, a demographic trend with origins in the days of slavery, when the city was a magnet for blacks escaping the plantations of the South. Washington remains largely segregated today.
'SLAVERY GOT MARRIED TO RACIAL BIGOTRY'
"People were brought over here in chains 375 years ago and slavery got married to racial bigotry. It goes back all the way to then," Professor Leonard Steinhorn of Washington's American University, an author of books on race issues, said.
Downtown Washington is sometimes referred to by tourists as the Paris of North America because of its stunning architecture and majestic monuments. Even the ethnic Adams Morgan district, home to immigrants from all over the world, thrives with nightlife, rivaling the historic Georgetown area as the trendiest in the city.
But the Southeast quadrant of Washington is where you go for a mugging at night, not a double latte.
At first glance, Southeast does not appear so bad. Its brick homes, many of them government-built projects, do not have the same kind of graffiti, piles of trash and broken windows of many inner-city slums. But Southeast residents routinely tick off a long list of problems with complex causes and evasive solutions.
"You're talking about a Third World nation," Nathan Price, a taxi driver who is leading a movement to remove Mayor Marion Barry from office, told Reuters. "Something is wrong."
Washington, a 68-square-mile (176 sq km) city of less than 600,000 people, had 397 murders last year, which ranks sixth in the United States behind megacities New York (986), Chicago (789), Los Angeles (709), Detroit (428) and Philadelphia (414), according to FBI crime statistics.
SAFER THAN TOPEKA?
That was why it came as such a shock to Washingtonians when Barry told CNN recently that Washington was safer than Topeka, Kansas (population 120,000), which had 17 murders in 1996. Barry later attempted to clarify his comments, saying he was referring to the downtown and tourist areas of Washington, serving only to confirm Washington as a city of two faces.
He spoke before three young people were found murdered with multiple gunshot wounds to the head on July 7 in a grisly scene at a Starbucks coffee shop in fashionable Georgetown.
Barry blames the district's unique status -- it has some of the attributes of a city and some of a state but is not really one or the other. "It does not work," he said. "The best manager in America, in the world, couldn't manage this government the way it's structured."
Even out-of-towners know about the two Washingtons.
Tourist Bill Wallpe, a bank manager from Danville, Illinois, said he had been warned about it by a friend back home who is a former Washington police detective.
"When we were driving into town yesterday we came through some of these areas and got kind of lost," Wallpe told Reuters outside the White House. "We got into some less than desirable parts of town. It was a little bit scary."

headline: FEATURE - U.S. blacks hope for best as feds reopen bombing case.
text:
The Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth believes he knows why only one man was convicted for the infamous Ku Klux Klan bombing of a Birmingham church that killed four young black girls in 1963.
"It is well known," the 75-year-old civil rights leader said. "There was collusion all along between the FBI, local law enforcement and the Klan."
The attack on the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church 34 years ago shocked most Americans and became a notorious symbol of the violence Southern whites were capable of in their resistance to the civil rights movement.
Klan member Robert Chambliss was convicted of the bombing in 1977. He died in prison eight years later at the age of 81. But civil rights leaders say police have always known that Chambliss was not the only white man behind the attack.
"I hate to say it but I think all of these people would have been caught if these men had killed four little white girls," said Abraham Woods, who heads the Birmingham chapter of the Southern Christian Leadership conference, a civil rights group founded by Martin Luther King Jr.
"Unfortunately, black life has not been so valuable. There is still a lot of racism in the state of Alabama," he added.
For many blacks, news this month that the FBI had reopened the case for the fourth time since 1971 stirred painful memories of bombings, beatings, lynchings and other violence once perpetrated against them with the full knowledge of local white authorities.
LOCAL POLICE DID NOTHING TO END KLAN ACTIVITIES
Shuttlesworth vividly remembers the day in 1956 when he realised local police not only knew members of the Ku Klux Klan but were resigned to do nothing to end their activities. A bomb had exploded at Shuttlesworth's home. At the time, he was pastor of the Bethel Baptist Church in Birmingham, which was a headquarters for civil rights campaigners.
A young white policeman, hat in hand and crying, emerged from a crowd of journalists, city officials and neighbours that had gathered outside. "I'm sorry, Reverend. I'd never have thought they'd go this far," the officer said, adding: "If I were you, Reverend, I'd get out of town as fast as I can."
Officers from the same Birmingham police department later became a part of the history of the civil rights era when they confronted black demonstrators with firehoses and attack dogs in front of network television cameras.
When civil rights leaders decided to move their headquarters from the Bethel church to the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church, hate crimes followed. Just after 10 a.m. on Sunday, Sept. 15, 1963, while young girls were changing into their choir robes in a basement lavatory, a bomb went off in the church.
The explosion killed Addie Mae Collins, Carole Robertson and Cynthia Wesley, all 14, and 11-year-old Denise McNair. Two people died and 19 were injured in subsequent rioting.
Two surviving parents -- Chris McNair, the father of Denise, and Alpha Robertson, Carole's mother  -- declined to comment on the latest reopening of the case.
POLICE PROMISED OTHERS WOULD FACE TRIAL
But the Rev. John Cross, who was pastor of the Sixteenth Street church at the time of the bombing, remembers sitting in the courtroom balcony during the Chambliss trial as state police quietly pointed out to him several men in the audience who were leading suspects. They promised Cross "there would be others" to face trial. But nothing happened.
Chambliss went to trial after federal officials reopened the case in 1971. It was reopened again in 1980 and in 1988 without much success.
The FBI announced this month that it was looking into the crime once again after receiving new information. Attorney General Janet Reno said the federal government was determined to see that those responsible were brought to justice.
"I felt real excited when I heard it," Cross, now 72, said. "I hope they'll make another arrest. I hope I'll be called to give some statement in court."
Local newspapers have identified three men as potential new suspects. One, who was questioned by investigators at his home in Texas, denies any connection with the Klan.
"I believe some arrests could have been made long ago," Woods complained. But successive investigations of the bombing have faced some formidable obstacles.
For instance, a 1980 Justice Department report said the late FBI director J. Edgar Hoover himself had once blocked the investigation despite assurances by FBI officers in Birmingham that they could make a case.
Black leaders also believe the decision to prosecute Chambliss irked enough white voters to cost former Alabama Attorney General Bill Baxley re-election.
This time around, some members of the Birmingham black community hope the climate has been changed by the Oklahoma City bombing, which brought the horrors of domestic terrorism into the nation's living rooms. But others remain sceptical.
"Interested, yes, but after 30 years ..." said Roberta Lowe, whose three children were slightly injured by the 1963 church blast. "I hope that there will be some closure and we will all learn to live in unity. If we can just learn to live together and be a unit, maybe that will prove something."

headline: IMF praises tiger economies after Thai baht crisis.
text:
The tiger economies of southeast Asia won high marks from the International Monetary Fund on Monday for handling the fallout of Thailand's currency crisis, but a top IMF official said Bangkok should act fast to keep its growth on track.
IMF First Deputy Managing Director Stanley Fischer told a news briefing that Thailand was likely to need a package of tax, banking and currency measures to keep the economy on track. Some elements of the plan had already been adopted.
"We do not see growth going to zero. We think with decisive action soon, they can still grow this year," he said. But if the authorties did not act promptly, Thailand could be heading for "a long period of slow growth", he added.
Thailand was forced to devalue the baht currency this month after strong speculative pressure, and the decision sent shockwaves through currency markets across the region.
The Philippines devalued the peso and won $1.1 billion in emergency IMF funding to support future policies, Indonesia widened the rupiah's trading band against the dollar and pressure has risen on the free-floating Malaysian ringgit.
"The authorities have behaved rapidly and impressively," Fischer said.
He said the IMF was in contact with the authorities in Indonesia, where the rupiah touched record lows against the dollar on Monday before recovering slightly. "We are quite confident that they know what they are doing and will deal with market pressures in the right way," he said.
Fischer said there was no reason for the currencies of regional economic powerhouses Hong Kong and Singapore to face speculative pressure.
"These are immensely strong currencies and not vulnerable in any way that we can see," he said. "They have very good monetary authorities."
Thailand, unlike the Philippines, has not asked the IMF for help to resolve its problems, but Fischer highlighted currency flexibility, reforms in the financial sector and fiscal measures as things that would probably be needed.
He said the enforced currency float meant that the first issue was already being tackled and the authorities had made progress in reforming the financial sphere.
A revised budget had been prepared before the currency crisis, but more action might be needed.
Fischer said there were similiarities between Thailand's problems and Mexico's financial crisis of 1995 but the problems were not on the same scale.
Growth had been strong longer in southeast Asian, which meant efforts to adjust policies to rein in problematic current account deficits were not likely to have the same recessionary effect.
Capital flows were more robust than during the Mexico crisis and capital markets were not reacting in the same way.
"I think, as with everything, there are similarities -- a country which was regarded as suspect by the markets -- but there are critical differences," he said.
"We do not see the underlying adjustment in any of these countries being anything like that which had to be done in Mexico," Fischer said. "There is a problem, but it is not on the same scale."

headline: Ephyx raises $3 million, investors include Sculley.
text:
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., July 21 (Reuter) Ephyx Technologies said Monday it had raised $3 million in a recently completed second round financing from investors including former Apple Computer Inc Chief Executive Officer John Sculley.
Other investors includ Catalyst Partners, parent company of Israel-based investment bank HK Strategy & Finance whose board Sculley joined last month, Israel-based Gemini II and Nippon Systemware (NSW), a Japanese software integrator.
Gemini II led the round, according to Ephyx, which was founded in 1994 to market a variety of interactive digital video products using its V-Active hyperlinked video platform.

headline: Calif. Assembly OKs Los Angeles breakup study.
text:
California's Assembly voted overwhelmingly on Monday to study the pros and cons of breaking up sprawling Los Angeles County.
The Assembly approved the bill on a vote of 63-3, sending the measure to Gov. Pete Wilson for review.
California's Senate approved the bill last week.
The bill would create a local agency, called the Los Angeles County Division Commission, to study proposals to divide up the county into two or three smaller counties.
The commission would issue a report advising state and local lawmakers on the breakup by January 2001.
Several bills have been introduced in Sacramento in recent years to break up Los Angeles County, which has a population of more than nine million people.
((-- San Francisco newsroom, 415-677-2511))

headline: Oklahoma bomb defendant to be pictured with kin.
text:
A federal judge Monday ordered authorities to allow Oklahoma City bombing defendant Terry Nichols to be photographed in prison with his wife and three children.
U.S. District Court Judge Richard Matsch said Nichols' lawyers had shown "good cause" in stating their case to have the photographs taken.
Last week Nichols asked for permission to have the photogaphs taken in the family setting so jurors in his upcoming trial would see him as a "human being."
Nichols goes on trial Sept. 29 for the April 19, 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah federal building that killed 168 people.
Last month Nichols' co-defendant Timothy McVeigh was found guilty of the bombing and sentenced to die.
The judge's order did not specify when the pictures will be taken saying only they will be part of "social visits with his wife and children."
The photographs will be taken in the visiting room at the suburban Denver federal prison where Nichols is being held, according to the judge's order.
Justice Department prosecutors opposed Nichols' request, saying he should not be allowed "to stage family scenes now simply to impress the jury."
The only pictures the public has seen of Nichols were taken when he was in custody, handcuffed and wearing a flak jacket.
Nichols has three children, his teenage son Josh from his first marriage and a son and a daughter from his second marriage to Marife Nichols, who comes from the Philippines. One son was not yet born when Nichols was arrested two days after the 1995 bombing.

headline: Scientists examine impact of chemicals on health.
text:
Oestrogen-like substances found in the environment may play a role in declining fertility and other health risks, but much more conclusive research is needed, U.S. scientists said on Monday.
"There may be critical health problems. We just don't know. We have to do much more research on this," said Kenneth Olden, director of the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, which is hosting a three-day conference on estrogens in the environment in Arlington, Virginia.
These oestrogen-like substances, some scientists argue, have the potential to disrupt the endocrine system and may mimic or block regular hormonal activities. They are found in a broad range of products from pesticides and solvents to detergents.
John Gibbons, science and technology adviser to U.S. President Bill Clinton, said the effect of estrogens was one of the Clinton administration's top five environmental health priorities. "This is a global and not just a domestic challenge," he said.
Most studies -- ranging from these estrogens' impact on breast and testicular cancer to lower sperm counts -- have focused on fish and wildlife but Olden said not enough was known about their effect on humans.
"Feminization of males, reproductive dysfunctions, behavioural changes and developmental problems are well studied in fish and wildlife," he said, adding that more research was needed on humans.
Fish and wildlife in the research studies were probably exposed to high levels of chemicals rather than the low levels that humans face in their daily lives.
"I think it is still hypothetical that low-level, man-made synthetic chemicals are having a health effect," he said.
Some delegates said they believed even low-dose exposure of some estrogens could have a negative impact on humans.
Frederick vom Saal, professor of reproductive biology and neurobiology at the University of Missouri-Columbia, said mice foetuses exposed to estrogenic chemicals were born with enlarged prostates, an early indicator of prostate disease.
The mice, he said were exposed to levels of chemicals that humans confront on a daily basis.
"There is no reason to believe that what we are seeing in animals you will not see in humans," he told Reuters. "We should not continue to assume that humans are disconnected from the animal world."
Other studies, he said, showed a strong decline in sperm counts in the United States and Western Europe, a rise in early puberty and a decrease in the ratio of male to female newborns which could be linked to estrogens.
However, some scientists said the methodology used in several studies was not adequate, particularly in the decline of sperm counts.
"Has male reproductive health declined? All of the studies published to date contain significant flaws that make it impossible to conclude anything regarding worldwide changes in semen quality over time," said Dolores Lamb, associate professor of urology and cell biology at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston.
A group of scientists at the conference called for the creation of an international agency to conduct research on estrogenic chemicals and to collate the information from the varying research being conducted worldwide.
Shanna Swan, a research scientist at the California Department of Health Services said such a body could, among other functions, act as a clearing house for the conflicting studies.

headline: US West Coast crude rises but trade appears over.
text:
U.S. West Coast light crude oil prices edged up Monday with gains in West Texas Intermediate/Cushing (WTI), while local refiners said they finished buying crude for August.
Local sales of light grade Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude -- the regional benchmark -- remained flat Monday, with no spot deal done in over a month. Exxon sold a cargo of ANS to Shell Oil Monday, traders said , but the deal was negotiated on secret "formula" terms, which allow parties to establish a price based on a monthly average of prices.
Key seller BP continued to offer at $1.85 under West Texas Intermediate/Cushing (WTI), but saw no buyers.
Discounts for ANS remained $2.16 a barrel under WTI. With the discount flat, outright prices for ANS crude rose to $17.00/17.15 a barrel, in line with higher spot prices throughout the U.S.
Meanwhile, Kern River and Wilmington crudes -- California heavy grades -- have remained unchanged since last Thursday, when several major oil companies increased postings.
((David Brinkerhoff, Los Angeles bureau +1 213 380 2014))

headline: US W. Coast wholesale gasoline eases amid thin talk.
text:
Wholesale prices for U.S. West Coast gasolines edged lower Monday, amid light trade and a weaker energy futures markets in New York, traders said.
The day's downward price trend was influenced by a slight dip in August unleaded gasoline futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX), which settled 0.01 cent a gallon to 60.04 cents. August crude, which expires Tuesday, fell nine cents a barrel to $19.18 cents.
The lower prices reflected concerns of increasing supplies now that the United Nations and Iraq appear to have agreed on final terms for the oil-for-food deal, which will renew exports from the Middle East producer.
LOS ANGELES:
Traders offered July and August CARB gasoline to Los Angeles refineries at 58.50 cents and 59.50 cents a gallon, traders said, 0.50 cents under Friday.
CARB diesel edged up slightly, to 56 and 57 cents a gallon, a half cent over Friday's levels.
Shell Oil Co's refinery in Martinez, Calif, near San Francisco, was operating normally Monday following a extremely short fire in an asphalt making unit Saturday. The fire, extinguish within minutes, failed to disrupt production or supplies to custmers, a company spokesman said Monday.
SAN FRANCISCO:
State-mandated CARB gasoline fell in line with L.A., and was talked at the same levels as Los Angeles. CARB diesel fuel remained about five cents under L.A. due to overproductionn.
((David Brinkerhoff, Los Angeles bureau 213 380-2014))

headline: Swedish bond yields end down, underperform Bunds.
text:
1440 GMT - Yields tracked falling European yields and ended lower. Swedish bonds underperformed, however, and the spread versus Germany widened three basis points to 96. Italian 10-year bond yields fell below their Swedish equivalents.
The crown gained to its strongest level since October 1996 against a generally weaker mark. The mark weakened against the dollar on growing expectations that the single European currency would be soft.
* Six month T-bill rate unchanged at 4.25 pct
* 10-year bond yield fell four basis points to 6.50 pct
* Crown firms to 4.3030 crowns against the mark versus 4.3325

headline: Port conditions update - Italy - Lloyds Shipping.
text:
Port conditions from Lloyds Shipping Intelligence Service --
ITALY, July 22 - Genoa - No vessels awaiting berths.
Savona - One vessel awaiting normal berth, average delay 12 to 24 hours. No vessels awaiting special berths.

headline: Kohl pledges support to flood-hit east Germans.
text:
German Chancellor Helmut Kohl took a detour on Tuesday on a scheduled trip to east Germany to assure flood-hit inhabitants they could count on full government backing in their plight.
Kohl's pledge came as east Germans struggled to reinforce dykes that have been straining to support the banks of the swollen River Oder, which marks part of the German-Polish border.
Hundreds of homes in the Oder region have been flooded, hit by power cuts and swamped by overflowing sewers. But Germany has escaped the loss of life that followed flooding in Poland and the Czech Republic.
With water swirling around his feet as he stood on a bridge in the eastern town of Frankfurt-an-der-Oder, Kohl said he had told emergency services to provide "every imaginable" help in the region.
"Now the point is to do everything that we can do to help the people here," Kohl told reporters. "Thank God Germany has been unified and all Germans regard this as their country and their problem."
Kohl, who stopped over in Frankfurt-an-der-Oder on his way to visit a steel mill in the nearby town of Eisenhuettenstadt, said he would propose at a cabinet meeting on Wednesday that soft government loans be made available to businesses hit by water damage.
He also repeated a promise made last week to help Poland in its efforts to counter the floods.
Earlier, water spilled through the small town of Brieskow-Finkenheerd some 15 km (10 miles) along the River Oder after leaks appeared in a dyke intended to contain the river's swollen banks.
Residents waded through the water to remove valuables from their houses but the water level was soon so high that even emergency services were not able to approach the flooded area.
Elsewhere in the region, border guards, German soldiers and volunteers were on Tuesday helping to repair dykes as local authorities said water gauge levels along the river continued to rise, albeit slowly.
Around one million sandbags were estimated to be in place in the area, either propping up dykes or lined up in front of ground floor properties in the event of further flooding.
Matthias Platzeck, environment minister in the state of Brandenburg, where the flood risk is greatest, said evacuations were now likely if water levels rose much further.
Farmers in the low-lying Oderbruch region, home to 20,000 people, were told that the some 40,000 cattle grazing there must immediately be moved out of the region for the livestock's safety and to facilitate any human evacuation.

headline: FOCUS-Music strong at PolyGram as film loss grows.
text:
Fresh-faced teen pop trio Hanson joined forces with veteran Irish rockers U2 to boost music profits at PolyGram, but growing film losses saw first half group profit dip slightly, PolyGram said on Tuesday.
Overall net profit for the first six months of 1997 slipped to 270 million guilders ($132.9 million) from 272 million a year earlier -- a completely flat half year performance since 1995 when the first half net profit was also 270 million guilders.
Analysts had been anticipating a net profit of as much as 286 million guilders, based on strong music sales from artists such as U2 and Hanson, with the consensus view at 276 million. Operating losses from films had been expected to continue.
First-half group sales climbed five percent to 4.53 billion guilders with music generating sales of 3.94 billion. Operating profit in music rose to 522 million guilders from 457 million during the half.
The film division saw first-half turnover dip to 589 million guilders from 681 million with operating losses widening to 92 million from 37 million.
Film's second-quarter operating loss was 37 million guilders compared to 55 million in the first quarter and 18 million in the second quarter of 1996.
PolyGram said the results of its filmed entertainment business reflected the division's lighter release schedule during the first six months of 1997, adding the division expected its strongest releases in the second half.
The Dutch company, 75-percent owned by Philips Electronics NV, has recently released "Bean", starring Rowan Atkinson, to enthusiastic audiences in Australia and the Netherlands. It plans to release mainstream movie "The Game", starring Michael Douglas, in September.
Film during the first half of 1996 benefited from the success of "Dead Man Walking", "Fargo", and "Mr Holland's Opus".
At the first-quarter stage in April PolyGram said underperformance of previously released films "Portrait of a Lady" and "Gridlock'd" had hit its earnings.
PolyGram said the combination of sales from established artists such as U2 and the Bee Gees, along with those from breakthrough artists such as Hanson had delivered results in the first half.
"Despite challenging conditions in some of our markets, PolyGram's expertise in breaking new acts and promoting established artists is reflected in the first half results," PolyGram chief executive Alain Levy said in a statement.
U2 sold over five million copies of their album "Pop" in the first half, while the Bee Gees sold 2.3 million albums. Newcomers Hanson -- decades younger than the Bee Gee trio of brothers -- sold three million copies of their album "Middle of Nowhere" in the second quarter.
In total nine albums sold over one million copies in the first half, compared to 15 in the first six months of 1996 when PolyGram released a bigger number of superstar albums.
Total unit sales for the top five albums in the first half of 1997 was 15 million compared to 13 million for the comparable period in 1996.
Analysts said the company's performance was broadly as they expected, although the film side had been a little disappointing.
"It (the film operation) is loss-making and will remain so for the time being. In the second half there are some good names, but we knew about them already. The prospects are good, but not spectacular," said Peter Wortel of Delta Lloyd Bank.
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040 ($ = 2.031 Dutch Guilders)

headline: Fashion world salutes Versace at Milan mass.
text:
Supermodel Naomi Campbell, one of murdered Italian designer Gianni Versace's favourite models, wept openly on Tuesday as she and scores of other international celebrities converged on Milan to say their final farewell.
Princess Diana, former wife of heir to the British throne Prince Charles and a lover of Versace's glamorous, sexy clothes, was expected to fly in later for the memorial mass at Milan'sb ornate gothic Roman Catholic cathedral at 6 p.m. (1600 GMT).
Campbell, wearing a black dress and jacket and dark glasses, had to be supported by a minder as she walked to the Versace empire headquarters in Milan's exclusive design district.
Reporters saw her doubled over and crying.
A simple wreath of yellow flowers hung on the Versace door with a small white card beside it. It read: "Mourning for the death of Gianni Versace, Tuesday July 22 1997, 1800 local time, a remembrance mass will be held in the cathedral of Milan."
About 15 police guarded the entrance and steel rails were erected on the pavements outside to keep bystanders at a distance as friends and family came and went in the sunshine.
Versace's blonde-haired sister Donatella, a talented designer and creator of the company's Versus line, arrived by car wearing a black dress and sunglasses. She said nothing.
Pop star Elton John, a fan of Versace's flamboyant outfits, arrived wearing a dark suit and white shirt. He walked into the Versace headquarters looking downcast.
Italian ski star Alberto Tomba and the editor of influential style magazine Vogue Italia, Carla Sozzani, were among other luminaries who filed into the 19th century palazzo. Singer Sting and Italian opera star Luciano Pavarotti were also expected.
Others farther removed from Versace's glittering list of clients also arrived to pay their last respects. Around 100 workers from a Versace factory outside Milan travelled by bus to attend the mass.
Versace was shot dead by a lone gunman on the steps of his mansion in Miami Beach, Florida, a week ago. Police have mounted a nationwide manhunt for Andrew Cunanan, a homosexual prostitute who is wanted in connection with four other killings in different states.
Versace was cremated in Miami and his ashes were placed in a temporary tomb in a cemetery on the edge of Lake Como in a simple family ceremony last week.
The ashes, in an ornate gold casket, have been under close guard, but eyewitnesses on Monday said a police escort appeared to have removed the casket from the cemetery, which is close to Versace's secluded 18th century villa on the Como lakefront.
A fashion industry source said she understood the designer's ashes would be at the Milan headquarters before the mass but this could not be confirmed and a Versace spokeswoman said any arrangements of that nature were private.
Tributes, meanwhile, continued to pour in from around the world for the designer, who vied with fellow Italian Giorgio Armani for the top spot in Italian chic.
"This is a great loss for the fashion world, Milan and all of his friends," said Rosita Missoni, wife of the Italian designer on her way into the Versace headquarters.
Versace's brother, Santo, the business brain behind the Versace empire, and sister Donatella have vowed to carry on the multi-million dollar fashion house, which put the Versace name on couture, jeans, perfume and even bedlinen.
An insurance industry source told Reuters on Tuesday that the fashion empire had the life of its flamboyant founder insured for $21 million at Lloyd's of London.

headline: Helsinki recoups losses as U.S. markets climb.
text:
Shares overcame early weakness to end higher in lively but jittery trade on Tuesday as U.S. markets rose amid bets on a bullish message from U.S. Federal Reserve chief Alan Greenspan later in the day.
The FOX index rose 0.95 percent to 1,187.34 points, recovering half of Monday's two percent losses, while the all-share HEX rose 0.63 percent to 3,431.30 points.
Volume was again hefty for July, at 690 million markka.
"The overall sentiment is positive and I think the rising trend will continue until the end of the month and we'll soon be back to where we started from," one broker said.  
Merita ended 1.20 markka higher at 22.00 after posting a new all-time high of 22.30 in brisk demand. It added almost five points to the FOX index's 11-point gains.
Some brokers said foreign demand for Merita was boosted by speculation of restructuring in the Nordic financial industry, rekindled by Monday's news of a merger between Bavarian Verinsbank and Hypobank.
But others said the stock was simply correcting overnight weakness. Volume in Merita totalled 63 million markka.
Forestries recovered some of their sharp Monday losses, with UPM-Kymmene gaining 1.60 markka to 131.60.

headline: East Germans unimpressed fazed by Kohl tour.
text:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl toured two east German cities on Tuesday to reassure the impoverished, flood-hit region he was doing his best to regenerate its flagging economy.
But east Germans were sceptical about his chances.
Kohl assured citizens in Frankfurt-an-der-Oder on the Polish border government aid if the swelling Oder river broke its banks. Heavy flooding throughout the region has already claimed more than 100 lives in the Czech Republic and Poland.
Later he was heading to steel town Eisenhuettenstadt. Built by communist East Germany in the 1950s as a model of industrial progress, and briefly named Stalinstadt after the Soviet dictator, it declined after German unification in 1990 but was rescued by huge cash injections from Bonn.
Kohl's Christian Democrats (CDU) are trailing badly in opinion polls in both cities, but his visit looked unlikely to convince east Germans who have become sceptical about the "blooming landscapes" he promised them in a 1990 unification pledge.
"The promises have always been there, but we still haven't seen any results," said Sylvia Eddert, 37, an unemployed sales assistant from Frankfurt-an-der-Oder.
Retired railway worker Egon Butschkat, 61, from nearby Potsdam, was also sceptical about Kohl's ability to help them beat unemployment and economic stagnation.
"I don't really feel the government can do much to help us with our problems," he said. "I think all this attention from politicians is just part of the election campaign."
The trip comes at a difficult period politically for the veteran chancellor. With just over a year until the next elections, his popularity is fading, especially in the former communist east.
Pollsters predict a hard fight for the CDU between now and the September 1998 polls. They argue that, as in the past two general elections, the contest will be won or lost in the east.
In Eisenhuettenstadt (Iron Works City), Kohl will visit a new steel mill at Eko Stahl GmbH, an east German company that would have folded without millions in subsidies from his government.
Eko, 60 percent owned by Belgian steel firm Cockerill Sambre, expects to become profitable in 1998. Cockerill has an option to buy the rest of it before 1999.
Commentators called the trip a thinly-veiled attempt by Kohl, 67, to woo eastern voters on the eve of a month-long holiday in the Austrian Alps -- and to show off an exceptional east German success story before rolling television cameras.
"It is no accident Helmut Kohl finds himself in Brandenburg one more time before his holiday," said Berlin's Tagesspiegel newspaper in an editorial on Monday. Eisenhuettenstadt and Frankfurt are both in the state of Brandenburg.
"Without political backing and additional financial help from Bonn, Eko Stahl would have gone into liquidation a long time ago. The region is obliged to be grateful to the chancellor," the paper said.
Commentators say that while Kohl made political capital by carrying off German unification, few believe he can fulfil his unification pledges to create a bouyant economy in the east, where unemployment currently averages 17 percent.
Surveys show that a slim majority of Germans oppose Kohl's next pet project, the launch of Europe's single currency. Most opponents are east Germans who were so pleased to have the deutschemark, they are loath to swap it for an untested euro.

headline: Fears for Kali & Salz jobs after BASF sale blocked.
text:
The decision by German Economics Minister Guenter Rexrodt to block BASF AG's attempt to sell its Kali & Salz unit to Potash Corp could put thousands of jobs in jeopardy, BASF said on Tuesday.
The German chemical giant had hoped to sell its 51 percent stake in Kali & Salz (K&S) to Potash Corp of Saskatchewan Inc (PCS) for 250 million marks, saying jobs could only be secured if K&S was a global competitor.
PCS's offer was the best option for retaining 7,500 jobs at K&S, Gerhard Wolf, BASF board member responsible for K&S, said, terming Rexrodt's decision was a bad blow for the security of thousands of jobs in the potash fertiliser industry.
But the Economics Minister insisted that the merger would not be in the public interest. "An obvious and concrete danger of anti-competition does not serve the public interest. Because of this I did not give my permission for the sale," he said.
Rexrodt made it clear that he thought the 7,500 jobs at K&S were just as safe, regardless of whether or not it was sold.
Possible monopolistic price hikes were one of the dangers to the public good, Rexrodt said. K&S already has a near monopoly in Germany with 80 percent of the market, and if the merger had gone ahead it would have dominated the market.
BASF still wants to sell its 51-percent K&S stake, and it said it did not rule out any course of further action at the moment, either by selling shares on the bourse or by seeking another industrial partner.
The remaining 49 percent in K&S belongs to the east German development agency BvS.
PCS chairman Charles Childers said that the group would review the purchase of K&S after the Rexrodt decision.
"While we are disappointed with the ruling, we must respect the decision of the Minister and we will now thoroughly review our position," Childers said.
The IGBE mining and energy union said its immediate concerns lay with employees at the K&S and related industries.
"With this decision, the opportunity to secure the future of the German potash industry has been missed. The 7,500 jobs have to be secured," the IGBE said in a statement.
The opposition Social Democrats (SPD) were disappointed.
"The future with a new shareholding partner is unclear. But we want to see support for one of the most important economic sectors in northern and eastern Hessen," SPD representatives Eberhard Fischer and Ilse Stiewitt said in a statement.
BASF said that the merger as planned would have ensured the continued employment of K&S's 7,500 employees, as well as employment in related areas, and "would have greatly improved Kali & Salz's competitiveness in the future."
BASF on its own had only limited chances of turning the company into a global competitor because of overcapacity in the potash fertiliser market.
Originally the German cartel office blocked the sale, citing possible dominance of the German potash market.
Potash and BASF could have applied to Berlin courts to have the cartel watchdog decision overturned,but instead it opted to ask Rexrodt, who can overturn a cartel office decision if there are overrriding implications for the economy or for employment.
"Clearly these paragraphs in German competition law are based on ensuring the public interest is served. But the real struggle for existence is being fought on a transparent and hard-fought global market," Wolf said.
Ralf Bethke, management board chairman of K&S, said: "This is very bad news for the company. Now we have to reassure our employees and their representatives, who supported the planned merger, that we will do our best to continue our operations."
-- Frankfurt Newsroom +49 69 756525

headline: German shares seek to hit new record highs in IBIS.
text:
1345 GMT - German shares push toward new record highs in post-bourse IBIS computer dealings. Demand for banking sector shares on prospects for more deals after Vereinsbank and Hypo-Bank said on Monday they to merge fuelling market advance along with dollar rising above 1.81 marks.
* IBIS DAX up 126.34 points at 4,266.30 points. DAX ended bourse up 122.02 points at 4,230.42 points.
* CSFB raises Allianz to buy, sets price target to 560 marks. Allianz ends bourse up 36 marks at 455.50 marks.
* DMG recommends shift into Lufthansa from BA, raises 1997, 97 DVFA earnings estimates on Lufthansa.

headline: EU Commission stands firm over Boeing merger.
text:
The European Commission stood firm on Tuesday in its determination to block Boeing Co's merger with McDonnell Douglas on Wednesday with virtually no chance that the U.S. aircraft giant could still meet its competition concerns.
But German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel hoped that a prohibition would be avoided, expressing fears this would cause a trade war with the United States.
"We cannot in any case let a trade war happen just because the concerned parties have little notion of reality," Kinkel told reporters.
"It is possible that something happens so that this Commission decison does not have to happen", he said. He added that he had discussed the issue with U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright by telephone on Monday and European Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan.
Kinkel was speaking on the sidelines of a regular meeting of EU foreign ministers.
Nothing seemed to be able to stop the Commission, however, which received twice the unanimous support of national antitrust experts for its plan to block the merger on the grounds it would damage fair competition in the 15-nation bloc.
European Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert, which opposed the deal from the start, needs only a majority of the 20-member Commission to win the vote on Wednesday.
Some European antitrust lawyers have speculated that the Commission may agree on a cautious statement saying that the merger cannot be allowed in its present form, leaving the door open for Boeing to refile a modified agreement at a later stage.
The climate on the two sides of the Atlantic has become very confrontational over the merger, with the U.S. Congress mounting a political and trade battle and French President Jacques Chirac claiming the merger is "extremely dangerous".
But a report in the Wall Street Journal on Tuesday hinted Boeing and McDonnell Douglas would not openly challenge an EU ban, saying they may delay a shareholders meeting which was expected to give the merger the final go-ahead on Friday. No one was available for comment at the two companies.
Boeing and the Commission have not held any substantive talks since last week, an EU source said on Tuesday, despite the presence in Brussels since Friday of Boeing's executive vice-president Richard Albrecht .
Asked if Boeing still had a chance to win a reprieve, the EU source said, "In 24 hours you can do a lot of things, but you can't disregard legal procedures."
He said it would be difficult for Van Miert to reverse his plan to ban the merger before Wednesday since he would have to draft a new text and send it to senior Commission officials and the EU national antitrust experts for review.
The Commission believes the deal would strengthen Boeing's already dominant position in the commercial sector, a conclusion rejected by the manufacturer, which argues McDonnell Douglas no longer constitutes a serious competitor.
McDonnell Douglas's strength in the military sector, also causes the Commission to fear that Boeing would benefit from defence funds to subsidise its commercial programmes.
But the most contentious point remains the exclusive supply contracts signed with large U.S. airlines AMR Corp's American Aitlines, Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines .
The source said there had been some progress during talks between the two sides, but that "As long as there is not an agreement on everything, there is no agreement at all."
The Commission's determination to block the merger has triggered a barrage of sharp criticism on the other side of the Atlantic and President Bill Clinton warned the United States might go to the World Trade Organisaton or impose sanctions if this happened.
The EU executive has the power to block the deal if it finds it would harm fair competition in the 15-nation bloc. Were Boeing to go ahead with the merger regardless, it could impose fines up to 10 percent of the companies' turnover.

headline: Swiss accounts list to appear in 28 countries.
text:
A list of pre-1945 accounts in Swiss banks including assets left by Holocaust victims will be advertised in newspapers in 28 countries on Wednesday, the Swiss Bankers Association said.
It said the lists would be accompanied by local telephone numbers for potential heirs to enter claims for the money, a procedure that will be run by auditing firm ATAG Ernst & Young.
"It will take the form of an advertisement that will be more than a page long in some newspapers, depending on the format," association spokesman Silvia Matile said.
"There will be free telephone numbers for contacting the ATAG office responsible for that country," she told Reuters.
Matile said the press advertisements would appear in Eastern and Western Europe, Britain, the United States, Canada, Argentina, Israel, South Africa and Australia.
In London, The Times newspaper said its version of the ad would run to three pages.
The Times said the list would also run in such papers as the New York Times, the Washington Post, the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, Le Monde, Johannesburg's The Star, the Jerusalem Post and Pravda in Russia.
The Times also revealed British names on the list, which it said included Kenneth Wadd from Cornwall, Paula Singer from Gloucestershire, Emil Muller from Liverpool and Londoners Paul Mayer, Amy Carey and Boris Foster.
"We have selected newspapers in countries around the world where there are populations of Jews who may be account-holders or their heirs," Jeffrey Taufield, a senior partner at New York public relations firm Kekst & Company, told The Times. Kekst & Co has been working for the Swiss Bankers Association.
The long-awaited list covers names and details of accounts opened by foreigners before the end of World War Two in 1945 and whose owners have not been heard from in at least 10 years.
These criteria mean the tally could include accounts whose owners dropped out of contact for other reasons than the Holocaust.
A second list will follow in October with dormant pre-1945 accounts opened by Swiss residents, who may have acted as proxies to hide away the assets of European Jews and others threatened by the Nazis.
Swiss banks are breaking with their tradition of secrecy in an effort to calm criticism led by the World Jewish Congress (WJC) that the banks withheld fortunes in accounts left by victims of the Holocaust. The banks deny hoarding dormant assets.
The controversy is separate from the issue of Nazi gold, which the Swiss central bank bought during the war. Critics say the Swiss laundered gold looted by the Nazis, but the Swiss National Bank says it did not know at the time the gold was stolen.
The list and details of the claims procedure will also be available on the Internet, with the address of the site to be made public at a news conference on Wednesday, Matile said.
The news conference was moved from the originally scheduled site in the capital Berne to Zurich airport.
Along with Swiss Bankers Association presdient Georg Krayer, the news conference will include Israel Singer, secretary general of the World Jewish Congress.
Former U.S. central bank chairman Paul Volcker will also be there in his capacity as head of an independent commission set up by the WJC and Swiss banks to scour bank records for traces of Holocaust accounts.

headline: FOCUS - Waigel reasserts hard line on EMU deficit.
text:
Germany answered France's latest bid to cut government borrowing on Tuesday by restating its own vow to score a direct hit on the budget deficit target for Europe's single currency.
Finance Minister Theo Waigel said he would continue Bonn's tough savings drive to meet the Maastricht treaty deficit goal of three percent of gross domestic product this year.
"Based on current estimates, the public sector deficit based on the national accounts will not exceed the limit of 3.0 percent (of GDP) in 1997," Waigel told a business audience in the city of Nuremberg. He said the 1998 deficit would be lower.
Waigel added that European economic and monetary union (EMU), scheduled to start in 1999, could only begin with a group of like-minded, stability-oriented countries.
"A chain is only as strong as its weakest link," he said.
Waigel reaffirmed the strict German view on Maastricht after giving a guarded welcome to deficit-cutting measures announced by his French counterpart Dominique Strauss-Kahn on Monday.
The 32 billion franc ($5.3 billion) package of tax hikes and spending cuts would still leave France a couple of tenths of a percentage point over the "three-point-zero" goal favoured by German euro hawks led by Bavaria's conservative state premier Edmund Stoiber.
German newspapers also said Strauss-Kahn's savings plan did not go all out for a deficit "point landing" and exposed deep differences between Bonn and Paris over EMU.
"Even when the French government pledges to meet its European partners in 1998 at the rendezvous with the European single currency, it is taking a different path," Die Welt said.
"It has not made three percent a top priority, while in Germany it has long been an article of faith."
The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung said: "France is making extra efforts to cut its borrowing a bit. But at the same time it fails to meet demonstrative (south) German demands for an immediate reduction in the deficit to 3.0 percent."
Surprisingly, the usually outspoken German euro hardliners have left it up to Waigel to do the talking this week. Stoiber hurried away from a television camera crew on Monday when asked about France's deficit-cutting efforts.
That left the field open on Tuesday for German euro doves to praise France and say that EMU could go ahead even if both Bonn and Paris slightly overshoot the Maastricht deficit limit.
Bundesbank council member Hans-Juergen Koebnick said EMU should start on time and the euro would be stable even if Germany and France slightly miss the strict deficit target.
"(The government) should explain to the people that the euro can very well be stable even if Germany's deficit is 3.2 percent and France deficit is 3.3 percent," he told German Radio. Koebnick, an opposition Social Democrat, also heads the central bank of Saarland and Rhineland-Palatinate.
Armin Laschet, who advocates a punctual EMU start in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrat party (CDU), also said a slight overshoot on the Maastricht deficit criterion would have no impact on the euro's stability.
"This criterion is completely unimportant for the stability of the currency," Laschet told InfoRadio Berlin.
"What is important is that international financial markets don't get the impression that Germany and France do not care about the euro's stability."
-- douglas.busvine@reuters.com (Bonn newsroom, 49-228-26097 150) ($ = 6.082 French Francs)

headline: Water spills through German town as dyke leaks.
text:
Water spilled through an east German town on Tuesday after leaks appeared in a flood dyke intended to contain the swollen River Oder.
A Reuters photographer in Brieskow-Finkenheerd on the Polish border said he saw water pouring through a hole in dyke wall there, flooding out a nearby street.
Residents waded through the water to remove valuables from their houses but the water level soon reached such a height that emergency services were not initially able to approach the flooded area, the photographer added.
Local authorities could not immediately confirm the extent of the leakage, nor was it clear how quickly the dyke wall would be repaired.
Brieskow-Finkenheerd is 15 km (10 miles) south of Frankfurt-an-der-Oder, one of the major towns in the state of Brandenburg which has seen most of Germany's flood damage in recent days.
Dykes set up to support the banks of the Oder, whose water levels are above normal following serious flooding in central Europe, have had to be repaired continually in recent days.
German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, due in the region to open a new steel rolling mill in the town of Eisenhuettenstadt, was visiting Frankfurt later on Tuesday to assess the flood situation.
Flood damage has so far affected hundreds of homes and businesses in the area but there has been none of the loss of life seen in Poland.

headline: Vatican denies it hid fascist gold.
text:
The Vatican on Tuesday denied a report that it had stored 200 million Swiss francs ($130 million), mostly in gold coins, for Croatian fascists after World War Two to keep the money out of Allied hands.
"These reports have no basis in reality," chief Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro-Valls said in a statement.
A previously classified U.S. document, dated October 1946 and made public on Monday by an American cable network, said that pro-Nazi Croatian fascists removed about 350 million Swiss francs from Yugoslavia at the end of the war.
In the document, U.S. Treasury Department official Emerson Bigelow wrote to the department's director of monetary research that the British managed to capture only about 150 million.
He said a reliable source in Italy had told him the Vatican held the rest and rumours were rife that much of that was later taken through a Vatican pipeline to Spain and Argentina.
Croatian fascist leader Ante Pavelic took refuge in those two countries after the war and was assassinated in Spain in 1957. Bigelow said in the document he thought the rumours were a smokescreen and that the funds remained at the Vatican.
The Vatican said the allegations were based on the flimsiest of evidence.
"The information, which is without any documentation, is only based on 'a reliable source in Italy' which, even if it existed, remains unidentified and of dubious authority," Navarro-Valls said.
A&E, the cable television network, said it came across the document during research for a two-hour documentary, "Blood Money: Switzerland's Nazi Gold," to be broadcast on Saturday.
The find marked the first time in a more than a year-long hunt of U.S. national archives by researchers that the Vatican has been mentioned in connection with gold looted by the Nazis or their allies.
($1=1.48 Swiss Francs)

headline: BASF - Bonn disallows sale of Kali und Salz.
text:
German chemical giant BASF AG said on Tuesday that German Economics Minister Guenter Rexrodt had not granted BASF permission to sell its Kali & Salz unit to Canada's Potash Corp.
BASF said it still wanted to sell its 51 percent stake in Kali & Salz, but it remained to be seen how this would be achieved.  
BASF had originally hoped to sell its Kali & Salz holding to Potash Corp of Saskatchewan Inc (PCS), but the German cartel office blocked the sale, citing a possible dominance of the German potash fertiliser market.
Gerhard Wolf, the BASF management board member with responsibility for Kali & Salz, said Rexrodt's decision was a bad blow for the German potash industry and a decision against the security of many thousands of jobs in the potash industry.
He said the planned sale "would have greatly improved Kali & Salz's competitiveness in the future," and that the merger would have ensured the continued employment of Kali & Salz's 7,500 employees.
"Clearly these paragraphs in German competition law are based on ensuring general well-being. But the real struggle for existence is being fought on a transparent and hard-fought global market," Wolf said.
Ralf Bethke, management board chairman of Kali & Salz, said: "This is very bad news for the company. Now we have to reassure our employees and their representatives, who supported the planned merger, that we will do our best to continue our operations."
-- Clifford Coonan, Frankfurt Newsroom +49 69 756525

headline: PRESS DIGEST - France - Le Monde - July 22.
text:
These are leading stories in afternoon daily Le Monde.
FRONT PAGE
-- Employers federation CNPF chairman Jean Gandois calls on Prime Minister Lionel Jospin to implement further cuts in public spending.
He says in an interview he regrets that the government's plan to put in order public finances is making businesses bear "all the effort", adds French businesses are the most highly taxed among industrialised countries, due to high local corporate taxes. He also warns that French industrial groups are on average half as productive as their main foreign competitors.
-- Secretary of State for Industry Christian Pierret in an interview says he seeks to turn La Poste into a "public service firm with an entrepreneurial spirit", adds La Poste plans to hire some 5,000 young workers by June 1998 to improve customer service. Other plans include the opening of new post offices in urban areas and possible shutdowns in remote areas. He also says La Poste aims to cut its losses by half to 300 million francs in 1997.
-- Framatome to transfer nuclear power plant buiding technology to Chinese partner DEC to build plants in China.
-- Paris Newsroom 331 4221 5452

headline: Oslo Total index up in correction from Monday.
text:
Norwegian share prices rose on Tuesday in line with other European markets in a correction from Monday's fall, dealers said.
Oslo's Total share index, which dropped 0.8 percent on Monday, rose 0.9 percent to 1,251.43 points in moderate turnover of 839 million crowns.
"It is a correction from yesterday," one dealer said. "The shipping and industry shares are pulling up the Total index. But volume is still low and everyone is waiting for what Greenspan will say tonight."  
He was referring to a report by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan on the American economy later in the day.
Industrial conglomerate Norsk Hydro, which plunged 2.8 percent on Monday after announcing first-half profits were down 4.5 percent, ended 0.78 percent higher at 390 crowns.
Hydro is Norway's largest listed company.
A-class shares in Bergesen, the country's biggest shipping group, were up 1.07 percent at 189.50 crowns.
--Rolf Soderlind, Oslo newsroom +47 22 42 50 41

headline: Swedish debt/currency market closing report.
text:
The crown strengthened on Tuesday to its firmest levels since October 1996, lifted by a strong dollar. Debt yields fell with foreign markets.
"The main thing today is that Italy's spread against Germany has shrunk below the German-Swedish spread," one dealer said.
Both European and U.S. debt markets showed strength. Dealers said Swedish yields underperformed other yields because Sweden plans to stand outside Europe's single currency.
Trade was thin and players sidelined ahead of U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's semi-annual Humphrey Hawkins testimony on monetary policy and economic conditions which begins at 1800 GMT.  
The mark weakened against the dollar on growing expectations of a soft euro. The dollar was sailing close to its new 71-month high against the mark in late European trade on Tuesday.
The Riksbank left its key repurchase rate at an unchanged 4.10 percent at this morning's tender which allocated 14.5 billions crowns to the market.
Six month T-bill rate was unchanged at 4.25 percent and the ten year bond yield fell four basis points to 6.50 percent. The crown firmed to 4.3030 crowns to the mark versus 4.3325 crowns on Monday.
-- Stockholm newsroom +46-8-700 1017

headline: Chirac renews call for firm line on Boeing.
text:
French President Jacques Chirac renewed a call on Tuesday for the European Commission to take a firm line on the planned merger between Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp, his spokeswoman said.
Presidential spokeswoman Catherine Colonna said Chirac and Luxembourg Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker discussed the disputed merger during talks in Paris on Tuesday, on the eve of a key Commission decision on whether to ban the deal.
"The president indicated to Mr Juncker that France wanted a very great firmness on this case, which it considers crucial to European interests," Colonna told reporters.
French officials said President Bill Clinton, who has threatened possible retaliation against the Europeans if they block the deal, had not telephoned Chirac to discuss the matter, although he had apparently been lobbying other EU leaders.
- Paris newsroom +331 4221 5452

headline: POLL -- Italy seen issuing 30.25 trln lire BOTs.
text:
The Italian Treasury is expected to issue between 29 and 31.5 trillion lire of short-term BOT bills at auction on July 27, with an average forecast for 30.25 trillion lire against 33.25 trillion lire maturing, analysts polled by Reuters said on Tuesday.
The Treasury is also seen issuing two trillion lire of both 18-month and 24-month zero coupon certificates (CTZ), while there are no CTZs maturing at the end of the month.
The Treasury will detail the amounts on offer at the end-month auction on Wednesday, while settlement date for the paper is July 31.
Following are the analysts' forecasts (in trillion lire)
