headline: Differences burst into open on EU enlargement.
text:
European Union governments openly bared their differences on Tuesday over how many former Iron Curtain countries to invite to entry talks for the EU's first eastwards expansion.
At the start of five months of horsetrading before EU leaders take a final decision in Luxembourg in December, a clear split emerged during a meeting of EU foreign ministers over whether to invite all 10 eastern applicants or just five.
In a policy blueprint for the next century the European Commission recommended last week that Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovenia and Estonia should be invited to talks, along with Cyprus, early next year.
Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, Romania and Bulgaria would have a separate status allowing them to prepare for membership at their own pace.
Italy, Denmark and Sweden told their EU partners during a televised debate on Tuesday the distinction risked creating a new curtain between east and west, creating popular resentment and setting back the reform process in the countries left out.
"It's extremely important for European stability that enlargement is organised in a way that enlargement does not cause fresh divisions," Danish Foreign Minister Niels Helveg Petersen told his colleagues.
"We are under a historic obligation to ensure Europe grows together."
Italian foreign minister Lamberto Dini said "We must ensure that no obvious differentiation is established, because of the effect that this would have on their process towards democratisation and the liberalisation of their economies."
"If we point fingers at certain countries I think this could have a detrimental effect on their development," he added.
The nordic states want all three of their Baltic neighbours, former members of the Soviet Union, to be included in entry talks to prevent them slipping back under Russia's wing.
Italy is concerned to avoid exclusion for struggling countries from the volatile Balkan region.
Their concerns are made more intense by the fact that the NATO military alliance decided against inviting countries from either region in its first eastern enlargement, which will embrace only Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary.
German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel and Austrian Foreign Minister Wolfgang Schuessel, on the other hand, said they were satisfied with the planned scheme for keeping countries left out of the first negotiating wave involved.
The discussion also pointed to deep arguments in the coming months and perhaps years over the way EU policies on agriculture, regional funding and financing should be changed to cope with new members.
EU farm ministers will discuss for the first time later on Tuesday a plan to cut guaranteed farm prices -- by 10 per cent in the case of dairy products and 20 percent for cereals -- to prepare for eastwards enlargement.
French Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine said France would insist that Europe's farmers retained their export capacity and that farmers' incomes were maintained.
"We want to make sure that that European agriculture can continue to export and that our farmers' incomes are ensured," he said.
Germany's Kinkel said that the EU's finances, which will keep their current ceiling for the expansion, would have to be rejigged so that his country paid less.
"The net contribution of Germany has gone out of all proportion over the past few years," he said.

headline: Dutch closing share market report.
text:
The Dutch share market outperformed most European rivals on Tuesday, ending over three percent firmer as the dollar pushed higher and Wall Street started strongly, dealers said.
The AEX index of leading shares closed up 29.28 points, or 3.14 percent, at 960.62 points.
The buying, said traders, came mainly from private investors. Overall volume was fairly low.
"Again we've seen private investors in the market itself and in options. Professionals have mainly just fine tuned their portfolios," one trader said.  
Financials performed particularly well after relative underperformance. ABN Amro rose 3.40 guilders to 48.30. Aegon was up 5.30 guilders to 155.00.
"Over the last seven or eight days, they have not been among the top performers and the bond market is up a fair bit today," one trader said.
Semiconductor equipment maker ASM Lithography and of software producer Baan also rose sharply ahead of first half results due out on Wednesday -- ASM Litho by 9.90 guilders to 161.80 and Baan by 5.50 guilders to 156.50.
Specific company news on Tuesday was limited to two stocks.  
Chemicals group DSM announced it would buy the polyolefin activities of Veba Oel unit Vestolen. The acquisition and expansion plans will cost DSM a billion guilders spread over several years. The shares gained 4.90 guilders to 229.40.
PolyGram first half profits, of 270 million guilders, were at the lower end of the forecast range and were two million guilders lower than for the same period in 1996. Its shares rose sharply after the news but dropped back soon after and, by the close, were up a modest 90 cents to 101.90 guilders.
"It was trading at that level when the figures came out and the index is now some 10 points higher," one trader said.
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040

headline: Milan's Mibtel and Fib30 indicies hit new highs.
text:
Italy's all-share Mibtel stock index and the Fib30 futures contract on the Mib30 blue chip stock index both hit record highs in late trading, dealers said.
The Mibtel touched a new record high of 14,967 and the September Fib30 contract hit a new high of 23,060.
-- Milan newsroom +392 66129502

headline: Athens bourse approves Themeliodomi's rights issue.
text:
The Athens stock exchange authorities cleared the 3.17 billion drachma rights issue of construction company Themeliodomi, it said in a statement.
Themeliodomi will issue 1,545,000 new common registered shares with a par value of 200 drachmas each, entitling existing shareholders to three new shares per 10 outstanding at 2,050 drachmas.
Proceeds from the rights issue will go towards financing capital investments and working capital, it said. --Angelos Kiosklis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

headline: EU welcomes decision to convene Albanian assembly.
text:
The European Union welcomed on Tuesday the move by Albanian President Sali Berisha to convene the first session of a new parliament for Wednesday.
And in a statement issued during a meeting of EU foreign ministers the bloc urged Albania's political factions to do all that is necessary to allow a new government, with a popular mandate, to be set up.
After Berisha signed the decree convening parliament on Monday, his Democratic Party said it would not attend.
"The European Union notes with satisfaction the convening of the Albanian parliament for Wednesday, July 23," the EU statement said.
"It appeals to all of Albania's political forces to do all they can to come quickly to the formation of a new government..."
Berisha has repeatedly said he will resign once the new parliament is in place but his statement gave no indication of when he planned to step down.
Berisha's Socialist opponents, who won a big majority in the June 29 elections, warned on Sunday that if he failed to issue the decree, they would call the first session themselves.
His own defeated Democrats said they would boycott the session to protest at the conduct of the polls.
Much of the country is still ruled by armed gangs and most Albanians are eager to see a new government take charge and start restoring law and order.
The EU statement said that an EU-World Bank donor conference would only be held later in the year if the government set up an International Monetary Fund-backed programme of economic reforms.

headline: Merged Bavarian bank seeks top credit rating.
text:
The head of Bayersiche Vereinsbank said on Tuesday that the new bank resulting from the merger between Vereinsbank and Bayerische Hypotheken- und Wechsel-Bank should get a top rating.
Vereinsbank management board chairman Albrecht Schmidt an annoucement that U.S. rating agency Moody's would examine Vereinsbank's ratings.
Moody's said it would be examining ratings after the news on Monday that Vereinsbank would merge with Hypo-Bank into a German banking giant second only to Deutsche Bank AG.
Schmidt also welcomed Moody's announcement that it had left its rating of Vereinsbank mortgage bonds unchanged at AAA.
The importance of the merger between the two Bavarian banks meant that an examination of ratings was necessary, Schmidt said, and Vereinsbank would do everything to convince Moody's of the quality of the new bank.
The new bank resulting from the merger "deserves the same good rating that Vereinsbank has enjoyed until now," he said.
--Frankfurt Newsroom +49 69 756525

headline: Princess Diana arrives in Milan for Versace mass.
text:
Princess Diana arrived in Milan on Tuesday for a memorial mass for the murdered designer Gianni Versace, one of her favourite stylists and a personal friend.
Diana, former wife of Britain's heir to the throne Prince Charles, wore a black sleeveless, knee-length dress and white pearls, black tights and black high-heeled shoes.
She went inside the Versace headquarters ahead of a memorial mass due to be held in Milan's huge gothic Roman Catholic cathedral at 6 p.m. (1600 GMT). She said nothing to waiting reporters.
Diana, hailed as one of the world's style icons, made an exception to her preference for the work of British designers to wear Versace's sexy, glamorous clothes and often spoke of her friendship for him. She said she was devastated by his murder.
The Italian designer paid tribute to the princess by naming a handbag after her -- the Lady Di.
Versace, who was 50, was shot dead by a lone gunman on the steps of his Miami Beach mansion a week ago. Police have mounted a massive manhunt for homosexual prostitute Andrew Cunanan.

headline: Siemens Espana aims to boost telecom turnover.
text:
Siemens Espana, the Spanish unit of German industrial group Siemens AG, aims to boost its turnover in the telecommunications business to around 60 billion pesetas ($393.3 million) in the year 2000, compared with an expected turnover of 34 billion for 1996-1997.
"Spain will be for Siemens one of the preferred markets in telecommunications in the coming years," said Eduardo Montes, chief executive of the group in Spain.
In December 1996, Siemens bought an 80 percent stake in Amper Elasa, a former unit of telephone equipment producer Amper, for around 13 billion pesetas.
Montes added that Siemens expects to become one of the main suppliers for Spanish telephone operator Retevision.
Siemens' telecommunications divisions now account for between 20 and 25 percent of total turnover of the group in Spain.
In the fiscal year 1995-1996 Siemens Espana had a total turnover of 155 billion pesetas and a net profit of 1.72 billion.
For 1996-97, Siemens Espana expects to reach sales of around 175 billion pesetas.
-- Madrid newsroom + 34 1 585 8340
($ = 152.5 Spanish Pesetas)

headline: EU Commission firm over Boeing merger.
text:
The European Commission stood firm on Tuesday in its determination to block Boeing Co's merger with McDonnell Douglas on Wednesday, with virtually no chance that the U.S. aircraft giant could meet its competition concerns.
But German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel hoped that a prohibition would be avoided, expressing fears this would cause a trade war with the United States.
"We cannot in any case let a trade war happen just because the concerned parties have little notion of reality," Kinkel told reporters.
"It is possible that something happens so that this Commission decison does not have to happen", he said. He added that he had discussed the issue with U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright by telephone on Monday and European Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan.
Kinkel was speaking on the sidelines of a regular meeting of EU foreign ministers.
Nothing seemed to be able to stop the Commission, however, which received twice the unanimous support of national antitrust experts for its plan to block the merger on the grounds it would damage fair competition in the 15-nation bloc.
European Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert, which opposed the deal from the start, needs only a majority of the 20-member Commission to win the vote on Wednesday.
Some European antitrust lawyers have speculated that the Commission may agree on a cautious statement saying that the merger cannot be allowed in its present form, leaving the door open for Boeing to refile a modified agreement at a later stage.
The climate on the two sides of the Atlantic has become very confrontational over the merger, with the U.S. Congress mounting a political and trade battle and French President Jacques Chirac claiming the merger is "extremely dangerous".
But a report in the Wall Street Journal on Tuesday hinted Boeing and McDonnell Douglas would not openly challenge an EU ban, saying they may delay a shareholders meeting which was expected to give the merger the final go-ahead on Friday. No one was available for comment at the two companies.
Boeing and the Commission have not held any substantive talks since last week, an EU source said on Tuesday, despite the presence in Brussels since Friday of Boeing's executive vice-president Richard Albrecht.
Asked if Boeing still had a chance to win a reprieve, the EU source said, "In 24 hours you can do a lot of things, but you can't disregard legal procedures."
He said it would be difficult for Van Miert to reverse his plan to ban the merger before Wednesday since he would have to draft a new text and send it to senior Commission officials and the EU national antitrust experts for review.
The Commission believes the deal would strengthen Boeing's already dominant position in the commercial sector, a conclusion rejected by the manufacturer, which argues McDonnell Douglas no longer constitutes a serious competitor.
McDonnell Douglas's strength in the military sector, also causes the Commission to fear that Boeing would benefit from defence funds to subsidise its commercial programmes.
But the most contentious point remains the exclusive supply contracts signed with large U.S. airlines AMR Corp's American Aitlines, Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines.
The source said there had been some progress during talks between the two sides, but that "As long as there is not an agreement on everything, there is no agreement at all."
The Commission's determination to block the merger has triggered a barrage of sharp criticism on the other side of the Atlantic and President Bill Clinton warned the United States might go to the World Trade Organisaton or impose sanctions if this happened.
The EU executive has the power to block the deal if it finds it would harm fair competition in the 15-nation bloc. Were Boeing to go ahead with the merger regardless, it could impose fines up to 10 percent of the companies' turnover.

headline: Ericsson to ship biggest-ever Brazil order by air.
text:
Swedish telecoms group Ericsson said on Tuesday it would ship equipment to fulfil a 1.3 billion crown mobile telephone network order to Brazil by air.
"We will ship it by air freight -- we always do," said Ericsson radio division logisitics spokesman Peter Makk.
Makk said he did not know how many tonnes the order would involve, nor by when it had to be delivered.
Ericsson announced earlier on Tuesday it won an order for an AMPS wireless communications network from Telecomunicacoes do Parana SA (Telepar), its largest ever order in Brazil.
-- Abigail Schmelz, Stockholm newsroom +46-8-700-1003

headline: Losses loom for Bunds if Greenspan fails to cheer.
text:
German Bunds and futures were hanging just below recent highs late on Tuesday, awaiting a key speech on the U.S. economy by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, due to start at 1800 GMT.
Analysts said that market, although firm, had a nervous air about it, with some saying the potential downside risk from Greenspan's speech was much greater than the potential upside.
"The outlook for this market all really depends on Greenspan. Domestic factors don't come into it at the moment," said one Frankfurt-based trader.  
By 1442 GMT, the September DTB Bund future was trading 32 basis points up at 103.02, off an earlier daily peak at 103.11.
"We've seen quite a bit of short covering in the market this afternoon," said another trader. "Every time we see the future come up a couple of ticks, there is quite a lot of activity in the cash market."
But dealers warned that ahead of such a key U.S. speech, German debt prices might be overstretching it a little.
"It doesn't really make much sense to cover shorts just before Greenspan's testimony. The downside risk is much bigger than the upside," said one.  
Analysts said markets would be keeping a close eye on any Greenspan comments on whether he considers the current relative slowdown in the growth of the U.S. economy is temporary, or whether it will continue to allow the Fed to hold off from tightening monetary policy in the coming months.
On Wednesday, a more domestic focus returns to Bunds, with the first releases of July consumer price data due from German states. Analysts said they expected the broadly subdued, low inflation environment to continue to support Bunds.
But the mark, which earlier slid to its lowest dollar level since 1991 over 181.0 marks, might take away some of the shine.  
In the cash market, the 10-year benchmark Bund was trading 27 ticks higher at 103.44 by 1508 GMT for a bid yield of 5.532 percent with the 10-year yield spread to U.S. Treasuries at 80 basis points.
-- Kate Kelland, Frankfurt Newsroom +49 69 756525

headline: Danish shares recover, rest up to Greenspan.
text:
Danish share prices closed higher on Tuesday, rallying on renewed buyer interest after two days of profit-taking and correction, with dealers seeing further gains if U.S. Fed chairman Alan Greenspan's Humphrey Hawkins speech is positive.
"The market undertone is positive after upturning the recent days' falls to rally with banks and Moeller up front. It's up to Greenspan now," one dealer said.
The KFX top-20 index gained 2.03 point to close at 190.59, while the KFX August future rose 3.50 point to 190.80 with 677 contracts each worth 100,000 crowns traded.
"I don't think Greenspan will say anything to hurt the market, so we should continue to rise," another dealer said.
SAS continued up, putting on 2.5 crowns to end at 102.50, while Moeller's D/S 1912 and D/S Svendborg went up 6,500 and 15,000 crowns to close at 295,000 and 420,000 crowns respectively.
Leading banks Den Danske Bank and Unidanmark moved 12 and four crowns up to finish at 766 and 424, while BG Bank rose 15 crowns to 387.
Overall turnover for the day was 1.221 billion crowns.

headline: Juncker-Move on EU policy coordination by year-end.
text:
Luxembourg Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker said on Tuesday that he expected a decision by the end of this year on how to intensify economic policy coordination under European monetary union.
France's new Socialist-led government has insisted on improving policy coordination to boost growth and jobs.
"We would have a definite decision on the coordination of economic policies by the end of this year," Juncker told reporters after a meeting with French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin.
Luxembourg this month took over the EU's six-month rotating presidency.
Juncker noted that an EU summit in Amsterdam had called for work detailing the ways in which policy coordination, foreseen in articles 102A and 103 of the Maastricht treaty, would be stepped up.
The question is to be discussed at an informal meeting of EU finance ministers in Luxembourg in September.
Asked whether he had discussed membership of the executive board of the future European central bank and fixing exchange rates under monetary union in his talks in Paris, Juncker said "briefly".
"I will have to deepen these points with the French finance minister," he said.
Juncker, who was due to go on to talks with French Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn, declined to give further details on these issues.
-- Paris Newsroom +331 4221 5381

headline: Boeing easing position on supply pacts - Kinkel.
text:
European Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert told EU foreign ministers on Tuesday that the United States was showing signs of easing its position on Boeing's exclusive supply pacts with airlines which has been the key for EU approval of the merger with McDonnell Douglas, German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said.  
"According to Van Miert, there appear to be signs that the American side is softening its position on the issue of (exclusive contracts) in the merger case," Kinkel said in a written statement.
"This could influence the decision of the Commission in the merger control process," he said, adding: "This decision is solely up to the Commission."
The comments followed an unexpected briefing by Van Miert to EU foreign ministers who were holding a regular meeting.
The long-term exclusive contracts signed between Boeing and U.S. airlines AMR Corp's American Airlines, Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines remain the most contentious point in the talks between the Commission and Boeing over the proposed $14 billion merger.
The Federal Trade Commission of the United States approved the merger unconditionally early this month but said the exclusive pacts were "potentially troubling".
Boeing proposed last week reducing the contracts to 13 years from 25 years and not concluding any new ones during the next 10 years, sources close to the negotiations said. The Commission considered that insufficient. Brussels newsroom 322 2876841

headline: Finland govt to cut back on construction - finmin.
text:
Finland's finance ministry budget proposal for next year includes a plan to cut back on construction activities to prevent the economy overheating, Finance Minister Sauli Niinisto said on Tuesday.
"There has been intensive investment in the construction sector recently to get colour to the construction market, and now that it has come, we can cut back slightly," he told a news conference.
But he said no sector would face cuts worth billions of markka.
Niinisto said earlier that the budget proposal for next year would set the deficit at 17 billion markka, four billion markka lower than earlier planned.
Second finance minister Arja Alho said fiscal austerity was a way to keep the Bank of Finland from monetary tightening.
"(Continued saving) shows the government wants to keep decisions for itself, in fiscal policy, so that in monetary policy there would not be a need to react on the (economic) situation," she said.
Niinisto said the forecast for growth in gross domestic product was 4.5 percent this year and 3.5 percent for next year.
The 1997 forecast was unchanged, but the 1998 forecast was lowered slightly from 3.6 percent earlier.
-- Helsinki newsroom +358-9-680 50 245, news@reuters.fi

headline: Arafat and Levy to meet face-to-face in Brussels.
text:
Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy will meet face-to-face in Brussels on Tuesday, European Union diplomats said.
"They will sit down with (Luxembourg Foreign Minister Jacques) Poos for a meeting," an EU diplomat told Reuters. "Both sides have agreed to the meeting, but we are not expecting anything concrete. It is just a start."
The Arafat-Levy meeting -- held on the fringes of a gathering of the EU's foreign ministers -- will be the highest level contact between Israeli and Palestinian officials for months.
The pair last met in Malta in April -- also during an EU-sponsored event -- and Tuesday's move marks another attempt by the 15-nation bloc to become more fully involved in the Middle East.
Diplomats said Levy and Arafat would also separately meet a full gathering of EU foreign ministers on Tuesday after the talks brokered by Luxembourg, which holds the current EU presidency.

headline: EU Commission to propose rights for part-time work.
text:
The European Commission is expected on Wednesday to propose rules to guarantee part-time workers the same rights as their full-time colleagues, in a move to encourage more people to accept more flexible forms of work.
The planned rules would oblige European Union governments to remove discrimination and other obstacles facing workers with a part-time contract.
A draft text was formally endorsed by EU officials, labour and employers' groups on June 6, after a year of negotiations between the EU employers' confederation UNICE, the trade union group ETUC and the public employers' group CEEP.
If approved tomorrow, the seven-clause proposal is likely to be put to EU social affairs ministers when they meet in Luxembourg on October 7.
The draft directive does not cover people doing other atypical types of work, such as temporary or seasonal jobs, or working from home, but it recognises the need to broker a similar arrangement for these people.
The rules prevent employers from sacking full-timers who refuse to switch to part-time work but say bosses can withhold the same benefits from casual workers if there are "objective reasons" to do so.
A spokeswoman for EU Social Affairs Commissioner Padraig Flynn told Reuters she expected the EU executive to approve the plans, in spite of lingering reservations from EU Trade Commissioner Leon Brittan about including references to penalties for firms which broke the rules.
Spokeswoman Barbara Nolan said Brittan's department was also reluctant to include in the text reference to the EU's commitment to fight discrimination on the basis of sex, race, ethnic origin, religion, handicap, age or sexual orientation.
The EU's trades unions and employers' groups -- the so-called social partners -- agreed in June 1996 to open talks on rights for part-time workers after the Commission asked them to consider ways of ensuring that employees in a broad range of flexible jobs did not face discrimination.
The draft directive will be the second piece of legislation to be worked out under the Maastricht Treaty's social protocol, which gives the social partners the right to strike a deal and then ask the Council of EU Ministers to turn it into EU law.
The British Labour government's decision to sign up to the social chapter means that British workers will be covered by the new rules in the same way as workers in other parts of the 15-member EU bloc.

headline: French employers want govt to help investment.
text:
National employers' federation chairman Jean Gandois said on Tuesday that after hitting French companies' profits, the Socialist government must show in the 1998 budget it is serious about helping investment.
In an interview released by the French afternoon daily Le Monde, Gandois said corporate tax rises unveiled by the government on Monday to bring down this year's deficit and help France qualify for a single European currency would not "facilitate investment."
"But I believe that if these measures do not add to others discouraging entrepreneurs and if signs are given when the finance law (is drafted) that government action will help open economic development, then investment can rebound," he said.
On Monday Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn announced a 15 percent surcharge in company tax in 1997 and 1998 falling to 10 percent in 1999. Corporate capital gains will be taxed at the same rate as profits. Small firms and loss-making companies were exempted from the increase.
The measures are part of a plan to help put the budget deficit back on track for the Maastricht treaty goal after an audit showed the 1997 deficit was running at 3.5 to 3.7 percent of gross domestic product, well above the three percent limit set by the Treaty.
Gandois said companies could understand plans to increase company taxes if it was "something exceptional to make the euro".
But he said it was "brutal" to bring capital gains taxation in line with company taxes, even if this was the case "in many countries, including the United States".
"I would have liked companies not to bear the whole burden," he said.
The euro is due to be launched in January 1999 by EU member states that want to join and whose economic performance in 1997 meets criteria set out in the Maastricht treaty.
-- Paris newsroom +331 4221 5432

headline: Strauss-Kahn eyes French wealth tax "adjustment".
text:
France's finance minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn is considering making "adjustments" to the tax on the very rich when drafting the 1998 budget, the parliament's finance comittee said in a statement.
Strauss-Kahn met members of the comittee on Monday to present the findings of an audit of public finances ordered by Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and measures aimed at bringing the budget deficit back on track for the Maastricht Treaty goal of three percent of gross domestic product (GDP).
Strauss-Kahn told the commission the government decided against cancelling income tax cuts decided by the previous conservative government,
"But he said that the 1998 draft finance law would include structural measures aimed at rebalancing capital and labour taxation, including an adjustment of the wealth tax," the statement said.
-- Paris newsroom +331 4221 5432

headline: Maersk in Canada route with Sealand, P&O.
text:
Danish shipping and energy group A.P.Moeller's Maersk Line said on Tuesday it was introducing in cooperation with Sealand and P&O Nedlloyd a new direct service linking ports in north Europe with Montreal, Canada.  
It said the cooperation deal, starting on September 1, called for three ice-class vessels of about 1,000 teus (twenty foot equivalent units) to provide weekly direct calls at Rotterdam, Bremerhaven, Felixstowe and Montreal.
Maersk said the new service would supplement its existing service to Halifax, Nova Scotia.
Sea Land Service Inc, a unit of U.S. CSX Corporation, based in Richmond, Virginia, is one of the largest container shipping companies in the world.
P&O Nedlloyd, headquartered in London, is also a world leader in its field, while Danish Maersk, based in Copenhagen, operates some 100 container ships and more than 250,000 containers globally.
--Chris Follett, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33969652

headline: French foreign minister on first trip to Britain.
text:
France's new Foreign minister, Hubert Vedrine, will visit London on Wednesday to discuss cooperation with Britain in Bosnia and in the quest for Middle East peace, his office said.
It will be Vedrine's first trip to London since he was named as part of the Socialist-led government of Lionel Jospin following a parliamentary election on June 1.
Bilateral issues such as the Channel Tunnel, cooperation in the fight against terrorism and controversies over fishing rights will also be discussed, Vedrine's spokesman told reporters.

headline: Aluminium sector hopes to boost share in EU cans.
text:
The aluminium industry believes the aluminium can may regain market share in Europe this year lost to steel in 1996, an official at Alcan Deutschland GmbH said on Tuesday.
He cited lower aluminium prices and efforts by the industry to boost can recycling.
High scrap value increased the attractiveness of recovering used beverage cans. Efforts were especially promising in eastern Europe, particularly Poland, where EU funds were available to construct recycling systems.
In 1996, aluminium cans accounted for 50 percent of all cans used in Europe, compared with 55 percent in 1995, after some producers switched their lines to tin-plated steel.
The data applied to the European Union, Turkey, Norway, Switzerland, eastern Europe and the CIS, where figures were available, and were collected by the industry body Aluminium Can Recycling Europe (ACRE).
The apparent consumption of all drinks cans in these countries in 1996 totalled 29.67 billion units.
Worldwide, the drinks can market amounts to 200 billion units, with an aluminium share in excess of 80 percent.
The aluminium can recycling rate in western Europe alone rose by two percentage points to 37 in 1996, and the industry is targeting at least 50 percent by the year 2000.
Western European recycling of beverage cans last year, at 75,000 tonnes, was down from 83,000 tonnes the previous year because overall can output was lower.
ACRE is based at Alcan Deutschland, but represents a number of can sheet producers including Alcoa, Reynolds, Pechiney and VAW.
--Vera Eckert, Hamburg newsroom, +49-40-41903275

headline: Diabetes drug has "dramatic" results - research.
text:
A new diabetes drug offers "dramatic" results and could actually prevent the disease in patients at risk, researchers said on Tuesday.
Jerrold Olefsky of the University of California, San Diego, said Sankyo Co Ltd's drug troglitazone, marketed under the names Noscal and Rezulin, helped regulate blood sugar levels in glucose-intolerant people.  
"We are not talking about making things better -- we are talking about making things right," he told a news conference.
Troglitazone, marketed by Warner-Lambert Co in the United States, by Pfizer Inc and by Glaxo-Wellcome in Europe, helps improve the body's sensitivity to insulin.
It is the first in a new class of drugs known as thiazolidinediones, which reduce insulin resistance. Olefsky, one of the first clinicians to test the drug for Japan's Sankyo, says insulin resistance is reponsible for most cases of type-two diabetes, known as non-insulin-dependent diabetes (NIDDM).
The drug is licensed for use in diabetic patients who are not responding well to standard insulin or drug therapy.

headline: Russia promises key trade proposals for autumn.
text:
Russia, driving to win entry to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) next year, promised key proposals in the autumn on Tuesday on how far it will open up to outside goods, trade sources and diplomats said.
Deputy foreign trade minister Georgy Gabuniya made the pledge at an informal WTO working party session looking into Moscow's four-year-old application for admission to the body, which would guarantee Russia access to world markets.
Gabuniya also told officials representing many of the 131 WTO members a similar package of commitments on openings to Russia's market for services should be ready by November or December.
But although major powers say they want Moscow in as soon as possible, the earliest that this could come at the present pace of negotiations would be around the end of next year, according to trade diplomats in Geneva.
Russia, like China which has been negotiating entry for more than a decade, had hoped to become a member by next May when the WTO holds its second Ministerial Meeting and celebrates the 50th anniversary of its predecessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
GATT was merged into the new body on its launch in January 1995.
Ministerial meetings, the WTO's highest authority, are held every two years. The first was in Singapore last December, which Russia and China attended as observers, and the 1998 gathering will be in Geneva.
Behind meetings of the Russia working party, detailed work is being done in bilateral discussions between Gabuniya's delegation and experts from the major trading powers, including the European Union (EU) and the United States, diplomats said.
Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin reaffirmed Moscow's ambition to become a member of the EU last week, although it has not formally applied and officials in Brussels voice doubts that this would ever be possible.
But EU trade diplomats say they would like to see Russia in the WTO quickly, but like U.S. officials, they insist this can only come on the basis of commercial, and not political, considerations.
The working party is focusing on new Russian laws and regulations affecting trade and on agriculture and farm subsidies, which would have to be gradually phased out under an entry agreement.
But trade sources say that in the bilateral meetings, a major topic is creating a predictable legal environment for foreign businesses operating in Russia, which the major powers say is vital to attract increasing foreign investment.
The United States and the EU have already called on Moscow for a "standstill" during the negotiations on trade legislation, making access to the Russian market more difficult.
Moscow, with an eye to the fractious Russian parliament, or Duma, where communists and nationalists suspicious of increasing links with the West, has declined to agree to such a commitment, arguing that reforms are still too fluid.

headline: European car rental business to pick up speed.
text:
The car rental business in Europe is clearly lagging the United States but is showing strong growth potential, Belgian Bank Brussels Lambert (BBL) said in a research note on Tuesday.
"Following the American example, a rented car is also gradually becoming a current consumer good in Europe," BBL said.
Only 12 percent of Europeans now occasionally hire a car against 26 percent in the United States, it said.
"The tendency to hire cars is a matter of habit. Here Europe still has to catch up important arrears on the U.S." BBL said.
The European car rental market has been rising by 2.7 percent per year on average in the past five years. About 600,000 rental cars are now touring in Europe, BBL said.
Tourism will be the main source for growth but new formulas, such as using replacement cars when owners' cars are in the garage, are also becoming more and more widespread in Europe, it said.
BBL said the main market segment and fastest grower remained the airport rental business, noting this accounted for 77 percent of turnover of Hertz and 45 percent of all U.S. rental companies combined.
The European car rental market, which accounts for between six and seven percent of the European car production, is dominated by five companies -- Hertz, Avis Europe, Europcar, Budget and Eurodollar.
Avis is market leader in Europe with 16.5 percent, with Hertz a close second on 15.6 percent. BBL noted Avis bought about 140,000 cars a year.
BBL said the European market was more fragmented than the U.S. one due to the high number of local players, which represented 39.9 percent against 7.9 percent in the U.S.
The Mediterranean is the main pole of attraction for tourists in Europe, with 70 percent of all car rentals, it said.
Germany is the main rental market in Europe with 28.6 percent, followed by Britain at 17.7 percent. France on 14.3 percent, Italy on 7.4 percent and Spain 7.0 percent.
-- Bert Lauwers, Brussels Newsroom +32 2 287 6815, Fax +32 2 230 7710

headline: Bank/Portugal drains funds at 5.4 pct.
text:
The Bank of Portugal said it drained 26 billion escudos from the money market at a fixed rate of 5.4 percent.
-- Lisbon newsroom 3511-3538254

headline: Danish shares rally after correction, outlook good.
text:
Danish share prices closed higher on Tuesday, rallying on renewed buyer interest after two days of profit-taking and correction, with dealers seeing further gains if U.S. Fed chairman Alan Greenspan's Humphrey Hawkins speech is positive.
"The market undertone is positive after upturning the recent days' falls to rally with banks and Moeller up front. It's up to Greenspan now," one dealer said.
The KFX top-20 index gained 2.03 point to close at 190.59, while the KFX August future rose 3.50 point to 190.80 with 677 contracts each worth 100,000 crowns traded.  
"I don't think Greenspan will say anything to hurt the market, so we should continue to rise," another dealer said.
SAS continued up, putting on 2.5 crowns to end at 102.50, while Moeller's D/S 1912 and D/S Svendborg went up 6,500 and 15,000 crowns to close at 295,000 and 420,000 crowns respectively.
Leading banks Den Danske and Unidanmark moved 12 and four crowns up to finish at 766 and 424, while BG Bank rose 15 crowns to 387.
Overall turnover for the day was 1.221 billion crowns. --Chris Follett, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33-969652

headline: Distrigaz seen gaining in Gazexport talks.
text:
Distrigaz has been in discussions with Gazexport about possibly buying Russian gas in the future, according to La Libre Belgique reports on Tuesday.
J-P Depaemelaere, Distrigaz representative, noted intense discussions between Gazexport, which is in charge of the export of Russian gas, and Distrigaz. This has resulted in the signing of a framework envisaging a future collaboration that would enable Distrigaz to buy Russian gas directly.
Distrigaz currently has no fixed date to buy Russian gas directly, which would be possible only after the Russian-Belgium link was completed. But they said their considerations are strategic ones, based on the next decade and will depend on the future evolution of the European market.
Distrigaz is ideally placed to benefit from Russia's vast natural gas reserves because of the under-sea gas link currently under construction between Russia (Bacton) and Belgium (Zeebruges). This will link Britain to the European continent from October 1, 1998 and further develop the natural gas trade in both directions. Via the Belgian network in the connection, Russian natural gas will reach the substantial British market.
Depaemelaere underlined the importance of a strategic link between Britain and Belgium to provide gas in a growing European market.
Russian Prime Minister Viktor Tchernomyrdine, also well aware of Belgium's importance in this equation, stopped-off at Bruges and Zeebruges and showed a particular interest in Distrigaz's works. Tchernomyrdine, the ex-president of Russia's Gazprom which is responsible for production of Russian gas and a 10-percent stakeholder in the under-sea link, stressed the importance of gas-related activities in Belgium. He also emphasised Zeebruges as the linchpin to and from Western Europe's gas reserves.

headline: Austrian shares climb, seen testing 1,470.
text:
Austria's ATX index rebounded on Tuesday to end moderately firmer and traders saw potential upside to 1,470 points, provided the market could break through resistance at 1,440.
"It was still a bit disappointing when you look at what the other markets did," said one trader. "It's noticeable that the future is constantly eight to 10 points above the cash market," he added.
Traders said they did not expect any major correction, only mild consolidation.
"We should see 1,440 this week, or at least at the beginning of next week," one trader said, predicting the index would test the previous high of 1,470.
"At 1,440 we will either turn back or surge to 1,470," he noted.
Dealers did not expect any negative impact from U.S. Fed Greenspan's testimony. "In the U.S. they are concentrating mainly on business results and we have had almost nothing negative recently," said one.
The ATX index edged up 0.59 percent to 1,408.44. Of its constituents 15 shares rose and six fell.
The top gainer was Lenzing, jumping 4.36 percent or 34 schillings to 814 schillings on continued demand from Monday's news a U.S. court ruled in its favour in a patent dispute with UK chemicals group Courtaulds Plc and confirmed Lenzing's patent in the U.S.
Insurer EA Generali led the decliners, dropping 75 schillings to 3,455.
The August ATX future added 17 points to 1,416 on turnover of 868 contracts.
-- Vienna newsroom, +431 531 12257

headline: Spain satisfied with two offers for CSI 35% - Pique.
text:
The Spanish government is satisfied with two competing offers received from Usinor and Arbed for 35 percent of state-owned steel firm CSI, Corporacion Siderurgica Integral, Industry Minister Josep Pique said on Tuesday.
"I have to say we are completely satisfied with plans presented for CSI," Pique told reporters, adding that the winning bid would be discussed with trade unions.
He said the government could approve the sale at its cabinet meeting on August 1, or right after the August summer holidays.
French steel group Usinor Sacilor said on July 4 it was offering 3.35 billion francs for 35 percent of CSI.
Luxembourg steel maker Arbed has said it is also interested in the stake.
The deadline for Spanish State holding company Agencia Industrial de Estado (AIE) to decide between the two offers was on July 21. Media comments have suggested that Usinor was the preferred bidder, but AIE has refused to comment.
After the sale of this 35 percent stake, Spain is expected to offer another stake of between 10 and 25 percent of CSI to non-technological partners, which could be domestic or international financial entities.
The third step is a public share offering for the remaining tranche, between 55 and 40 percent, propably in the autumn.
-- Madrid newsroom + 34 1 585 8340

headline: Ericsson wins 1.3 bln skr order in Brazil.
text:
Swedish telecoms group Ericsson said on Tuesday it won an order worth 1.3 billion crowns from Telecomunicacoes do Parana SA (Telepar) for an AMPS wireless communications network.  
Ericsson said the order included the latest dual-mode -- meaning analog and digital -- RBS 884 base stations.
Ericsson said the order was the largest ever in Brazil.
"This order is a turnkey project in which Ericsson will provide project management services involving everything from site acquisition and cell planning through final network testing and evaluation," Ericsson said in a statement.
-- Abigail Schmelz, Stockholm newsroom +46-8-700-1003

headline: Portugal govt to sell 10 pct steel firm SN-Longos.
text:
The Portuguese government will sell its remaining 10 percent stake in steel company Siderurgia Nacional-Empresa de Produtos Longos (SN-Longos) in a Public Offer to Sell (OPV) on the Lisbon bourse on August 4, according to a public announcement published in local media.
The state will sell off 10 percent of the capital of SN-Longos, or one million shares, at 400 escudos per share. Employees will be entitled to 500,000 shares and small investors and emigrants the remaining 500,000.
The seller of the shares is Siderurgia Nacional-Empresa de Servicos, held by the state.
Buy orders should be delivered to Lisbon bourse between July 23 and August 1.

headline: BT Office Products sees takeovers.
text:
BT Office Products International Inc said on Tuesday it expected to buy office products distributors in the second half of 1997.
"We anticipate a resumption of acquisition activity, as acquiring established, quality office products distributors in the U.S. and Europe continues to be an important part of our long-term strategy," the 70 percent owned unit of Koninklijke KNP BT said in a statement issued in the Netherlands.
BT Office Products said its acquisition activity had been slow in the second quarter of 1997 as the firm focused on integrating previous acquisitions into existing operations.
Earlier today, BT Office Products posted a 1997 second quarter net profit of five million dollars, up from 3.9 million in the year-ago period.
The company's first-half net totalled $9.3 million, compared with eight million in the first six months of 1996.
Net sales rose by 15.2 percent to $390.7 million in the second quarter of 1997. BT Office Products said previous acquisitions accounted for a 13 percent sales boost. Organic expansion raised second-quarter turnover by 4.5 percent but currency changes had a negative impact of 2.3 percent.
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040

headline: PolyGram first-half net falls but sales rise.
text:
Music and entertainment group PolyGram NV said Tuesday its net profit for the first half slipped slightly, with music performing strongly but again offset by losses from its young film business.
Earnings for the first six months declined to 270 million guilders ($132.9 million) from 272 million ($134 million) returning to the level reported for the first half of 1995.
Analysts had anticipated a net profit of as much as 286 million guilders ($141 million), based on strong music sales from artists such as U2 and Hanson.
"Compared with a strong first half of 1996, PolyGram's 1997 performance in film has been relatively weak to date," Chief Executive Alain Levy said in a statement accompanying the results.
"As a result, income from operations was 430 million guilders ($212 million) for the first half of 1997, an increase of 2 percent over last year," he added.
First-half group sales climbed 5 percent to 4.53 billion guilders ($2.23 billion), with music generating sales of 3.94 billion ($1.94 billion).
Operating profit in music rose to 522 million guilders ($257 million) from 457 million ($225 million) during the half. Veteran Irish rockers U2 sold over five million albums, while teenage newcomers Hanson sold three million.
The film division's first-half revenues dipped to 589 million guilders ($290 million) from 681 million ($335 million), with operating losses widening to 92 million ($45 million) from 37 million ($18 million). Film's second-quarter operating loss was 37 million guilders ($18 million), compared with 55 million ($27 million) in the first quarter and 18 million ($8.8 million) in the second quarter of 1996.
PolyGram said the results of its filmed entertainment business reflected the division's lighter release schedule during the first six months of 1997, adding that the division saw its strongest releases in the second half.
Film during the first half of 1996 benefited from the success of "Dead Man Walking," "Fargo," and "Mr. Holland's Opus."

headline: Maastricht gives room for interpretration-Juncker.
text:
The Maastricht treaty leaves room for interpretation on whether countries qualify for a single European currency, Luxembourg Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker said on Tuesday.
"3.0 percent is not 'sine qua non' (an absolute requirement)," he told reporters, referring to a treaty provision limiting budget deficits to three percent of gross domestic product.  
France has said it will reduce its budget deficit toward three percent of GDP but has said that the treaty itself allows for a flexible interpretation which does not require deficits to be reduced to precisely 3.0 percent of GDP.
Asked about this, Juncker said, "the treaty provides a figure -- it is three percent but the treaty also provides the means for interpretation of this three percent figure".
Everything depended on the judgment made next year on whether a country met Maastricht treaty criteria and proved they could sustain budgetary and economic convergence, he said.
"The treaty is a nuanced treaty," said Juncker, whose country currently holds the European Union presidency.
Earlier, Juncker met President Jacques Chirac and was due to have further talks with finance minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn.
He said that he would deepen discussions with Strauss-Kahn on issues due to be addressed during the Luxembourg EU presidency which runs from July to December.
A decision would be made by year-end on how to enhance economic policy coordination inside Europe, a call made by France's new Socialist-led government.
"A decision will be made by the European council by the end of the year," Juncker said.
He declined to give details of his talks with France on this and other issues.
He also declined to say whether Luxembourg plans to address during its presidency the question of how to fix exchange rates in monetary union.
"It will be dealt with at the appropriate time," he said.
-- Paris Newsroom +33 1 4221 5452

headline: Raisio says Bayer drug no rival.
text:
Finnish food and chemicals group Raision Tehtaat does not view Bayer AG's Baycol cholesterol-reducing agent as a competitor to its Benecol fat-soluble agent, a spokesman said on Tuesday.
"I would say it is not a competitor," Sten von Hellens told Reuters by telephone, referring to an earlier report that British drug group SmithKline Beecham would market Bayer's product in the United States.  
"It's a medicine, and we're in the foodstuffs business," von Hellens said.
"It's a statin like other statins on the market. This is just one more," he said, adding that a statin is a common drug used in cholesterol treatment.
Raisio's share briefly dipped on the Helsinki bourse on Tuesday after SmithKline Beecham said it had agreed to co-market Baycol in the United States starting in early 1998, brokers said.
At 1645/1345 GMT Raisio traded at 605.00 markka, down 5.00, after falling 23.00 markka to 587.00 on the news.
Raisio soared last week on news that it had sealed a deal with U.S. consumer goods giant Johnson & Johnson unit McNeil on the North American marketing of its cholesterol-cutting agent Benecol, which is fat soluble and can form the basis for foods.
--John Acher, Helsinki Newsroom +358-9-680 50 235

headline: EU hopes to bring Arafat and Levy face-to-face.
text:
The European Union on Tuesday stepped up efforts to win a greater role in the Middle East peace process by trying to broker the highest-level meeting between Palestinian and Israeli officials in months.
Palestinian President Yasser Arafat and Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy were due to hold separate talks with current EU president Luxembourg later on Tuesday, but officials were also hoping to persuade them to meet face-to-face.
With the stalemate in the peace process entering its fifth month, the meetings were being arranged on the sidelines of a regular gathering of EU foreign ministers.
A European diplomat would only say that  Luxembourg Foreign Minister Jacques Poos and EU Middle East envoy Miguel Angel Moratinos would hold separate meetings with Arafat and Levy.
"If we get them together, that would be very good news indeed, but you must not judge progress on achieving this goal," the diplomat said.
German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel told a news conference earlier that if the meeting went ahead, it would show "the role of the Europeans has become more important".
"Europe, through the work of Moratinos, has a little more of a foot in the door," he said.
The last time Arafat and Levy met was on the fringes of an EU-sponsored Euro-Mediterranean conference in Malta in April, where the pair had a brief but cordial exchange.
Peace talks broke down in March after Israel began building a new settlement in Arab East Jerusalem, which Palestinians regard as the capital of their future state.
Earlier on Tuesday, Levy was given a hostile reception by many members of the European Parliament when he addressed its foreign affairs committee.
"I know that some of you feel Israel is not helping the peace process, but this is not us being stubborn, this is us defending our lives," he said in a robust defence of Israeli policy.
At one point he shouted at a heckler: "You have to be in Israel or with Israel to understand completely."
The Moroccan-born foreign minister -- speaking a mixture of French and Hebrew -- told MEPs: "I am not so naive as to believe I could have come here and changed opinions. All I can do is explain our position."
But he reminded the committee of the threat Jews had faced in the past, particularly in Europe.
"We hate war...we have been victims of a war that was designed to eradicate us completely," Levy said.
"It is our right to expect from Europe...to allow the two sides to try to resolve the matter without interference."
The EU has long been a vociferous backer of Palestinian aspirations and is the biggest bankroller of aid to the fledgling Palestinian Authority.

headline: EU has previously blocked eight company mergers.
text:
The European Commission, which looks set to reject the Boeing/McDonnell Douglas merger on Wednesday, has previously blocked eight mergers since the European Union's merger regulation came into force in 1990.
The regulation gives the EU executive the power to vet mergers with a combined worldwide turnover of at least five billion European currency units ($5.45 billion) and where each firm has an EU turnover of 250 million Ecus or more.
Here is a list of the blocked deals:
-In 1991, the Commission blocked an alliance involving Boeing's De Havilland subsidiary, which France's Aerospatiale and Italy's Alenia sought to acquire in a joint bid.
-In 1994, it blocked the German pay-television venture Media Service GmbH between German media giant Bertelsmann, the Kirch Group and state telephone company Deutsche Telekom.
-In July 1995, the Commission rejected a venture to operate and distribute satellite television in the Nordic countries.
-In September the same year, the Commission said it could not approve Dutch television alliance Holland Media Groep. However, it later approved a new version of the venture.
-In April 1996, it blocked South Africa's Gencor and British-based Lonrho from merging their platinum businesses.
-In November the same year, the EU executive banned the merger between Finnish wholesaler and retailers Kesko and Tuko.
-In December it blocked the merger of the silicon carbide businesses of French glassmaker Saint-Gobain and Wacker-Chemie of Germany.
-In June this year, it decided against the acquisition by Dutch toy retailer Blokker Holding BV of the operations of Toys 'R' Us in the Netherlands.
-- Brussels newsroom +32 2 287 68 11

headline: Raisio dips on Bayer's US cooperation.
text:
Shares in Finnish food group Raision Tehtaat wobbled on Tuesday after reports that British SmithKline Beecham would co-market Bayer AG's cholesterol-cutting drug in the U.S., brokers said.
Raisio dipped to 587.00 markka on the report, down 23.00 or almost four percent, and volume was a lively 59 million markka, but by 1630/1330 GMT, it recovered to 600.00 markka.
"It's only natural that some people get jumpy after the share rose so quickly," one broker said.
Raisio soared last week on news that it had sealed a deal with U.S. consumer goods giant Johnson & Johnson unit McNeil on the North American marketing of its cholesterol-cutting agent Benecol.
-- Helsinki Newsroom +358-9-680 50 235, news@reuters.fi

headline: TABLE-Belgian leading indicator improves in June.
text:
The Belgian central bank released the following indices based on its monthly survey of three key economic sectors -
    BELGIAN LEADING INDICATOR    June 97     May 97
    Overall			    -1.0	  -3.8
    Manufacturing		     1.4	  -1.6
    Trade				-6.3	  -9.7
    Building			   -6.6	  -8.4
In a statement the central bank said the leading indicator had improved to a point unseen since the end of 1994 thanks to an improvement in all three reporting sectors.
NOTE - The leading index is based on central bank surveys of manufacturing, construction and retailing and calculated on the basis of the difference between positive and negative answers to questions. It is slightly positive at the top of an economic cycle and strongly negative at the depth of a recession.
-- Brussels Newsroom +32 2 287 6810, Fax +32 2 230 7710

headline: EU agrees unchanged 5.0 pct 1998 cereals set-aside.
text:
The European Union on Tuesday formally agreed an unchanged five percent compulsory set-aside rate for cereals planted for the 1998 harvest, EU officials said.
EU farm ministers, who last month demanded that set-aside be kept at five percent, adopted the European Commission's proposal without discusssion.  
Ministers also agreed to suspend penalty set-aside, for exceeding planting limits, for another year to June 30, 1998. Penalties for exceeding irrigated area limits will be reduced to match those for dry-land farming.
Farmers irrigating their crops will have to set-aside an extra one percent of their land for every one percent overshoot, instead of 1.5 percent previously.
Keeping set-aside at five percent will help to maintain production without rebuilding excessive stocks, the Commission has said.
Compulsory set-aside, introduced under the 1992 farm reform to remove costly surpluses, was lowered to 10 percent in 1996/97 after being initially fixed at 15 percent in 1993/94.
-Peter Blackburn Brussels bureau +322 287 6830

headline: Danish grain season said proceeding normally.
text:
Denmark's grain growing season is proceeding normally this year but any quality or quantity forecast would be premature at present, the Danish Department of Plant Production told Reuters on Tuesday.
"It looks like the Danish grain harvest will have a more or less normal duration, but if we get a period with a lot of sun it could be brought forward just as rainy weather would delay things," departmental chief consultant Carl Aage Andersen said.
"Major harvesting of winter wheat and spring grains will not take place until mid-August, when we issue our first forecast. It is too early now to make any firm forecasts," he said.
The department calculated that around one million hectares were sown to winter grain and 600,000 hectares to spring grain.
It said that the area under cultivation was a little bigger than in 1996, when it totalled 1,545,175 hectares.
KFK, Denmark's biggest grain wholesaler, said in its first-half 1997 report last week that prospects for the Danish 1997 grain harvest looked good, but that it wanted more to see rain.
--Chris Follett, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33969652

headline: Oil World increases EU, Canada rapeseed forecasts.
text:
European Union rapeseed output could reach 8.1-8.2 million tonnes in 1997, the Oil World newsletter said, revising its earlier projection of a 7.9 million tonne crop.
Last year's EU crop totalled 7.1 million.
Most of the increase would be in France and Germany, Oil World said.
Harvesting in France was progressing well, with two thirds of the crop gathered by the end of last week.
High yields were reported as a result of favourable weather in May and June.
France may produce three million or 3.1 million tonnes, compared with 2.9 million last year.
Canadian canola production could total 6.7-6.9 million tonnes versus earlier estimates of 6.6 million and last year's five million, Oil World added.
Canola prices were likely to decline towards the lower European levels under harvest pressure.
-Vera Eckert, Hamburg newsroom +49-40-41903275

headline: Poland seen importing more rapeseed, products.
text:
Flood damage to Polish crops may boost rapeseed imports in 1997/98 (July/June) to 470,000 tonnes, compared with 370,000 in 1996/97, as well as oils and oilmeal imports, the Oil World newsletter said.
It said the country's 1997 rapeseed crop may fall to 350,000 tonnes from 461,000 tonnes last year and the 906,000-tonne annual average recorded between 1991 and 1995.
The 1997 crop would represent only 40 percent of installed domestic seed crush capacity, which had been expanded.
Poland was likely to import not only more rapeseed, but also sunseed and soybeans.
Soybean imports may rise to 115,000 tonnes in 1997/98 versus 95,000 previously, and an initial sunseed import forecast for 1997/98 of 15,000 tonnes may be too low.
Total oils and fats imports in Oct/Sept 1997/98 were forecast at 260,000 tonnes, up from 233,000 in 1996/97, of which soyoil should be 82,000 tonnes, rape oil 30,000, sun oil 66,000 and palm oil 46,000.
Oilmeal imports, mostly soymeal, were forecast to rise to 700,000 tonnes in 1997/998 from 650,000 tonnes in 1996/97.

headline: Finnish finmin proposes FIM 17 bln budget deficit.
text:
The finance ministry's budget proposal for 1998 puts the deficit at 17 billion markka, some four billion markka below earlier estimates, Finance Minister Sauli Niinisto told a news conference on Tuesday.
He said total spending would be about 188 billion markka, which is three billion markka below earlier estimates.
The unemployment rate would fall to 15 percent this year and 13.5 percent next year, compared to an earlier forecast of 14.4 percent and 13.0 percent respectively, he said.
No further forecasts were immediately available.
-- Helsinki newsroom +358-9-680 50 245, news@reuters.fi

headline: France Telecom buys Etralie.
text: France Telecom SA said it is acquiring Etralie, a French company which installs trading systems and had 1996 sales of 250 million francs. A France Telecom spokesman declined to give the price of the transaction.

headline: Siemens, Sun sign smart card deal.
text:
German industrial group Siemens AG said on Tuesday its semiconductor unit licensed technology from Sun Microsystems Inc. for a new generation of smart cards.
Siemens planned to use technology based on Java -- Sun's programming language that can run on different types of computers -- to make chips for credit-card sized cards that could store bank account, health and other personal information.
The chips would be ready in volume in the middle of 1998, and would make it easier for consumers to use the cards to buy products, do their banking and conduct other transaction over the Internet.
"The Jave-enabled chip technology increases the information capacity of the chips," said Siemens general manager for smart cards, Ulrich Hamann. "Consequently it allows for more information and additional functions to be included."
The market for integrated circuits for smart cards was expected to grow from $520 million this year to $2.8 billion in 2001, Sun said.
Smart cards are most often used today as telephone cards that allow people to call from pay phones without using coins or cash. But those cards cannot work with vending machines, toll booths, automated teller machines or computers connected to the Internet.
In the future, smart cards are expected to work with many different types machines and replace cash in many cases, said Jonathan Cassell at market researcher Dataquest Inc.
"The smart card is undergoing a transition -- from being a simple, single-purpose device that interfaces to stand alone equipment to being a complex, multi-application (card)."
In the nine-month period that ended June 30, Siemens semiconductor sales rose 20 percent to 4.1 billion marks, although its full-year pretax profit was expected to be pressured by falling memory chip prices.
-- Neal Boudette, Bonn Newsroom, +49-228 26097150

headline: Tuskar to begin testing Nigerian oil well.
text:
Tuskar Resources Plc said on Tuesday that the Obe-4 well, the first of two appraisal wells planned for the Obe Oil Field, offshore Nigeria, has been successfully drilled to a total measured depth of 9,315 feet.
The primary targets, two oil reservoirs that had been separately tested by the Obe-1 and Obe-3 wells respectively, were both encountered, Tuskar said in a statement.
Production testing of the two primary zones will commence in the next few days to determine the well's production capability, after which it is expected to be temporarily suspended as an oil producer.
Planning for commercial production facilities is at an advanced stage with final decisions to be made following completion of the current well testing, Tuskar said.
A second development well, Obe-5, is currently scheduled for drilling later this year.
-- Dublin Newsroom +353 1 676 9779

headline: London-based Greek priest shot dead in Athens.
text:
A Greek Orthodox priest posted to a London parish church was shot dead by a young woman in a suburb of Athens on Tuesday, police said.
Archimandrite Anthimos Eleftheriadis, 55, was shot at point-blank range six times in the head and chest as he got into his car.
Eyewitnesses told police the woman had apparently been waiting for Eleftheriadis and approached him as soon as he left his apartment building in suburban Nea Smyrni.
They said she was aged about 30 and wearing a black leather skirt, waistcoat and sunglasses. Police said they were searching for the woman, whose motives were unclear.
The Greek Orthodox archbishopric in London said Eleftheriadis had been assigned to the St Nicholas church in west London for the last three years. He was in Athens for summer holidays.

headline: Irish bond, equity turnover slips in June - ISE.
text:
Turnover on the official list of the Irish Stock Exchange slipped to 1.72 billion Irish pounds in June from 1.79 billion in May, official figures showed on Tuesday.
Turnover in Irish government bonds also fell back, to 8.94 billion from 11.99 billion.
The market capitalisation of the official list rose to 28.19 billion at June 30, 1997 from 26.70 billion at end-May and 20.49 billion at the end of 1996.
-- Dublin Newsroom +353 1 676 9779

headline: BCH H1 profits up 22.6 pct as basic banking back.
text:
Spain's Banco Central Hispano reported first-half profits rose 22.6 percent on Tuesday, as its massive restructuring effort put basic banking business back on track.
Net attributable profit at Spain's fourth-largest bank rose to 25.03 billion pesetas ($164.8 million) from 20.42 billion a year earlier, and the bank announced it would split shares following a 107 percent rise in their value over the past year.
"This is hard-core banking business improvement," Emilio Novela, general manager and a member of the management board told journalists at a news conference.
BCH, the product of the 1991 merger of Banco Central and Banco Hispanoamericano, has pursued a sweeping restructuring and rationalisation plan to purge its balance sheet of loan problems, contain costs and boost earnings.
BCH's shares outpaced the market on the results and share split news, rising 150 pesetas, or 2.54 percent, to 6,050 while the IBEX-35 index rose just 104.91 points, or 1.55 percent, to 6873.20.
"These are very good results. There is (core banking) improvement. They haven't even leaned on trading income," said analyst Ignacio Cornejo at Beta Capital in Madrid.
Net interest income, which captures lending business, rose 12.6 percent to 145.51 billion pesetas.
Ordinary revenues, which also includes commission and trading revenues, rose 11.6 percent to 210.50 billion pesetas although trading revenues slipped 11 percent.
"The improvement in the composition of the results of BCH group during the first-half reflects that 100 percent of resources generated came from typical banking activity," BCH said in a note.
The bank has also kept a tight hold on costs, reducing them overall by 0.44 percent in the period.
Under the restructuring plan for the year, the bank is aiming for a 25 percent rise in net profit from full-year 1996 profits of 33.5 billion pesetas and analysts said it is on track.
"It seems that net profits are going to be clearly above 20 percent and more toward 25 percent," said Javier Bernat, banking analyst at Inverban in Madrid. "It shouldn't be too difficult for them to reach their goal."
Traditional banking margins -- the difference before interest earned on loans and paid out on deposits -- has been under heavy pressure as the Bank of Spain has steered rates four full points lower since December 1995.
BCH's Novela said margins had narrowed two full points in the last year. But as part of its overall refitting, BCH set up an internal group to buttress its margins against erosion.
At the moment, it earns 8.01 percent on loans, while paying out 3.98 percent -- leaving its margin at 4.03 percent. The competition earns 7.70 percent, pays out 4.46 percent for a margin of just 3.24 percent.
Novela said the group would hold a shareholders meeting in September to approve a share split which could occur about one month later, provided the share price is decisively above 6,000.
--Madrid Newsroom +34  1 585 2167
($ = 151.9 Spanish Pesetas)

headline: German shares seek fresh gains, fuelled by banks.
text:
Germany's DAX index surged three percent in bourse dealings on Tuesday as merger mania gripped the banking industry after two regional banks set off a feeding frenzy in the sector by announcing a deal on Monday.
The 30-share DAX index ended bourse trade up 122.02 points at 4,230.42 points in a dramatic recovery from a two percent drop on Monday tied to profit-taking and some fresh speculative selling that sought to test whether the market had peaked.
The DAX ended at a new record high, besting the old mark of 4,227.31 points set on July 17.  
Traders looked for the market to post fresh gains in the coming days and for the focus to remain on banking shares.
Commerzbank AG, which will become Germany's fourth-largest bank if the merger of Bayerische Vereinsbank and Bayerische Hypotheken- und Wechselbank AG is allowed, surged 12 percent as traders said the Frankfurt bank was a prime takeover target.
"It's the next target for a takeover," said one Frankfurt dealer about Commerzbank. "Or they are going to have to step up and make an acquisition. They are the only one left without an international partner of some size. The pressure is growing."  
Other bank shares, including Vereinsbank and Hypo-Bank, posted gains well above the DAX advance, which traders said was the key reason for the blue-chip index's hefty gains.
"The banks are clearly driving the market higher," said one dealer. "The traditional stocks that tend to profit profit from a higher dollar are not faring as well as the market."
"The focus for the rest of this week is clearly on the banks, but it may then be time for a look at another sector."
Vereinsbank rose nearly 12 percent, adding 9.90 marks to 95.60 marks, while Hypo-Bank rose 10 percent to 73.45 marks.
BHF-Bank rose five percent to 54.01 marks.  
Insurance group Allianz AG, which is the top shareholder in Hypo-Bank, rose 36 marks to 455.50 marks, a gain of nearly nine percent. CS-First Boston said it raised Allianz to a buy rating from hold and set a price target of 560 marks.
The banking sector focused distracted market attention away from Tuesday's meeting in Frankfurt of a committee of banks and the German bourse to review the DAX portfolio.
Sportswear group Adidas AG is touted as the top pick to enter the DAX and was widely believed to be ready to oust beleaguered retailer Karstadt AG.  
But Monday's banking merger may allow Adidas to join the DAX when the merger is completed in the fall and also allow Karstadt to remain in the prestigious index.
Adidas shares ended bourse trade steady at 218.50 marks, while Karstadt shares rose 7.50 marks to 682.50 marks.
Among other shares, Deutsche Lufthansa AG surged 1.65 marks to 34.05 marks after investment banker Deutsche Morgan Grenfell recommended switching into the airline from British Airways.
DMG also raised its earnings per share estimates on Lufthansa for 1997 and 1998.  
But not all DAX components fared well in the rally. Carmaker Volkswagen AG slumped nine marks to 1,395 marks despite reporting a nearly 10 percent rise in global vehicle sales during the first half of 1997. VW also said sales in western Europe rose four percent during the same period.
Chemicals group BASF AG rose 60 pfennigs to 68.60 marks despite the German government disallowing the sale of its Kal und Salz shares to Canada's Potash Corp on anti-competition grounds. BASF said it still intended to sell the Kali shares.
--Frankfurt Newsroom, +49 69 756525

headline: EU clears Nintendo licensing deals.
text:
The European Commission said on Tuesday it had cleared new licensing agreements awarded by video-game company Nintendo to firms that develop games for use on its Entertainment System consoles.
The European Union executive said the agreements, which have been under scrutiny by the Commission and by British competition authorities for months, were now compatible with EU competition law.
"Under the new agreement, there are no longer limits on the number of games that a Nintendo licensee may release on the market, and prior approvals by Nintendo are no longer required, until and unless a Nintendo licensee elects to use a Nintendo trade mark for a given game," a Commission statement said.
Another Commission concern, also resolved, included a Nintendo requirement that it was the exclusive manufacturing rights holder for licensees' games.
"The Commission takes the view that any possible infringement of EU competition law arising from Nintendo's Game Boy, Nintendo Entertainment System and Super Nintendo Entertainment System licensing agreements has been brought to an end..." the statement said, adding that no problems were expected with agreements for Nintendo's new "N64" product.
-- Brussels newsroom +32 2 287 68 11 (PIC)

headline: Greek May registered unemployment falls to 6.8 pct.
text:
Greece's registered unemployment fell to 6.8 percent in May from 8.5 percent in April, not seasonally adjusted, and the number of registered unemployed dropped to 182,280 in May from 210,494, the central bank said.
Registered unemployment stood at 6.3 percent in May 1996 when 157,401 people were registered as unemployed, it said in its July bulletin of coincidental indicators.
Greece's registered unemployment rate is volatile and is widely regarded as underestimating the actual rate. Registered unemployment figures are provided by the labour ministry.
Greece's unemployment rose to 10.4 percent in 1996 from 10 percent in 1995 based on annual data from the National Statistics Service.
--Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

headline: BHF-Bank exercises ProSieben greenshoe.
text:
BHF-Bank, the global coordinator for German television group ProSieben's initial public offering, said on Tuesday it had exercised the full greenshoe option for the share issue.
The greenshoe option, of 1.75 million preference shares, allows additional shares to be distributed to investors. The ProSieben listing was many times oversubscribed, meaning many would-be investors were not allocated shares.
BHF-Bank said a total of 17.5 million preference shares had now been placed. This equates to 50 percent of the company's basic capital.
ProSieben shares ended Monday's trade up 25 pfennigs at 90 marks. They listed on the market at 87 marks.
-- Frankfurt Newsroom +49 69 756525

headline: EU Foreign Ministers meet on fur, Middle East.
text:
European Union foreign ministers were gathering for a meeting on Tuesday during which they will tackle issues ranging from trap standards for catching fur-bearing animals to the Middle East peace process.
Ministers from the 15-nation bloc were due also to hold talks with Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy, but EU officials stressed they were not expecting any breakthrough on the stalled Middle east peace talks.
Luxembourg, which currently holds the rotating EU presidency, is backing a deal with Canada and Russia on more humane standards for the leg-hold traps used to ensnare animals such as wolf, beaver and otter for pelts.
But EU officials said agreement on the controversial issue might be blocked again as Britain and the Scandinavian countries in particular think the proposed laws are too weak.
The foreign ministers' meeting will open with a traditional beginning of presidency debate during which Agenda 2000 -- the EU's enlargement plans -- is likely to feature.
Ministers will also discuss the situation in former Yugoslavia as well as an international donors' conference on Bosnian reconstruction to be held in Brussels on Wednesday and Thursday.

headline: Overnight guilders surge briefly, then settle.
text:
Overnight guilders surged briefly during brisk Tuesday midsession trade as several major players found themselves momentarily strapped for cash, dealers said.
Call money was traded as high as 3.50 percent as demand for one-day guilders outstripped supply, traders said.
But they said the flurry only lasted two hours or so. By the end of the session overnight money had subsided to 3.12 percent bid, in line with its customary level of recent weeks.
"It was just a blip; not structural," a dealer said, adding that the bulk of the day's deals had been done at 3.12 percent.
Other rates were unchanged and trade was slack, dealers said. Three-month guilders have been quoted at 3.20/28 percent bid/offer for around a week now.
Prices for the government's Dutch Treasury Certificates were also unchanged at 3.18 percent for the tranche maturing at end-August and 3.17 percent for both the September and December programmes.
Dealers said there had been little or no primary or secondary activity in the paper.
The guilder was fixed at a steady 112.575 guilders per 100 marks.
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040

headline: Madrid airport back to normal after lightning hit.
text:
