Madrid's Barajas airport returned to normal on Tuesday after an antenna was struck by lightning causing delays, airport authority Aena said.
The airport stemmed the flow of departing planes for 30 minutes this morning when a bolt of lightning damaged an antenna at a nearby control point during a freak storm. Arrivals were not affected.
Flights were delayed for a further two hours, but by midday planes were departing on time again. A total of 800 flights are scheduled to pass through the airport on Tuesday.
-- Madrid newsroom + 34 1 585 2161

headline: Kinkel says EU may not ban Boeing merger.
text:
German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said on Tuesday that "something" may happen which would enable the European Commission not to ban the proposed merger between Boeing Co and McDonnell Douglas Corp .
"It is possible that something hoppens so that this Commission decision does not have to happen", Kinkel told reporters. He declined to elaborate, but said he had discussed the issue with U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright by telephone on Monday. The Commission is widely expected to block the merger on Wednesday on the grounds it would harm fair competition in Europe.
Some antitrust lawyers have speculated the Commission may declare that the $14 billion merger is "incompatible" with EU merger control law but at the same time invite Boeing to refile the plan with appropriate modifications.
U.S. political pressure intensified last week on national EU governments, causing some officials to express fears in private that a prohibition of the deal could trigger a bitter transatlantic dispute.
"We cannot in any case let a trade war happen just because the concerned parties have little notion of reality," Kinkel said.
He was speaking on the fringes of a regular meeting of EU foreign ministers. He added he had also discussed the merger with European Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan.
Kinkel said he had stressed to Albright that the issue was "of great importance" for Europe, but added that it was for European industry to build up a counterweight to Boeing's dominance. This could only be done through strengthening Airbus Industrie .

headline: EU refinery output rises slightly in June.
text:
Refinery output in Europe rose by 135,000 barrels per day (bpd), or 1.1 percent, to 12.439 million bpd in June from May, Stichting Euroilstock said in its latest monthly report.
Crude intake in June was up 117,000 bpd (1.0 percent) to 11.797 million bpd, representing a utilisation rate of 89.37 percent, the report said. In May, the utilisation rate was 88.48 percent.
Stichting Euroilstocks reports data for the 15 countries of the European Union plus Norway.
Gasoline production rose by 7,000 bpd (0.2 percent) in June to 3.358 million bpd, but was 1.9 percent less than a year ago.
Middle distillate output was down 96,000 bpd (1.7 percent) in June to 5.559 million bpd, but was 4.2 percent higher than year ago levels.
Fuel oil output fell by 23,000 bpd (1.3 percent) in June to 1.790 million bpd which was 4.9 percent more than a year ago.
Naphtha output was up 17,000 bpd (1.8 percent) to 968,000 bpd and was 14.8 percent higher than in June 1996.
They are based on a nameplate capacity of 13.2 million bpd for the European Union plus Norway. Refinery intake represents crude only and excludes natural gas liquids, feedstocks and other inputs.
-- Philip Blenkinsop, Amsterdam Newsroom, +31 20 504 5004

headline: Swiss Re sells $137 mln in quake bonds.
text:
Swiss Reinsurance Co said it had placed $137 million in two-year bonds tied to reinsurance losses from a potential California earthquake, an issue that is part of a growing effort by insurers to securitise risks.
Swiss Re, the world's second-biggest reinsurer, said the notes were offered in several tranches with different risk levels to satisfy various investzor needs.
Swiss Re and Credit Suisse First Boston were placement agents for the notes issued by SR Earthquake Fund Ltd, a freestanding reinsurance group set up Swiss Re in the Cayman Islands.
The deal also involved Swiss Re purchasing $112 million in California earthquake reinsurance coverage from SR Earthquake Fund, Swiss Re said in a statement.
"The size of the issuance was increased from $115 million to $137 million as a result of investor demand," Swiss Re said.
"The investors were U.S. and Europpean financial institutions, including life insurance compnaies, money managers and banks," it added.
Swiss Re said the senior tranche in the issue was the first of its kind to be rated investment grade based on the level of catastrophe risk.
The notes are an example of so-called catastrophe bonds that a few insurers are testing in an effort to see whether potentially large risks, such as earthquakes or hurricanes, can be covered with the help of the world's booming capital markets.
-- Zurich Newsroom, +41-1-631 7340

headline: Denmark sugar beet crop said progressing well.
text:
The prospects for the upcoming sugar beet harvest in Denmark are good, the Danish Department of Plant Production told Reuters on Tuesday.
"Sugar beet crops in Denmark have benefited from the lack of drought so far this season, but the long growth period means that the final result is still unforeseeable," departmental chief consultant Carl Aage Andersen said.
"The harvest will not be until October and an awful lot can happen by then," he said.
Andersen stressed that precipitation had been uneven in growing areas, with key regions such as west Zealand hit by a lack of rain.
Danisco, Europe's fourth biggest sugar producer, with a virtual monopoly of sugar production in Denmark and Sweden and with eastern German plantations, is to announce the first sugar test results of the new season around August 13.
The second and third sugar beet test results are due around September 3 and 24 respectively.
--Chris Follett, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33969652

headline: Sweaty Santas frolic at summer parade in Denmark.
text:
Scores of sweaty Santas linked hands to dance round a Christmas tree under a sweltering summer sun in Copenhagen's Town Hall Square on Tuesday at the start of Denmark's 34th annual Father Christmas World Congress.
More than 100 Santas from 10 nations have gathered in the Danish capital for the four-day off-season jamboree.
Earlier the red-robed, white-bearded Santas, accompanied by hordes of elves and a convoy of veteran red fire engines, ho-hoed through central Copenhagen, tossing sweets to children and showering unsuspecting tourists with traditional yuletide greetings.
Once in the square, the costumed men and women danced and sang Christmas carols to the strains of their own brass band, before adjourning to a nearby hostelry to quaff Danish yule ale and sample traditional Christmas pastries.
As usual politics dominate this year's congress and the hottest item on the agenda is how to ensure that it is only bone fide Father Christmases who entertain children in the festive season.
Before they even arrived in Copenhagen for this week's congress, the authorised delegates had been upstaged by a breakaway group of renegade Nordic Santas who held a rival gathering in a Danish provincial town in early July.
"There is a grave danger that children's illusions could be ruined if a mass of fake Santas suddenly turn up on the Father Christmas circuit," said congress chairman Kurt Flemming, who doubles as a circus clown outside the Christmas season.
The Santa fraternity has also been dogged in recent years over which Nordic country is the true home of Father Christmas.
Greenland laid claim to the title, but Finnish Lapland, Sweden, Norway and Iceland all put in rival bids until agreeing to differ and concentrate on how best to do the job.
This week's programme has drawn delegates from Australia, Britain, Canada, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain, Scandinavia and the United States.

headline: Drachma up vs ecu/mark, FRNs weak, short rates down.
text:
The drachma was advancing against the ecu and the mark in early dealings benefiting from favourable market sentiment linked to expectations of a soft euro, dealers said.
Bonds were holding Monday's late price levels, unfazed by sharply lower short-term depos and forex forwards but FRNs came under selling pressure from abroad that drove discount margins higher to 110 basis points, dealers said.
"The specter of a soft euro has helped the dollar, the pound, other EMS currencies and the drachma but has depressed the mark," said a chief forex dealer at a foreign bank."Ecu/drachma is currently testing 309.50 and might go lower."
An audit of France's budget deficit on Monday showed that its budget deficit was running at 3.5 to 3.7 percent of GDP and the socialist government announced a package of measures to bring the deficit closer to the three percent Maastricht target.
"The market sentiment has changed and favours the drachma," the dealer said. "It is a matter of time before some London-based players reverse course and unwind their long ecu/drachma positions."
Fixed coupon bonds were fluctuating narrowly in early dealings but seven-year floaters due 2002 and 2003 were counting losses with discount margins rising to 110 bassi points from 102 late on Monday, dealers said.
Prices of 10-year bonds were steady at 94.50, seven-year bonds were trading lower at 94.95 from 95, five-year taxable were little changed at 96.95 and three-year taxable bonds due March 2000 were flat at 98.10, dealers said.
"Fixed coupon bonds are stable but FRNs due 2002 and 2003 are down with discount margins at 110 basis points," a bond dealer said. "We have seen sales of FRNs from players abroad."
Greece is to auction 150 billion drachmas of seven-year floaters on July 29.
Short-term depos and forex forwards fell sharply in early trade on a boosted liquidity from forex and other domestic sources, money dealers said.
The mark was quoted at 156.49/54 from Monday's 156.970 fix, the dollar at 282.70/80 drachmas from 282.000 and the ecu at 309.46/56 from 309.80 drachmas.
The National Bank of Greece quoted the following early rates:
** Overnight at 11.80-12.30
** T/N at 11.80-12.30
** S/N at 11.80-12.30
** One week at 11.80-12.30
** Two weeks at 11.80-12.30
** Three weeks at 11.80-12.30
** One month at 11.80-12.30
** Two months at 11.80-12.30
** Three months at 11.70-12.20
** Six months at 11.20-11.70
** Nine months at 11.00-11.50
** Twelve months at 10.80-11.30
--Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

headline: Temperatures hit records in Algerian Sahara.
text:
Temperatures in the Tidikelt area of Algeria's Sahara Desert have hit records of more than 48 degrees Celsius (over 118 degrees Fahrenheit) in the shade during the day, Algeria's official news agency APS said on Tuesday.
Even at night, the average has been 34 to 36 degrees (93 to 97 degrees Fahrenheit), it said, adding that fans, air conditioners and humidiers could not cope with the heat.
The agency said there was also a shortage of drinking water caused by the main water distribution firm, which is in financial difficulties, having its power cut off for non-payment of bills.
The main town in Tidikelt region is In Salah, some 550 km (345 miles) north of Algeria's main southern town of Tamanrasset.

headline: EU standing firm on Boeing decision.
text:
The European Commission planned to rule Wednesday on Boeing Co.'s planned $14 billion acquisition of McDonnell Douglas Corp. with virtually no chance that Boeing could produce an acceptable offer by then, an EU source said Tuesday.
The source said Boeing and the Commission had held no substantive talks since last week and that the company had not yet fully satisfied the EU executive body on any of its three main concerns about the combination.
Asked if Boeing still had a chance to win a reprieve, he said, "In 24 hours you can do a lot of things, but you can't disregard legal procedures."
He said it would be difficult for Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert to reverse his plan to ban the merger before Wednesday since he would have to draft a new text and send it to senior Commission officials and EU national competition experts for review.
The Commission believes the deal would strengthen Boeing's already dominant position in the commercial aircraft sector, a conclusion rejected by the manufacturer, which argues McDonnell Douglas no longer constitutes a serious competitor.
McDonnell Douglas's strength in the military sector also causes the Commission to fear that Boeing would benefit from defence funds to subsidise its commercial programmes.
But the most contentious point remains the exclusive supply contracts Boeing has with three large U.S. airlines -- AMR Corp.'s American Aitlines, Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines.
The source said there had been some progress during talks between the two sides, but that "As long as there is not an agreement on everything, there is no agreement at all."
The Commission's determination to block the merger has triggered a barrage of sharp criticism on the other side of the Atlantic and President Clinton said the United States might go to the World Trade Organisaton or impose sanctions if this happened.
The EU executive has the power to block the deal if it finds it would harm fair competition in the 15-nation bloc. Were Boeing to go ahead with the merger regardless, the Commission could impose fines up to 10 percent of the companies' turnover.

headline: Eridania unit to invest in Poland.
text:
Eridania Beghin-Say said on Tuesday that its Cereol unit reached an agreement to buy a 45 percent stake in Poland's oilseeds crusher ZT Kruszwica.
In a statement the Franco-Italian food group also said it was eying a "majority stake" in the company, which is being privatised, before the end of the year.  
The balance of Kruszwica capital will be held by the Polish government (five percent), staff (15 percent), various farm sector players (15 percent) and private investors (20 percent).
Kruszwica, which is located 200 km northwest of Warsaw, has an annual crushing capacity of 300,000 tonnes.
It generates annual sales of over 900 million francs and controls 35 percent of the Polish crushings market.
-- Paris newsroom +331 4221 5432

headline: Germany's DAX up three percent, boost from banks.
text:
Germany's DAX index surged three percent in bourse dealings on Tuesday as merger mania gripped the banking industry after two regional banks set off a feeding frenzy in the sector by announcing a merger on Monday.
The 30-share DAX index ended bourse trade up 122.02 points at 4,230.42 points in a dramatic recovery from a two percent drop on Monday tied to profit-taking and some fresh speculative selling that sought to test whether the market had peaked.
The DAX ended at a new record high, besting the old mark of 4,227.31 points set on July 17.
Commerzbank AG, which will become Germany's fourth-largest bank if the merger of Bayerische Vereinsbank and Bayerische Hypotheken- und Wechselbank AG is emerged, surged 12 percent as traders said the Frankfurt bank was a prime takeover target.
"It's the next target for a takeover," said one Frankfurt dealer about Commerzbank. "Or they are going to have to step up and make an acquisition. They are the only one left without an international partner of some size. The pressure is growing."
Other bank shares, including Vereinsbank and Hypo-Bank, posted gains well above the DAX advance, which traders said was the key reason for the blue-chip index's hefty gains.
"The banks are clearly driving the market higher," said one dealer. "The traditional stocks that tend to profit profit from a higher dollar are not faring as well as the market."
"The focus for the rest of this week is clearly on the banks, but it may then be time for a look at another sector."
Vereinsbank rose nearly 12 percent, adding 9.90 marks to 95.60 marks, while Hypo-Bank rose 10 percent to 73.45 marks.
Another possible takeover candidate, BHF-Bank, rose five percent to 54.01 marks.
Insurance group Allianz AG, which is the top shareholder in Hypo-Bank, rose 36 marks to 455.50 marks, a gain of nearly nine percent. CS-First Boston said it raised Allianz to a buy rating from hold and set a price target of 560 marks.
The banking sector focused distracted market attention away from Tuesday's meeting in Frankfurt of a committee of banks and the German bourse to review the DAX portfolio.
Sportswear group Adidas AG is touted as the top pick to enter the DAX and was widely believed to be ready to oust beleaguered retailer Karstadt AG.
But Monday's banking merger may allow Adidas to join the DAX when the merger is completed in the fall and also allow Karstadt to remain in the prestigious index.
Adidas shares ended bourse trade steady at 218.50 marks, while Karstadt shares rose 7.50 marks to 682.50 marks.
Among other shares, Deutsche Lufthansa AG surged 1.65 marks to 34.05 marks after investment banker Deutsche Morgan Grenfell recommended switching into the airline from British Airways.
DMG also raised its earnings per share estimates on Lufthansa for 1997 and 1998.
But not all DAX components fared well in the rally. Carmaker Volkswagen AG slumped nine marks to 1,395 marks despite reporting a nearly 10 percent rise in global vehicle sales during the first half of 1997. VW also said sales in western Europe rose four percent during the same period.
Chemicals group BASF AG rose 60 pfennigs to 68.60 marks despite the German government disallowing the sale of its Kal und Salz shares to Canada's Potash Corp on anti-competition grounds. BASF said it still intended to sell the Kali shares.

headline: Egypt could buy 300-5000,000 tonnes wheat - trade.
text:
Egypt, now shopping for modest quantities of French and U.S. wheat, could end up buying between 300,000 and 500,000 tonnes soon, European grain exporters said on Tuesday.
Egypt re-entered the world market with two tenders for a total of 100,000 tonnes of French and U.S. wheat despite a government decree last week requiring grain imports to show proof they have not been genetically altered.
"I have announced two separate tenders -- one for French wheat only (50,000 tonnes) and one for French or U.S. wheat (also 50,000 tonnes)," Egypt's main grain buyer Samir el-Shakankiri told Reuters in Cairo.
The joint tender, announced on Monday, is for 50,000 tonnes of U.S. or French wheat for delivery in August and results are expected shortly, Shakankiri said. There had been trade reports that this tender was for U.S. wheat only.
The tender announced Tuesday is for 50,000 tonnes of French-only wheat to be loaded in August, September, or October.
European exporters said that despite the smaller than usual quantities in the two tenders, Cairo could decide to buy more if it wanted to cover its needs for August onwards.
It normally buys some 400,000 tonnes a month, they said.
"We are coming to the end of July and the Egyptians have not yet made their purchases for August, so they will buy at least 300,000 tonnes," one European trader said.
"If the Egyptians want to buy to cover part of September they could go to 500,000 tonnes," he added.
Egypt's wheat imports are seen at 6.5 million tonnes this season (July/June) according to the International Grains Council this month -- unchanged from last year but up from 6.2 million tonnes estimated in a previous June report.
That would restore Egypt's rank as the largest world wheat importer after a record surge in Iranian imports last year.
Traders noted French wheat prices remained uncompetitive when put in direct competition with U.S. values. Soft red winter is valued near $135 for October compared with French wheat in the mid-$140s. The gap is wider for August where soft red is worth $128.
The European Commission's subsidy stance will be crucial but cannot yet be easily evaluated since last week's first auction of the season was dominated by refunds of less than one Ecu to cover outstanding sales to Iraq and Cuba.
But exporters said they would remind the Commission that Egypt had returned to the European market in the past season after previously having bought mostly U.S. wheat since the Gulf War.
Cairo bought 1.53 million tonnes in the first 10 months of 1996/97 (July/June) against just 100,000 tonnes in the whole of 1995/96. In 1991/92, Egypt imported no French wheat at all.
--Paris newsroom +331 4221 5146

headline: Drachma effective rate down 3.4 pct y/y in June.
text:
The nominal effective exchange rate of the drachma was down 3.4 percent year-on-year in June and 2.5 percent since December 1996 but was unchanged month-on-month, the central bank said.
The nominal effective exchange rate of the drachma stood at 63.7 in June from 65.3 in December 1996 and 65.9 in June 1996. The index is calculated using 1990 as the base year, it said in its July bulletin of conjunctural indicators.
The drachma depreciated 3.4 percent year-on-year to 309.7 against the ecu in June and 1.5 percent since December 1996 but firmed 0.4 percent month-on-month in June. --Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

headline: Germany in contact with partners on forex-Waigel.
text:
German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said on Tuesday that Germany was in contact with its trading partners regarding foreign exchange matters.
"We are in contact with our partners and that is all I can say," he said.
-- Bonn Newsroom, +49-228 26097150

headline: Waigel-Bonn to meet EMU criteria in 97, beat in 98.
text:
Finance Minister Theo Waigel said on Tuesday Germany would meet the entry criteria for European economic and monetary union (EMU) in 1997, and beat the fiscal targets in 1998.
"We will hold to the Maastricht criteria in 1997 and improve in 1998," Waigel said.
-- Bonn Newsroom, +49-228 26097150

headline: Buba's Welteke sees France, Germany in timely EMU.
text:
Bundesbank council member Ernst Welteke said on Monday France had now made clear that it would not meet the European single currency three percent target ratio for deficits to GDP in 1997.
"The French government obviously has said that it will not reach three, while the German government still assumes that it will hit three," Welteke told reporters.
He added however that the decision on which countries would be in the first round of European economic and monetary union (EMU) was more a political decision and said central banks should keep out of the process.
Asked whether he still thought France would be in the first round of EMU members he said: "As ever I see a timely EMU start and it wouldn't make sense without France or Germany."
Welteke, who is also president of the state central bank in Hesse, was speaking to reporters before an event hosted by the Social Democratic (SPD) party in Frankfurt.
France's budget minister earlier said that the French 1997 budget deficit was currently running at 3.5 to 3.7 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) way above the reference value of three percent stated in the Maastricht Treaty for EMU.
The French government immediately said it planned to reduce the deficit by 32 billion francs, or 0.4 percent of GDP, but did not give a numerical target for the the final 1997 deficit-to-GDP ratio.

headline: Buba's Krupp sees no problems solved in EMU delay.
text:
Bundesbank council member Hans-Juergen Krupp said on Monday worries were unfounded that the new single European currency would be unstable if public budget deficits were not exactly at three percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) to qualify for the euro.
Krupp also said the best outcome for the start of the new currency, scheduled for January 1999, is for the most nations as possible to qualify but for entry criteria in the Maastricht Treaty not to be weakened.
"Worries about the stability of the Euro because an on-target landing on three percent (defict of GDP) was not achieved are not warranted," Krupp told journalists.
"We have achieved great stability in Europe but that is often overlooked," he said.
Krupp, saying a delay in the euro's start was no solution to the problem of European nations seeking to meet the Maastricht Treaty criteria, also said Bundesbank President Hans Tietmeyer had made clear the treaty does not say three percent in reference to public budget deficits.
German Finance Minister Theo Waigel has repeatedly said the Maastricht Treaty should be interpreted as saying the budget deficit must be at three percent in 1997, the year when nations are judged on whether they can join the new currency.
Krupp said: "Tietmeyer has not said what does not conform to the treaty. Therefore he has not said three (percent)."

headline: Rhone-Poulenc set to report better H1.
text:
Rhone-Poulenc SA is set to report higher first half profits on Friday, just days before it is free to declare its bid on minorities in Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc.
Financial analysts said on Tuesday they were expecting a first half net attributable income of 1.48 to 1.60 billion francs compared to 1.41 billion in the first half of 1996 -- a rise of between seven and 13 percent after a 6.5 percent first quarter rise.
The percentage increase would be at the lower end of the company's full-year forecast that 1997 earnings per share would rise by 20 percent.
Financial analysts, according to Reuters Securities 3000, are on average expecting the full year earnings per share figure to rise by 23 percent to 10.40 francs in 1997 and 13.70 francs in 1998, from 8.44 francs in 1996.
This increase would be booked despite the setback of an albumin blood plasma product recall at the U.S. Centeon joint-venture with Germany's Hoechst.
The company's polyester activities in Brazil, hit hard by a price crisis, should show an improvement while the higher dollar would also support its results.
Some asset gains could also be announced. Company Chairman Jean-Rene Fourtou said in April that 1997 asset sales gains could top five billion francs instead of the three billion planned.

headline: EU jobs summit set for Nov 21-22 - Belgian minister.
text:
European labour ministers have agreed that a European Union summit on the fight against unemployment should be held on November 21-22 in Luxembourg, Belgian Labour Minister Miet Smet said.
It was the first time exact dates had been given for the jobs summit, which was originally announced following a meeting of EU leaders in Amsterdam in June.
Smet told the Belgian daily newspaper De Standaard in an interview published on Tuesday that the summit, the first to be held specifically on the subject, should aim to agree on measures which would halve unemployment in the 15-nation bloc.
EU leaders should set ambitious targets. "In a Europe with more than 18 million unemployed there is no alternative," she said.
Measures should include cheap loans from the European Investment Bank to companies and more effective use of structural funds for aid to impoverished regions.
Cash should be pumped into large infrastructure projects, such as high-speed train links and telecommunications networks, she said.
France proposed last Thursday that European trade unions and employers be represented at the summit.
Paris wants to discuss the idea of a reduction in working hours to create jobs.
Other countries are likely to call for greater labour market flexibility, to which France is hostile.

headline: POLL-PGS H1 pre-tax seen at $35 mln.
text:
Norwegian offshore services and seismic company Petroleum Geo-Services ASA (PGS) is expected to book a pre-tax profit of $35 million in the first six months of 1997, a Reuters poll of seven analysts showed.
In the first half 1996, the Houston-headquartered group posted profits before tax of $25 million.
Two of the analysts recommended buying the share, three said hold, one sell and one declined to give a recommendation.
Analysts who have downgraded their recommendation on PGS attributed the move to a sharp rise in the share price over recent months.
The analysts said they were focusing on margins and new technology, together with PGS' own plans to get into the floating production sector.
PGS will present first half results on Wednesday. Following lists analysts expectations:
			     (millions of crowns unless stated)
				     Expectations
			     Average    High	 Low	H196
Operating income	   216	 227	 204	 192
Operating result	    44	  50	  36	  33
Net financial items minus 10  minus  8 minus  12  minus  8
Pre-tax profit		35	  40	  26	  25
Net result		    22	  24	  19	  18
EPS H197 ($)		 0.70     0.80	0.60	0.66
EPS 1997 ($)		 2.06     2.19	2.00
EPS 1998 ($)		 2.68     2.92	2.30
--Terje Solsvik, Oslo newsroom +47 22 93 69 75

headline: EU challenge to farm methods after pig crisis.
text:
A swine fever epidemic devastating the Dutch pig industry is evidence that intensive farming must be re-examined, a senior European Union official said on Monday.
"Look at what is happening in the Netherlands. The situation is no longer tenable; we cannot continue like that," Guy Legras, director general for agriculture at the European Commission, told a Paris news conference on proposed EU farm reforms.
The epidemic which broke out in February has led to authorities killing more than five million pigs in the Netherlands. Most of the bill has been financed by the EU.
Spain and Belgium have also been affected.
"I think the Netherlands, which has been the champion of intensification, realises today that we are in a position where half the country is closed off and the crisis continues to spread," Legras said.
"All this imposes a very serious reflection on the need to bring agriculture closer towards environmental necessities and in this respect the pig crisis is an example," he added.
Legras gave the outbreak as one example of how farm reforms must bow to environmental concerns, though the pig industry is not one of those affected by the package announced last week.
"This crisis has already cost us 350 million Ecus and we cannot continue in this way, so we must think," Legras said.
The EU aims to bring rural development strategies into its 30-year-old Common Agricultural Policy for the first time in a price-cutting reform designed for the turn of the century.

headline: Table of Greek central bank fixing rates, July 22.
SocGen ups Lafarge 1997 profit forecast. [CORRECTED 12:58 GMT]
text:
French bank Societe Generale raised its 1997 profit forecast for building materials group Lafarge and reiterated its "buy" recommendation following a private visit to the company, an analyst at the bank said on Tuesday.
Murielle Fellous, analyst at Societe Generale in London, said she had increased her 1997 net profit forecast to 2.3 billion francs from 2.27 billion previously and had upped her prediction for operating profit to 5.293 billion from 4.830 billion.
She raised her 1998 net profit forecast to 2.615 billion from 2.585 billion and 1998 operating profit to 5.790 from 5.260 billion.
Fellous said she thought the outlook for operating profit was better across the whole Lafarge group except for paints and formulated products such as mortar. (Corrects to clarify product types.)
Lafarge shares were up 4.24 percent at 396.1 at 1208 GMT, outpacing the CAC 40 index of leading shares and close to the session high of 398.0 francs.
U.S. subsidiary Lafarge Corp was due to publish its half-yearly results at 1300 GMT.
-- Paris Newsroom +331 4221 5542

headline: Breakthrough artists boost PolyGram music in H1.
text:
Fresh-faced teen pop trio Hanson joined forces with veteran Irish rockers U2 to help boost first half music sales and profits at PolyGram NV, the Dutch company said in a statement on Tuesday.
Group first half net profit slipped to 270 million guilders from 272 million a year earlier, with a strong music performance hit by increased operating losses from its film business.
"Despite challenging conditions in some of our markets, PolyGram's expertise in breaking new acts and promoting established artists is reflected in the first half results," PolyGram chief executive Alain Levy said in the statement.  
Sales at the music division rose to 3.94 billion guilders in the first half from 3.63 billion, with operating profit up to 522 million from 457 million.
Within the division pop sales increased by 10 percent to 2.99 billion, or 66 percent of first half sales.
The best selling album in the first half was "Pop" from U2, with over five million copies sold, while breakthrough act Hanson sold three million copies of their album "Middle of Nowhere", during the second quarter. Two albums from Italian singer Andrea Bocelli collectively sold 4.2 million copies over the first half.  
In total nine albums sold over one million copies in the first half, compared to 15 in the first six months of 1996 when PolyGram released a bigger number of superstar albums.
Total unit sales for the top five albums in the first half of 1997 was 15 million compared to 13 million for the comparable period in 1996.
The company, 75-percent owned by Philips Electronics NV, said it had a strong second half music release schedule with albums from Bjork, Boyz II Men, Elton John, Metallica and LL Cool J.
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040

headline: Merita gains sharply in brisk demand.
text:
Shares in Finnish banking group Merita rose sharply on Tuesday in brisk demand, possibly boosted by further restructuring in European banking as Bavarian Vereinsbank is merging with Hypobank, brokers said.
At 1505/1205 GMT, Merita traded at 22.00 markka, up 1.20 markka or almost six percent, but stopping short of its July 16 life-high of 22.10 markka. Volume was a sturdy 45 million markka.
Brokers said Merita rose on some big overseas demand, but they were mixed on whether the German merger was fuelling speculation of Nordic finance industry consolidation.
-- Helsinki Newsroom +358-9-680 50 235, news@reuters.fi

headline: Italy awaits war crimes verdict with bated breath. [CORRECTED 13:15 GMT]
text:
Families of the 335 victims of Italy's worst World War Two atrocity waited with bated breath on Tuesday for the verdict in a sensational trial of two former Nazi SS officers.
"All I'm hoping for is justice and a lesson in morality for young people," Giulia Spizzichino, who lost seven male relatives in the March 1944 Ardeatine Caves massacre, told Reuters.
A three-judge panel in a military courtroom in Rome's Rebibbia prison earlier retired to consider its verdict on former Nazi captain Erich Priebke and Karl Hass, who held the rank of major. Both are accused of complicity in the killings.
The verdict is not expected before 4 p.m. (1400 GMT).
Many relatives of the victims consider the trial a second chance for Italy to put the record straight after a first war crimes trial last year ended in uproar and embarrassment.
"This is another shot to get it right because the whole world came down on them last time," said Robert Katz, a U.S. historian of the Nazi period.
The Ardeatine Caves massacre has revived painful memories of the Nazi occupation. SS officers rounded up 335 men and boys, including 75 Jews, and took them to the caves, south of Rome, where they shot them in reprisal for a partisan attack.
Priebke was the sole defendant in an often chaotic first trial that ended on August 1 last year. A military court, split 2-1 (corrects split and number of judges on panel from "2-3" to "2-1"), decided that the 83-year-old German was guilty but should not be punished because of a statute of limitations -- in other words, too much time had elapsed since the original crime.
Protesters laid siege to the courtroom, where Priebke was arrested hours later. The verdict was later quashed on appeal.
"What the judges are deciding now is how politically to present it (the verdict)," said Shimon Samuels, Director of International Affairs for the Los Angeles based Simon Wiesenthal Center that specialises in tracking ex-Nazis.
"They don't want to repeat what happened last year...What it looks like it's going to be is a condemnation but with clemency due to age," he told Reuters.
Priebke turns 84 next week and Hass is a year older. Both men have been held under house arrest during the trial.
The prosecution has demanded a life sentence for Priebke and 24 years for Hass, saying Priebke's crimes were aggravated by cruelty, brutality and premeditation, while Hass could claim mitigating circumstances.
Lawyers for the victims' families want five life sentences for each of the two Germans. The defence wants them set free.
Priebke was extradited in November 1995 from Argentina, where he lived openly for nearly half a century.
Hass was a reluctant prosecution witness in Priebke's first trial, but broke his pelvis trying to flee to avoid giving evidence and eventually testified from his hospital bed.
He was arrested after admitting that he also took part in the massacre. Both men have admitted they each shot two victims and Priebke has said he also ticked names off a list.
But both have said they were obeying orders, and would have been shot themselves had they refused.
Spizzichino said she had felt "much hope" during the trial, which began in April. "But today I'm prepared for the worst."
"I hope that this time Italy's moral health will prevail," said Rosina Stame, who lost her husband at the caves. "The whole world is watching. Either way, my bitterness remains."
Katz summed up the feelings of many of the victims' families, gathered at the courtroom to await the verdict.
"I can't see how they could not find (Priebke) guilty to the fullest extent," he said. "But then again, I thought so last time as well."

headline: PolyGram H1 net falls, sales rise.
text:
Music and entertainment group PolyGram NV said on Tuesday first-half 1997 net profit slipped slightly, with music performing strongly but again offset by losses from its young film business.
Net profit in the first six months of 1997 declined to 270 million guilders ($132.9 million) from 272 million, returning to the level reported for the first half of 1995.
Analysts had been anticipating a net profit of as much as 286 million guilders, based on strong music sales from artists such as U2 and Hanson, with consensus seen at 276 million.
"Compared with a strong first half of 1996, PolyGram's 1997 performance in film has been relatively weak to date," PolyGram chief executive Alain Levy said in a statement with the results.
"As a result, income from operations was 430 million guilders for the first half of 1997, an increase of two percent over last year," he added.
First-half group sales climbed five percent to 4.53 billion guilders with music generating sales of 3.94 billion.
Operating profit in music rose to 522 million guilders from 457 million during the half. Veteran Irish rockers U2 sold over five million albums, while teenage newcomers Hanson sold three million.
The film division saw first-half turnover dip to 589 million guilders from 681 million with operating losses widening to 92 million from 37 million. Film's second-quarter operating loss was 37 million guilders compared to 55 million in the first quarter and 18 million in the second quarter of 1996.
PolyGram said the results of its filmed entertainment business reflected the division's lighter release schedule during the first six months of 1997, adding the division saw its strongest releases in the second half.
Film during the first half of 1996 benefited from the success of "Dead Man Walking", "Fargo", and "Mr Holland's Opus".
At the first-quarter stage in April PolyGram said underperformance of previously released films "Portrait of a Lady" and "Gridlock'd" had hit its earnings.
PolyGram shares were up 5.10 guilders to 106.10 on a sharply higher Amsterdam bourse, roughly doubling gains posted ahead of the results.
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040 ($ = 2.031 Dutch Guilders)

headline: Analysts' comments on PolyGram H1 profits.
text:
Dutch music and entertainment group PolyGram on Tuesday reported first half net profits of 270 million guilders, against 272 million guilders in the first half of 1996. The company did not give a forecast for the full year.
Below is a selection of analysts' comments:
PETER WORTEL, DELTA LLOYD BANK:
"There's nothing that wasn't expected. They had some good artists in the first half and some albums, notably U2's, sold really well. On the film side, it's a bit disappointing. It's loss-making and will remain so for the time being. In the second half there are some good names, but were knew about them already. The prospects are good, but not spectacular."  
THIJS BERKELDER, HSBC VAN MEER JAMES CAPEL
"The results were right on target for most analysts. Nothing was surprisingly higher or lower. Music had maybe somewhat lower profit and film had a slightly lower loss (than expected). For the second half, you have to look at the new releases and they have quite a number and they can benefit from new films. 'Bean' for instance is already introduced and looks promising. Looking at the release schedule, you must remain relatively positive for the second half."  
ANDRE MOONS, ING BARINGS
"My first reaction is that again it's a stable result, which particularly in a stock market climate like this...is not so inspiring. When you look at the results breakdown, film is a lot lower -- as expected -- and while music did a lot better after correction for currencies and so forth it's not that impressive. Polygram gave no firm forecasts for 1997, although their release schedule for the second half contains some strong acts like Boyz II Men, Shania Twain...and Jackie Cheung. Even so, that's rather an unsteady base on which to project major earnings growth. Film is expected to perform better (in the second half).
We have the stock on a hold recommendation and based on currency strength we expect to maintain this."
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040

headline: Ansaldo talking with Daewoo - minister.
text:
Italy's industry minister Luigi Bersani on Tuesday confirmed that energy group Ansaldo, part of state-controlled Finmeccanica, was studying the possibility of co-operation with South Korea's Daewoo.
Bersani said while attending a conference here that he had had a meeting with Daewoo chairman Kim Woo-Choong, and added it was clear that Daewoo and Ansaldo had complementary industrial areas.
He also regarded as positive the interest from chairman Heinrich Von Pierer of German electronics and engineering group Siemens in the privatisation of Italy's defence and engineering group Finmeccanica.
Milan financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore reported on Tuesday that Von Pierer had expressed interest in the planned privatisation of Finmeccanica.
Finmeccanica and Siemens have been co-operating since 1992 in the areas of railway equipment and gas turbines.
-- Milan newsroom +392 66129502

headline: Ministers to discuss export refund/animal welfare link.
text:
Farm ministers will on Tuesday discuss practical and legal problems with a proposal to make payment of export refunds for farm animals dependent on respect of animal welfare rules, EU officials said.
Problems include whether spot or comprehensive checks should be carried out, who should conduct them and who should carry the cost.
Seven countries, including Germany, Sweden and Britain, want speedy action to improve animal welfare and soothe public opinion outraged by media reports of mistreatment of animals.
But some exporting countries, such as France and Ireland, are cautious about making exporters legally liable for respecting EU animal welfare rules outside the 15 member states and say the extra cost could make exports uncompetitive.
A decision cannot be taken until after the European Parliament has given its opinion in October.
The EU exports about 600,000 cattle, sheep and goats annually -- mostly to Egypt, Libya, Lebanon and Turkey. But EU exports are mostly in the form of meat.

headline: Levy says Israelis "defending our lives".
text:
Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy gave a spirited defence of his country's commitment to Middle East peace on Tuesday, telling European members of parliament that Israelis were "defending their lives".
"We see peace as a value and a goal, but it is a complicated issue," he told members of the European Parliament's foreign affairs committee.
"I know that some of you feel Israel is not helping the peace process, but this is not us being stubborn, this is us defending our lives."
Levy, in Brussels for talks with the European Union's foreign ministers and also possibly a meeting with Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, refused to accept any blame for the breakdown in the Middle East peace process.
"We have fulfilled all our obligations under the various accords -- the other party has not," he said. "We demand responsibility from the other side, and this responsibility must be demonstrated by action."
Disputes between Israeli and Palestinian leaders over settlements and security have nudged the Middle East peace crisis into its fifth month.
An Arafat/Levy meeting would be the highest-level Israel-PLO contact since April and follows Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's decision to dispatch his senior adviser to Washington for peace consultations. A formula for reviving talks remains, however, elusive.
Levy was given a hostile reception by many Euro MPs, but he robustly defended Israeli policy, shouting at one heckler: "You have to be in Israel or with Israel to understand completely."
The Moroccan-born foreign minister, speaking a mixture of French and Hebrew, told MPs: "I am not so naive as to believe I could have come here and changed opinions. All I can do is explain our position."
But he reminded the committee of the threat Jews had faced in the past -- particularly in Europe, adding: "We hate war ... we have been victims of a war that was designed to eradicate us completely.
"It is our right to expect from Europe ... to allow the two sides to try to resolve the matter without interference."
The EU has long been a vociferous backer of Palestinian aspirations for a homeland and is the biggest bankroller of aid to the fledgling Palestinian Authority.

headline: Highlights of Tuesday's Commission briefing.
text:
Following are highlights of the midday briefing by the European Commission on Tuesday:
Spokesman Josep Coll i Carbo said there would be a trilateral meeting between EU representatives including Commissioner Manuel Marin, Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy and Palestinian President Yasser Arafat on Tuesday at about 1700/1500 GMT.
Asked wether there were concrete EU proposals to restore the peace process in the area, Coll i Carbo said that even if there were any, he would not say so.
Spokesman Nikolaus van der Pas said that Wednesday's Commission midday briefing would take place at 1145/0945 GMT instead of 1200/1000 GMT.
Van der Pas said that Commissioner Karel Van Miert would hold a news conference on the Commission's decision on the proposed Boeing/McDonell Douglas merger at 1200/1000 GMT on Wednesday.
Van der Pas also said European Commission President Santer would hold a joint news conference with Austrian Chancellor Viktor Klima at 1230/1030 GMT.
In answer to a question, van der Pas said the World Bank and European Commission would host a donors conference for the reconstruction of Bosnia on Wednesday in the Borschette Center.
Van der Pas said he was not aware of any contact between President Santer and the U.S. authorities on the Boeing/McDonell Douglas proposed merger.
- - - -
The Commission released the following documents:
- IP/97/671: Public procurement: infringement procedures against France, Italy Spain and Austria.
- IP/97/672: Commissioner Wulf-Mathies welcomes the IRA's cease-fire announcement
- IP/97/675: TENs projects in the energy sector - ECU 7.48 million for feasibility studies.
- IP/97/676: The Commission clears Nintendo's new licensing agreements.
- Eurostat news release No 53/97: 149.3 million in the EU with a job.
- Eurostat - Statistics in focus - Energy and industry No 1997-18: Producer price index of industrial production.
- Eurostat - Statistics in focus - Energy and industry No 1997-19: Installed capacity of thermal power stations.
- Eurostat - Statistics in focus - Population and social conditions No 1997-8: labour force survey.
- Provisional agenda for Wednesday July 23's Commission meeting.
- ME97/23.7: Midday Express.

headline: Lafarge up ahead of subsidiary's results.
text:
Speculation that a subsidiary of French building materials company Lafarge would publish favourable results on Tuesday afternoon boosted Lafarge shares by more than four percent, traders said.
Lafarge shares rose as high as 398 francs and at 1146 GMT were trading up 4.24 percent at 396.1 francs, outpacing the CAC 40 index of leading shares which was up 0.87 percent.
"We're waiting for the Lafarge Corp results this afternoon and everybody's speculating about that," a trader said.
U.S. subsidiary Lafarge Corp. was due to publish its half-yearly results at 1300 GMT.
-- Paris Newsroom +331 4221 5542

headline: Inapa says gains more without state plan.
text:
The president of Portuguese privately owned pulp group Inapa said it had little to gain from a government proposal to reorganise the pulp and paper industry and was best off without it.
"Our contribution to this (reorganised) business would be disproportionate to what we would receive in return," Vasco Pessanha told reporters.
"The potential for our company to rise in value is much greater alone than as part of this scheme," he added.
Under the government proposal, Inapa would merge with state-owned Portucel and Soporcel to form a new company. The government would retain a "golden share" of about five percent, and 45 to 50 percent would be dispersed among the public.
-- Lisbon newsroom +(351-1) 3538254

headline: EU standing firm on Wednesday Boeing decision.
text:
The European Commission still intends to rule on Boeing Co's merger with McDonnell Douglas on Wednesday with virtually no chance that Boeing could produce an acceptable offer by then, an EU source said on Tuesday.
The source said Boeing and the Commission had held no substantive talks since last week and that the company had not yet fully satisfied the EU executive on any of its three main concerns about the $14 billion merger.
Asked if Boeing still had a chance to win a reprieve, he said, "In 24 hours you can do a lot of things, but you can't disregard legal procedures."
He said it would be difficult for Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert to reverse his plan to ban the merger before Wednesday since he would have to draft a new text and send it to senior Commission officials and EU national competition experts for review.
The Commission believes the deal would strengthen Boeing's already dominant position in the commercial sector, a conclusion rejected by the manufacturer, which argues McDonnell Douglas no longer constitutes a serious competitor.
McDonnell Douglas's strength in the military sector, also causes the Commission to fear that Boeing would benefit from defence funds to subsidise its commercial programmes.
But the most contentious point remains the exclusive supply contracts signed with large U.S. airlines AMR Corp's American Aitlines, Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines.
The source said there had been some progress during talks between the two sides, but that "As long as there is not an agreement on everything, there is no agreement at all."
The Commission's determination to block the merger has triggered a barrage of sharp criticism on the other side of the Atlantic and President Bill Clinton warned the United States might go to the World Trade Organisaton or impose sanctions if this happened.
The EU executive has the power to block the deal if it finds it would harm fair competition in the 15-nation bloc. Were Boeing to go ahead with the merger regardless, it could impose fines up to 10 percent of the companies' turnover.

headline: France seeks to soothe Arab anger after X-film.
text:
France said on Tuesday that the broadcasting by a French channel of a hard-core pornographic film around the Arab world instead of a children's programme was "unacceptable" and the result of a technical error.
The state-funded Canal France International (CFI) has apologised for the mistake, which resulted in all its programmes being yanked off the air by the Arabsat satellite consortium after the broadcast at prime time on Saturday afternoon.
"We deeply regret this unacceptable incident and we share in the high feelings prompted in Saudi Arabia and more widely in the Arab world," foreign ministry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt told a daily press briefing.
CFI "took no part in the broadcasting of such a programme. It was an unacceptable incident which resulted from a technical error", he said.
CFI said the mistake took place at the France Telecom state communications agency which feeds French television programmes to satellites across the world -- among them Arabsat, which broadcasts throughout Arab countries.
Instead of sending a scheduled feature for children, France Telecom sent the pornographic film from a private French station destined for clients in the Pacific.
France Telecom confirmed the incident and said an investigation was under way.
Officials said French diplomats in Saudi Arabia had tried to smooth over what could be a disaster for France's efforts to reach audiences in the Arab world, where most Western programmes are American-made.
CFI said that in 1995, its programmes went to a potential audience of more than 33 million people in and around the Middle East.

headline: Dead Nazi poet causes row in Austria.
text:
The man who wrote the words of the Swastika Song, one of the favourite election themes of Adolf Hitler's Nazis, could have his name removed from many Austrian streets and squares.
An Austrian political group on Tuesday announced a campaign for the renaming of all public places commemorating the poet Ottokar Kernstock in Lower Austria province.
"Kernstock is not entitled to get recognition by having public areas named after him," Andreas Kollross, chairman of the province's young Social Democrats, said in a statement.
Judging from his literary works, Kernstock could be described as "paving the way for right-wing radicalism", he added.
Kernstock wrote the "Hakenkreuzlied", or Swastika Song after the crooked cross symbol of Hitler's National Socialists, in the spring of 1923 for the Fuerstenfeld local branch of the party.
The Nazis then used the song widely as election propaganda after Kernstock's death in 1928. Around 20 streets are named after him in Lower Austria.

headline: DNIB ups 4-yr callable matador to up 13 bln pta.
text:
De Nationale Investeringsbank (DNIB) increased by up to three billion pesetas to 13 billion pesetas a four-year callable bond, with a coupon at 5.49 percent, at 100.9, Banco de Negocio Argentaria said.
Banco de Negocio Argentaria is joint lead manager with Banco Urquijo and BNP.
The bond, initially announced on July 18, will mature on September 3, 2001, and has a pay date on September 3. Minimum tranche is for 10,000 pta. Total fees are one percent.
DNIB has a rating of AA3 by Moody and AA+ by Standard and Poor's. The bond is callable by the issuers after the first year, on September 1 1998 at par.
--Madrid Newsroom +34 1 585 2167

headline: Analysts comfortable SAP will hit Q2 goals.
text:
Results of German software group SAP AG, due on Thursday, should avoid unpleasant surprises after its recent forecast of strong second-quarter profit growth, financial analysts said.
"The company's forecast came out only a few weeks ago, so that should give a pretty good indication of the results," said Deutsche Morgan Grennfell's Juergen Hackenberg.
Based on SAP's July 7 advisory that profit growth would be similar to the first quarter's 54 percent rate, Credit Lyonnais analyst Hans Peter Wodniok said he expected pretax profit of about 580 million marks for the first half of 1997, up from 374 million marks a year ago.
Pretax profit above 600 million marks would be very positive and could spur SAP shares to another sharp rise, Wodniok said. Anything under 560 million marks would be a disappointment.
Wodniok predicted six-month sales would reach 2.4 billion marks, compared with 1.594 billion in the year-ago period.
"I'm looking for a 45 to 50 percent increase in pretax profit in light of their prognosis and the favourable currency situation," he told Reuters.
In the first quarter, currency effects accounted for about 55 million marks, or eight percentage points of its 49 percent rise in sales to 1.032 billion marks.
The company draws about a third of its sales from the U.S. market, where the dollar stands at an eight-year high of 1.80 marks, even higher than the 1.67 rate at the end of the first quarter.
Its shares were trading at 414.50 marks at 1140 GMT, up 9.30, with the blue-chip DAX index showing a gain of around three percent to around 4,230. They have risen 19 percent in the last 30 days as Daimler-Benz AG, Volkswagen AG and Bayer AG signed deals to use SAP's R/3 software in global computer projects.
R/3 allows large companies to control manufacturing, purchasing, personnel and financial data from computers spread throughout their organisations.
The strength of the dollar is likely to enable SAP to exceed its full-year estimates of a sales rise of 30 percent and a profit increase of a few percentage points more, Wodniok said.
"We are forecasting more than 30 percent sales growth and clearly more than 30 percent profit growth because of the currency," he said.
Hackenberg predicted 1997 earnings per share of eight marks, up 46 percent from last year's 5.48 marks.
However, SAP shares could still be in for a bumpy if upward ride in the second half, Wodniok said.
Third-quarter results are likely to show large gains compared to a year ago, when SAP reported an unexpected slowdown in sales and profit growth that led to a sharp drop in its share price, he said.
In this year's fourth quarter, growth rates could show much slower growth against the year ago period, when SAP rebounded and returned to dramatic growth rates.
"That is the real question," Wodniok said. "What will the second half be like?" -- neal.boudette@reuters.com (Bonn =49-228 26097150)

headline: UN body protests to Bangladesh over refugees.
text:
The United Nations refugee agency UNHCR said on Tuesday it had protested to Bangladesh over what it termed "disgraceful" forced expulsions of refugees back into military-ruled Burma.
UNHCR spokeswoman Pam O'Toole said that in action by Bangladesh police on Sunday and earlier on Tuesday, nearly 400 people including women, children and sick "were rounded up indiscriminately," taken to the frontier and made to cross.
"This kind of conduct is a disgrace," she told a news briefing.
Reports from Bangladesh on Sunday said some 20 people, including six policemen, were injured in clashes between the police and Burmese Moslem refugees resisting repatriation.
Police used teargas and fired rifle shots in the air after the "Rohingya" refugees turned on officials and securitymen with spears, axes and iron rods trying to foil attempts to send them home.
O'Toole said the Geneva-based UNHCR, whose representatives on the spot in camps in the south-east corner of Bangladesh witnessed the expulsions, was considering asking Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina to intervene.
Earlier requests to the Bangladesh Foreign Ministry and to local officials to stop forced expulsions of the some 21,000 refugees -- mainly Burmese Moslems known as Rohingas -- had been ignored, she added.
O'Toole said the actions on Sunday and Tuesday appeared to be the start of an effort to deport some 7,500 of the refugees who have been cleared for repatriation by the authorities in Rangoon. But only a handful had volunteered to go, she added.
In both swoops, she told the news briefing, UNHCR staff in the area reported that families had been split up.
"In both cases, the refugees were loaded onto buses before UNHCR field staff could get to them. In both cases, UNHCR was not able to do the usual checks to ensure people were going back voluntarily, and we were not allowed to do medical checks.
"We have sent a second letter of protest to the Bangladesh authorities. We insist that this forced repatriation should stop," the spokeswoman added.
Bangladesh argues the refugees, and others the UNHCR reports are still flocking across the border, are economic migrants who put an unbearable burden on the poverty-ridden country.
The UNHCR says while many of the refugees -- the remnants of some 250,000 Rohingas who fled Burma in the early 1990s -- admit they were seeking a better life, others insisted they were escaping political persecution and forced labour.
Bangladeshi officials say more than 15,000 Rohingyas have arrived in Bangladesh over the last three months in a new influx, triggered by what the refugees said were continuing military persecution and recent rise in food prices.
O'Toole said many new arrivals from Burma who had been contacted by UNHCR staff had come from deeper inside Burma than the earlier refugees. "They speak of their land being confiscated and of forced labour," she added.

headline: Greek Jan-May borrowing requirement down 59pct y/y.
text:
Greece's general government net borrowing requirement fell provisionally 59 percent to 309 billion drachmas or 0.9 percent of GDP in January-May from 751.1 billion or 2.5 percent of GDP in the same period in 1996, the central bank said.
The net public sector borrowing requirement also dropped to 330 billion drachmas or 1.0 percent of GDP in the first five months of the year from 732.6 billion or 2.5 percent of GDP in the same period in 1996, it said.
The figures are on a cash basis and do not include capitalised and accrued interest, said the central bank in its July bulletin of conjunctural indicators. -- Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

headline: Kohl tours stricken east Germany to boost morale.
text:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl set off on a whistle-stop tour of two east German cities on Tuesday to reassure the impoverished, flood-hit region he was doing his best to regenerate its flagging economy.
Kohl left Berlin for Frankfurt-on-the-Oder on the Polish border, where the Oder River was threatening to break its banks. Heavy flooding throughout the region has already claimed scores of lives in the Czech Republic and Poland.
Later he was heading to steel town Eisenhuettenstadt. Built by communist East Germany in the 1950s as a model of industrial progress, and briefly named Stalinstadt after the Soviet dictator, it declined after German unification in 1990 but was rescued by huge cash injections from Bonn.
Kohl's Christian Democrats (CDU) are trailing badly in opinion polls in both cities, as well as in Berlin.
The trip comes at a difficult period politically for the veteran chancellor. With just over a year until the next elections, his popularity is fading, especially in the former communist east.
Pollsters predict a hard fight for the CDU between now and the September 1998 polls. They believe that, as in the past two national elections, the contest will be won or lost in the east.
In Eisenhuettenstadt (Iron Works City), Kohl will visit a new steel mill at Eko Stahl GmbH, an east German company that would have folded without millions in subsidies from his government.
Eko, 60 percent owned by Belgian steel firm Cockerill Sambre, expects to become profitable in 1998. Cockerill has an option to buy the rest of it before 1999.
Commentators called the trip a thinly-veiled attempt by Kohl, 67, to woo eastern voters on the eve of a month-long holiday in the Austrian Alps -- and to show off an exceptional east German success story before rolling television cameras.
"It is no accident Helmut Kohl finds himself in Brandenburg one more time before his holiday," said Berlin's Tagesspiegel newspaper in an editorial on Monday. Eisenhuettenstadt and Frankfurt-on-the-Oder are both in the state of Brandenburg.
"Without political backing and additional financial help from Bonn, Eko Stahl would have gone into liquidation a long time ago. The region is obliged to be grateful to the chancellor," the paper said.
Commentators say that while Kohl made political capital by carrying off German unification, few believe he can fulfil his 1990 pledge to create "blossoming landscapes" in the east, where unemployment averages 17 percent.
Surveys show that a slim majority of Germans oppose Kohl's next pet project, the launch of Europe's single currency, Most opponents are east Germans who were so pleased to have the deutschemark, they are loath to swap it for an untested euro.
Kohl has also personally backed cutting the solidarity tax surcharge levied to finance the reconstruction of east Germany -- a move that has bred resentment in east Germany but been applauded by west Germans who shoulder most of the burden.

headline: FOCUS-Dutch DSM to boost Euro plastics production.
text:
Dutch chemicals group DSM on Tuesday unveiled a billion-guilder acquisition to boost its position as a leading European polyolefins producer in the new millennium.
The acquisition and expansion of Vestolen GmbH's polyolefin activities at Gelsenkirchen, Germany, will involve an investment of one billion guilders ($492.2 million) spread over several years, DSM said.
It declined to disclose the purchase price, to be financed from existing cash flow, and estimated by some industry sources at around $200 million.
Under the deal, DSM -- currently Europe's fifth largest polyolefins producer -- will take over the polyolefin activities of Vestolen, a unit of German oil refiner Veba Oel AG.
Vestolen's Gelsenkirchen site has polyethylene production capacity of 150,000 tonnes per annum(TPA) and 200,000 TPA polypropylene.
Over the coming years DSM plans to step up production at the site by building a 300,000 TPA linear low-density polyethylene gas-phase plant and a 250,000 TPA polypropylene gas phase plant.
"After completing the projects in 2001, DSM will be one of the leading producers of polyethylene and polypropylene in Europe, with the lowest possible costs, a broad polyolefins portfolio and world-scale technological capabilities," DSM said.
Chairman Simon de Bree told a telephone news conference that after expansion, synergies between the Geleen and Gelsenkirchen sites would generate cost savings of some 100 million guilders a year.
"Our leading cost position has been secured for the future," De Bree said.
He said the deal would also secure DSM's existing strong position as supplier of polyethylene well into the first decade of the next century.
By the millennium, DSM's total polyolefins capacity will exceed 2.5 million tonnes a year, he said.
Current annual polyolefin capacity at DSM's Geleen plant is 1.52 million.
The agreement is aimed at meeting the strong growth in global demand for polyethylene, used in packaging articles such as bottles, bags and films, and polypropylene, used in packaging, textile fibres and plastic car parts.
Western European polyethylene consumption is set to jump by some 3.5 million TPA to 13.5 million by 2010, while polypropylene use will jump to nine million TPA from 5.4 million, DSM says.
Worldwide consumption is seen growing even more.
After the expansion, DSM will command around 12 percent of both European markets, said Henk van Dalen, head of DSM's polyethylenes business group.
"This European market growth does not take into account the very large growth potential of eastern Europe," he added.
De Bree said that around 90-95 percent of polyolefin production at the sites was destined for European consumption.
He said DSM's Geleen site, one of the world's largest integrated production complexes for polyethylene and polypropylene, offered too little scope for expansion.
"(The acquisition) is a real opportunity as in Geleen there is not sufficient olefins capacity, specifically in polypropylene," he said.
Consequently DSM was opting for a "Buy and Build" approach.
"By acquiring an existing site which offers scope for expansion and guarantees a secure supply of ethylene and propylene, DSM can copy its successful 'Geleen model' in polyolefins," the company said.
These feedstocks will be supplied to Gelsenkirchen by Veba Oel from the production plants of Ruhr Oel, its 50-50 joint venture with Petroleos de Venezuela, under a long-term contract stretching to 2015.
De Bree stressed the plastics investment did not come at the expense of further expansion in fine chemicals and other downstream activities.
"The level of investment is about one-fifth of what we will spend over that period (to 2002)," he noted.
DSM said in February it expected to invest around one billion guilders over 1997, excluding acquisitions.
On the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, DSM shares opened 5.50 guilders higher on the news at 230.00, touching 233 guilders before settling at 228.00 at midsession in a buoyant market.
Analysts were also broadly upbeat on the news, although some said the move had taken them a little by surprise.
"We had been expecting an expansion in fine chemicals, and now it's plastics," said Patrick Rutten, chemicals analyst with Van Lanschot Bankiers.
"Positive is the fact that this will make DSM European market leader by 2001 -- there is sure to be concentration in the sector but DSM has stolen a march on the competition."
He said that over the longer term, the deal would hike profits per share by an average 4-6 guilders a year over the full industry cycle.
Asked to comment, De Bree said "I do not see any reason to disagree with that estimate", agreeing it was a realistic ball-park figure.
DSM posted 1996 net profits of 720 million guilders or 23.83 guilders per share, down from a year-earlier 1.07 billion or 29.60 per share.

headline: Danish bonds up ahead of Greenspan, levels to hold.
text:
Danish bond prices rose in a quiet market, echoing advances on other European markets, with dealers predicting that levels would hold ahead of the evening's Humphrey Hawkins speech by U.S. Fed chairman Alan Greenspan.
"It is foreign markets which are forcing prices moderately up. We are just folllowing suit with little activity seen before Greenspan," one dealer said.
The benchmark eight percent state bond due 2006 was up 0.19 point from the opening at 114.13, yielding 5.86 percent. The upcoming seven percent 2007 benchmark rose 0.21 point to 106.97, with yield at 6.06 percent.  
Turnover in the 2006 and 2007 tone-setters was 1.6 billion and around one billion crowns respectively.
The 2006's September future rose 0.27 point to 113.50 with only one contract traded. The six percent mortgage bond due 2026 gained 0.18 point to 92.13. The crown traded at an unchanged 3.8075 per mark at 1135 GMT.
The 2007's 10-year yield gap with Germany was unaltered at 53 basis points. The Central Bank was active on the market selling a small amount of seven percent 2007 and seven percent 2024 bonds as part of its routine financing operations.
--Chris Follett, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33-969652

headline: Volvo Cars in secret product development - MD.
text:
Swedish vehicle maker Volvo said on Tuesday that a secret project drove up product development costs in its cars division in the second quarter of 1997.
Volvo Car's Managing Director Tuve Johannesson told a news conference held to discuss Volvo's first half profits that the project had increased costs, but he refused all comment on what the project involved.
"We had higher volumes in the second quarter and better margins but we also had higher product development costs because of a special marketing project," he said without elaborating.
Volvo Cars has recently launched several new models.
-- Simon Haydon, Stockholm newsroom +46-8-700-1004

headline: U.S. partner for Volvo still on cards-analysts.
text:
Swedish vehicle maker AB Volvo will probably reverse the performance of its ailing North American truck unit by year-end although analysts said on Tuesday a bid for a U.S. rival was still a good bet.
Analysts say the group will concentrate on restructuring the loss-making North American truck operations before looking for possible partners, of which Mack Trucks Inc. is the most often named.
Allentown, Pennsylvania-based Mack Trucks Inc. is owned by French carmaker Renault SA.
"First of all Volvo has to get ongoing operations under control. Cooperation with Mack or a takeover of Mack would be a strategic move and depend on whether or not Renault wants to sell it," said Den Danske Bank (DDB) analyst Hans Westerberg.
Volvo Trucks had 9.3 percent market share in North America in the first half of 1997, a dip on the first half of 1996.
Volvo Truck's operating profit slumped to 688 million crowns in the first half from 1.08 billion while net sales were nearly flat at 23.51 billion crowns compared to 23.11 billion in the same period a year earlier.
"It's clear they have to do something to get volumes up," said Gustaf von Essen, Volvo analyst at brokerage Carnegie.
Most analysts say the division will begin to show improving results in the third quarter of 1997, although some say they have changed their forecasts and do not expect improvement until the final quarter.
Karl-Johan Bonnevier, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson analyst, said Volvo Truck's focus on the long-haul segement would mesh well with Mack's operations.
"If they were able to buy Mack it would be a very good fit for them strategically," Bonnevier said, adding: "I am not sure the owner is willing to part with them."
Volvo declined to comment on the merger reports.
Chief Executive Leif Johansson said restructuring progammes had not yet filtered through to results and vowed to carry on aggressive reforms.
"Major rationalisation and cost-saving programmes have been instituted but have not yet had full effect. Aggressive improvements must continue," Johansson said in a statement.
The group, now a pure transport company following a three-year long divestment programme, posted an operating profit of 3.95 billion crowns in the first six months of the year compared to 2.28 billion in the same 1996 period.
Head of Volvo Truck's U.S. operations Karl-Erling Trogen was vague about when U.S. operations would turn around, saying the rate of improvement in North American was strong.
"This will lead to improved results," he told a news conference after the results were released.
"Clearly it is unsatisfactory that we are losing money in the short-term. But we have a continuingly improved rate of improvement and strong order intake on the VN trucks," he said.
Analysts say the U.S. market looked better than before.
"If you look at the U.S. market it seems to have stabilised for them. It's not the bottomless pit it was two or three quarters ago. I'm sure we are going to see better results in the third and fourth quarters," Bonnevier said.
Renault and Volvo still have large cross holdings in each other following a disastrous failed merger between the two companies, which broke up just as agreement was about to be signed in 1993.
-- Stockholm newsroom +46-8-700 1003

headline: UN agency says Cambodians fleeing fighting.
text:
The United Nations refugee agency UNHCR said on Tuesday thousands of Cambodians fleeing fighting in their country following the recent coup were reported massing near the border with Thailand.
But the Thai authorities were not allowing them to cross and the UNHCR was not being allowed into the area, spokeswoman Pam O'Toole told a news briefing.
"We are increasingly concerned about reports that thousands of people may be massing at Cambodia's border with Thailand and are not being allowed to cross," she said. The UNHCR was appealing to the Thai authorities to open the borders.
Up to 2,000 Cambodians had gathered at a western border point at Poipet seeking entry to Thailand, while there were reports that there could be more than 20,000 more massed near the northern border in an area called Chong Chom Pass.
O'Toole said relief organisations on the spot had reported these included members of military units who supported the FUNCINPEC party of ousted first prime minister Prince Norodom Ranariddh and their families.
In Bangkok, the Thai capital, she added, a growing number of refugees were arriving at the UNHCR office asking for help in obtaining asylum. Many were members of FUNCINPEC or of another party called the Union of Cambodian Democrats, she said.
These were alleging that many of their colleagues had been tortured or killed. Ranariddh, now in exile, has said that at least 30 senior officials loyal to him have been executed by forces of Cambodian strongman and Second Prime Minister Hun Sen.

headline: First German July state CPI data due on Wednesday.
text:
The statistics offices of the German states of Bavaria and Hesse said on Tuesday that they plan to release provisional consumer price data for July early on Wednesday.
The state of North Rhine-Westphalia said it would release its report either late on Wednesday or on Thursday, while the state of Baden-Wuerttemberg said it has provisionally planned to release its report on Friday, July 25.
Data from the four states is used to compute provisional west German consumer price data.
-- Frankfurt Newsroom, +49 69 756525
