headline: BES expects to grow organically.
text:
Portuguese bank Banco Espirito Santo expects to grow organically, but does not rule out making acquisitions if opportunities arise, its president Ricardo Espirito Santo Salgado said.
Speaking after the release of six-month results, he told a news conference that BES hoped to boost activities in the Portuguese, Spanish and Brazilian markets, and acknowledged that it could do so via acquisitions.
"Our policy of organic growth has not been not changed, nor do we expect it to change in the near future. But we are not dogmatic, and if a good opportunity arises, we will take advantage of it," Salgado said.
"We would like to increase our activity in the Portuguese, Spanish and Brazilian markets, but until now we have found no opportunity," he added. "If that opportunity arises, we will be ready to pursue it."
Earlier, BES reported a 43 percent increase in consolidated net profit in the first half to 15.2 billion escudos.

headline: Frankfurt dollar fix 1.8126 marks.
text: The dollar was fixed at 1.8126 marks in Frankfurt on Tuesday, after 1.7956 marks on Monday. There was no Bundesbank intervention. REUTER

headline: Madrid stocks improve gains in knee-jerk climb.
text:
Madrid stocks fattened gains at midday on Tuesday in a movement dealers called a technical reaction to losses in two previous sessions.
The index of most liquid shares, the Ibex-35 was up 88.5 points, or 1.34 percent, to 6,857.60, while chartists said it was targeting a new climb to 6,910. The general index climbed 5.20 points, 0.87 percent, to 602.53.
"Longer term, the Spanish bourse remains risky. People are starting to consider these prices too expensive," a dealer at a foreign bank in Madrid said.
Iberdrola was sharply outperforming the market, up 2.36 percent.  
"The market has tracked the rise in other stock markets, but frankly it may have been too much and we may have to pay in coming sessions," one dealer said.
Turnover was slightly lower than in previous sessions with 73.5 billion pesetas changing hands.
Banks, and BCH in particular, outperformed the market. BCH jumped 5.08 percent to 6,200 after the group posted a 22.6 percent rise in first-half profits, and said it was considering a share split.
-- Madrid newsroom + 34 1 585 2161

headline: France tax measures show a will for EMU - Juncker.
text:
Measures announced on Monday by France to reduce its budget deficit show a will to meet Maastricht treaty criteria in 1997 and 1998, Luxembourg Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker said on Tuesday.
"It shows that France is strongly committed to the date of January 1, 1999, and France is willing to meet the convergence criteria in 1997 and 1998," he told reporters after a meeting with French President Jacques Chirac.

headline: Inapa sees substantially higher H1 '97 net.
text:
Portuguese pulp group Inapa-Investimentos, Participacao e Gestao expected to post a first half 1997 profit substantially higher than the 0.4 billion escudos profit in the first half 1996, its president said.
"Inapa's profit in the first half was substantially superior to that obtained in the first six months of 1996," Vasco Pessanha told a news conference.
He declined to give a figure.
He told reporters that Inapa forecast a consolidated net profit of 1.5 billion escudos in 1997, up from 1.05 billion in 1996.

headline: Buba council expected to leave rates, M3 untouched.
text:
German monetary policy will remain pinned to its steady course after the Bundesbank's council meeting on Thursday, financial analysts predict.
Despite a sharp decline in the mark versus the dollar -- a factor which raises the likelihood of inflationary pressure -- analysts said the struggling economic recovery posed few risks on the prices front.
"Despite the weak currency, the Buba cannot afford to hike rates because of the weak internal and domestic demand," said Rosanne Maddalena, economist at San Paolo Bank in London.
The mark was trading at almost six-year lows to the dollar on Tuesday above 1.81 marks.
"The key here is that the dollar (appreciation) has still not led to inflationary pressures. There is still no danger for consumer prices either," said David Brickman, economist at Yamaichi International in London.
All 10 economists polled by Reuters expected no change in headline interest rates at Thursday's meeting -- or for the rest of 1997 -- with discount and Lombard rates remaining at 2.5 and 4.5 percent, respectively, until the turn of the year.
Some analysts said the monetary policy status quo would remain in place well beyond that.
"There is a very good chance that the Bundesbank will keep rates on hold even through 1998," said Ros Lifton, economist at HSBC Markets in London.
"The fundamentals signal that there is no need for a change in policy ... The correction of the mark provides a sufficient boost for the economic sectors in Germany and will keep the recovery process on track," she added.
With no change expected for quite some time in the central bank's key interest rates, greater attention will be focused on the repo, or repurchase rate.
Some market participants have been speculating recently that the sharp depreciation in the mark might prompt the central bank to move to a variable rate rather than the fixed 3.0 percent which has been in place since August last year.
But analysts said that this move, too, was unlikely to come for at least another few months.
Hans-Jorg Naumer, economist at Societe Generale in Frankfurt, said a repo move could come in September.
"The repo could see a move in September this year," he said. "The Bundesbank could switch to a variable tender and raise the repo rate to 3.125 percent."
Apart from credit conditions, the other main talking point of this week's meeting -- the last before the council takes a summer break -- will be a review of the M3 money supply indicator which the central bank uses as an early warning signal oninflation.
Central bank council member Ernst Welteke said on Monday that with M3 money supply growth finally within the bank's 3.5 to 6.5 percent target corridor, the review of the indicator would be an easier task.
Annualised M3 money supply growth slowed to 6.4 percent in June from 7.0 percent in May, reaching the target zone for the first time this year.
"It is comforting to see that M3 has reached the target corridor. It means that our discussion about M3 will be easier," he told reporters.
Analysts said Welteke's words, coupled with a string of comments from other key Bundesbank officials in recent months defending M3 as a monetary policy aid, meant that any change in the bank's use of the indicator, or in its 3.5 to 6.5 percent 1997 target zone, was highly unlikely.
-- Frankfurt Newsroom +49 69 7

headline: Italy to offer tax breaks to firms that reinvest.
text:
Italy's industry minister Luigi Bersani on Tuesday said that there would be tax breaks from 1998 to Italian companies that reinvest profits back into their own businesses.
"In 1998, I hope to start to lighten the tax burden for those (companies) that reinvest in their businesses," Bersani said while attending a conference.
-- Milan newsroom +392 66129502

headline: Iberdrola charges ahead on Goldman recommendation.
text:
Shares in Spanish utility Iberdrola gained sharply on Tuesday after news that brokerage Goldman Sachs had upgraded it to "market outperformer" from "market performer", while rival Endesa had been downgraded, dealers said.
The Goldman note underlined the feeling that Iberdrola is a better bet than Endesa at current prices, with the latter having gained strongly ahead of its autumn privatisation, they added.
At 1045 GMT, Iberdrola was up 45 pesetas, or 2.65 percent, to 1,740 pesetas. Meanwhile the Ibex-35 blue chip index rose 1.32 percent to 6,857.54 and Endesa was up 1.18 percent to 12,030 pesetas.
Dealers pegged resistance for Iberdrola between 1,765 and 1,780 pesetas.
"We also think Iberdrola is quite undervalued, and although the (utility) sector will be an underperformer this year and it's difficult to predict, Iberdrola will do roughly 10 percent better than the sector," said a dealer at Ahorro Corporacion Financiera (ACF).
ACF has a target price of 1,920 pesetas/share, he said.
One analyst at a Spanish brokerage said that although the news was good for the stock, he did not consider Ibedrola would far outstrip the market.
-- Elisabeth O'Leary, Madrid newsroom +341 585 2160

headline: Merck U.S. units to combine pharma business.
text:
German pharmaceuticals group Merck KGaA said on Tuesday that two of its U.S. units -- EM Industries in New York and Dey Laboratories in California -- would merge their pharmaceuticals business.
Dey Laboratories would take over responsibility for marketing and distribution from an EM Industries' subsidiary called Center Laboratories.  
At the same time, the allergies treatment business of Center Laboratories will be sold to the U.S. group Heska in Fort Collins, Colorado, Merck said.
Marketing and distribution of existing products would now be carried out by a new independent company called Center Pharmaceuticals Inc, based in Florida.
Merck employes 2,000 people in the U.S. through its subsidiaries EM Industries Inc., Dey Laboratories Inc., Lipha Americas Inc., as well as its holdings in Bracco (Bracco Diagnostics Inc.) and VWR Scientific Products Corporation.
In 1996 sales to customers in North America grew 21.7 percent to 1.02 billion marks, and the group said that its U.S. business would continue to expand.
--Clifford Coonan, Frankfurt Newsroom +49 69 756525

headline: La Poste to create 5,000 jobs for young - Le Monde.
text:
The French Post Office plans to create 5,000 jobs for young people by end June 1998, state secretary for industry Christian Pierret said in a newspaper interview.
"...Besides hiring 3,000 people through contracts and 1,500 civil servants in 1997, La Poste will hire an additional 2,500 young people this year and as many during the first half of 1998..," Pierret told French afternoon daily Le Monde.
These young people will get full-time five-year contracts, he specified. La Poste will use the extra staff to improve customer services.
-- Paris newsroom +331 4221 5432

headline: European feeds sapped by dollar strength.
text:
Europe's physical feed trade offered soymeal a few dollars higher on Tuesday morning, after the close in Chicago but an overnight rise in the U.S. currency sapped any early buying, traders said.
Very nearby positions in Argentine sunmeal were reported to be very tight, based on recent consumer offtake and a lack of shipments. These positions now attracted a premium, pushing up nearby rates to $130 a tonne, against $120 further out.
But there were no trades reported early on.
"With the dollar/mark above 1.80, you can forget it," one trader commented. -- Amsterdam Newsroom +31 20 504 5000

headline: San Paolo warns of Italian banks in crisis.
text:
Italy's largest banking group San Paolo di Torino said some 40 Italian banks are facing a critical situation, and that mergers between Italian banks tend to increase costs rather than reduce them.
In an interview with Milan daily Corriere della Sera on Tuesday, the bank's chairman Giovanni Zandano said that the next few years will be crucial for Italian banks. He added that abroad bank mergers help cut costs but in Italy they can double costs due to a lack of labour flexibility.
"In Italy, labour laws are too rigid. A merger does not rationalise, but can double the structure," he said.
Italy has a very fragmented banking structure with nearly 1,000 difference banking groups, and the nation has also just started to restructure and reform its banking system.
Zandano added that the next two years will be crucial, and Italy must have the courage to eliminate rules on the costs and rigidity of labour. He declined to name the 40 banks he said were in crisis.
-- Milan newsroom +392 66129502

headline: UCB recovers from Friday's drubbing.
text:
Shares in Belgian chemicals and pharmaceuticals firm UCB SA, knocked down nearly 11 percent on Friday, rose more than seven percent on Tuesday.
At 0943 GMT UCB was up 6.8 percent at 141,300 francs after earlier rising by as much as 7.3 percent to 142,000. The market was closed on Monday for a holiday.
Dealers said a combination of foreign buying interest, recent broker upgrades and speculation of a share split contributed to the recovery.
They said the Bel-20 heavyweight could easily home in on its 153,000 franc record set on Thursday but warned its short-term outlook was uncertain and Friday's slide might not be the last one despite some persistent foreign buying interest.
"We're not touching (UCB)...it could soon be at 190,000 francs soon, but just as easily at 100,000," one dealer said.
Another said it might soon start suffering from worries that the Brussels bourse could decide to reduce the weight of UCB in the Bel-20 index.
-- Bert Lauwers, Brussels Newsroom +32 2 287 6815, Fax +32 2 230 7710

headline: Celebrities gather for final farewell to Versace.
text:
International celebrities converged on Milan to pay a final farewell to murdered Italian fashion designer Gianni Versace at a Tuesday evening mass in the northern city's ornate gothic Roman Catholic cathedral.
Princess Diana, former wife of heir to the British throne Prince Charles, pop singers Elton John and Sting, close friend and supermodel Naomi Campbell and opera star Luciano Pavarotti were among those expected to be present.
Italian media said Diana would attend the mass which was scheduled to begin at 6 p.m (1600 GMT). A spokewoman for Diana's office in London declined confirmation but told Reuters: "The princess is aware of the arrangements for the memorial service. If she does attend, it will be in a private capacity."
The princess, among the world's most photgraphed women, was snapped in Versace designs and often spoke of her friendship for the designer, who was shot dead outside his mansion in Miami Beach, Florida, last week.
Versace, who was 50 when he died, had returned the compliment by naming a handbag -- the Lady Di -- after her.
During his flourishing career, he dressed the rich and famous from U.S. singer Madonna to Princess Caroline of Monaco in his raunchy signature style.
Fashion industry sources and newspapers said there would be a chance for friends to pay their respects privately at the Versace headquarters in Milan's exclusive Via Montenapoleone design district in the hours before the mass.
Police stood guard and barriers were up outside the entrance to the palazzo but the street was quiet.
Versace was cremated in Miami and his ashes were placed in a temporary tomb in a cemetery on the edge of Lake Como in a simple family ceremony last week.
The ashes, in an ornate gold casket, have been placed under close guard. The family is reported to fear vandalism after their mother's tomb in southern Italy was tampered with 10 years ago.
But eyewitnesses on Monday said a police escort appeared to have removed the casket from the cemetery, which is close to Versace's secluded 18th century villa on the Como lakefront.
A fashion industry source said she understood the designer's ashes would be at the Milan headquarters before the mass but this could not be confirmed and a Versace spokeswoman said any arrangements of that nature were private.
Tributes, meanwhile, continued to pour in from around the world for the designer, who vied with fellow Italian Giorgio Armani for the top spot in Italian chic.
Versace's brother, Santo, the business brain behind the Versace empire, and his sister, Donatella, a talented designer in her own right, have vowed to carry on where their brother left off.
The Italian press quoted designer Karl Lagerfeld as saying he was ready to design for the fashion house, which Versace built into a multi-million dollar empire after launching his first own-name collection at the age of 31.
But a spokeswoman for Lagerfeld in Paris denied the reports.
British supermodel Campbell, a close friend of the dead designer, was expected to fly in from South Africa for Tuesday's cathedral service.
Campbell, who always sashayed along the Milan catwalk for Versace's ready-to-wear collections, broke down in tears on television when talking about the designer.
"I'm still in shock, I still can't believe what's happened," she said.

headline: Beet sugar content at 17.24 pct in southern Spain.
text:
The average sugar content of beet in southern Spain tested at 17.24 percent at the factory gate on July 20, slightly higher than last year but within a normal range, the National Sugar Beet association told Reuters on Tuesday.
A test on July 13 showed sugar content at 17.33 percent.
The southern crop, which represents about a third of Spain's total beet harvest, draws to a close early next month.
Field tests on the northern harvest are available as of mid-September, a spokesman for the association said.
--Madrid Newsroom +34 1 585 2167

headline: German Allianz braced for big flood claims.
text:
Allianz AG, Germany's largest insurer and market leader in the flood-hit eastern region, said on Tuesday it expected significant claims to result from water damage to homes and businesses there.
Allianz acquired some 3.4 million home insurance policies and a further 1.1 million building policies when it took over the state insurer for the former Communist-controlled region in 1990. Most of the policies cover flood damage.
"We expect considerable costs. But the full damage can only be appraised when the water level has fallen back," a spokesman for the Munich-based company said in response to enquiries.
He added that the damage caused by flooding around the River Oder, which marks the German-Polish border, had already affected hundreds of homes on the German side.
"But we shall also have to see if there will be a second wave which could indeed be greater than the first. We hope this won't happen," the spokesman said.
While the old east German policies generally offer flood damage protection as standard, new policies signed since 1990 only include this as an extra.
The floods swept through central Europe last week claiming scores of lives. The fact that their arrival in Germany was widely forecast means however that the extent of individual damage claims should be limited.
Allianz had said earlier in a statement that motor insurance policies would only cover damage to vehicles if it was clear that a customer had not acted negligently by, for example, parking in a possible flood zone.
Equally, it is hoping that householders have acted to move any valuables out of cellars and ground floors up to higher storeys while the flood danger remains.
On Monday, reinsurance group Munich Re said it expected to face claims of between 20-60 million marks as a result of the floods.
--Frankfurt Newsroom +49 69 756525

headline: POLL - Bank of Spain seen holding rates on Wednesday.
text:
The Bank of Spain will leave its key money rate unchanged at 5.25 percent at Wednesday's repurchase auction, according to a Reuters poll.
All ten analysts polled said on Tuesday the Spanish central bank would hold its monetary policy steady, at least until the third quarter.
By then, more about 1998 fiscal policy and entrance levels for European currencies into the single euro currency could prompt the Bank of Spain to shave another 25 basis points off its key rate.
Recent indications suggesting gross domestic product growth is running well above the European trend at three percent and expectations inflation is picking up support views for steady policy.
But a stronger peseta, pulled higher against the mark by a buyoant U.S. dollar, could eventually provoke a rate cut, some analysts said.
"After the Bank of Spain's recent interventions in the forex market, we can't rule out a money market rate cut. I'll give a 30 percent possibility to such a move," said Alfredo Urrutia, chief economist at Societe Generale in Madrid.
Since December 1995, the Bank of Spain has cut its key money market rate 12 times from 9.25 percent to 5.25 percent.

headline: Danyard says Stolt ship orders risk delay.
text:
Danish shipping and shipbuilding group J.Lauritzen's Danyard unit said on Tuesday there could be delays in further chemical tanker orders from Norwegian-U.S Stolt Parcel Tankers beyond the present seven vessel order and warned of a possible production stop.
"With our new efficiency drive allowing us to deliver ships within a period of between three to three and a half months, we should be ready this October to cut the first steel for a further ship for Stolt," Danyard managing director Torben Mejnertsen told Reuters.
"But we will probably not manage to complete negotiations on any new orders with them before then, meaning that a production stop may be necessary," he said.
Mejnertsen said the board of Stolt had given the go-ahead for its tankers unit to order two more chemical tankers of the type Danyard were producing for them, but added that the Norwegian-U.S. shipper was looking elsewhere at other offers.
The last of seven chemical tankers for Stolt is due to be completed this summer by Danyard, which has in recent years suffered heavy losses due to stiff competition, adverse currency movements and productivity problems.
Lauritzen said in April that it allocated Danyard extraordinary loss provisions of 400 million crowns in 1996 but expected the yard to return negative operating results this year and next year.
Mejnertsen said also that delays in the sale of a 48 percent stake in Danyard to Malaysia's Penang Shipbuilding Construction (PSC) announced in April were also complicating negotiations with Stolt on new orders.
--Stig Pedersen, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33969659

headline: Austria sees 98, 99 fed budget deficit 2.6 pct GDP.
text:
Austria's budget deficit for 1998 and 1999 is expected to be 2.6 percent of gross domestic product (GDP), compared with 2.7 percent this year, a finance ministry spokesman said on Tuesday.
The budget deficit, estimated at 67.3 billion schillings in 1998 and 70.1 billion schillings in 1999, would be well in line with Maastricht criteria for the starting group of European economic and monetary union (EMU) in 1999.

headline: Saga says Snorre oil restart unknown.
text:
Oil production at the North Sea Snorre oilfield would remain shut in on Tuesday, operator Saga Petroleum ASA said.
"There will be no production today and it is too early to say when it might start," he said.
The company had hoped to restore output at the 200,000 barrel-per-day field as soon as the platform's power supply had been restored following a black out due to a short circuit on Sunday.
"The main power supply is okay now, but the auxilliary supply is not working properly," a spokesman for Saga said.
Safety regulations require that both systems function before oil production can resume.
The spokesman said the systems were being examined and tested.
--Tanya pang, Oslo newsroom, +47 22 42 50 41

headline: Waigel - financial globalisation weighs on mark.
text:
German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said on Tuesday the mark's role as a reserve currency meant it was more affected by financial globalisation than other currencies.
According to a text of a speech due to be delivered today, Waigel also said that in the past uncertainty in financial markets has led to flight into the mark.  
Waigel-financial globalisation weighs on mark
Basically globalisation was certainly welcome because it improved capital allocation, Waigel said.
"Germany was affected overproportionally by financial golobalisation because of the mark's worldwide role as a second reserve currency."
He said in the past "every uncertainty on the financial markets led to a flight into the deutschemark. Erratic increases in value were the result."
Waigel made no direct comment on the current weakness on foreign exchange markets of the deutschemark, which fell on Tuesday below 1.81 to the U.S., the lowest since summer 1991.
He did say, however, that European monetary union (EMU) offered great potential for the German economy.
"A more stable European currency could become an alternative to the U.S. dollar in the world currency system," Waigel said. "As an export nation Germany would profit from a stable European bloc."
This would lead to lowering of capital market rates, Waigel said. It also increased price transparency and reduced exchange rate risks.
-- Bonn Newsroom, +49-228 26097150

headline: Petzetakis sets up subsidiary in UK.
text:
Greek company Petzetakis, which makes plastic pipes, said it set up Heliflex Ltd in the UK in May 1997 to expand into a market from which it has been absent for five years.
Petzetakis said its absence was caused by its lack of higher-technology hoses and the failure to set up a distribution network.
Heliflex Ltd will be run by Ian Marshall who was previously employed by the UK's leading hose company Eurohose of the Interplas Group, Petzetakis said.
Petzetakis said its group sales in the first five months of 1997 rose 25 percent from the year before and management expects turnover growth to remain high throughout 1997 and 1998. --Angelos Kiosklis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

headline: Petrogal, Gas de Portugal study natural gas merger.
text:
Portuguese state oil firm Petrogal and gas company Gas de Portugal (GDP) are studying forming a natural gas company, a Petrogal spokesman said.
"Petrogas, a 100 percent owned unit of Petrogal, and GDP are studying the possibility of joining forces in the natural gas business," Antonio Mocho told Reuters.
He said GDP was considering taking a 60 percent or 80 percent stake and Petrogas the remainder.
"GDP would have a majority stake. No time-scale has been set. Nothing definitive has been agreed yet," Mocho said.
He was commenting on a report in Diario de Noticias newspaper on Tuesday that Petrogal and GDP had decided to form a new company called Gaspor, encompassing their natural gas activities.
-- David Brough, Lisbon newsroom +351-1-3538254

headline: Minister to re-examine La Poste-AGF plans - Le Monde.
text:
French secretary of state for industry Christian Pierret said on Tuesday that he would re-examine plans by the French post office and insurer AGF to allow La Poste to distribute non-life insurance products.
The deal was "maybe announced a little quickly and must be re-examined in discussions with all parties," Pierret told French daily Le Monde.  
In early June La Poste said it was holding talks with a number of potential partners including AGF to distribute non-life insurance products. La Poste already sells life insurance products through state-owned Caisse Nationale de Prevoyance.
Pierret told Le Monde that the government might seek bids from interested companies but it would take decision by the end of the year.
-- Paris newsroom +331 4221 5432

headline: Greek credit expansion falls to 8.4 pct y/y in May.
text:
Greece's total credit expansion slowed to 8.4 percent year-on-year in May from 9.3 percent in April but fell outside the central bank's 4.0-6.0 percent target zone for 1997, the Bank of Greece said.
Total credit expansion grew 5.8 percent year-on-year in December 1996.
Credit growth to the public sector fell to 4.4 percent year-on-year in May from 5.8 percent in April and credit to the private sector was 16.4 percent, marginally down from 16.5 percent in April, it said in its July Bulletin of Conjunctural Indicators. The central bank monitors developments in total credit expansion and has set an annual target range that is consistent with the final goal of monetary policy to bring inflation down to 4.5 percent at end-1997 and below 3.0 percent by end-1998. --Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

headline: BES shares firm after H1 profit surge.
text:
Shares in Portuguese bank Banco Espirito Santo reacted positively to the 43 percent increase in consolidated first half profit, but the share was not expected to exceed the day's high of 4,500 escudos, dealers said.
"The results were very good, and slightly above expectations, but I doubt that the they will climb above 4,500 escudos, at least for now," said one operator.
BES shares hit a high of 4,500 escudos after the opening, and later eased back to 4,450 escudos, up 35, in volume of 321,557 at 1003 GMT.

headline: SPD calls for cut in German EU budget payments.
text:
Germany's opposition Social Democrats (SPD) on Tuesday backed government calls to cut Bonn's net contributions to the European Union (EU) budget and said Britain's EU budget rebate should be scrapped.
SPD finance spokeswoman Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier told the Express newspaper that Germany's budget payments should be cut by five billion marks ($2.8 billion) a year to reflect the fall in average living standards that followed unification in 1990.
"The government must insist that German net payments are cut," Matthaeus-Maier said, adding that lower payments should take effect "by 1999 at the latest."
She also called for further EU farm policy reforms and said the EU budget rebate won by former British prime minister Margaret Thatcher should be scrapped.
"We cannot accept any more that the British pay less every year than they should," she told the newspaper.
Before unification, Germany was the second wealthiest country in the EU. Now, taking into account the poorer east, it ranks only in mid-table.
That means net German contributions of 22 billion marks in each 1995 and 1996 are too high, Matthaeus-Maier said.
Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel last weekend argued for a cut in German payments, saying it could not be right that Germany paid over half of net contributions to Brussels when its economic output made up only a quarter of the EU total. ($ = 1.804 German Marks)

headline: Swiss 3-month money market claims yield 1.302 pct.
text:
The annual yield on the latest issue of Swiss federal government three-month money market claims is 1.302 percent, up from the previous issue's 1.210 percent, the Swiss National Bank said.
The latest issue, to be paid for on July 24, raised 1,001.6 million Swiss francs and was priced at 99.672 percent.
The previous issue, paid for on July 17, raised 791.90 million and was priced at 99.695 percent.

headline: Germany will hit strict EMU deficit target - Waigel.
text:
German Finance Minister Theo Waigel on Tuesday reiterated that Bonn would hit the strict budget deficit target required this year for entry to Europe's single currency.
According to the text of a speech he was due to give here, Waigel also said European economic and monetary union (EMU) could only go ahead with countries which have achieved a similar degree of monetary stability.  
Waigel said Germany would hold to its goal of hitting the Maastricht treaty budget deficit target of three percent of gross domestic product exactly this year.
"Based on current estimates, the total public sector deficit based on the national accounts will not exceed the limit of 3.0 percent (of GDP)," Waigel said.
Only countries with a strong stability record should join EMU. "A chain is only as strong as its weakest link," he said.
He added that convergence should dictate the timetable for all EMU candidates, and the best measure was the sustainable fulfilment of the Maastricht criteria.
Waigel also said that a strict and narrow interpretation of the Maastricht treaty was indispensable for the German government, and was expected both by financial markets and the German public.

headline: Dassault Systemes rises on H1 results.
text:
Shares in Dassault Systemes rose strongly on the Paris Bourse on Tuesday after the publication of its first half results.
At 0939 GMT, Dassault Systemes was up 5.33 percent at 415 francs as the 60 percent increase in second quarter earnings per share was better than expected.

headline: RESEARCH ALERT-CSFB upgrades Allianz to buy.
text:
Credit Suisse -First Boston said on Tuesday it has raised its rating on German insurance group Allianz AG to buy from market performer and set a target price for Allianz shares at 560 marks.
Allianz shares were up 26.50 marks at 446 marks in bourse dealings. The 30-share DAX index was up 98.75 marks at 4,207.15 points.
--Frankfurt Newsroom, +49 69 75625

headline: Eureko says candidate to take over GAN.
text:
Eureko, an alliance of six European financial services companies, said on Tuesday it was a candidate to take over ailing French state-controlled insurer GAN which the government plans to privatise.
"Eureko's ambition is to pursue its development strategy in taking a strong position in the French market, one of the most important in Europe," Eureko said in a statement.
"In this light, Eureko has proposed to government authorities and to GAN management a solution which would allow the French insurance company to remain intact and to develop its national and international position."  
Eureko, Europe's seventh largest insurance group, is made up of Dutch Achmea, BCP/Atlantico of Portugal, British Provident, German Gothaer, Danish Topdanmark and Wasa of Sweden.
"Eureko is proposing a solution under which it would take over all of GAN and no more than 25 percent of CIC," said a Eureko spokeswoman. CIC is GAN's profitable banking arm.
The spokeswoman said that the amount of the offer would depend on the conditions the government imposes on the sale.
"We cannot say right away (how much Eureko will offer)," she said.
Eureko had decided to seek to acquire GAN "because they complement each other geographically and have complementary activities," she said.  
Rowing back on its earlier anti-privatisation stand, the new leftist government said on Friday it would not block the sale planned by the previous conservative government of GAN and CIC.
AGF, Allianz AG of Germany, Fortis AG SA, Assicurazioni Generali SpA of Italy and ING Groep have either expressed interest in acquiring GAN or are likely candidates, GAN chairman Didier Pfieffer has said.
GAN, which is 76-percent state owned, lost 5.7 billion francs last year because of bad real estate investments and the conservatives in February had to come up with a 20 billion franc bailout plan.
That plan must still be approved by the European Commission, and France promised to privatise both GAN and CIC to win that approval.
The conservative government had to cancel the sale of CIC last year because of a shortage of bids considered suitable.
-- Paris Newsroom +33 1 4221 5452 pmc

headline: Coke drops India commercial after boy dies.
text:
Coca-Cola India, a fully-owned unit of Coca-Cola Co, said on Tuesday that it had withdrawn a television commercial featuring bungee jumping after a 10 year-old child died in Calcutta when aping the commercial.
In a statement, the company said: "We are deeply saddened by the untimely death. We have immediately withdrawn the airing of the commercial. We reiterate that the advertisement was an illustration of an adventure sport".
The commercial, made by the Indian affiliate of U.S. advertising agency Leo Burnett, featured a model bungee jumping off a cliff to grab a bottle of Thums Up, a local cola brand owned by Coca-Cola, off a delivery truck at the base of the cliff.
This is the second death of a minor trying to ape the commercial. A child died in Bombay in April 1996, when he jumped off a 10-storey building trying to reach a beverage truck at the bottom of the structure.
"Following the child's death, all subsequent airing of the commercial was preceded by a written and spoken warning not to imitate what was shown in the film," Jimmy Mogal, senior manager, external and corporate affairs, Coca-Cola India, told Reuters.
He said the commercial had been airing on both satellite and terrestrial channels since March 1996, and played before programmes with high audience ratings.
Mogal said the withdrawn commercial was the second to feature bungee jumping. He added the target audience for all of Coca-Cola India's advertising was from the early teens to the late twenties.
-- Sanjit Singh, New Delhi newsroom +91 11 301 2024

headline: Bristol-Myers, Schering-Plough earnings surge in quarter.
text:
Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Schering-Plough Corp. Tuesday reported sharply higher second-quarter earnings, boosted by surging worldwide demand for their pharmaceutical products.
"Our strong growth continued in the second quarter, with pharmaceutical, consumer medicines and beauty care sales volume increasing at robust double digit rates," said Charles Heimbold, Jr., chairman of Bristol-Myers.
Bristol-Myers said its profits rose 13 percent, matching Wall Street expectations, to a record $738 million, or 74 cents a share, from $655 million, or 65 cents a share, in the year-ago period.
Sales grew 10 percent to an all-time high of $4.1 billion from $3.7 billion. Domestic sales increased 15 percent, while international sales rose 4 percent.
Excluding foreign exchange effects, pharmaceutical sales jumped 18 percent over the same period of 1996. Domestic pharmaceutical sales soared 26 percent and international sales grew 9 percent, Bristol-Myers said.
Sales of Pravachol, the company's largest selling product, increased 21 percent to $307 million, with growing evidence of the product's benefits in lowering cholesterol, it said.
Sales of Taxol, Bristol-Myers' leading anti-cancer agent, rose 13 percent to $225 million.
Among other products, sales of Glucophage, an oral medication for treatment of non-insulin dependent diabetes, grew 93 percent to $145 million, while the anti-cancer agent Paraplatin rose 14 percent to $105 million.
Beauty care sales increased 18 percent excluding the effect of foreign exchange in the second quarter. Sales of the New York-based company's hair care products jumped 25 percent, led by the Herbal Essences and Infusium 23 brands.
Nutritional sales in the second quarter edged up 2 percent, excluding the effect of foreign exchange, while medical device sales fell 4 percent, it said.
At Schering-Plough, earnings rose 18 percent to $373.1 million, or 51 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30. In the year-ago period, the Madison, N.J.-based company had profits of $317.1 million, or 43 cents per share, adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split on June 3, 1997.
Sales jumped 16 percent to $1.7 billion from $1.5 billion, but were lowered by 3 percent due to the dollar's appreciation.
"Schering-Plough's solid second-quarter performance was again led by our worldwide pharmaceuticals business," said Richard Jay Kogan, president. "The company continues to perform well, with all major business components recording higher sales versus the same period a year ago."
Growing sales of prescription drugs were led by the Claritin line of nonsedating antihistamines and Intron A, an antiviral/anticancer agent, Schering-Plough said.
Second-quarter worldwide sales of the Claritin line, the antihistamine, surged 54 percent to $535.7 million. Sales of Intron A rose 15 percent to $144.0 million.
U.S. sales of prescription pharmaceuticals rose 29 percent in the second quarter.
International ethical pharmaceutical sales rose 12 percent, excluding foreign exchange effects.
Second-quarter sales of the company's worldwide animal health business edged up 2 percent, or 5 percent excluding foreign exchange effects.
Sales for Schering-Plough HealthCare Products grew 6 percent in the second quarter, largely due to the addition of Dynastep Inserts to the Dr. Scholl's foot care line, it said.
Bristol-Myers' stock fell $1.94 to $82.25, while Schering-Plough rose $1.125 to $49.875 on the New York Stock Exchange in late morning trading.

headline: FRANCE SEEKS TO SOOTHE ARAB ANGER AFTER X-FILM.
text:
France said on Tuesday that the broadcasting by a French channel of a hard-core pornographic film around the Arab world instead of a children's programme was "unacceptable" and the result of a technical error.
The state-funded Canal France International (CFI) has apologised for the mistake, which resulted in all its programmes being yanked off the air by the Arabsat satellite consortium after the broadcast at prime time on Saturday afternoon.
"We deeply regret this unacceptable incident and we share in the high feelings prompted in Saudi Arabia and more widely in the Arab world," foreign ministry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt told a daily press briefing.
CFI "took no part in the broadcasting of such a programme. It was an unacceptable incident which resulted from a technical error", he said.
CFI said the mistake took place at the France Telecom state communications agency which feeds French television programmes to satellites across the world -- among them Arabsat, which broadcasts throughout Arab countries.
Instead of sending a scheduled feature for children, France Telecom sent the pornographic film from a private French station destined for clients in the Pacific.
France Telecom confirmed the incident and said an investigation was under way.
Officials said French diplomats in Saudi Arabia had tried to smooth over what could be a disaster for France's efforts to reach audiences in the Arab world, where most Western programmes are American-made.
CFI said that in 1995 its programmes went to a potential audience of more than 33 million people in and around the Middle East.

headline: ANALYSTS' COMMENTS ON POLYGRAM H1 PROFITS.
text:
Dutch music and entertainment group PolyGram on Tuesday reported first half net profits of 270 million guilders, against 272 million guilders in the first half of 1996. The company did not give a forecast for the full year.
Below is a selection of analysts' comments:
PETER WORTEL, DELTA LLOYD BANK:
"There's nothing that wasn't expected. They had some good artists in the first half and some albums, notably U2's, sold really well. On the film side, it's a bit disappointing. It's loss-making and will remain so for the time being. In the second half there are some good names, but were knew about them already. The prospects are good, but not spectacular."  
THIJS BERKELDER, HSBC VAN MEER JAMES CAPEL
"The results were right on target for most analysts. Nothing was surprisingly higher or lower. Music had maybe somewhat lower profit and film had a slightly lower loss (than expected). For the second half, you have to look at the new releases and they have quite a number and they can benefit from new films. 'Bean' for instance is already introduced and looks promising. Looking at the release schedule, you must remain relatively positive for the second half."    
ANDRE MOONS, ING BARINGS
"My first reaction is that again it's a stable result, which particularly in a stock market climate like this...is not so inspiring. When you look at the results breakdown, film is a lot lower -- as expected -- and while music did a lot better after correction for currencies and so forth it's not that impressive. Polygram gave no firm forecasts for 1997, although their release schedule for the second half contains some strong acts like Boyz II Men, Shania Twain...and Jackie Cheung. Even so, that's rather an unsteady base on which to project major earnings growth. Film is expected to perform better (in the second half).
We have the stock on a Hold recommendation and based on currency strength we expect to maintain this."
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040

headline: POLYGRAM H1 NET FALLS, SALES RISE.
text:
Music and entertainment group PolyGram NV said on Tuesday first half 1997 net profit slipped slightly, with music performing strongly but again offset by losses from its young film business.
Net profit in the first six months of 1997 slipped to 270 million guilders from 272 million, returning to the level reported for the first half of 1995.
Analysts had been anticipating a net profit of as much as 286 million guilders, based on strong music sales from artists such as U2 and Hanson, with consensus seen at 276 million.
"Compared with a strong first half of 1996, PolyGram's 1997 performance in film has been relatively weak to date," PolyGram chief executive Alain Levy said in a statement with results.
"As a result, income from operations was 430 million guilders for the first half of 1997, an increase of two percent over last year," he added.
First half group sales climbed five percent to 4.53 billion guilders with music generating sales of 3.94 billion. Operating profit at music rose to 522 million guilders from 457 during the half. Veteran Irish rockers U2 sold over five million albums, while teenage newcomers Hanson sold three million.
The film division saw first half turnover dip to 589 million guilders from 681 million with operating losses widening to 92 million from 37 million. Film's second quarter operating loss was 37 million guilders compared to 55 million in the first quarter and 18 million in the second quarter of 1996.
PolyGram said the results of its filmed entertainment business reflected the division's lighter release schedule during the first six months of 1997, adding the division saw its strongest releases in the second half.
Film during the first half of 1996 benefited from the success of "Dead Man Walking", "Fargo", and "Mr Holland's Opus".
At the first quarter stage in April PolyGram said underperformance of previously released films "Portrait of a Lady" and "Gridlock'd" had hit its earnings.
PolyGram shares were up 5.10 guilders to 106.10 on a sharply higher Amsterdam bourse, roughly doubling gains posted ahead of the results.
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040

headline: EU clears Nintendo licensing deals.
text:
The European Commission said on Tuesday it had cleared new licensing agreements that video-game company Nintendo awards to firms that develop games that are compatible with its consoles.
The European Union executive said the agreements were compatible with EU competition law.
-- Brussels newsroom +32 2 287 68 11

headline: BREAKTHROUGH ARTISTS BOOST POLYGRAM MUSIC IN H1.
text:
Fresh-faced teen pop trio Hanson joined forces with veteran Irish rockers U2 to help boost first half music sales and profits at PolyGram NV , the Dutch company said in a statement on Tuesday.
Group first half net profit slipped to 270 million guilders from 272 million a year earlier, with a strong music performance hit by increased operating losses from its film business.
"Despite challenging conditions in some of our markets, PolyGram's expertise in breaking new acts and promoting established artists is reflected in the first half results," PolyGram chief executive Alain Levy said in the statement.    
Sales at the music division rose to 3.94 billion guilders in the first half from 3.63 billion, with operating profit up to 522 million from 457 million.
Within the division pop sales increased by 10 percent to 2.99 billion, or 66 percent of first half sales.
The best selling album in the first half was "Pop" from U2, with over five million copies sold, while breakthrough act Hanson sold three million copies of their album "Middle of Nowhere", during the second quarter. Two albums from Italian singer Andrea Bocelli collectively sold 4.2 million copies over the first half.
In total nine albums sold over one million copies in the first half, compared to 15 in the first six months of 1996 when PolyGram released a bigger number of superstar albums.
Total unit sales for the top five albums in the first half of 1997 was 15 million compared to 13 million for the comparable period in 1996.
The company, 75-percent owned by Philips Electronics NV , said it had a strong second half music release schedule with albums from Bjork, Boyz II Men, Elton John, Metallica and LL Cool J.
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040

headline: German TV host Gottschalk signs with Disney.
text:
Germany's top television talk show host Thomas Gottschalk has signed an exclusive global contract with U.S. entertainment giant Walt Disney Co , sister firm Buena Vista Productions International said on Tuesday.
A Buena Vista spokeswoman said the deal would start on January 1, 1998 and said the firm hoped to develop joint ideas with Gottschalk for the German and possibly the U.S. television markets.
Private German channel Sat.1, where Gottschalk currently hosts his Haus-Party (House Party) chat show, said it was interested in negotiating with Buena Vista over the programme, but it did not think the deal meant they would lose the show.
A Sat.1 spokeswoman said a decision would be reached in the next few weeks as to who would win rights to the show, which attracts up to five million viewers.
Sat 1. also said the new deal did not affect Gottschalk's presentation of their "Kulmbacher Filmnaechte" (Kulmbacher Film Nights).
Buena Vista said the host would also be able to continue to present his "Wetten, dass... ?" (Wanna Bet?) game show with public channel ZDF.

headline: DE BEERS TO BUILD ANGOLA GEM SORTING UNIT.
text:
De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd said on Tuesday it had signed an agreement to develop a 12-storey building in central Luanda to house a purpose-built and secure diamond sorting facility for Angolan diamonds.
The building will be constructed on land leased from national diamond company Endiama, which will own three floors of the new building.    
The building, similar to sorting centres which De Beers has constructed in Botswana, Namibia and South Africa, will cost approximately $30 million to develop and equip.
George Burne, company director responsible for Angola, said the deal underlined De Beers' commitment to investing in Angola. The country produces an estimated two million carats of diamonds each year.
Endiama and the South African company have previously signed agreements covering prospecting in three different areas of Angola, the marketing of gems from the principal Cuango basin producing area and the operation of diamond buying offices.
-- Johannesburg newsroom +27 11 482 1003

headline: Zimbabwe war veterans block road to Africa summit.
text:
Zimbabwean war veterans blocked the main entrance to an African-American business summit on Tuesday in a pay protest, calling for action by President Robert Mugabe's government.
About 300 former guerrillas sat around the gate into the grounds of the Harare International Conference Centre where African leaders, including Mugabe, were to meet U.S. business executives to try to win trade, investment and economic aid for the world's poorest continent.  
About 150 protesters broke through a riot police cordon at the gates outside the conference centre, pushing their way through to the main entrance of the building.
As the veterans moved to the glass doors, most of the U.S. delegates rushed through the doors in fear of being trapped outside.
The independence war fighters, some crippled and on crutches, sang and held placards calling on Mugabe to address them. "Mugabe our patron please meet us," read one of the placards. "We will not leave until he comes," they shouted, but made no attempt to stop delegates using a side entance to the conference centre.
Armed police kept a low profile and directed traffic to the side entrance. Various workshops that will run alongside the four-day summit started on time.

headline: S.AFRICA'S MOLOPE BUYS FOODS GROUP FOR 70 MLN RAND.
text:
South Africa's Molope Foods Ltd, which is to list on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE) later this year, said on Tuesday it had acquired Grantham Integrated Food Services Group for 70 million rand from July 1.
Black-owned Molope also announced that it had changed its name from Molope Bakeries with immediate effect.
"Molope Foods has today acquired all the businesses of the Grantham Integrated Foods Group with effect from July 1," managing director Sam Molope told reporters.
The Grantham business was started in 1978 and has grown to employ over 1,000 employees.
The purchase price would be settled through the issue of between 17.5 and 23.5 million Molope "N" shares to the Grantham vendors. The exact number of shares to be issued would be announced around August 11.
As a result of the acquisition Molope said its after-tax profit for the year ended June 30, 1998 was expected to exceed 30 million rand. This translates to earnings per share of between 20 and 22 cents.
Molope said it was ready to make its stock exchange debut but still had to decide on the timing of the listing. It would, however, be before the end of the year.
The group was also looking to make other acquisitions in the food sector, which would provide synergies with its existing businesses.
-- Charles Phahlane, Johannesburg newsroom +27 11 482 1003

headline: FOCUS-Indonesia markets recover but volatile.
text:
The Indonesian rupiah recovered partially on Tuesday from a speculative attack that drove it to a historic low, but dealers and brokers said it remained volatile.
They said the foreign exchange market had not stabilised yet, although the local currency had partially recovered from Monday's steep plunge to an all-time low of 2,665 against the dollar.
The rupiah bounced back to 2,573/83 to the dollar at 1000 GMT from an opening of 2,633/43 after renewed central bank intervention on Tuesday afternoon.
The stock market also found support, with the composite index gaining 0.04 percent in mid-afternoon. It later eased back to 711.44 points, down 0.13 percent at the close on late profit-taking.
The index fell 1.6 percent to 712.40 points on Monday as rupiah panic spilled over to the stock market.
"It's a volatile day. In general the market has not stabilised yet, but it's better than Monday," a currency dealer in Singapore said. The dealer added that there were already customers looking to short the U.S. currency at the 2,600 rupiah level.
The rupiah made the largest single-day loss on Monday by plummeting almost five percent to 2,665 against the dollar before recovering slightly to 2,640 at the close.
The plunge was larger than when the market was hit by nervousness in July last year over the health of President Suharto and riots in Jakarta.
However, the rupiah recovered with ease on both those occasions, reflecting offshore confidence in Indonesia. But the confidence was shaken in recent weeks after speculative attacks on regional currencies forced devaluations in the Thai baht and the Philippine peso.
Economists said the attack on the rupiah had nothing to do with economic fundamentals and represented a contagion effect.
"This wave of contagion hitting the regional currencies will be a relatively long-running affair. The danger is that this is a temporary calm we're seeing," said Desmond Supple, head of Asian currency research at BZW Asia.
Supple said a meeting of Asian central bankers in Shanghai later in the week could yield strong verbal support for the region's currencies, but he added that he did not expect it to result in coordinated intervention.
Currency dealers said there was a lot of profit-taking in dollars at the opening, pushing the dollar down to the 2,600 level. It tumbled to a low of 2,570 after the central bank intervened, which triggered stop-loss selling in dollars.
"The market was looking for signals and directions from the central bank. The bank intervention gave a very good signal in the market and it took the signal by selling dollars down," Edwin Png, country treasurer of Bank of America, told Reuters.
Short-covering helped the dollar recover, but it was still below the psychologically important level of 2,600.
"The market is quite reluctant to buy (the dollar) up too high. Anything above the 2,600 level, I think the market is willing to go short again," Png said.
Finance Minister Mar'ie Muhammad said on Tuesday the government had no plans to alter monetary policy in the wake of the speculative attack on the rupiah.
Mar'ie said he was confident the market would improve on the back of the country's sound economic fundamentals.
He said turmoil in the currency market was speculative and it could not continue for long because speculation implied a hit-and-run strategy.

headline: Indonesian growth seen slowing on rupiah crisis.
text:
The fall in the value of Indonesia's rupiah may slow economic growth as interest rates will have to remain high to counter a likely rise in inflation, economists said on Tuesday.
They also said the country's debt burden, estimated at around $110 billion, could increase if the rupiah remained weak, although parts of the export sector could benefit from more competitive prices.
The rupiah on Monday came under fierce speculative attack which beat it down about five percent to a historic low of 2,665 against the dollar before central bank intervention brought about a marginal recovery.
On Tuesday, the currency was volatile but had strengthened to about 2,585 against the dollar in the late afternoon.
Nevertheless, the rate was sharply down from the 2,430 level that prevailed two weeks ago.
"Curbing inflation in the last eight to nine months has been very helpful in the central bank lowering interest rates," said a Singapore-based regional economist.
"Now with inflation likely to pick up (after the currency depreciation), this is put into question."
Alex Erskine, regional market strategist with Citibank Corp in Singapore, agreed.
"Interest rates are up just now, which will take the edge off growth," he told Reuters Financial Television. "That is a challenge to the longer term."
"I think we are beginning to see a weaker rupiah," Erskine added. "Corporates next week will try to cover some of their foreign exchange exposures, so I think more weakness lies ahead."
Finance Minister Mar'ie Muhammad  told reporters on Tuesday that monetary policies would not be altered in the wake of the speculative attack on the rupiah.
But economists said continued weakness in the local currency and resulting inflationary pressures could force authorities to revisit their policy of allowing interest rates to decline.
The I.D.E.A. consultancy said a weaker rupiah could add to the foreign debt burden.
"Local corporates and institutions with unhedged exposure would suffer by way of higher debt servicing costs," it said in a report.
"A sustained weakened rupiah will also threaten to derail the government's plans to prepay debt," the consultancy added.
However, Asian Development Bank president Mitsuo Sato said during a visit to Jakarta that the country's debt levels were not a matter of concern.
"Let me again stress at this moment I don't have any concern about the level of (Indonesia's) foreign debt," he told reporters after a meeting with President Suharto on Tuesday.
I.D.E.A. said the rupiah depreciation could help boost lower value-added exports, although higher value-added goods would suffer from increased costs due to higher import content.
"It (the depreciation) is going to make Indonesian exporters more competitive vis-a-vis other exporters," said the regional economist.
"But bear in mind that a lot of regional currencies have also weakened and these are also competitiors. So the overall trade picture is hazy," I.D.E.A. said.
"But certainly vis-a-vis the major industrialised countries, Indonesian exports to Europe and the United States will be cheaper. On a net basis, I would say it would help the export sector."

headline: SAUDI HALTS BEEF IMPORTS FROM BELGIUM.
text:
Saudi Arabia imposed a ban on beef and beef-related products imported from or through Belgium, the official Saudi Press Agency (SPA) reported on Monday.
It said the move followed evidence that some Belgian companies were exporting banned British beef to the kingdom under false Belgian certificates of origin.
"The ban includes all beef and related products," SPA quoted an official at the Saudi Ministry of Trade as saying.
Saudi Arabia, where meat is a major staple for its 18 million population, imposed a ban on British beef in 1996 after scares that mad cow disease could affect humans.

headline: TABLE -- GREEK ECONOMIC INDICATORS -- JULY 22.
FOCUS - DSM UNVEILS BILLION-GUILDER TAKEOVER.
text:
Dutch chemicals group DSM on Tuesday unveiled a billion-guilder acquisition to boost its position as a leading European polyolefins producer in the new millennium.
The acquisition and expansion of Vestolen GmbH's polyolefin activities at Gelsenkirchen, Germany, will involve an investment of one billion guilders spread over several years, DSM said.
It declined to disclose the purchase price, which it told analysts would be financed from existing cash flow.
Under the deal, DSM -- currently Europe's fifth largest polyolefins producer -- will take over the polyolefin activities of Vestolen, a unit of German oil refiner Veba Oel AG .
Vestolen's Gelsenkirchen site has a polyethylene production capacity of 150,000 tonnes per annum (TPA) and 200,000 TPA polypropylene.
Over the coming years DSM plans to step up production at the site by building a 300,000 TPA linear low-density polyethylene gas-phase plant and a 250,000 polypropylene gas phase plant.
"After completing the projects in 2001, DSM will be one of the leading producers of polyethylene and polypropylene in Europe, with the lowest possible costs, a broad polyolefins portfolio and world-scale technological capabilities," the company said.
By the millennium DSM's total polyolefins capacity will exceed 2.5 million tonnes a year, it said. Current annual polyolefin capacity at DSM's Geleen plant is 1.52 million.
"The polyolefins business is an important and profitable building block in our portfolio," DSM chairman Simon de Bree said.
"(The deal) secures our existing strong position as supplier of polyethylene well into the first decade of the next century."
The agreement is aimed at meeting the strong growth in global demand for polyethylene, used in packaging articles such as bottles, bags and films, and polypropylene, used in packaging, textile fibres and plastic car parts.
DSM said its existing site in Geleen, one of the world's largest integrated production complexes for polyethylene and polypropylene, offered too little scope for expansion.
Consequently DSM said it was opting for a "Buy and Build" approach.
"By acquiring an existing site which offers scope for expansion and guarantees a secure supply of ethylene and propylene, DSM can copy its successful 'Geleen model' in polyolefins," it said.
These feedstocks will be supplied to Gelsenkirchen by Veba Oel from the production plants of of Ruhr Oel, its 50-50 joint venture with Petroleos de Venezuela.
On the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, DSM shares opened 5.50 guilders higher on the news at 230.00, touching 233 guilders before settling at 228.50 at mid-morning in a strongly higher market.
Analysts were also broadly upbeat on the news, although some said the move had taken them a little by surprise.
"We had been expecting an expansion in fine chemicals, and now it's plastics," said Patrick Rutten, chemicals analyst with Van Lanschot Bankiers.
"Positive is the fact that this will make DSM European market leader by 2001 -- there is sure to be concentration in the sector but DSM has stolen a march on the competition."
He said the deal was not expected to contribute to earnings in the first two years, but over the longer term it would hike profits per share by an average 4-6 guilders a year over the full industry cycle.
DSM posted 1996 net profits of 720 million guilders or 23.83 guilders per share, down from a year-earlier 1.07 billion or 29.60 per share.
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040.

headline: UCB OUTLOOK UNCERTAIN DESPITE RECOVERY.
text:
Shares in Belgian chemicals and pharmaceuticals firm UCB SA, knocked down nearly 11 percent on Friday, had an uncertain short-term outlook despite a leap of more than seven percent on the Brussels bourse on Tuesday.
Dealers said the Bel-20 index heavyweight could easily home in again on its 153,000 franc record set on Thursday but warned that Friday's mishap might not be the last one despite some persistent foreign buying interest.
"We're not touching it...it could soon be at 190,000 francs soon, but just as easily at 100,000," one dealer said.
Another said it might soon start suffering from worries that the Brussels bourse could decide to reduce the weight of UCB in the Bel-20 index.
At 0943 GMT UCB was up 6.4 percent at 140,850 francs after earlier rising 7.3 percent to 142,000.
-- Bert Lauwers, Brussels Newsroom +32 2 287 6815, Fax +32 2 230 7710

headline: RESEARCH ALERT-BEKAERT STILL A 'BUY'.
text:
Shares in Belgian steel cord and wire maker Bekaert are still a 'buy' despite the sharp recovery in its stock price, brokers KB Securities said.
In a report dated July 18 analyst Pascal Weber (+32 2 546 4106) noted Bekaert rose by 35 percent from 18,150 francs since KB's recommendation of December 18.
While the current price implied a P/E of 22.8 for 1997, above Bekaert's average historical P/E of 21, Bekaert was nevertheless a long-term buy based on prospective earnings.
The stock might, however, underperform the BEL-20 in anticipation of the first half results which are expected to be below the results of H1 1996, reflecting the fall in steel cord prices, the flooding of its BMB plant in Brazil and the benefits of the restructuring not being felt until H2 1997.
A recovery on the back of higher capacity use, a stronger order book and the recent rise of the dollar might be felt from H2 1997 onwards.
Bekaert's management aimed to achieve a 13 percent ROE by the beginning of the next millennium.
KB said this could be achieved on the back of Bekaert's restructuring plan, enabling it to cut operating costs by 2.3-3.3 billion francs over the next five years.

text:
Finance Minister Sauli Niinisto will hold a news conference today at 1600/1300 GMT on the finance ministry's proposals for next year's state budget, the ministry said in a statement on Tuesday.
Niinisto, second finance minister Arja Alho, and top officials at the finance ministry have been working on the proposals since Monday and talks with other ministries are due to start on Wednesday.
The government is due to start its budget talks on August 13.

headline: GREEK MAY REGISTERED UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO 6.8 PCT.
text:
Greece's registered unemployment fell to 6.8 percent in May from 8.5 percent in April, not seasonally adjusted, and the number of registered unemployed dropped to 182,280 in May from 210,494, the central bank said.
Registered unemployment stood at 6.3 percent in May 1996 when 157,401 people were registered as unemployed, it said in its July bulletin of coincidental indicators.
Greece's registered unemployment rate is volatile and is widely regarded as underestimating the actual rate. Registered unemployment figures are provided by the labour ministry.
Greece's unemployment rose to 10.4 percent in 1996 from 10 percent in 1995 based on annual data from the National Statistics Service. --Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

headline: ELECTRAFINA RAISED SUEZ/LYONNAISE STAKE - PAPERS.
text:
Belgian holding company Electrafina has increased its holding in French group Suez/Lyonnaise des Eaux to over 10 percent, Belgian papers said on Tuesday.
Quoting a Paris bourse statement the papers said Electrafina directly and indirectly held 11.75 percent of the capital and 10.23 percent of the voting rights of the French group.
Electrafina itself has 10 percent of the capital and 8.71 percent of the votes, the remainder being held by its Royale Belge and associated companies.
The papers quoted Electrafina as saying in the statement the transaction was realised "in the wake of the merger between Compagnie de Suez and Lyonnaise des Eaux, an exchange of Suez shares and various purchases on the bourse."
Electrafina said the deal had the approval of the management of Suez/Lyonnaise des Eaux. It was an expression of "its policy of progressively strengthening (its stake) in the capital of this company." But Electrafina did not intend to take control.
Electrafina, part of Belgian holding company Groupe Bruxelles Lambert (GBL) , is controlled by financier Albert Frere, who has been eyeing a seat on Suez/Lyonnaise des Eaux board.
In May Frere said Electrafina's stake in the group was nine percent.
The French group is seeking to become a world leader in collective services, notable energy, water and waste management.
-- Brussels Newsroom +32 2 287 6810, Fax +32 2 230 7710

headline: GREEK 1M ATHIBOR FALLS TO 12.34 FROM 12.58 PCT.
DRACHMA UP VS ECU/MARK, FRNS WEAK, SHORT RATES DOWN.
text:
The drachma was advancing against the ecu and the mark in early dealings benefiting from favourable market sentiment linked to expectations of a soft euro, dealers said.
Bonds were holding Monday's late price levels, unfazed by sharply lower short-term depos and forex forwards but FRNs came under selling pressure from abroad that drove discount margins higher to 110 basis points, dealers said.
"The specter of a soft euro has helped the dollar, the pound, other EMS currencies and the drachma but has depressed the mark," said a chief forex dealer at a foreign bank."Ecu/drachma is currently testing 309.50 and might go lower."
An audit of France's budget deficit on Monday showed that its budget deficit was running at 3.5 to 3.7 percent of GDP and the socialist government announced a package of measures to bring the deficit closer to the three percent Maastricht target.
"The market sentiment has changed and favours the drachma," the dealer said. "It is a matter of time before some London-based players reverse course and unwind their long ecu/drachma positions."
Fixed coupon bonds were fluctuating narrowly in early dealings but seven-year floaters due 2002 and 2003 were counting losses with discount margins rising to 110 bassi points from 102 late on Monday, dealers said.
Prices of 10-year bonds were steady at 94.50, seven-year bonds were trading lower at 94.95 from 95, five-year taxable were little changed at 96.95 and three-year taxable bonds due March 2000 were flat at 98.10, dealers said.
"Fixed coupon bonds are stable but FRNs due 2002 and 2003 are down with discount margins at 110 basis points," a bond dealer said. "We have seen sales of FRNs from players abroad."
Greece is to auction 150 billion drachmas of seven-year floaters on July 29.
Short-term depos and forex forwards fell sharply in early trade on a boosted liquidity from forex and other domestic sources, money dealers said.
The mark was quoted at 156.49/54 from Monday's 156.970 fix, the dollar at 282.70/80 drachmas from 282.000 and the ecu at 309.46/56 from 309.80 drachmas.

headline: FINLAND BANK TENDER RATE UNCHANGED AT 3.00 PCT.
text:
The Bank of Finland on Tuesday drained 2.35 billion markka of spot liquidity in an auction of one-month paper at an unchanged 3.00 percent tender rate.
Before the opening, the central bank forecast a spot liquidity surplus of 10.1 billion markka. The required daily balance for banks was 6.18 billion markka.
The Bank of Finland's tender rate -- its chief monetary policy tool -- has been unchanged since it was lowered to 3.00 percent from 3.10 percent on October 9, 1996.
-- Helsinki newsroom +358-9-6805 0245, news@reuters.fi

headline: FINNISH CHEMICAL RESTRUCTURE PLANS DENIED -PAPER.
text:
Reports about government plans to merge Kemira's and Neste's chemical industries and Asko's Uponor are unfounded, daily Helsingin Sanomat on Tuesday quoted officials as saying.
It said trade journal Chemical Week had reported that the ministry of trade and industry's study on cooperation between power producer Imatran Voima and oil and energy group Neste included examining a chemical sector restructuring.
"As far as I know, there is no base for that," Helsingin Sanomat quoted Kemira CEO Heimo Karinen as saying.
Deputy head of department Markku Tapio at the ministry of trade and industry said he had heard such rumours but they were unfounded, the paper reported.
The government owns 54 percent of Kemira, 84 percent of Neste and 96 percent of Imatran Voima.
Neste owns 26 percent of Asko, whose biggest unit is plastic pipes maker Uponor.
-- Helsinki newsroom +358-9-680 50 245, news@reuters.fi

headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- JULY 22.
text:
Leading stories in the Greek general press:
KATHIMERINI
--The government is preparing a series of measures for public sector organisations and enterprises designed to contain inflation, expected to be revealed in September. The measures will be included in talks on Tuesday on the drafting of the 1998 budget between Prime Minister Costas Simitis and National Economy and Finance Minister Yannos Papandoniou.
--Insurance companies in Greece say excessive charges by obstetricians are behind their decision to reduce coverage for pregnancies. One of the biggest firms active in Greece has already decided to remove pregnancy and birth coverage from its books and many now offer only a lump sum payment.
--One in three Greeks under the age of 24 is unemployed, according to the latest UNICEF figures. Greece comes fifth in its percentage of youth unemployment among 22 developed countries. 
--A meeting at the foreign ministry on Monday reportedly decided that Greece would not hinder Turkey's rapprochement efforts towards the European Union if Ankara explicitly stated that it would seek recourse to the International Court of Justice at The Hague over the issue of the islet of Imia. Statements by Turkish deputy prime minister Bulent Ecevit over the weekend provoked the anger of both Greece's foreign minister and government spokesman.
ELEFTHEROTYPIA
--Labour Minister Miltiades Papaioannou said on Monday that economic refugees from neighbouring Balkan countries such as Albania and Bulgaria would be eligible to receive work permits. According to reports, the new "green card" will be distributed to all illegal workers regardless of nationality but under strict criteria following a discussion of the issue by the inner cabinet. 
--Simitis has defined five directions for economic policy in 1998, according to reports: containment of prices and wages and tax breaks, taxes, the continuation of the 'hard drachma' policy, and covering spending through 200 billion drachmas raised through interest rates.
--Against the backdrop of the Acropolis and by the light of a full moon, Greek songstress Haris Alexiou sang for 5,000 Athenians who turned out to support the Athens 2004 Olympic Games bid.
TA NEA
--Environment, Town Planning and Public Works Minister Costas Laliotis has sent a warning to 22 ministers and deputy ministers of the danger of public works projects and loss of funding from the European Union due to the drafting of sloppy studies on environmental effects of the projects. Laliotis set ministers a 15-day deadline to take immediate measures. 
--An increasing number of robberies and abductions on the Greek-Albanian border has led the government to step up measures on the border with an increased police and military presence and 'discreet' repatriations of a number of Albanian illegal immigrants. 
ELEFTHEROS TYPOS
--Education Minister Gerasimos Arsenis conferred with Simitis on changes to the Greek educational system on Monday. A number of changes have been postponed for further discussion. 
ETHNOS
--The number of successful university entrants this year are at about the same levels as last year's, according to reports. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
