headline: EMS/Mark near lows on crosses, Sfr rallies.
text:
The mark sank on its European cross rates on Tuesday as belief in a broad-based, timely start to European monetary union was reinforced by the French budget statement on Monday and Germany's effective endorsement of it.
A fresh bout of mark selling was again concentrated against the dollar, which successfully cleared 1.80 marks, and sterling. But the move also filtered through to a weaker mark against European units like the French franc, lira and Swedish crown.
The Swiss franc too was a major beneficiary of rekindled concerns about the stability of the single currency, reinforced by its traditional haven status and the Swiss economic recovery.
"France has effectively given up trying to get to 3.0 percent (budget deficit/output ratio) this year and Germany has effectively endorsed this," said Nick Parsons, foreign exchange strategist at Banque Paribas.
"The perception this creates and the comments we've heard from the Bundesbank since can only encourage buying of Swiss francs, as well as the dollar and sterling."
Bundesbank council members Hans-Juergen Krupp and and Ernst Welteke stressed late Monday that the Maastricht Treaty does not require a deficit/GDP ratio of exactly 3.0 pct. Their colleague Hans Juergen Koebnick endorsed that view today.
Koebnick said he did not think the stability of the euro would be compromised if Germany and France had deficits in the region of 3.2-to-3.3 percent of GDP.
The Bundesbank comments followed the announcement from French Finance Minister Dominque Strauss-Kahn on Monday of public deficit cuts worth about 0.4 percent of gross domestic product. The cuts are aimed at reducing a 1997 deficit estimated to be running at between 3.5 and 3.7 percent of GDP at present.
German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said he was convinced  of Strauss-Kahn's commitment to meeting the deficit goals but declined to say whether the French measures Monday were enough.
While there is some debate as to the degree of investor concern about a wide EMU or what exactly a "soft" euro would entail, traders said the uncertainty is a major factor.
On one hand European inflation and budget deficits are falling, European bonds and equities are robust and the signs gradual economic recovery are evident in Germany.
"The problem is what sort of interest rate policy the European central bank will conduct for a wide EMU area," said a trader at a UK fund manager in London. "It's relatively predictable for Germany France and Benelux, but when you include Italy and Spain the picture becomes muddier."
The market assumption is that if France and Germany agree that overshooting deficit targets is now acceptable, then it will much more difficult to exclude the traditionally volatile Italian lira from the launch of the single currency.
The argument is not all one way, however. Some analysts believe a constitutionally independent European central bank will offset any fiscal laxity with a tight monetary policy, not least to establish its inflation-fighting credentials.
There is also the fact that European countries starting EMU will have in excess of $200 billion of foreign exchange reserves to defend the new currency.
This view is countered, however, by concerns the ECB will come under increasing political influence to keep interest rates low and the exchange rate soft while Europe restructures.
The weak state of the European economy was highlighted today by the bigger-than-expected 1.6 percent drop in French industrial output in May.
At 0942 GMT, mark/French franc was at 3.3723/26 versus 3.3738/41 late Monday. Mark/Swiss was at 0.8201/02 versus 0.8215/18. Mark/Swedish crown fell to its lowest since last October and was last at 4.3160/90 versus 4.3260/90 Monday.
--Mike Dolan, London newsroom +44 171 542 6762

headline: UK's Labour reaches out to Lib Dems with new panel.
text:
Prime Minister Tony Blair has established a joint cabinet committee comprising members of the Labour government and leaders of the centre-left Liberal Democrats to discuss policy issues of mutual interest, a spokesman for Blair said on Tuesday.
He said the consultatiuve committee marked Labour's desire to create a new politics in Britain by reaching out to like-minded parties, but said there would be no formal pact or coalition between Labour and the Liberal Democrats.  
Blair will chair the committee, which is likely to have 11 senior MPs drawn from the two parties and will meet probably once a month, the official said.
Top of the agenda will be discussion of constitutional issues, including devolution, the possible introduction of proportional representation for the House of Commons and reform of the House of Lords.
Subsequent topics might include Europe and Northern Ireland.
Officials stressed that the government will continue to make policy and said the committee, which is unprecedented in post-war British politics, did not remotely mean that Lib Dem MPs were in line for ministerial jobs.
But they said Blair felt it was important to signal to the British public that there is no reason why parties that see eye-to-eye on certain issues should not be able to say so and provide input into each others' policy-making.  
"It is part of our fulfilment of a new politics," a spokesman for Blair said.
He said the Prime Minister and Lib Dem leader Paddy Ashdown, who will be a member of the committee, had agreed on its workings in an exchange of letters.
The panel will be serviced, as is the case with other cabinet committees, by the Cabinet Secretariat. But because it is consultative in nature, the Lib Dem members would not be bound by collective government responsibility.
Officials frankly acknowledged that one of the aims of the panel is to bind the Lib Dems closer to Labour in case the ruling party becomes in greater need of parliamentary support than it is now.
"We won't have a 179 majority for ever," one said.
The Liberal Democrats made an electoral breakthrough at the May 1 election, almost doubling their representation in parliament to 46 seats. -- London Newsroom +44 171 5427767

headline: UK's Blair faces new pressure over IRA ceasefire.
text:
British Prime Minister Tony Blair faced fresh demands on Tuesday from political leaders of Northern Ireland's majority Protestant community angered at the terms of a new ceasefire declared by IRA guerrillas.
Blair was due to meet Ian Paisley and other leaders of the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), second biggest of the pro-British Protestant parties in the province.
They insist Sinn Fein, political wing of the Irish nationalist IRA guerrillas, must not be allowed into Northern Ireland peace talks without a commitment from the IRA to hand in its guns.
Peter Robinson, deputy leader of the DUP, told reporters:
"The prime minister has to be told that the people of Northern Ireland do not accept IRA/Sinn Fein coming into a process holding onto their guns, without giving any commitment of the permanency of their ceasefire."
He added: "I think we would want to talk to the prime minister about how we might have a proper talks process with constitutional legitimate parties."
Northern Irish Protestants have expressed scepticism at the IRA (Irish Republican Army) ceasefire declared on Sunday because it makes no reference to a permanent truce in its 28-year struggle against British rule.
The last ceasefire, declared in August 1994, was broken 17 months later when the IRA exploded a huge bomb in London's Docklands area, killing two people.
Hardline Unionists have said their political leaders should not sit down with Sinn Fein, which is now expected to be let into the peace talks following the IRA truce.
Leaders of the Orange Order, an influential organisation in the Protestant community, threw the peace process further into doubt on Monday when they called on all unionist parties to pull out of the talks at Stormont Castle in Belfast at once.
Orange Lodge Grand Master Robert Saulters, described the peace process as a "poisoned chalice".
He called for "all Unionist parties to withdraw immediately in an act of unity and solidarity from the Stormont talks, the existence and purpose of which is to solely satisfy the insatiable demands of the republican agenda".
Unionists have been angered by the prospect of the IRA's ceasefire winning Sinn Fein a seat at the peace talks without the guerrillas being forced to turn in their weapons.
One of the smaller unionist groups has already pulled out of the talks and the future of the negotiations depends on the reaction of the mainstream unionist parties.
Northern Ireland's leading unionist, David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP), told Blair on Monday that the IRA must start handing its arms in or peace talks would fail.
But Trimble, who was to have further telephone contact with Blair on Tuesday, stopped short of pulling out from the talks.
Jeffrey Donaldson of the UUP said unionist politicians must not allow Sinn Fein to take over the peace process.
"We're not going to allow Sinn Fein/IRA to set the agenda," he told the BBC.
"The democratic parties of Northern Ireland have got to take control of this process. After all we represent the majority of the people."
A further session of the peace talks was due to take place on Tuesday before the participants vote on Wednesday on a joint proposal from the British and Irish governments that decommissioning of guerrilla arms be tackled by a subcommittee in parallel with political negotiations.
The UUP has already made clear it will not vote for this proposal as it stands.
Sinn Fein, which convinced the IRA it was worth calling a ceasefire, says the handing over of weapons should be part of a final settlement, not ongoing negotiations.
Sinn Fein negotiator Martin McGuinness said at the weekend that the IRA would not hand in a single bullet.

Robusta coffee futures look set to consolidate in lower ranges but the lack of solid support under the market could still herald further weakness, technical analysts said on Tuesday.
Prices on the London market extended their fall on Monday in sympathy with New York but trading was slow and activity generally subdued.
Traders called the London market to open unchanged from Monday's close.
Technical analysts said while September had psychological support at $1,500, followed by an unfilled gap between $1,368 and $1,415, there was little solid support before the $1,200 lows at the start of the year.
"There's not much really in the way of support," said independent technical analyst Elli Gifford, who pegged nearby resistance at Thursday's high of $1,645.
"That's unlikely to be challenged as we're on the way down," Gifford said.
Traders have said sentiment could be weighed down in both the London and New York markets by the no-frost forecast for Brazil through to the end of July, which is traditionally the end to the frost season.
-- Jeremy Smith, London Newsroom +44 171 542 8064

headline: INSIGHT-IPE Brent to test support if uptrend broke.
text:
---------------------------------------------------------------
NEARBY MONTH CLOSE * SUPPORT * RESIST  * RSI-14 * MA-10 * MA-20
 BRENT	  18.09 *  18.00  *  18.20  *   47   * 18.22 * 18.25
 GAS OIL     162.50 * 160.00  * 167.00  *   47   *163.00 *163.21
---------------- VIEWS FROM THE MARKET - JULY 22 --------------
* While technicals for Brent for the medium term are not constructive the short term looks positive while prices are on the right side of the up trend and the $17.80 double bottom.
* A move below the trend line will be bearish and the weight drawn from the medium to long term technicals may become more evident.
IPE Brent crude and gas oil futures were expected to move sideways on Tuesday, though a break of the short term uptrend line for Brent could force a test of support at the lower levels, analysts said.
The convergence of the uptrend line from June 11's low of $17.32, extending up through $17.80 to $18 and the longer term downtrend line from January 9's high of $24.91 that crosses the uptrend at $18 on the spot month continuation chart continues to cap and underpin a narrowing trading range, at the same time forming a bear flag.
Analysts said the longer term downtrend line continues to be the dominant factor fuelling bear sentiment in all but the very short term.
This was further backed up by a Doji candlestick which was preceded by Friday's long white candlestick formation and is seen as a signal the recent rally has ended, according to Japanese candlestick charting techniques.
Peter Sceats analyst at CharTech MCS said in his weekly report, "While background technicals for the medium term are not constructive the short term looks okay while prices are on the right side of the (up) trend line and the $17.80 double bottom which was the 'banker pattern' week last".
"Needless to say a move below the trend line will be bearish and the weight drawn from the medium to long term technicals may then become more evident," Sceats added.
Some analysts saw the market attempting another step higher but unless stiff resistance around $18.20 is breached then a test to the lower side and possibly through support at $17.98 may be seen, though momentum is expected to be slow and the traded range narrow.
They said the double bottom support in at $17.80 could block any sharp fall for a while then further support comes in at $17.50 and $17.32 though these are not expected to be tested today.
Fenella Graham at MeesPierson Derivatives Limited said "Neutral to negative preparation across the board has us watching the range closely and taking profits on convincing support at the lower levels".
Gas oil was seen continuing to move sideways between $162.50 and $163.50 with the rally of the past two weeks at an end, though $160 remains sturdy support should sentiment turn bearish.
--Colin Wooster, London Newsroom, +44 171 542 7456

headline: INSIGHT - Cocoa could fall further after spec sales.
text:
-------------------------------------------------------------
 SEPT	Close  * Support * Resist * RSI14 *   MA10 *   MA30
 COCOA	985   *    960  *  1,040 *   32  *  1,034 *  1,081
---------------VIEWS FROM THE MARKET - JULY 22---------------
Cocoa futures look poised to rack up further losses after the recent bout of speculator liquidation drove benchmark September through 1,000 stg support, technical analysts said on Tuesday.  
On Monday, the London market derailed from its upward track with a 3.7 percent loss that dragged prices to a four-month floor as speculators unloaded long positions.
London's sharp decline also weighed heavily on the New York market, causing the U.S. September contract to gap down $34 a tonne at the outset.
Traders called London to open five stg lower than Monday's close, adding that while they saw prospects of the market bottoming out at current levels, an immediate rebound was probably unlikely.
Technical analysts said September's slide through key psychological support at 1,000 stg -- broken during the first 25 minutes of trading -- had made the charts even more bearish than before the selling spree.
"It's now broken down through 1,000 and that has to be considered as a complete reversal of its earlier fortunes," said independent analyst Elli Gifford.
Gifford pegged initial support at 960 stg but said the key downside target had now shifted below 900 stg to the mid-February trough of 895 stg.
On the upside, the recent highs of 1,044 and 1,063 stg would provide nearby barriers but the upper target was unlikely to be challenged in the near term on account of the market's weak momentum.
"There's a solid band reaching up to 1,063...but I wouldn't have thought that an attempt to get anywhere near that high was likely," said Gifford.
The maximum upside move would be up to 1,025, she said. "But I wouldn't expect it right now."
Other analysts have said improved prospects for the cocoa crop in Ivory Coast have added to the overall bearish sentiment, although the release of the next round of crop estimates is still some three weeks away.
But Ivorian crop analysts and regional buyers said on Monday that the country's 1997/98 cocoa crop (Oct-Sept) was developing strongly with large harvests possible if favorable weather continues into August.
-- Jeremy Smith, London Newsroom +44 171 542 8064

headline: UK'S Brown says no extension of VAT to food, books.
text:
British Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown said he was standing by a pledge not to impose VAT on food, clothes or books for the life of the current parliament.
"For the life of the parliament, we will not extend VAT to the items that the Conservatives were considering like food or children's clothes or books or newspapers or transport," Brown told BBC radio.
"That would be the wrong thing to do because every tax decision should be based on fairness...VAT on food would be unfair in this way," he added.
Brown was responding to an IMF report which praised the new Labour government for its economic policies but which said Brown's July 2 budget could have been tilted more heavily against free-spending consumers.
--London Newsroom +44 171 542 7950

headline: INSIGHT - European precious metals to consolidate.
text:
--------------------------------------------------------------
 SPOT     NY CLOSE  * SUPPORT * RESIST * RSI14 *   MA10 *   MA30
 GOLD   328.70/9.20 *  319.50 * 330.00 *    50 * 320.31 * 331.72
 SILVER   4.28/4.30 *    4.17 *   4.40 *    34 *   4.30 *   4.57
 PLAT   412.00/4.00 *  394.00 * 410.00 *    51 * 402.85 * 417.50
-----------------VIEWS FROM THE MARKET - July 22--------------
Gold along with silver and platinum look set to consolidate on Tuesday, though may attempt to tick higher near-term following their recoveries from recent long-time lows, traders and chartists said.
Gold will find resistance at $330.00 an ounce, while silver will struggle at $4.30 and $4.40, they added.  
GOLD - Gold is expected to trade sideways on Tuesday after having been lifted from recent 12-year lows of under $320.00 last week on the back of short-covering and investment fund interest sparked by extremely oversold chart signals, traders and chartists said.
Gold is expected to meander between $322.00/$325.00 and $330.00.
"Gold is absorbing its gains after already having reached an initial target of $330.00," Karen Jones of Credit Suisse First Boston said.
Traders agreed saying that they expect gold to find selling towards moves to $330.00.
Above this level next resistance is expected from a near-term down trend line currently around $337.00.
Below $322.00 a stiff band of support is likely to emerge between $318.50 and $319.50.
At 0750 GMT spot gold was quoted at $325.30/325.70, against Monday's London close of $326.40/$326.90.
SILVER - Also seen handcuffed to a narrow ranges but needs to break $4.40 resistance to bolster upside confidence which has been waning recently. "Levels of $4.60 would help to restore bullish confidence," one trader said.
On the downside $4.17 remains key support. A breach of this level could see prices driving towards $4.00.
At 0750 GMT spot silver was quoted at $4.26/4.28, versus $4.27/29.
PLATINUM - Gains are likely to limited unless the market can break strong resistance between $415 and $416. " Even if it can overcome this level there is strong resistance up to $420," Jones said.
Support for platinum was seen at $400 followed by $394
At 0750 GMT spot platinum was quoted at $411.20/414.20, against $411.50/$414.50.
--London Newsroom +44 171 542-8075

headline: INSIGHT - Copper and aluminium capped, could slip.
text:
---------------------------------------------------------------
 3 MONTH     CLOSE  * SUPPORT * RESIST * RSI14 * MA10 * MA30
 COPPER     2325/27 *  2300   *  2340  *  41   * 2301 * 2427
 ALUMINIUM  1607/09 *  1560   *  1620  *  43   * 1600 * 1627
---------------VIEWS FROM THE MARKET - July 22-----------------
Lacking in upside momentum both copper and aluminium are unlikely to test overhead resistance and could slip lower in range-bound dealings, traders and chartists said on Tuesday.
Resistance for copper was pegged around $2,340 a tonne, while aluminium's upside barrier was seen at $1,620. Initial support is expected at $2,300 and $1,600 respectively.  
COPPER - The level of $2,340 a tonne is likely to offer resistance on any probes higher and prices may drift back under technical selling to test support at $2,300, traders and chart watchers said on Tuesday.
"This market seems to have lost upside momentum," Harry Creates of LME brokers Amalgamated Metal Trading (AMT) commented.
Creates said copper needs to break above $2,340 to spark further gains towards $2,360 and higher. On the downside Creates said a breach of $2,318 could leave the market open to falls to $2,302 and $2,280.
According to another analyst the appearance of a shooting star on the candlestick chart suggests that prices should start moving downwards on Tuesday.
"...$2,340 has proved to be a strong resistance level and as a result the market continues to range trade," the chartist said.
But brokers Brandeis were cautious to declines in the copper market.
"With tightness believed to persist through to the end of the month the cash to three months spread could flare from time to time as the large shorts look to cover," Brandeis said.
"This should in turn help to underpin prices in a $2,300/$2,360 range in the short term," they added.
Brandeis noted that the 10-day moving average towards $2,300 was offering chart support.
At 0645 GMT three months LME copper was quoted at $2,325/30, against Monday's late London close of $2,325/27.
ALUMINIUM - May drift to test support at $1,600 and possibly lower after recently failing to overcome resistance towards $1,620. "The appearance of an inverted hammer on Monday's candlestick chart indicates that the market is uncertain about moving higher," Brandeis said.
They pegged good resistance around $1,620/25 and support at $1,600/05.
At 0645 GMT three months aluminium was quoted at $1,606/10, against $1,607/09.
-- London Newsroom +44 171 542-8075

headline: PRESS DIGEST - Financial Times - July 22.
text:
This daily press summary is produced for Reuters by the Broadcast Monitoring Company, which is responsible for its contents. For further information on these articles or details of BMC's other international press and broadcast services call Simon McMillan on +44 (0)171 256 5130 or e-mail bmc.co@ft.com
-- FRANCE INCREASES BUSINESS TAXES TO MEET EMU TARGETS
The French government announced higher-than-expected taxes for profitable businesses as part of the plan to get the country back on line for the EMU regulation of a maximum deficit of three per cent of gross domestic product as a prerequisite for joining the single currency. Finance and industry minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn offered no guarantee that the FFr32bn public deficit reduction plan, FFr22bn of which will come from companies, would be sufficient to meet the EMU criterion.
-- BOEING STANDING FIRM OVER SUPPLY CONTRACTS
On the eve of the Brussels ruling on the Boeing-McDonnell Douglas merger in which the EC has urged Boeing to drop the 20 year agreements for exclusive aircraft manufacture deals with American, Delta and Continental Airlines, Boeing has offered to reduce the contracts to 13 years only but the Commission has rejected this. The three airlines have emphasised the benefits of only buying from one suppl ier but American have agreed to follow Boeing if they wish to change the exclusivity deal although Delta would not comment. Continental said it would not buy from Airbus Industrie regardless of the exclusivity clause.
-- SMITH BACKS DOWN ON 'NOT-FOR-PROFIT' LOTTERY POLL PLEDGE
The government backed down on a white paper warning by Chris Smith, culture secretary, that the National Lottery would be run on a not-for-profit basis. The election campaign proposal was reversed as Smith conceded that profits may well be vital to ensure efficiency and a well run system. Virgin announced that Richard Branson was no longer interested in the lottery after initially bidding to run the business for no profit.
-- TESCO HALTS MEAT PURCHASES AFTER TV CLAIMS
Tesco suspended purchases from its biggest meat supplier, St Merryn Meat in Bodmin, Cornwall, prior to the scheduled broadcast of a Granada Television World in Action documentary on the alleged poor practice at the plant. The retail chain has 1billion stg in annual meat sales as the country's biggest butcher and took action as a precaution. Tesco claimed that the suspension has nothing to do with hygiene or safety.
-- WINDFALL PAYOUT SURVEY ALLAYS SPENDING FEARS
Consultancy firm Gavin Anderson has revealed survey results that suggest that only eight per cent of the consumers receiving windfall payouts from the year's 30 billion stg building society and life insurer demutualisation will be spending their money immediately. The lower-than-expected spending will help to deter the predicted rises in interest rate and inflation as 56 per cent said they would keep the shares, 22 per cent will convert them to PEPs and 7 per cent said they would invest their share funds into other savings products.
-- JAPAN'S OKI TO BUILD ADVANCED FAX MACHINE AT SCOTTISH PLANT
Japanese electronics company Oki Electric has announced plans to base the production of its new range of 'plain paper' fax machines at its Cumbernauld plant near Glasgow. The overseas production investment could create 200-500 new jobs at the 1000-strong workforce plant by early next century and give the company a predicted sales rise of 1.3 million fax machines in Europe by the year 2001.
-- PRIVATISATION OF AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL URGED
The Civil Aviation Authority has told the government that it cannot sustain investment unless the National Air Traffic Service, a CAA wholly owned limited company, is privatised. The department of transport has said that ministers will decide the future of Nats and it is understood that John Prescott, deputy prime minister, is opposed to a 'regulated utility' on the grounds of safety but is not uncompromising in finding private investment.
-- ACTION URGED ON IT STAFF SHORTAGE
Barbara Roche, minister for industry, urged businesses to help the government tackle the shortage of trained IT staff in the face of the growing dependence upon computers in the commercial sector. Roche has offered to match any private investment into an IT skills programme and emphasised the sense of urgency in meeting the demands of the future with change needed by the millennium.
-- SETBACK FOR COURTAULDS AS RIVAL WINS RULING ON PATENT
British-based chemicals company Courtaulds has suffered a legal setback in a battle with rival Austrian company Lenzing over a competitor to its fibre Tencil. The Courtaulds product has won acceptance from retailers and the fashion industry, but the company has been fighting competition from Lenzing's generic version of the fibre, lyocell. The US Court of Appeal has upheld one of Lenzing's patents.
-- WATERFORD CHIEF URGES BACKING OF MERGER PLAN
Members of the milk cooperative of Irish dairy company Waterford Foods have been urged to attend an extraordinary meeting on Friday to back the proposed merger with Avonmore Foods. The plea has been issued by Matt Walsh, group managing director of Waterford, who said the proposed alliance would create arguably the world's fourth largest dairy company. For a full range of news monitoring services, phone BMC +44-171-377-1742 END

headline: PRESS DIGEST - British Business - July 22.
text:
This daily press summary is produced for Reuters by the Broadcast Monitoring Company, which is responsible for its contents. For further information on these articles or details of BMC's other international press and broadcast services call Simon McMillan on +44 (0)171 256 5130 or e-mail bmc.co@ft.com
- - - -
DAILY TELEGRAPH
-- COURTS FURNISHES THE COHENS WITH SHARE OPTIONS BONANZA
The latest annual reports from the Courts Plc furnishings group reveals that six directors made share option gains during the year which came to a total of 2.9 million stg. Bruce Cohen, managing director and chief executive of the group, received a total of 810,000 stg last year, including a salary of 323,000 stg which had increased by 43 per cent on the previous year.
-- PROFITS PLUNGE 35 PER CENT AT AT&T
U.S. telecoms company AT & T Corp has reported a 35.6 per cent fall in second-quarter profits, to $959 million net (600 million stg). Robert Allen, chairman and chief executive, said the company's local service efforts had been "slowed by the foot-dragging of entrenched monopolies". AT & T had issued a profits warning in March, and Dan Somers, chief financial officer, said he believed this week's results would be the low mark and that future quarters would see improvements.
-- NATIONWIDE SEEKS EARLY DECLARATION
Nationwide Building Society, Britain's largest building society, is expected to reveal on Tuesday whether it will give the results of elections to its board. The results could determine whether Nationwide remains a mutual, as five rebel candidates are standing on a platform of converting the society to a bank. The deadline for the poll is Tuesday morning, but over one million votes have already been cast.
THE TIMES
-- RAISE TAX TO COOL ECONOMY, IMF ADVISES
Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown is expected to receive a warning on Tuesday from the International Monetary Fund that he may have to raise consumer taxes in order to cool the UK economy. A team from the IMF has been holding meetings in London with Brown, the Treasury and the Bank of England over the past 10 days.
-- CHIEF OF UNITED UTILITIES QUITS IN BOARDROOM RIFT
Shares in multi-utility United Utilities dropped sharply on Monday as the City reacted to the shock resignation of Brian Staples as company's chief executive. The move, which prompted shares to fall 69.5p to 699.5p, comes amid rumours of a bitter boardroom rift. A statement from United said that Staples had left after "a loss of confidence in him by the board".
-- ARNAULT QUITS GUINNESS IN PROTEST
Bernard Arnault, chairman of the French luxury goods firm LVMH which is opposing the proposed merger of Guinness and Grand Metropolitan, has resigned from the board of Guinness. The move was in protest at the "negative and vitriolic" response he received from the two suitors to his own alternative proposal for a three-way alliance involving the drinks businesses of Guinness, GrandMet and LVMH.
- - - -
THE GUARDIAN
-- GERMANY SHAPES UP FOR THE EUROPEAN BANK SHUFFLE
German banks Bayerische Vereinsbank and Beyerische Hypotheken and the Wechelbank have initiated the start of a 12 billion stg merger as part of a two-stage plan which will form a single bank with overall assets of 743 billion marks and a workforce of almost 40,000 sometime early next year. The new alliance will form Europe's second-biggest bank next to Deutsche Bank, but the banking trade union fears job losses of up to 20 per cent. The merger has yet to be confirmed by shareholders and the watchdog commission, but is expected to be approved.
-- NO DIVIDEND AT SKETCHLEY AFTER GROUP LOSES 4.3 MLN STG
Owners of SupaSnaps and the dry cleaning chain Sketchley denied shareholders a dividend after announcing a 23 per cent increase in losses of 4.3 million stg on turnover of 157.6 million stg. The Sketchley group, which last year had a 3.5 million stg deficit and announced the closure of 160 of its 720 high street shops, still retained some optimism with the report of growth in its textile services sector. Heavy losses were blamed on the 7.5 million stg one-off cost of the store closures.
-- SIGNET'S NEW FACETS FAIL SHAREHOLDERS TEST
The jeweller Signet has faced fresh calls for its break-up from the UK Active Value Fund following the completion of its capital restructure which converted its ordinary and four preference shares into ordinary shares, leaving the original ordinary shareholders with only 17.5 per cent of the company and the old preference shareholders without receiving 164.5 million stg of owed dividends. UK Active now own six per cent of the company, which announced a 6.6 per cent sales increase in the first half of the year.
- - - -
THE INDEPENDENT
-- SIEMENS TO PUSH AHEAD WITH SECOND TYNESIDE PLANT
German electronics and engineering giant Siemens AG has revealed it will expand operations at its Tyneside plant, a move which could bring thousands of jobs to the area. Siemens president Heinrich Von Pierer stated plans for the company's second plant in the area would proceed as planned, and a third factory for Tyneside is also being considered. Siemens' talks with General Electric Co Plc (GEC) into the future of its GPT telecoms venture are continuing, with Von Pierer saying it was unlikely that GEC would acquire a 60 per cent stake in the GPT.
-- MAKEOVER TO COST TESCO 4 MLN STG
The 120,000 employees at Britain's largest supermarket chain, Tesco, are to undergo a 4 million stg makeover which will see them issued with a new wardrobe as designed by dry cleaning group Sketchley. Sketchley have spent the past few months consulting with staff on their wardrobe preferences, and as a result staff will now have the option of choosing from a wide variety of styles and colours. Sketchley also have careerwear contracts with Sainsbury and the Rover Group.
-- DOMECQ BUYS SANDWICH CHAIN
Allied Domecq has purchased the Togo's chain of 200 U.S. franchised sandwich shops for $50 million (30 million stg) in an attempt to expand its U.S. fast food business. Allied plan to expand the number of Togo's outlets to 1,000 in locations close to its existing fast food outlets which will all be managed as a single operation. Current annual turnover at Togo's is about $120m on average sales of $600,000.

headline: UK housing market faltered in June, RICS says.
text:
Britain's fast-recovering housing market faltered in June as worries about possible measures in Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown's first budget kept buyers at bay, the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said on Tuesday.
But since the budget did little to take any steam out of the market, last month's wobble will prove short-lived, it said.
The net balance of chartered surveyors across the country reporting price increases fell to 56 percent in the three months to June, from 60 percent in May.
The balance measures the difference between the percentage of respondents who reported price rises and the percentage who said prices fell.
Confidence was hit hardest in the most buoyant areas -- London, the South East and the South West.
Brown's July 2 budget measures did not hit the housing market as hard as had been expected.
Tax relief on mortgage interest payments (MIRAS) was cut to 10 percent from 15 percent from next April, not abolished altogether, while stamp duty on house purchases was raised to 1.5 percent only on houses selling for more than 250,000 pounds ($419,000) and to two percent on properties worth 500,000 or more.
At present, the duty is levied at one percent on all properties worth more than 60,000 pounds.
"The cut in MIRAS...was not as large as had been feared and the increase in Stamp Duty will only affect around 30,000 of the 1.4 million transactions expected over the next 12 months," said RICS housing market spokesman Ian Perry.
The survey showed the number of house sales rose, on average, by 12 percent over the three months to June compared with the same period last year as buyers scurried to complete purchases before the budget. The number of properties for sale fell by 25 percent.
"In the event, the market had little to fear from the budget, although we expect the Chancellor to have abolished MIRAS entirely by 1999," Perry said.
He said even the widely predicted interest rate rises -- base rates have been ratcheted up to 6.75 percent in three, quarter-point moves since Labour took power on May 1 -- have failed to subdue the market.
"Given the shortage of property for sale, we can expect prices to continue to rise over the next 18 months."
($ = 0.595 British Pounds)

headline: Women face daily threat of violence - UNICEF.
text:
To be born female is to be born high risk in a world of genital mutilation, dowry killings and domestic violence, according to a United Nations report released on Tuesday.
"There should be 60 million more women in the world today but they have been killed or have died through violence directed at their gender," said a spokesman for the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).
Along with the 60 million "missing", UNICEF said millions more, in every country and from every class, live under the daily threat of physical abuse.
"This chronic condition of violence amounts to the most pervasive human rights violation in the world today," said Carol Bellamy, UNICEF's executive director.
"In today's world, to be born female is to be born high risk. Every girl grows up under the threat of violence," she said in a statement. UNICEF released its findings in "The Progress of Nations", an annual report that ranks nations on issues affecting the health, welfare and rights of children. Violence against females was highlighted because it affects children around the world and delivers a broad picture on how countries develop, said a spokesman.
The report detailed a litany of abuses directed at women and girls -- dowry killings in India, genital mutilation in Africa, domestic violence in the United States or acid hurling in Bangladesh.
The report suggests the scope of violence far exceeds earlier estimates, saying 25 to 50 percent of all women have suffered physical abuse at the hands of a partner.
"Even in a comparatively open society like the U.S., only one in 100 battered women ever reports the abuse she suffers," said UNICEF.
Nor are women the only ones to suffer.
"Violence against women also means violence against girls and some types of gender violence specifically target girls," said Bellamy.
So-called "son preference" results in the widespread abortion of female foetuses and the murder of new-born girls occurs in some Asian communities, it said.
Genital mutilation -- in which all or part of a girl's genitalia are removed -- is common in at least 28 countries, mostly in Africa, it added.
"Up to 130 million women and girls today have had their genitals excised," said the report.
As for solutions: UNICEF urged better schooling for girls and increased legal protection for women.
Out of 193 nations in the world, just 44 have enacted legislation against domestic violence, 27 have laws against sexual harassment and 17 regard marital rape as a crime, it said. Even in those countries where legislation does exist, the law is not always enforced.
"The status quo is intolerable," Bellamy said. "We must insist that violence against girls and women be viewed as a shocking aberration, not an invisible norm."

headline: Strong to very strong demand at London tea auction.
text:
Strong demand was seen at Monday's London tea auction, with prices generally five to 10 pence per kilo firmer for all categories, the official report said.
The offshore sector emerged as very strong, with gains of 10 to 20 pence.
The next auction will be held on Monday, July 28.
--Stephen Grainger +44 171 542 8074.

headline: Carpetright sales up 25 pct in 1st 12 weeks.
text:
British carpet retailer Carpetright Plc said on Tuesday sales in the first 12 weeks of the current financial year were up 25 percent on last year.  
The company said its share of the market was now in the region of 17 percent.
"With a growing economy and a carpet market that continues to strengthen after a slow start in May, we are looking to continued growth during the rest of our year," chairman and chief executive Lord Harris told the annual general meeting.
He said in a statement that the company had opened four Carpetright stores and seven Carpet Depots since April, bringing the totals to 212 and 64 respectively.
"We expect to open a total of 39 stores during this financial year and, as a result of MFI Homeworks conversions, have a major opportunity over the next two years to open many new stores and to extend some of our smaller stores," Lord Harris added.
-- London newsroom +44 171 542 4365

headline: OPTIONS - Dollar vols bound up with sparky spot.
text:
Implied volatilities on dollar/mark options flew up around half a point as spot soared to fresh 71-month highs above 1.81 marks.
Traders said the prospect of further hefty spot upmoves and uncertainty over U.S. Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's key Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, which kicks off today, had conspired to boost vols.
One-month dollar/mark vol rose to 10.4/10.6 percent by 1012 GMT from late Monday's European level of 9.9/10.0. Traders said activity was concentrated in shorter dates, but volatility levels rose across the curve, with one-year quoted at 10.2/10.6 percent compared to 9.9/10.0.  
In the spot market, the dollar scaled a new peak of 1.8120, far above yesterday's 1.7960/70 close.
"It's pretty lively with the break through 1.80 and awaiting Greenspan's speech -- there's quite a lot of uncertainty about the result of his testimony," said an options dealer at a U.S. bank here.
Risk reversals -- which measure the market's preference for calls or puts -- slightly sharpened their skew for dollar calls. Traders qoted one-month dollar/mark risk reversals at 0.45/0.75 percent against 0.3/0.6 percent late on Monday.  
Dollar/yen vols were also firm, taking their cue from spot, but in both markets the move was less pronounced than in dollar/mark.
One-month dollar/yen volatility rose to 9.9/10.4 percent from late Monday's 9.6/10.1, while nine-month and one-year vols stayed steady at 10.5/10.8 and 10.6/11.1 respectively.
Spot was quoted at 116.16/26 at 1028 GMT compared to its previous close here of 115.80/90.
Risk reversals continue to reflect a market unconvinced by the dollar's upside potential against the yen.
One-month risk reversals have stabilised at around 0.35/0.65 percent for yen calls/dollar puts, though the skew has diminished sharply from the sharp 3.0 percent preference for yen calls seen in early July.
-- Abigail Levene, London Newsroom +44-171-542-8968

headline: London gold glued to tight range in sluggish AM.
text:
Gold consolidated quietly on Tuesday in early Europe but dealers said it may take another look at the upside later in the day if nearby support continues to hold.
"We're close to where New York closed and there's not a lot of impetus to move from here this morning," a dealer said.
"The market has mixed feelings, but another try at $330 looks fairly reasonable," he added, noting that physical offtake below $325.00 was underpinning the market for the time being.
Bullion was fixed virtually unchanged at $326.00 per ounce, compared to $326.20 on Monday afternoon and a London close of $326.40/$326.90.
Gold prices had come off highs on Monday afternoon after buying interest from U.S. investments funds pulled back.
Short covering by funds had been behind gold's rise from under $320 level last week, and dealers said their strategies would continue setting the tone in the precious metals markets.
Gold sank to 12-year lows earlier this month after news that the Australian central bank sold 167 tonnes of gold from its reserves prompted big amounts of short selling by hedge funds.
Silver, taking its lead from gold, was very quiet at $4.28/$4.30, hovering just one cent above the previous day's close.
The platinum group metals (PGMs), meanwhile, maintained their recently firmer tone against a background of ongoing uncertainty about Russian exports to Japan.
Japanese traders said shipments of Russian platinum had not arrived yet despite pledges by Russian PGM export agency Almazjuvelirexport to resume exports this week.
Almaz this month resumed palladium exports to Japan after a six-month suspension blamed on bureaucratic snarl-ups.
But traders said the volumes were not enough to ease supply tightness in the Japanese market.
"The Japanese must be getting very frustrated. A couple of weeks ago it looked like smooth sailing with the PGMs but there are still obviously problems," a dealer said.
"Noone is getting into the PGMs if they can avoid it."
Platinum was last indicated at $414.00/$417.00, up $2.50, while palladium was up $3.50 at $192.00/$195.00.
--Lida Poletz, London newsroom +44 171 542 2936

headline: UK's Brown sees major tax and benefits reform.
text:
British Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown said on Tuesday he was convinced that major reforms of the tax and benefits system were needed to boost job creation.
"In relation to work, I am absolutely convinced that we will need reforms to the tax and benefits system to encourage employment opportunity in this country," he told parliament's newly-appointed Treasury Select Committee.
He said the welfare-to-work programme, funded by a windfall tax on Britain's privatised utilities, was just a starting point.
Brown said it was wrong for the lowest paid to face crippling marginal tax rates, up to 150 percent.
"Half the people who get into jobs become unemployed again within a year. There are disincentives built in to our tax and benefits system."
To that end, he said the review set up under Barclays Plc chief executive Martin Taylor would look at the whole system in detail. "I look forward to being able to discuss reforms we will bring forward in the next budget," he said.
-- Mike Peacock, London Newsroom +44 171 542 7708

headline: UK's Brown says no major extra spending on BSE.
text:
British Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown said the costs of dealing with bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) would be dealt with over a period of years without incurring huge extra public spending bills.
"Of course we are concerned about expenditure on BSE. And I make no apology for saying that we have inherited what I would say is a mess from the previous government which has got to be dealt with," he told the House of Commons Treasury Select Committee.
"But I am determined that we solve the problem of BSE over the time of the government without incurring huge extra public spending bills."
-- Richard Murphy, London Newsroom 44 171 542 2774

headline: BT says mulling "extremely tough" price caps.
text:
British Telecommunications said on Tuesday proposed limits on the prices it charges rivals for carrying calls on its network were tough and "a little unjustified" but added it was too soon to consider challenging them with a monopoly inquiry.
"This is going to represent extremely tough targets for BT," a company spokesman said. "We do need to look at it more closely." But he said BT believed the proposals were a step in the right direction.
Earlier, telecoms watchdog Oftel said it was proposing a new, four-year price regime for BT's so-called "interconnect" prices -- which make up a large proportion of other operators' costs -- at the lower end of its previously suggested range.
It wants to cap BT's charges to eight percent below retail price inflation (RPI-8). A one-off price cut of around 10 percent is also proposed on October 1.
Oftel, which wants to boost competition with its plans that will cut BT's charges by around 28 percent in real terms over the next four years, had been looking at a range of RPI-6 to RPI-12 and at a one-off price cut of up to 20 percent.
"The one-off 10 percent we feel is a little unjustified and the value of X (RPI-8) is very challenging," the BT spokesman said. "But broadly we welcome the direction that the proposal is going."
BT, which emphasises that British interconnect charges are already around one third of those in other countries, has argued that price caps representing about one billion pounds of its total costs of 12 billion pounds could harm infrastructure investment in Britain.
The telecoms giant, which has said it would consider seeking a Monopolies and Mergers Commission inquiry if necessary, will be studying the proposals and will be making its formal response to Oftel on August 22.
Final Oftel proposals will be considered by BT's board in September.
-- London Newsroom +44 171 542 7987

headline: FOCUS-Shares rises as markets wait for Greenspan.
text:
European share markets recovered lost ground on Tuesday as profit-takers retreated but few investors took big risks before the U.S. central bank chief reported on the American economy later in the day.
Germany led the way with blue chips up almost 2.5 percent, set alight by bank shares following news of a big merger in the overcrowded sector.
Markets are fairly confident that Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan will not drop any bombshells when he begins testifying to Congress at 1800 GMT. Despite a strong U.S. economy, inflation seems to be well under control.
But Greenspan can always surprise, as he did last December when he warned investors on Wall Street against irrational exuberance. The comment sent stock markets around the globe tumbling, but not for long.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 16.26 points to 7,906.72 on Monday -- 26 percent higher than its close on December 16, the low point after the Greenspan comments.
Greenspan could still spark market jitters on Tuesday by saying in his twice-yearly Humphrey-Hawkins testimony that strong economic growth could put upward pressure on prices and interest rates later in the year.
This might hurt stock and bond markets, but would give support to the dollar which is already powering ahead.
"Maybe he will make reference to the exuberance in stocks that he referred to last December, since when the (U.S.) market has gained 25 percent, and he may talk about the outlook for stronger growth," said one senior stock dealer in London. "But ... providing he's not too severe then the markets will probably be OK."
Greenspan's testimony has two legs. On Tuesday he appears before the House of Representatives banking sub-committee and on Wednesday he addresses the Senate banking committee.
Notwithstanding the Greenspan jitters, European stock markets took heart from Wall Street's firmer close on Monday after two sessions of heavy profit-taking.
By mid morning London's FTSE-100 index, which tumbled 143 points in the past two sessions, was up 24.0 points or 0.5 percent at 4,829.7.
Germany was the strongest performer, with the DAX index surging 101.1 points or 2.46 percent to 4,209.5. A firmer dollar and fresh buying after Monday morning's steep drop bolstered the market.
Bank shares led the way after Monday's news that two of Germany's largest commercial banks, Bayerische Vereinsbank AG and Bayerische Hypobank, would merge.
This sparked hopes of a consolidation in the banking industry. Commerzbank AG led the way, gaining 7.40 marks or 13.2 percent to 63.50.
Wall Street and the dollar also helped the Paris bourse, which seemed to have shrugged off Monday's announcement of company tax rises aimed at cutting the state budget deficit for European monetary union. The CAC-40 was was up 22.68 points or 0.79 percent at 2,896.80.
Foreign exchange markets were also waiting for Greenspan, although the dollar pushed to a 71-month high against the mark.
"It's hard to see what he can do to hurt dollar/mark," said Jesper Dannesboe, treasury economist at ABN-Amro in London. "The U.S. economy is slowing down and there is little sign of inflation picking up."
The dollar hit 1.8057 marks but one German bank dealer said: "Volume is very low and will be until we see what Greenspan comes out with."
It was also firm against the yen at 116.22 but failed to hold above last week's high of about 116.50.
CURRENCIES AT 0930 GMT
The dollar was at 1.8057 marks and 116.22 yen, compared with 1.7952 and 115.70 in late trading on Friday.
STOCK MARKETS AT 0930 GMT
LONDON - The FTSE-100 index was up 24.0 points or 0.5 percent at 4,829.7.
FRANKFURT - The DAX index rose 101.1 points or 2.46 percent to 4,209.5.
PARIS - The CAC-40 was up 22.68 points or 0.79 percent at 2,896.80.
PRECIOUS METALS
Gold was at $326.05 after closing at $326.95 an ounce on Monday. Silver was up one cent at $4.29.

headline: Treasuries up in London, await Greenspan's wisdom.
text:
U.S. Treasuries edged up in London on Tokyo and New York levels on Tuesday, patiently awaiting a presentation on the economy from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, traders said.
Treasuries were vulnerable to a setback after their recent rally but it was unlikely Greenspan would say much to significantly dent a market flourishing in near-optimal economic conditions, they said.
"We've been a very cautious mode since last Thursday preparing for Mr. Greenspan to give us his words of wisdom today," said a trader at a U.S. bank in London.
"I think we are going to be higher at the end of the week than we are now. He's going to give himself a pat on the back and say his usual things about being vigilant (on inflation) and I think the market can take that as being the right stance," he said.
Greenspan delivers the first leg of his semi-annual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony on monetary policy and economic conditions to a House Banking subcommittee at 1800 GMT. He presents the second part on Wednesday to a Senate banking panel.
Many analysts expect Greenspan to say the economy was growing in a benign inflationary environment but price pressures could never be totally stamped out.
The benchmark long bond was quoted at 101-05, yielding 6.533 percent at 0949 GMT, compared with 101-02 in Tokyo and 101-03 at New York's close on Monday.
Two year notes were steady at 100-04, yielding 5.928 percent. Analysts say two year notes usually yield around 65 to 70 basis points over the federal funds rate when interest rate policy is deemed to be neutral.
With the fed funds target rate now at 5.50 percent, this is where the market could take a severe hit if Greenspan says comes out with anything hawkish. The Eurodollars futures strip was also looking overpriced.
An auction of $15.5 billion of two year notes on Tuesday and a $11.5 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday could also weigh on the short-to-medium end of the curve, they said.
Peter Osler, head of research at British brokerage GNI in London, markets would be also wary about anything Greenspan says about simmering U.S. equities after his thoughts last year on so-called irrational exuberance in markets sent shares diving.
"I don't think he will want to scare the markets but he may bring that up again and he may highlight that risks are on the upside for the economy," he said. "But I don't think we're going to get a hugely sharp reaction."
--Jacqueline Thorpe, International Bonds Unit +44 171 542 6176

headline: Enterprise signs oil lease deal with Greece.
text:
Britain's Enterprise Oil Plc said on Tuesday it had signed lease agreements with the Greek government to explore two blocks in onshore Greece.
They are the first oil exploration and production contracts signed between Greece and foreign oil companies for many years, and are the results of awards made under the first International Licensing round, the company said in a statement.  
Enterprise Oil will hold a 40 percent stake in the Ioannina and N.W. Peloponnesos blocks as operator.
Union Texas of the United States will hold 28 percent, Hungarian oil and gas company MOL 20 percent and Greece's Public Petroleum Corporation Exploration and Exploitation of Hydrocarbons SA 12 percent.
The blocks cover more than 6,000 square km and are located onshore western Greece.
Enterprise said the group will need to spend $37 million in a period of up to six years to support exploration activities, which will include drilling at least two exploration wells, one in each block.
"The Ioannina and N.W. Peloponnesos blocks share many similarities to the successful discoveries we have made onshore Italy in the southern Apennines," said Iain Paterson, International Director of Enterprise Oil.
-- London newsroom +44 171 542 4365

headline: Dlr/mark above 1.81, highest since Aug 91-dealers.
text:
The dollar traded above 1.81 marks in Europe for the first time since August 1991, said dealers.
Dollar/mark touched a high of 1.8102 marks in morning Europe. By 0951 GMT, the dollar stepped back slightly, trading at 1.8088/98 compared with 1.7960/70 marks late Monday in Europe.
-- London forex, +44 171 542 6745

headline: IPE oil futures edge higher, seek direction.
text:
IPE Brent crude gas and oil futures were slightly firmer in early trade on Tuesday, but traders said the market would hold just above opening levels, waiting for further direction.
By 0937 GMT September Brent was seven cents firmer at $18.16 a barrel with gas oil 25 cents higher at $162.75 a tonne.
"A test of the lower range is favoured today, but there is no point getting too bearish while support levels hold," GNI Research said in a report.
GNI on Monday pegged potential support at $17.95, $17.85-80, $17.60, $17.45/50 and $17.30.
Brokers said news Iraq would on Tuesday formally present its aid distribution plan to the United Nations would not affect the market.
"It's an old story. The Iraq news is already built into the market," one broker said.
Prices were little moved on Monday when the U.N. said it had received a copy of Baghdad's aid plan.
Acceptance of the plan was an Iraqi condition for the resumption of its crude exports.
Iraq needs to sell around 1.5 million barrels of crude per day to raise the $1 billion it needs to buy humanitarian aid before the deal ends in September.
The second phase of the oil-deal started on June 8.
--Simon Gardner, London Newsroom + 44 171 542 7714

headline: INSIGHT -T-bonds' upside seen capped at 114-15.
text:
Positive feedback from the U.S. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan on Tuesday may give a quick boost to T-bonds but any gains are likely to be capped at 114-15 and a consolidation period beckons, technical analysts said.
Tom Hobson, director of technical analysis at Merrill Lynch in London, said the market had been suffering from fatigue since setting a high of 115-02 last week. It has since failed to get to the top of a two-and-a-half month bull channel at 114-15.
A negative response from Greenspan's key Humphrey-Hawkins testimony at 1800 GMT however could push the September T-bond contract down to 113-00, which would likely hold.
"The directional risk over the short term has shifted to the downside, but the market, with no major support levels violated, still has not reversed this medium term bullish tone," Hobson said.
By 0910 GMT, September T-bonds were trading at 114-02 in automated trade, up 2/32 on the day. At the short-end December Eurodollars gained 0.005 to 94.050.
Hobson said some of the long positions had been liquidated ahead of the Greenspan speech, but support was intact at 113-30, which triggered consistent buying last week, and more crucially at 113-13, a 38.2 retracement of the July rally.
"A break below 113-00 would pretty much confirm a reversal of the July rally and most likely trigger additional liquidation," said Hobson.
Analysts at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell said in a research note it would be hard to scoot to new highs even after a friendly testimony from Greenspan, although this should allow the market to hold the July 15 low of 113-07.
"Look for the market to edge down to at least 113-15/10 in here as per our wave measurements with possible support around 113-23/21," DMG analysts said.
A move below 113-07 however would set the stage for losses to 112-29, and even down to 111-26.
Hobson said a positive reaction could fuel the market to 114-19, a selling area last week, with the next target being 114-30.
"I would be more interested in selling 114-30, then I would be buying 113-02, because I think the market is generally tired here," said Hobson.
He said he expected the market to be rangebound within 113-00 and 115-00 in the medium-term.

headline: UK parliamentary committee to debate FIDS Tuesday.
text:
The British parliamentary committee examining the Finance Bill implementing this month's budget will consider the clause relating to Foreign Income Dividends (FIDS) later on Tuesday, committee members said.
They said they expected debate on the issue to begin at 1530 GMT.
The opposition Conservatives are harshly critical of proposals by Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown to abolish FIDS from April 1999, which they claim could drive some major companies abroad.
But their economy spokesman, Peter Lilley, said on Tuesday there were "smoke signals from the Treasury" indicating there might be some accommodation to protect international holding companies.
He noted that in a written parliamentary answer on Monday, Financial Secretary Dawn Primarolo said: "Provision will be made in the next Finance Bill to ensure that international headquarter companies can continue to pay dividends out of foreign income without having to pay advance corporation tax."
"It is a quite clear promise of a concession," Lilley told reporters.
He said he hoped ministers would give further details of their plans during the debate in the committee.
-- London Newsroom +44 171 542 7767

headline: BZW back under microscope over loss reports.
text:
British investment bank BZW is under renewed scrutiny amid reports of heavy trading losses in its equities division.
But the firm dismissed suggestions of losses on stock market linked derivative deals as "rumour and speculation".
"We never comment on our trading," a BZW spokesman told Reuters on Tuesday.
But traders said certain derivatives positions had gone against BZW and other investment banks because of government tax changes and could amount to overall losses of around 600 million pounds ($1 billion).
Shares in BZW's parent Barclays Plc were up 8-1/2 pence at 12.47-1/2 pounds on Tuesday after falling 44 pence on Monday.
It has not been an easy six months for BZW amid persistent rumours it was about to be hived off by Barclays, even though these rumours were denied by its chairman Andrew Buxton last month.
But whatever the long term outlook is for BZW, analysts expect the investment bank to drag Barclays' first half results down when the group reports next month.
Some analysts think Barclays has paid a heavy price on recruiting personnel and setting up the necessary infrastructure to make BZW one of the world's top investment banks.
BZW chief executive Bill Harrison, hired from Robert Fleming last year, was paid 2.852 million pounds in 1996, including a signing bonus of 1.5 million pounds in cash.
It then embarked on a high-profile hiring and firing spree in an attempt to rebuild itself.
This process, combined with an unpopular move to the Canary Wharf development in London's Docklands area to the east of the City, has resulted in a higher-than-usual staff turnover.
The latest high-profile departure came only last week when British finance and tobacco group B.A.T Industries Plc said Patrick O'Sullivan, BZW's chief operating officer, was joining its Eagle Star insurance arm as chief executive.
While insiders say these factors have been overdone by those outside the group, analysts and institutional investors are so far unconvinced enough has been done to turn BZW around.
"BZW is the main problem area for the group," analysts at Lehman Brothers said in a recent research note on the bank.
Barclays was unlikely to be prepared to commit the necessary resources, and "until the longer term strategy for the business is clearer, BZW is likely to continue to be seen by investors as diluting the value of the group".
It said the inclusion of BZW within another large investment banking group would be a potential solution to the longer term issues, but pointed out it contains treasury functions Barclays would need to retain.
Lehman Brothers' analysts said BZW's return-on-equity was only eight percent in 1996, even though it deploys a third of group risk assets.
The latest rumours of losses in its equities division were prompted by the departure last week of Mike Gaeton, deputy head of proprietory trading in this area.
A BZW spokesman declined to give any detail on why Gaeton had left the firm. "We just comment on individuals," he told Reuters when asked if Gaeton's contract would be honoured.
Gaeton, who was reported to have resigned, had been at the firm for at least 10 years.
BZW's U.S. operation BZW Securities has also been in the headlines in recent days, with reports it is being probed by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over compliance at its New York equities trading business.
But BZW said the matter was "an isolated incident" which took place at the beginning of 1996 and was restricted to two examples of the incorrect completion of error report forms.
The firm's spokesman confirmed four people had left the New York office but he declined to say if the SEC was investigating the episode or reports BZW had absorbed trading losses incurred by clients. ($ = 0.597 British Pounds)

headline: Midland Bank withdraws 50 mln stg FRN increase.
text:
Midland Bank has withdrawn its 50 million stg increase of a subordinated structured 10-year FRN because the proceeds did not qualify as lower tier two capital, lead manager HSBC Markets said on Tuesday.
"The Bank of England was not prepared to count it as lower tier two capital because it was 29 days short of a full five years," an HSBC syndicate manager said.
The deal, nominally due in June 2007, is likely to be called in June 2002, otherwise the coupon steps up to three-month LIBOR plus 70 basis points from three-month LIBOR plus 20 b.p.
That June 2002 date means the 50 million stg increase launched on July 16 with a July 29 payment date will not run for a full five years, the minimum period required by the Bank of England for subordinated debt to qualify as lower tier two capital.
The 150 million stg originally launched on June 2 is unaffected.
-- Dan Lalor, London newsroom +44 171 542 8863

headline: BA down as DMG says switch into Lufthansa.
text:
Shares in British Airways Plc dropped on Tuesday as analysts at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell cut the stock to "neutral" from "overweight" and advised investors to switch into Lufthansa, dealers said.  
BA shares were down 18-1/2p to 644 by 0908 GMT in volume of 2.4 million shares. Lufthansa was up 1.50 marks at 33.90.
DMG analyst Jurgen Pieper said he saw Lufthansa as currently enjoying the more positive earnings momentum, adding that he had raised the German carrier to "overweight" from "neutral."  
Having for some time seen BA as the prime choice in the European aviation sector, Pieper said he now expected Lufthansa to catch up in terms of sales growth and in cost savings.
"The momentum is clearly stronger for Lufthansa," he said. "Revenue growth and cost savings are improving."
Dealers were surprised by the sharp move in BA shares, and said there were also continued worries over the impact of the strike action that the company is currently facing.
The company is due later this week to hold talks with unions representing cabin crews, whose 72-hour strike earlier this month hit hundreds of flights and led analysts to lower their earnings expectations.
-- David Holmes, London Newsroom +44 171 542 4367

headline: IBCA GIVES BANKERS INS CO CLAIMS SETTLING RATING.
text:
IBCA, the European rating agency, has assigned a Claims Settling Ability rating of BBB+E (Adequate security with explicit support) for Bankers Insurance Company Limited (BICL) based in High Wycombe, England.
BICL is part of the Bankers Insurance Group in the UK which is ultimately owned by American Bankers Insurance Group based in Miami, Florida, USA.
Following a period of deteriorating results, positive intervention by American Bankers Insurance Group has resulted in significant changes. A new management team has been installed, with Tom Anderson as the new Managing Director.
GBP10million has been injected into the company with a guarantee of additional capital if required. The company has re-entered the Creditor and Warranty insurance sectors, bringing it more in line with the business written by American Bankers Insurance Company, following the expiry of a non-compete agreement related to the sale of Financial Insurance Group in the late 1980s.
BICL enjoys the full support of American Bankers Insurance Group, one of the oldest and the largest insurers of Creditor and Warranty business in the world. This, in IBCA's view is an essential part of the future success and development of the company.
A comprehensive business plan outlining the future aims and aspirations of the company is in place and being achieved.
IBCA believes that these changes and the adoption of many of the historically profitable underwriting principles and reserving practices used by American Bankers Insurance Group will significantly improve results.
In the agency's opinion, the company - with the continued support from, and close working relationship with American Bankers Insurance Group - is on target to breakeven in 1997 and return a pre-tax profit for 1998 year end. Monday, 21 July 1997 15:15:44

headline: Nationwide - UK house prices rise 10.1% y/y in Q2.
text:
British house prices were 10.1 percent higher in the second quarter than in the same period in 1996, the Nationwide Building Society said on Tuesday.
Prices were 2.8 percent higher in Q2, on a seasonally adjusted basis, than they were in the first quarter of the year but Britain's largest remaining building society insisted there was no sign of the housing market boosting consumer demand.
House price inflation remains highest in London where it is rocketing along at an annual 17.5 percent. Some slowing in growth was seen over the last three months in the capital but it was still the only area of the country to enjoy significant price rises in recent months.
Price increases in the capital have had an impact on adjacent areas but the Nationwide said price rises were weaker further north while the turnover of property transactions has been fairly flat across the country so far this year.
London is no exception in that respect, with turnover at about 13 percent compared with nearly 20 percent at the height of the 1980s boom.
"The improvement in the housing market is spreading outwards from London, where demand and supply imbalances are being resolved to some extent," said Paul Sanderson, Nationwide's head of research.
"However, turnover levels remain relatively low everywhere and contrast sharply with experience during the 1980s."
There was no sign of equity withdrawal re-emerging on a large scale to fund high street spending. Windfall payments from building societies converting into banks has had a far greater effect there.
"There is no evidence that the housing market is directly contributing to consumer demand as it did in the 1980s," the Nationwide said.
The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said house prices faltered in June in the run up to Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown's first budget on July 2.
But as it turned out it said the budget measures, cutting mortgage interest tax relief and raising stamp duty only on very expensive houses, did little to take any steam out of the market.
Sanderson at Nationwide agreed. "The recovery clearly has further to go and the outlook should not be significantly affected by the relatively modest measures announced in the Budget," he said.
"The main risk now is the threat of high interest rates aimed at dampening consumer demand although evidence suggests spending is not being directly driven by the housing market."
-- Mike Peacock, London Newsroom +44 171 542 7708

headline: BOE allots 225 mln stg in UK repo.
text:
The Bank of England allotted 225 million stg in repos to the UK money market in an early round of assistance after forecasting a liquidity shortage of around 1.6 billion stg.
The repos are to August 5 & 6 and the repo rate was unchanged at 6.75 percent.

headline: INTERVIEW - Littlewoods defends strategy.
text:
British home shopping and football pools group Littlewoods on Tuesday defended a decision to keep most of its town centre stores, reversing earlier plans to sell them.
Chairman James Ross said the Littlewoods' board had looked at a whole array of offers for its shops, including some for the entire 135 strong chain, but had decided a sale would not maximise value for shareholders in the privately held group.
"We have definitely decided not to sell the stores (division) in its entirety because to do so would have been to destroy substantial value in the process," he told Reuters in an interview.
Littlewoods, owned by the multi-millionaire Moores family, last month abandoned plans to sell its entire chain of shops, saying it would sell only selected sites. Last week it announced the sale of 19 shops to rival Marks and Spencer Plc for 192.5 million pounds.  
Reports in the British press on Monday suggested some Littlewoods' shareholders were unhappy with the M&S deal, which will mean redundancies of between 1,700 and 1,800.
The articles also gave details of a 540 million stg offer for Littlewoods 135 shops from venture capital firm CVC Partners, which they said was still on the table. But Littlewoods responded saying that CVC had not made a clean cash offer that would have allowed the group to exit the retailing business.
When asked about the press reports and the offer from CVC, Ross said, the board had tested the market and decided not to sell. He said the board had performed the normal job of any board to manage the process and make a recommendation to shareholders.
"No board of either a private or a quoted company...goes with all the details of every offer that is made to the shareholders and says please tell us what to do."
He said all the 32 Moores family members, who own Littlewoods, had signed up to a shareholder charter last April, which separated shareholder and board responsibilities.
This aimed to put an end to past squabbles over the direction of the group.
Shareholders will vote on the sale to M&S at a meeting in September, he said.  
-- London Newsroom + 44 171 542 7717

headline: Mark sinks again as wide, punctual EMU on course.
text:
The mark sank on its European cross rates on Tuesday as belief in a broad-based, timely start to European monetary union was reinforced by the French budget statement on Monday and Germany's effective endorsement of it.
A fresh bout of mark selling was again concentrated against the dollar, which successfully cleared 1.80 marks, and sterling. But the move also filtered through to a weaker mark against European units like the French franc, lira and Swedish crown.
The Swiss franc too was a major beneficiary of rekindled concerns about the stability of the single currency, reinforced by its traditional haven status and the Swiss economic recovery.  
"France has effectively given up trying to get to 3.0 percent (budget deficit/output ratio) this year and Germany has effectively endorsed this," said Nick Parsons, foreign exchange strategist at Banque Paribas.
"The perception this creates and the comments we've heard from the Bundesbank since can only encourage buying of Swiss francs, as well as the dollar and sterling."
Bundesbank council members Hans-Juergen Krupp and and Ernst Welteke stressed late Monday that the Maastricht Treaty does not require a deficit/GDP ratio of exactly 3.0 pct. Their colleague Hans Juergen Koebnick endorsed that view today.  
Koebnick said he did not think the stability of the euro would be compromised if Germany and France had deficits in the region of 3.2-to-3.3 percent of GDP.
The Bundesbank comments followed the announcement from French Finance Minister Dominque Strauss-Kahn on Monday of public deficit cuts worth about 0.4 percent of gross domestic product. The cuts are aimed at reducing a 1997 deficit estimated to be running at between 3.5 and 3.7 percent of GDP at present.
German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said he was convinced of Strauss-Kahn's commitment to meeting the deficit goals but declined to say whether the French measures Monday were enough.  
While there is some debate as to the degree of investor concern about a wide EMU or what exactly a "soft" euro would entail, traders said the uncertainty is a major factor.
On one hand European inflation and budget deficits are falling, European bonds and equities are robust and the signs gradual economic recovery are evident in Germany.
"The problem is what sort of interest rate policy the European central bank will conduct for a wide EMU area," said a trader at a UK fund manager in London. "It's relatively predictable for Germany France and Benelux, but when you include Italy and Spain the picture becomes muddier."  
The market assumption is that if France and Germany agree that overshooting deficit targets is now acceptable, then it will much more difficult to exclude the traditionally volatile Italian lira from the launch of the single currency.
The argument is not all one way, however. Some analysts believe a constitutionally independent European central bank will offset any fiscal laxity with a tight monetary policy, not least to establish its inflation-fighting credentials.
There is also the fact that European countries starting EMU will have in excess of $200 billion of foreign exchange reserves to defend the new currency.  
This view is countered, however, by concerns the ECB will come under increasing political influence to keep interest rates low and the exchange rate soft while Europe restructures.
The weak state of the European economy was highlighted today by the bigger-than-expected 1.6 percent drop in French industrial output in May.
At 0942 GMT, mark/French franc was at 3.3723/26 versus 3.3738/41 late Monday. Mark/Swiss was at 0.8201/02 versus 0.8215/18. Mark/Swedish crown fell to its lowest since last October and was last at 4.3160/90 compared with 4.3260/90 Monday.
--Mike Dolan, London newsroom +44 171 542 6762
