headline: Booker rises, UBS repeats positive stance.
text:
Shares in UK food distributor Booker Plc climbed seven percent after house broker UBS reiterated its positive stance on the stock.
Booker shares climbed 17.5p to 264.5p by 0845 GMT as analysts at UBS said the stock looked a little oversold.  
Booker shares have fallen from highs of 403p over the past eight months as exceptional charges of 89 million stg dragged 1996 profits lower.
The company said in May group sales had risen 36 percent in the first four months of this financial year. The figures were boosted by the recently acquired Nurdin & Peacock cash-and-carry business.
-- London Newsroom +44 171 542 7717

headline: LME Copper to dip, but not collapse -MG official.
text:
LME three month copper could slip to $2,200 or $2,150 per tonne in coming weeks as tightness evaporates and stocks keep building during the seasonally slow summer period, a London official of Germany's Metallgesellschaft said.
But the global copper market will end the year roughly in balance before moving into a clear surplus in 1998, Christian Schirmeister, Associate Director of Client Liaison for the firm's metals subsidiary Metallgesellschaft Ltd, told Reuters in an interview.
"We would not be surprised if stocks continue to rise, if business is slowing down, to see prices a little bit lower... $2,200, $2,150, in that area, would be no surprise," he said on Monday.
"We don't see the price collapsing, we see the price trying to find a new way," he added.
On Tuesday morning, three month prices were hovering just below the previous afternoon's kerb close of $2,319 per tonne.
Stocks have increased by 74,400 tonnes since bottoming at 121,550 tonnes in late June. An 11,550-tonne rise on Tuesday brought the total to 195,950 tonnes.
"We felt that between 50-70,000 tonnes of copper could have been attracted by the LME. Now we have seen more than 50 (thousand tonnes) going in already," Schirmeister said. "I expect another good tonnage coming up for this week."
Analysts say some metal is being sucked in by a strong backwardation, other material is arriving due to the summer slowdown while Far East metal ended up in the Singapore warehouse due to lacklustre conditions in the region.
Technical tightness caused the cash/threes backwardation to flare to $270 last week and the nearby spreads to trade up to LME-imposed limits. LME chief executive David King said last week he was continuing to watch the copper market.
In response to a question, Schirmeister said to his knowledge, MG had not been contacted by the LME regarding the latest backwardation.
The MG official said he was not bothered by market talk suggesting that MG holds long positions and squeezes the market.
MG was one of the largest LME brokers and its primary focus was keeping its clients happy, he said.
The market has been wrong about a looming surplus for the past three years due to higher than expected consumption and delays in getting new mines on line.
"At the moment we would call it a balanced market...but it will definitely swing over to higher production in coming years...not '97 but '98 could be the first one," he said.
Schirmeister said the market would be in surplus when the balance was tipped by 100,000 tonnes, since often there was that much tonnage in the pipeline being delivered throughout the world. --Eric Onstad, London Newsroom +44 171 542-8065

headline: CU new business figures lifts shares.
text:
Shares in British insurer Commercial Union rose on Tuesday, helped by strong growth in new business in the first half of the year.
Commercial Union shares added 6 pence to 700-1/2 pence after the group reported a 21 percent rise in worldwide new business to 1.58 billion stg in the first six months of 1997.
Analysts said the figures continued the growth trend seen in the first quarter, particularly in Poland and Italy.
New single premiums worldwide were up 17 percent to 1.22 billion stg over the period and new annual premiums up 38 percent to 154 million stg.  
"The problem CU has had from an investors standpoint has really been the currency impact -- it is a heavily European-based group. Aside from that and the weakness of the French life market, the group is doing very well in a number of territories," said one.
Chief executive John Carter described the performance as very good.
"Our Netherlands company, Delta Lloyd, and our UK business produced strong growth and an excellent level of new business was achieved in Italy and Poland," he said.
UK single premium sales rose 75 percent to 265 million stg and new annual premiums four percent to 25 million stg.
Single premium business at Delta Lloyd increased 51 percent to 120 million stg and annual premium new business was 31 percent higher at 33 million stg.
Commercial Union said that consumer uncertainty surrounding the recent elections and the reorganisation of the sales force in France had an adverse effect on sales.
"The French problems were no surprise and the currency does exacerbate the position," said an analyst.
Single premium sales in France amounted to 624 million stg, including a 295 million stg contribution from AFER, down 15 percent after adjusting for exchange rate movements.
Annual premium sales were 11 million, down 30 percent.
-- London Newsroom +44 171 542 5106

headline: INTERVIEW - Stagecoach aims for Euro bus buys.
text:
Rail-to-bus group Stagecoach Plc is set to continue its expansion spending spree on the European Continent, but said the UK bus business would be grown organically due to inflated prices.
"UK bus acquisition prices at the moment are too high due to regulatory uncertainty. So we will aim for organic growth," Stagecoach group finance director, Brian Cochrane, told Reuters in an interview.
He said the main tools for this would be new pricing initiatives and promotions. But he added Stagecoach was continuing to scour the Continent for a follow-up deal to its SweBus(Swedish Bus)acquisition last year.  
The finance chief said the group was more likely to target overseas deals in buses before rail. "The bus market is at a more advanced stage (in the privatisation process).
"So it is likely we will initially make deals on the bus side. But in the long-term we would like to capitalise on our experience with SWT (South West Trains rail franchise) and Porterbrook (the rolling stock group)."
Cochrane said the group remained confident that even without deal-making in the UK it could maintain passenger growth in its domestic bus business. It reported passenger growth of 1.7 percent last year against a market that declined by 2-2.5 percent.  
Barry Hinkley, executive director with responsibility for buses, told Reuters this constituted real growth of four percent and he was confident the pace could continue.
But one problem area in the overseas bus empire is African business in Malawi and Kenya.
The Malawi business is seen to be more problematic, with margins being eroded by unregulated competition in the country.
Cochrane said the business was under review as a result. "The business has suffered and we are looking at the options open to us. One option is to downsize the business to a profitable core and focus on the intercity routes."  
The Kenyan woes stem from the recent flaring up of political unrest due to demands by opposition politicians for democratic elections. Stagecoach was less perturbed by this development, however, seeing the situation eventually resolving itself.
Turning to the impact of the strong pound on its financial performance, Cochrane said its effect had been fairly limited so far and mainly stemmed from sterling's appreciation against the Swedish currency, with the exposure in Africa fairly limited due to the small size of the operations.
But he refused to be drawn on the current year's potential impact as the pound flirts above the three Deutsche mark level.  
He added the threat of higher interest rates being levied on Stagecoach's sizeable debt was not a pressing concern as 95 percent of the group's interest costs were fixed.
Cochrane said group gearing had been reduced "substantially" over the last year "reflecting the strong cash generation of our businesses." Stagecoach was therefore not constrained by its debt in future expansion ambitions, he said.
--By Edna Fernandes, London newsroom +44 171 5427717.

headline: Arjo Wiggins to shed 160 jobs in the U.S..
text:
Appleton Papers Inc, the main U.S. subsidiary of British paper manufacturer Arjo Wiggins Appleton Plc, said on Tuesday it was planning to close down certain older and less cost-effective equipment at its Newton Falls mill.
The closure would result in loss of 160 jobs, the company said.  
The company said the closure was part of its efforts to improve its position in America's coated free sheet paper market in which it made its debut in June 1995.
Arjo bought the Newton Falls mill in New York and began expansion of is Combined Locks facility in Wisconsin. Total investment in these projects was $210 million stg.
--London Newsroom +44 171 542 4366

headline: IPE gas oil seen 50 cents up, Brent up 5-10 cents.
text:
IPE gas oil futures were called to open 50 cents higher on Tuesday, while Brent crude was expected to open around 5-10 cents higher, but the market was in a holding pattern waiting to be given direction, brokers said.
IPE August gas oil was anticipated to open 50 cents higher at around $163.00 a tonne, after settling on Monday at $162.50.
September Brent closed just one cent lower at $18.09 a barrel, after bouncing off key support at the the $18 mark.
Brokers said news that Iraq was on Tuesday due to formally present its aid distribution plan to the United Nations was already factored into the market.
"Brent is just holding reasonably well. So much of the Iraq news is already built in to the market. I don't see it having much affect," one broker said.

headline: Brown awaits LPC report before UK low wage decision.
text:
Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown said on Tuesday reports that he wanted the proposed UK minimum wage to be set at less than four pounds per hour were speculation.
He added that he was awaiting a report from the low pay commission before making a decision on the appropriate rate.
"We've now got a low pay commission which is sitting and looking at this thing...They will look at the issue and they will come back with what I hope is a sensible recommendation," Brown said on BBC Radio 4's Today programme.
Asked whether he himself wanted the rate to be under four pounds, he said "Well I think this is all speculation. What I've supported and what the government has done is set up a low pay commission... and I think it's quite important that we listen to their recommendations before making a decision," he said.
Brown said that most people agreed with the principle of minimum wages because "they give a degree of dignity that is necessary in any civilised society but, of course, it depends on the rate at which the minimum wage is implemented."
Brown said that every country which was more successful than Britain, including the U.S., had a minimum wage.
A report released this morning by the international Monetary Fund voiced general approval for the new Labour government's economic policies since seizing power at the May 1 election but cautioned that a minimum wage was "a blunt instrument for achieving a fair income distribution and a two-edged sword for rewarding work if set too high."
--Cheryl Juckes +44 171 542 5109

headline: Diana expected to attend Versace memorial service.
text:
Princess Diana, former wife of heir to the British throne Prince Charles, is expected to fly to Italy on Tuesday for the memorial service of murdered fashion king Gianni Versace.
Diana, who said she was devastated by the killing last week of Versace in Miami, was reported by newspapers to be intent on attending a memorial service on Tuesday evening at Milan's main Roman Catholic cathedral.
A spokeswoman at Diana's office declined to confirm the reports but told Reuters; "The Princess is aware of the arrangements for the memorial service. If she does attend, it will be in a private capacity."
Diana, one of the most photographed women in the world, made an exception to her preference for the work of British designers to wear Versace clothes and often spoke of her friendship for him.
The Italian designer paid tribute to the princess by naming a handbag after her -- the Lady Di.

headline: Bahrain arrests 24 including children - opposition.
text:
An exiled Bahraini opposition group said on Tuesday Bahrain had arrested 24 Shi'ite Moslems over the past seven days in connection with political unrest in the Gulf Arab state.
The Bahrain Freedom Movement said in a statement sent to an international news agency that 14 children were among those held including a seven-year-old girl from the Shi'ite village of Bani Jamra, some 12 km (seven miles) west of the capital Manama.
They were held in various areas of Bahrain, it said, adding some had been freed but others were still in detention.
"The fate of Iman Hassan Ibrahim, seven, was not yet known after she was summoned by police...for questioning. She lives with her parents in Bani Jamra area," the movement said.
The claim could not be immediately confirmed.
Bahraini officials have repeatedly denied the arrest of children but they say that the Gulf Arab state sometimes summoned people for questioning over acts of violence.
More than 30 people had been killed on the island since anti-government protests, bombings and arson attacks by Bahrain's majority Shi'ite community started in December 1994. Hundreds of people had been detained.

headline: Stagecoach rolls higher after profit soars.
text:
Shares in UK transport business Stagecoach Holdings Plc rose in early business after the company announced annual profit had almost trebled.
The shares were 10.5p higher at 747.5p at 0736 GMT after opening at 757.5p.  
"These are quality results from an increasingly quality company," said analyst Nigel Hawkins of Yamaichi.
"They have scotched concerns about the Porterbrook acquisition," he added.
Acquisitions helped Stagecoach to increase profits almost threefold to 120.5 million stg. Total dividend rose to 9.0p from 6.7p.
The company has expanded from being purely a UK bus operator by buying the Porterbrook rolling stock company and winning the SWT regional rail franchise in Britain. It has also purchased the largest bus and coach operator in Scandinavia.
Richard Hannah of UBS said the results had been better than his 112 million stg forecast. He also identified Porterbrook as a key element in the better than expected earnings.
-- London Newsroom +44 171 542 7717

headline: INSIGHT- BTPs aim to capture 137.10 contract high.
text:
September BTP futures on LIFFE will try to conquer their 137.10 peak on Tuesday after a strong rally that saw critical hurdles wiped out on Monday, technical analysts said.
Martin Scott, analyst at MCM YieldWatch in London said Monday's bounce from the Fibonacci level of 135.85 and the close above 136.52 suggested further gains were likely short-term.
The September contract has already taken out the initial resistance of 136.75 and by 0730 GMT it stood 0.42 higher on the day at 136.98.
Scott said the target now was the contract high of 137.10.

headline: UK shares marked higher after steady Dow close.
text:
UK shares opened higher on Tuesday after two days of sharp declines, with nerves steadied by a firm close on Wall Street and as the International Monetary Fund said UK rates may rise less than expected.
Down 143.3 points in the past two sessions, the FTSE 100 was up 13.3 points at 4,819.0 by 0734 GMT, with gainers in an eight-to-one majority.
But gains were expected to be held in check ahead of Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's twice-yearly Humphrey-Hawkins testimony to U.S. legislators on the state of the world's biggest economy.

headline: UK's Ascot Holdings sells S. African unit.
text:
British diversified industrial and services company Ascot Holdings Plc said on Tuesday it had sold its only South African subsidiary, Refrigeration Investment Company Pty Ltd, to a Danish group, Danfoss A/S, for 16.7 million stg.  
Danfoss is a supplier of controls for refrigeration, air conditioning, heating and water valves.
Of the total consideration, Ascot will receive 14.7 million cash while the balance covers borrowings.
The sale proceeds will be used to reduce Ascot's bank borrowings.
---London Newsroom +44 171 542 4366

headline: INSIGHT - Notionnel eyes upside, must break 130.60.
text:
September notionnel futures traded on MATIF have an upward bias, but must first overcome resistance at the July 17 high of 130.60, technical analysts said on Tuesday.
Once above there, the contract will have a chance of reaching the contract high of 130.88 set on July 9.
"The momentum picture isn't great, but for choice the upside is the bias," said Gerry Celaya, senior technical analyst at American Express Bank in London.
September notionnel futures were trading up 30 basis points at 130.52 by 0725 GMT, after reaching a high of 130.58 earlier.  
Celaya said the U.S. markets were likely to provide the impetus for major moves in European markets. Testimony by the Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, due at 1800 GMT, would deter investors from taking positions this session, Celaya said.
But if the contract high could be overcome, that would spur further gains, he added.
"Through 130.88 is a great move," Celaya said. "It would take the market to 131.00 and 131.50."
A technical analyst at a European bank in London said he was targeting 132.00, and he noted the market should continue to hold above the 129.50 level.  
Celaya saw support in a band around Monday's high of 130.38.
Monday's low of 130.08 was the next support, followed by 129.80, the low hit on July 15 and July 4.
At the short end, September Pibor futures were up 0.05 at 96.55. The analyst at the European bank said the market had continued in correction mode after last week's bearish break from a small triangular pattern.
He cited good support in the mid 96.40s, while 96.55 and 96.60 are the two overhead hurdles the market will have to negotiate.

headline: Stagecoach to steam ahead on strong figures.
text:
Shares in UK transport business Stagecoach Holdings Plc were set to open higher on Tuesday after the company's results beat forecasts.
"These are quality results from an increasingly quality company," said analyst Nigel Hawkins of Yamaichi.
Acquisitions helped Stagecoach to increase profits almost threefold to 120.5 million stg. Total dividend rose to 9.0p from 6.7p.  
-- London Newsroom +44 171 542 7717

headline: INSIGHT -FTSE to stay on hold in 4,800-4,820 area.
text:
The FTSE 100 should at least hold on to the 4,800 level on Tuesday and perhaps climb as high at 4,820 on relief that Wall Street managed to halt its recent decline and manage a small comeback overnight, technical analysts said.
Investors in the UK market may still be numbed after two days of sharp falls -- in which the FTSE lost 143 points or nearly three percent of its value. Some players will be wary about rushing back into the market and this should make for a slow session today, they added.
By 0715 GMT, the FTSE was indicated down 0.1 at 4,805.6.  
On Monday, the Dow Jones industrials struggled to find its feet and closed up 16.26 to 7,906.72. Over the past two days, the Dow has lost 114 points, or 1.4 percent.
But there is still investor uneasiness about the state of the U.S. market and an adverse reaction may still occur in New York which would upset UK shares, analysts said. This general uncertainty is expected to limit the FTSE's near-term upside to around the 4,820 level, they said.
But a positive view is that by not beating the FTSE down below 4,800 on Monday, market bears have allowed the bulls an opportunity to make a stand around current levels.  
The market had appeared technically overbought late last week but the 143-point plunge since then has made the FTSE's short-term oscillators now show neutral readings.
Amid such readings, the market has an evens chance of making a swift recovery, analysts said.
But trend analysis of the market -- using trendlines and moving averages -- suggest the probability is more in favour of a cautious move up with the FTSE's 20-day moving average providing near-term support.
The 20 day average is currently at 4,787.
-- Pradip Mishra, London Newsroom +44 171 542 7954

headline: Atlantic Telecom lines rise to 12,926 to Q2.
text:
Britain's Atlantic Telecom Group Plc said on Tuesday its number of telecommunications lines increased to 12,926 at end-June from 9,322 at end-March.  
"The continued rise in the number of lines at a rate in excess of our expectations is very encouraging," chairman Graham Duncan said in a statement.
The company said that lines connected in Glasgow increased by 109 percent over the quarter.
It said the network is continuing to be built up and it is expected that the whole of Glasgow, representing around 42 base stations, will be complete and operational by September 30.
Atlantic Telecom said that it is launching a service across Scotland to areas where it is currently unable to provide customers directly. The indirect service will use British Telecommunications Plc's network and the group's own call routing boxes.
-- London Newsroom +44 171 542 4365

headline: Hercules Prop to buy David Glass.
text:
British property services company Hercules Property Services Plc said on Tuesday it had agreed to take over another UK property service firm David Glass Associates Plc for 8.3 million stg.  
According to the recommended offer, Hercules valued David Glass shares at 153 pence each. The offer is being made on the basis of 5.885 new Hercules shares for every 10 David Glass shares.
A full cash alternative of 133 pence per share was also available.
David Glass closed at 127-1/2 pence on the London Stock Exchange on Monday.
Hercules said it had received irrevocable undertakings of acceptances regarding 51.86 percent of shareholding in David Glass.
--London Newsroom +44 171 542 4366

headline: Littlewoods profits fall.
text:
Littlewoods, the privately-owned retailing-to-football pools group, said on Tuesday overall profits fell last year, but home shopping produced strong results.
The company said sales from its home shopping and Index catalogue business rose by 13 percent in the first 10 weeks of the current year.  
Chairman James Ross said current trading had been in line with expectations and home shopping's performance had been particularly encouraging.
The retailer, owned by the secretive multi-millionaire Moores family, is in the middle of a major restructuring, which originally included plans to sell its entire chain of around 135 stores.
The disposal plans were scaled back and Littlewoods decided to keep its stores division and sell only selected sites. Last week the company sold 19 shops to Marks and Spencer Plc for 192.5 million pounds ($322.1 million).
"Our strategy remains to focus on core home shopping and leisure businesses and to maximise value from our stores operations," Ross said in a statement.
The group reported pretax profits of 85.2 million pounds for the 12 months to April 30 1997, down from 90.7 million in the same period a year earlier. These figures were stated on a proforma basis, as the company is changing its year end. ($ = 0.597 British Pounds)

headline: Stagecoach profit almost triples.
text:
British transport group Stagecoach Plc on Tuesday posted a 176 percent jump in annual profits which reflected the impact of its recent acquisition spree and the first full-year contribution from South West Trains (SWT).
Pre-tax profit for the year to April 30 was 120.5 million pounds ($201.6 million) compared to 43.6 million a year earlier. Sales leapt to 1.152 billion pounds from 501.2 million. The dividend was raised to nine pence from 6.7 pence.  
Brian Souter, executive chairman, described the results as "excellent" after a year in which the company was dogged by criticism following widescale train cancellations on its SWT rail franchise.
"These achievements reflect further developments in our core bus businesses in the UK and overseas; a first full- year contribution from SWT; the impact of the current year acquisitions of Porterbrook and Swebus," Souter said.
It also includes 15.2 million in proceeds from the sale of a stake in Strathclyde Buses.
Stagecoach said the current year had "started well" and that prospects looked good. Souter said he believed the group's expansion programme would deliver "strong growth in earnings for the future".
Since the end of the results period, Stagecoach has concluded its acquisitions of Thames Transit Ltd and Docklands Transit Ltd for 8.2 million in cash , with a further one million linked to performance targets.
It has also finalised a 3.7 million pound acquisition of part of Transit Australia, a 120-strong bus operation in Queensland. ($ = 0.597 British Pounds)

headline: INSIGHT -Gilts trapped in range, resistance 115-05.
text:
September gilt futures on LIFFE will continue to comb a broad range with key resistance at the contract high of 115-05, technical analysts said on Tuesday.
Lynn Branigan, technical analyst at MCM YieldWatch in London said a breach of Monday's low of 114-11 however would pave the way for further losses to 113-30, the low last week.
"Daily stochastics, and RSI are all around 50's. It's not pointing in any direction," said Branigan.
He pegged initial resistance at around 114-25, around the intraday high on Monday and a break of 115-05 would clear the path for 115-09, he said.  
At 0708 GMT, September gilts were 3/32 up at at 114-18.
Branigan said below 113-30, a key trendline support drawn from lows in end-May came in at 113-15. That level would provide a strong support level in the short term.
Richard Adcock, manager of technical research at HSBC Futures said in a note to clients to continue trading the range while the September contract remained below 115-05.
The stochastic indictor has turned up but "prices remain within the formation with only penetrations of 115-05 completing the pattern opening the way for a sustainable advance through 116-00," Adcock said.  
Within the sideways range further support developed to see the market challenge the significant supply offered by 115-05 which held, prompting retreats into the close on Monday.
Adcock pegged resistance initially at 114-30 while support was at 114-16 followed by 114-04, but came in strongly at 113-24, the low on July 3.
At the short end of the curve, December short sterling stood 0.02 up on the day at 92.59.
Adcock said any gains should be used as an opportunity to add to existing short positions, with the next downside target being 92.40. To the upside stops should be placed at 92.70.

headline: UK sets BT interconnection charges.
text:
UK telecoms regulator Oftel on Tuesday laid out final plans for the way British Telecommunications Plc charges other network operators for carrying calls, saying such charges should fall by around 28 per cent in real terms over four years.
Oftel chief Don Cruickshank said that where there were as yet insufficient alternatives to using BT's network, average charges would be subject to charge caps and required to fall by eight percent below the rate of inflation.  
Oftel in May suggested a range of between six and 12 percent below inflation for such charge caps.
Cruickshank said in a statement that considering comments received on the range of assumptions and alternative forecasts such as growth of the markets, the changes in BT's share, the way BT's costs vary and the scope for improvements in BT's efficiency, eight percent was the right figure.
Oftel said the moves should mean even more competition in the UK telecoms market.
Under the new arrangements, Cruickshank said: - there will be no direct control over charges for services where network operators have a choice of suppliers - for services which are likely to become competitive by 2001 there will just be a safeguard cap so charges cannot increase in real terms - where there are as yet insufficient alternatives to using BT's network -- like call termination -- average charges will be subject to charge caps and required to fall by eight percent below the rate of inflation. The use of charge caps, like the familiar caps on retail prices, at the wholesale level is a new approach. It is much less interventionist than the current system under which Oftel determines the exact price for interconnection services. It will ensure that the sort of efficiency improvements that would be expected in a competitive market will be reflected in network charges.
Cruickshank said the system for assessing interconnection charges -- to such operators as Cable & Wireless Communications Plc -- would be changed from one based on historic, fully allocated costs to one based on forward-looking incremental costs.
The industry, including BT, agree this is the right way forward as do other regulators around the world, he said.
"Since historic costs are higher than future costs, the change means there is a reduction in the charges that will start from 1 October, compared with those that apply under the present arrangements. I expect this to be of the order of 10 percent."
"UK interconnection costs are already among the lowest in the world. Today's announcement means they are set to fall further still. The reductions should increase competition in telecoms services," the regulator added
--London Newsroom +44 171 542 7717

headline: INSIGHT -Bunds mired below 103.00/10 resistance.
text:
September Bund futures traded on LIFFE will find their upward path blocked by resistance from 103.00 up to a trendline at 103.10, technical analysts said on Tuesday.
"We could see more upticks initially to test resistance at yesterday's high of 102.80 and Friday's high of 102.90," said Gerry Celaya, senior technical analyst at American Express Bank in London. "But it's looking capped around the 103.00 area."
He said the market was uninspired this session, with momentum indicators neutral. The 14 day Relative Strength Index was at 61 percent in early trade.  
September Bund futures were up three basis points at 102.75 by 0655 GMT, after an early stab at the 102.80 resistance was rebuffed.
Trendline resistance comes in at the 103.10 level, Celaya said, drawn on the continuation chart to join the February 18 high of 104.04, the February 28 high of 103.98, and the July 14 high of 103.14.
"Above the trendline, it's clear sailing to 104.00," he said.
A technical analyst at a European bank said Bunds will first have to breach the 103.50 level before reaching 104.00.  
On the downside, a zone of congestion from 102.60 down to Monday's low of 102.53 was marked as initial support, while a break below there would bring congestion around 102.30 into the picture, analysts said. The next big level was the July 15 low of 102.17.
"The major risk area everyone's looking at is 102.00 down to 101.87, the June 16 high," said Celaya. "If it gets through there then 101.00 is possible."
The European bank analyst said the first real warning for the shorter term bears would be a slip through trendline support through the 102.30s. He said that would bring 101.70 into view.  
At the short end, December Euromarks were down 0.02 at 96.65. Monday's high of 96.67 was acting as initial resistance, while support was pegged at 96.64 the July 15 high, analysts said.

headline: CU says H1 new business up 21 percent.
text:
British insurer Commercial Union Plc said on Tuesday that worldwide new business rose 21 percent to 1.58 billion stg in the first six months of 1997.
New single premiums were up 17 percent to 1.22 billion stg over the period and new annual premiums up 38 percent to 154 million stg.  
Chief executive John Carter described the performance as very good.
"Our Netherlands company, Delta Lloyd, and our UK business produced strong growth and an excellent level of new business was achieved in Italy and Poland," he said.
Single premium business at Delta Lloyd increased 51 percent to 120 million stg and annual premium new business 31 percent higher at 33 million stg.
However, Commercial Union said that consumer uncertainty surrounding the recent elections and the reorganisation of the sales force in France had an adverse effect on sales there.
Single premium sales in France amounted to 624 million stg, including a 295 million stg contribution from AFER, down 15 percent after adjusting for exchange rate movements.
Annual premium sales were 11 million, down 30 percent.
-- London Newsroom +44 171 542 5106

headline: IMF praises UK govt's "excellent" economic start. [CORRECTED 07:45 GMT]
text:
The International Monetary Fund (IMF) on Tuesday praised the "excellent start" made by Britain's Labour government and said interest rates might not need to rise as far as markets expect to head off the threat of inflation.
In the conclusion to its annual review of Britain's economy, released by the Treasury, the Fund also said it expected the pound sterling to fall back from its current six-year highs.
"The new government has made an excellent start. It has set a high standard for its economic policies, aiming to maintain stability and foster long-term growth while seeking fairness and developing human potential.
"And it has taken decisive steps toward these goals by making the Bank of England independent, introducing a budget that makes rapid strides toward sound public finances, and initiating welfare-to-work and other programmes to enhance employability," the Washington-based IMF said.
The Fund said the policies put in place since Prime Minister Tony Blair's Labour party swept to power on May 1 were timely because of looming imbalances (corrects from "balances") in the economy.
Domestic demand was surging, and may gather further strength because of windfalls from the stock market flotation of building societies (mortgage lenders), just as exporters start to feel the pinch from the strength of sterling.
"With output now close to potential and the associated risks of rekindling inflation, the economy faces a period of increased uncertainty. Encouragingly the fiscal and monetary policies should alleviate these tensions significantly," the IMF said.
It said the budget unveiled by Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown, Britain's finance minister, on July 2 could have been tilted more heavily against free-spending consumers.
But it was difficult to criticise the scale of the fiscal tightening, which should slow the upswing in the economy and set the public finances on a sound medium-term track, it added.
The IMF welcomed the three quarter-point rises in British interest rates since the election, saying they were overdue.
Further action would probably be required but "with substantial fiscal and monetary tightening in the pipeline interest rates may not need to rise as far as markets expect".
The IMF said sterling's strength complicated the task of steering the economy. As the surge "appears unsustainable and, according to market expectations, temporary", it was uncertain to what extent it would help slow growth by reducing exports.
Brown welcomed the report. "This is a ringing endorsement of the government's economic policies from the world's most respected international monetary body," he said in a statement.
The IMF applauded the government's emphasis on labour market flexibility and initiatives to ease the unemployed back into work.
But it said the welfare-to-work programme, which subsidises firms to take on unemployed young people for six months, would have to be implemented skillfully to achieve its objectives.
The Fund was also doubtful about another cherished Labour policy, the national minimum wage. It called it "a blunt instrument for achieving a fair income distribution and a two-edged sword for rewarding work if set too high".
It suggested a lower set of wage rates for young people to ensure they would not be priced out of the labour market.
The IMF also said Brown's "golden rule" on public borrowing, which says the government may borrow only to fund investment over the course of the business cycle, lacked ambition.
It said the government should aim to balance its books completely to release extra resources for private investment.
The IMF welcomed changes in corporate taxation made in the budget, including the abolition of tax credits offered to pension funds on dividend payments.
But it urged the government to reconsider its refusal to extend value added tax to a wider range of goods. REUTER

headline: STOCKS -- Closing stock market indices, July 21.
text:
Here is how major stock markets outside the United States ended on Monday.
LONDON - Britain's FTSE 100 index suffered its second consecutive sharp decline as the latest Wall Street jitters sparked a round of profit-taking in leading British shares. The FTSE 100 closed at 4,805.7, down 71.5 points, or 1.47 percent.
FRANKFURT - A merger of two of Germany's largest regional commercial banks failed to keep the 30-share DAX index from tumbling about two percent in bourse trade as a long-awaited wave of profit-taking hit the market. The DAX-30 index closed at 4,108.40, down 88.13 points, or 2.10 percent. In later screen-based trade the IBIS DAX index ended at 4,139.96, up 8.02 points, or 0.19 percent.
PARIS - Shares finished slightly lower after the government announced widely anticipated increases in corporate taxes to enable France to reduce its budget deficit and qualify for European monetary union. The CAC-40 index closed at 2,874.12, down 2.57 points, or 0.09 percent.
ZURICH - Shares continued their recent slide in nervous trading to end two percent lower after index heavyweights were pressured by derivatives-linked transactions. The Swiss market index closed at 5,620.5, down 116.6 points, or 2.03 percent.
MILAN - Shares closed mostly higher, as values swung back and forth after Wall Street's choppy start, with Fiat riding out the impact of a bonus share issue while Mediaset powered ahead. The All Share Mibtel index closed at 14,626, up 85 points, or 0.58 percent.
AMSTERDAM - Shares finished a see-saw session lower as nerves about U.S. Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony to Congress on Tuesday gained the upper hand in late trade. The AEX index closed at 931.34, down 10.45 points, or 1.11 percent.
TOKYO - The financial markets were closed today for a national holiday, they will reopen tomorrow. On Friday, the Nikkei 225 shed 269.93 points or 1.32 percent to finish at 20,249.32.
HONG KONG - Stocks lost momentum in late afternoon trade to close marginally down, chiefly due to weakness in properties and conglomerates as well as banking giant HSBC Holdings, brokers said. The Hang Seng index closed at 15,536.30, down 34.10 points, or 0.22 percent.
SYDNEY - The stock market ended 1.15 percent lower and near the day's lows in response to Wall Street's 1.6 percent dip on Friday. The All Ordinaries index closed at 2,653.4, down 30.8 points, or 1.15 percent.
JOHANNESBURG - Gold shares finished firmer but off highs reached in the morning as the volatile bullion price dipped a couple of dollars during the day. The All-share index closed at 7,431.9, up 7.0 points, or 0.09 percent. The All Gold index closed at 1,008.3, up 16.3 points, or 0.47 percent, while the Industrial index closed at 8,979.7, up 42.0 points, or 1.64 percent.

headline: FOCUS - Oil directionless ahead of Iraq news.
text:
World oil prices marked time on Monday as the market remained directionless ahead of an expected wave of Iraqi crude exports under the terms of a deal with the United Nations.
The U.N. was widely expected to approve Iraq's plan for aid distribution submitted on Monday, a precursor for further exports.
Brent crude oil, the world benchmark grade, ended on the London futures market three cents lower at $18.09 per barrel.
Baghdad is set to resume pumping for a three-month period to earn a further $1 billion with which it will be allowed to fund humanitarian aid.
The current period began on June 8. But because of delays caused by the discussion of the technicalites of aid distribution, traders fear Iraq will have to increase the flow of oil to around 1.5 million barrels per day in the remaining weeks of the three-month period to make up its revenue.
This would be around double the rate of earlier tranches of exports and would further depress oil prices which have already fallen by around 25 percent this year.
Brokers said U.N. approval of Baghdad's plan was likely to cause few ripples in the market.
But London-based GNI research said in a report that while U.N. approval was fully expected by the market, the fact that it could mean Iraqi oil shipments in the next couple of weeks meant there should still be a reaction.
"Perhaps the most bearish aspect of the Iraqi deal is the need to compress $1 billion worth of sales into a five- to six-week period," the GNI report said.
--Simon Gardner, London Newsroom + 44 171 542 7714

headline: Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.
text:
ACADEMIC PREDICTS MORE INDUSTRIAL DISPUTES
A leading industrial relations expert is forecasting more bitter struggles between employers and workers, similar to the Rio Tinto mining dispute.
The head of Sydney University's Department of Industrial Relations, professor Russell Lansbury, says unions are feeling increasingly threatened.
Professor Lansbury says although the Hunter Valley dispute now seems to be at an end, unions are facing an ongoing struggle.
Speaking at a two-day industrial relations conference in Sydney, Professor Lansbury says the government's IR reforms are bringing about an evolution rather than a revolution in workplace relations.
But he says the move from collective to individual agreements is striking at the very existence of the union movement in Australia.
"It's a bitter struggle," Lansbury said.
"It's akin to the 1890s when we had a similar kind of period of strong bitter disputes in which unions established their right to exist.
"And they're having to re-establish that at the moment."
- - - -
BEAZLEY SAYS COSTELLO MUST SHARE BLAME FOR PACIFIC DOCUMENT
Federal Opposition Leader Kim Beazley says Treasurer Peter Costello must share some of the blame for the publication of a confidential document highly critical of South Pacific political figures.
Costello says he has ordered a full investigation into how the document, which describes some Pacific ministers as corrupt and incompetent, was left unattended at a Cairns conference last week.
The treasurer says the media is as much to blame, saying the decision to publish the information was morally irresponsible.
However Beazley has told ABC Radio Costello would have undoubtedly seen the document before the conference and should have ordered its destruction.
Beazley says Costello should have gone to the authors of the document, or anyone who was immediately to hand, and told them they'd never want to see a document like that again.
He says the treasurer should have told the report's authors that the sort of advice contained in the document ought to be completely rephrased, the gratuitous elements eliminated from it and somebody should get "a royal bollicking."
- - - -
MINISTER DENIES MISHANDLING DROUGHT PROBLEM
Federal Primary Industries Minister John Anderson has rejected the Queensland premier's criticism that he's not up to the job because of the way he's dealt with drought .
Rob Borbidge has described a decision by Anderson to revoke drought exceptional circumstances provisions in 29 Queensland shires as stupid.
But Anderson says it's unfair to accuse the federal government of being heartless, as assistance has been extended in some cases.
"I want to calm this issue down by saying that there is always that opportunity to apply again," Anderson said.
"That's what seems to be being missed. There's a lot of heat going into saying this is a wrong decision, it ought to be overturned."
Anderson said the criticism overlooked the fact that state governments can apply again for drought assistance if they have concerns.
- - - -
SURVEY SHOWS BUSINESS FRAUD SIGNIFICANT
Accountancy firm KPMG says as many as one in two Australian companies could be experiencing significant fraud.
The latest KPMG fraud survey shows nearly half of the 480 companies questioned had fraud cases in the past two years costing them at least A$104 million.
KPMG says this is only the tip of the iceberg, with a national cost of business fraud possibly as high as A$20 billion.
The survey showed the communications and hospitality industries were the most susceptible to fraud.
- - - -
AMNESTY WANTS MORE PRESSURE ON BURMA
Amnesty International is asking the Australian government to use its influence with ASEAN member states to pressure them to take an active role in protecting human rights in Burma.
Amnesty has released a report it says documents atrocities committed by the Burmese army against ethnic minority groups in eastern Burma.
It says the admission of Burma into ASEAN will test the regional grouping's promise of using constructive engagement with Burma's military junta, SLORC, over human rights.
Amnesty Australia's Burma Co-ordinator, David Begg, says ASEAN members must accept responsibility for the protection of human rights there, and wants Australia to ensure that responsibility is acted on.
Begg says the ASEAN members have in the past said that their policy of constructive engagement will produce a better result on human rights in Burma.
"Now clearly this hasn't happened in the past. So we're asking the Australian government to do what they can to talk quietly with the ASEAN nations and have them apply pressure on the Burmese authorities," he said.
- - - -
SHARK KILLS AUSSIE SURFER IN SOUTH AFRICA
Australian diplomats in South Africa are seeking more details of the death of a 25-year-old Sydney man in a shark attack.
The man was attacked while surfing off a remote beach at Breezy Point, between East London and Durban.
His body was washed up on the beach with the right leg missing.
Relatives of the dead man, from Sydney's northern beaches, have been informed as Australian Embassy officials in Pretoria attempt to piece together details of the attack.
- - - -
TAYLOR CONDEMNS PITCH CHANGE REPORTS
Australian cricket captain Mark Taylor has condemned reported interference in the preparation of the pitch for the the fourth test against England at Headingley, which begins this Thursday.
It's claimed England chairman of selectors David Graveney, and England and Wales Cricket Board's pitch consultant, Harry Brind, have ordered Yorkshire officials to prepare another pitch, instead of the one originally selected for the test.
It has been reported the two men visited the Leeds venue at the weekend and found the test pitch with bare patches, prompting them to order the change.
They told the curator that another pitch with an even cover of grass should be the test pitch, to counter the spin of Shane Warne.
Taylor says he was disappointed after hearing reports about a possible pitch change, but insists he's going to Headingley with an open mind and won't take up the matter with the match referee.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: NZ shares close shade softer, recover early losses.
text:
* NZ index closes touch weaker, recovers after early losses
* Telecom pares losses after interest rate spike
* Small cap stocks show good gains, leaders mixed
---------------------------(July 22)---------------------------
Price movements at the close
	    LAST CHG  * NZSE40 cap index -5.47 at 2,453.82
  134   -1  * NZSE-10 cap index -4.31 at 1,229.76
  368   -2  * NZSC cap index +7.37 at 5,248.51
  337   -1  * NZMC cap index +2.66 at 1,991.21   380   +1  * Volume NZ$54 million Futures untraded
  728   -5  * Other movers - +6 +10
The New Zealand share market closed slightly weaker on Tuesday but retraced much of the ground lost early when higher interest rates hit Telecom.
Telecom closed five cents off at NZ$7.20, after shedding 13 cents in the first hour, and the share's move accounted for most of the falls in the bluechip indices.
At the close the NZSE40 Capital index was down 5.47 points at 2,453.82, with the leaders mixed. Smaller issues showed good gains in selected stocks, with the small companies index finishing 7.37 firmer at 1,991.21.
Turnover totalled NZ$54 million.  
Duncan Rutherford at brokers BZW said the market was again driven by rising interest rates and a weaker currency.
"Today was a very, very quiet day. If you take out some of the big lines that were done, there wasn't a hell of a lot actually going on."
Derek Howarth at brokers Lawrence Millton Howarth said trading was featureless.
"It walked through a narrow range of quotes. If you look at the pros and cons it was all pretty dull." he said.
"A ho-hum day with few leads from offshore markets."  
Rutherford said leaders, with the exception of Brierley Investments, were reasonably well supported, with Fletcher Building closing up six cents at NZ$4.42. Fletcher Energy, up two at $4.90, topped turnover among the leaders with just over three million shares crossed.
Cashed-up second liner Queen Charlotte topped the turnover overall with 3.2 million shares traded. The issue closed one cent firmer at 27 cents, but brokers were unable to explain the interest.
"Some of the exporters did well such as Sanford and some of the currency-related stocks," Rutherford said.  
Fishing company Sanford added 10 cents to $2.95.
Howarth said Ports of Auckland, five cents better at $6.90, rose after a bullish report that its container traffic was up 15 percent in the year to June.
Rutherford said fears the currency could yet go lower "might take some of the stuffing out of the market".
--Vernon Small, Wellington newsroom 64 4 473 4746
e-mail - wellington.newsroom@reuters.com

headline: New PNG prime minister vows anti-corruption drive.
text:
Port Moresby mayor Bill Skate was elected prime minister of Papua New Guinea on Tuesday after joining forces with parties he once labelled corrupt -- and immediately vowed to investigate his new allies.
Skate, a moderate who campaigned against a failed mercenary deal earlier this year, also pledged to work for peace on Bougainville island.
"We will fight corruption, but not destroy our own people," Skate told parliament. "We will ensure that our government will be transparent."
Skate defeated former prime minister Sir Michael Somare by 71 votes to 35 in an open ballot in the South Pacific nation's new 109-seat parliament.
Former deputy prime minister Chris Haiveta, criticised by a judicial inquiry into this year's mercenary fiasco, was expected to be reappointed deputy leader. Haiveta sat in his usual chair at Skate's right hand during the vote.
Skate's shock election resulted from a last-minute deal under which his party, the People's National Congress, and other small parties and independents backed the former government.
On Sunday, Skate's People's National Congress was still siding with Somare, but political analysts said Somare's refusal to allow Skate the top job saw him defect late on Monday.
The back-room deal rescued the former ruling coalition, the People's Progessive Party (PPP) and Pangu party, from political oblivion after it was decimated in the June election.
A voter backlash against the former government over alleged political corruption and the hiring of African mercenaries to end the secessionist revolt on Bougainville saw 15 ministers, including Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan, lose their seats.
Chan's hiring of mercenaries sparked an army revolt and two days of looting in March in the capital Port Moresby -- the country's worst political crisis since independence in 1975.
Skate had campaigned heavily for the removal of Chan during the crisis, but in the end Chan was said to be key to wooing Skate's support for his coalition.
Asked by reporters how he could now side with his rivals, Skate said: "Papua New Guinea has its own way of playing politics, it is not for foreigners, outsiders, to come here and dictate how we run our politics."
Skate said he would investigate a series of corruption charges, including those linked to the $36 million contract with British military consultancy Sandline International.
"We will not be vindictive, but we will look at all the issues, including Sandline...," said Skate, who during the June elections said he would never join forces with the PPP-Pangu parties. The two parties are the largest in the new parliament with 16 and 15 seats respectively.
Skate is expected to be a dove on his country's most intractable problem, the nine-year revolt on Bougainville, and said on Tuesday that peace rested with the island's people.
"The people of Bougainville are crying out for peace, my government will listen to what they want," Skate said. "It is up to Bougainvilleans to find a solution to the problem."
Skate was born in 1953 and has a degree in accountancy from the University of Technology in the city of Lae. He was a senior public servant before entering politics five years ago.
Skate is well known in Port Moresby as a good administrator who has cleaned up the city and improved services, but he lacks a national following -- which analysts said may pose an obstacle to any attempts to bring peace to Bougainville.
Skate's election comes at a crucial time for peace. The New Zealand government said on Tuesday that the rebels planned to release five PNG soldiers held hostage since September 1996.
Two weeks of peace talks in New Zealand between rebels and government-backed Bougainville administration ended last week with an agreement to seek formal peace talks, the island's demilitarisation and an international peacekeeping force.
Thousands have died in the Bougainville conflict since landowners revolted in 1988 over damage caused by the huge Panguna copper mine and the royalties they received from it.

headline: Australia bonds retain bid tone, risky days ahead.
text:

FUTURES					  CASH YIELD

AUD/USD  0.7404 (PREV 0.7415) US 30-YR  6.55   (6.54 NY)
---------------------(July 22)------------------------------
*Australian bond yields were only marginally higher in the face of a weakening U.S. Treasury market and another slump in New Zealand debt ahead Wednesday's key inflation data.
*Greenspan to deliver first leg of Humphrey-Hawkins speech.  
By Colin Brinsden
Australian bond yields were only marginally higher in the face of a weakening U.S. Treasury market and another slump in neighbouring New Zealand debt ahead Wednesday's second quarter inflation data.
The local market has priced in an extremely benign inflation outcome, so there is the risk of a 'buy the rumour, sell the fact' scenario, but even so, there is a strong belief that it will lead to the Reserve Bank easing policy again.
"As long as wages are okay (Thursday), we will be looking for a rate cut Friday," one bond trader said.  
Median forecasts centre on a 0.1 percent quarterly fall in the headline CPI for a year-on-year rate of just 0.5 percent, and an underlying rate of 0.4 percent for an annual rate of 1.7 percent, below the RBA's 2.0-3.0 percent target.
However, such are the market's expectations for inflation it may need outcomes at the low end of forecasts to spur on any further significant rally in the market, traders said.
Ranges for quarterly inflation in a recent Reuters survey of economists were plus 0.3 to minus 0.3 percent for the headline rate and plus 0.2 to 0.6 percent for the underlying.  
The bond futures market is very close to all-time-highs after rallying since April, so the market is going into the data very much on the long side, traders said.
One hurdle the market must overcome before the data is the reaction to the first leg of Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's semi-annual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony later on Tuesday in the U.S. at 1800 GMT (0400 a.m. eastern Australia).
"(But) Greenspan could actually do us a favour if he is as negative as people expect him to be, in that it will give us more room to manoeuvre and give a bigger reaction to our data if we go into it offered," one bond trader said.  
Such is the expectation for the inflation data that two reasonably negative surveys for the bond market by independent banks failed to daunt the market.
HSBC chief economist John Edwards said that his bank's wages report, which showed enterprise bargaining agreements running at 4.9 percent in the June quarter, should not prevent a rate cut, although it may cause the RBA concern further down the track.
Likewise, Westpac's chief economist Nigel Stapledon said there is still ample slack in the economy for an easing, despite his bank's leading index in May showing annual growth at 8.2 percent, which is indicating growth picking up into 1998.

headline: Australia Yield Spreads-Poised for compression.
text:
---------------------------------------------------------
 AUD VS   3-YR	   10-YR	* AUD 3-YR/10-YR SPREAD
 USD	-39 (- 02)    33 (UNCH) * FUTURES   74   (UNCH)
 CAD	 69 (+ 01)    60 (+ 03) * CASH	94   (UNCH)
 NZD     -165 (- 21)   -40 (- 17) *
---------------------------------------------------------
The Australian 10-year bond yield spread to the U.S. held little changed as the local market patiently awaited Wednesday's key second quarter inflation report which is expected to produce a sharp compression.
"Excellent inflation and encouraging wages outcomes are likely to see the spread head towards our short tern target of 25-30 basis points this week," said Su-Lin Ong, fixed income economist at Hambros Bank.
Median forecasts centre on a 0.1 percent fall for the headline CPI for an annual rate of 0.5 percent and 0.4 and 1.7 percent for the policy sensitive underlying rate.
As long as average weekly earnings data on Thursday remain reasonably contained the local bond market will be on full alert for a policy easing as early as Friday from the Reserve Bank, analysts added.
However, the market has one hurdle to get through before the data, being Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's semi-annual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, which starts later on Tuesday in the U.S.
U.S. Treasuries softened again on Monday ahead of Greenspan's overview of the U.S. economy.
Meanwhile, New Zealand debt grossly underperformed the dollar bloc as the N.Z. dollar again came under attack, causing the market to again readjust to keep monetary conditions within the RBNZ's desired level.
-- Colin Brinsden 61-2 9373-1800

text:

OVERNIGHT CASH  8.50 PCT  (PREV 8.25)  US 5-YR  6.17 (PREV 6.15)
NZD/USD    0.6497/04 (PREV 0.6531/38)  US 10-YR 6.26 (PREV 6.24)
TWI 64.39  (PREV 64.67)		    US 30-YR 6.54 (PREV 6.53)
RBNZ MCI  NZ/MCI 773.18 (PREV 764.57) Reuters NZ MCI -52 vs -60
---------------------------(JULY 22)---------------------------  
Another dramatic fall by the Kiwi dollar hoisted the entire New Zealand yield curve more than 20 basis points on Tuesday, and dealers said the currency would continue to dictate its shape for some time to come.
"It's going to come back to the Kiwi. I suspect the Kiwi will go lower at some point, just the way it traded today. It does still look and feel pretty vulnerable," a senior dealer said.
The kiwi, which plunged one U.S. cent last Friday, resumed its slide in early Tuesday trade with a sharp drop of over 50 basis points to US$0.6480. It closed just under 65 cents.  
The key 90-day bank bill rate responded with an early spikeup of over 20 points. Bond yields also jumped higher, with the liquidation of some offshore holdings in the middle to longer part of the curve seen aggrevating the move.
Although The kiwi's late stabilisation in afternoon trade relieved some pressure on the yield curve, dealers said an air of trepidation pervaded the debt markets with the widespread expectation that the currency will fall further.
"It's never really bounced all day, it's just been sitting there, and it's got the whole market very nervous," one said of the kiwi. The TWI ended at 64.45, versus Monday's 64.54 close.  
He said rates should rise further if the kiwi continued to sink simply because of the Reserve Bank's use of the Monetary Conditions Index (MCI), which measures the mix of the 90-day rate and the kiwi's Trade-Weighted Index (TWI).
"In theory, yes. I guess because of the MCI concept and the way it works, they have to go higher. But I really wonder whether bond rates have got a lot left in them. They have sold off a lot now in the last three or four trading days," he said.
"But if the short end goes, the long end will follow to a certain extent. It's all in the hands of the kiwi."

headline: Papua New Guinea elects surprise new PM.
text:
Bill Skate, the mayor of Port Moresby, was elected prime minister of Papua New Guinea on Tuesday after joining forces with former government parties he once labelled corrupt and vowed never to support.
Skate beat former prime minister Sir Michael Somare by 71 votes to 35 in a vote in the South Pacific nation's new 109-seat parliament.
Former deputy prime minister Chris Haiveta, who was criticised by a judicial inquiry into a failed mercenary plan, was expected to be a contender for the number two job when Skate announces his ministry.
Skate's shock election rescued the former ruling coalition, the People's Progessive Party (PPP) and Pangu party, from political oblivion after it was decimated in the June election.
A voter backlash against the former government, angry with political corruption and the hiring of African mercenaries to end the secessionist revolt on Bougainville, saw 15 ministers including prime minister Sir Julius Chan lose their seats.
In fact, Skate campaigned heavily for the removal of the former prime minister Chan over his involvement in the failed US$36 million mercenary deal.
Chan's hiring of mercenaries sparked an army revolt and two days of looting in the capital Port Morebsy -- the country's worst political crisis since independence in 1975.
"Our nation has been torn apart with division and more and more questions about corruption in high office," Skate said as he introduced an anti-Chan motion in parliament in March.
"We have the crisis today because of one man's ego -- it is madness, madness," he added.
During the June election Skate said he would never join forces with the PPP-Pangu parties.
On Sunday Skate's People's National Congress was still siding with Somare, but political analysts said Somare's refusal to allow Skate the top job saw him defect late on Monday in a deal that Chan himself helped mastermind.
Skate becomes the first ethnic Papuan to serve as prime minister since independence in 1975 -- a move which will be widely welcomed. Papua is a region in the south of the mainland.
However, while Skate is well known in Port Moresby as a good administrator who has cleaned up the city and improved services, he lacks a national following which may pose an obstacle in efforts to solve the nine-year Bougainville revolt.
Skate's election comes at a cruicial time for Bougainville peace efforts. The New Zealand government on Tuesday announced that rebels plan to release five PNG soldiers held hostage since September 1996 as a sign of goodwill.
Two weeks of peace talks in New Zealand between rebels and government-backed Bougainville officials ended last week with an agreement to seek formal government peace talks, the demilitarisation of Bougainville and an international peacekeeping force.
Thousands have died in the Bougainville conflict since landowners revolted in 1988 over damage caused by the huge Panguna copper mine, and the royalties they received from it.
The mine is owned by a unit of the Anglo-Australian giant Rio Tinto Ltd.

*Australian bond yields stayed close to the highs going into the lunchtime recess ahead of Fed Greenspan's testimony, but hopes remain high over Wednesday's local inflation outcome.
*HSBC says wage deals running at 4.9 percent in Q2.  
Australian bond yields stayed close to the day's highs going into the lunchtime recess ahead of Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's Humphrey-Hawkins testimony later on Tuesday in the U.S.
The mildly weaker tone largely reflected a jittery U.S. debt market on concerns about a hawkish estimate by Greenspan, and renewed weakness in New Zealand bonds.
However, there was limited damage on the local market amid hopes of an extremely benign outcome to the Australian inflation report on Wednesday, which is forecast to have recorded headline CPI deflation in the second quarter.  
"An inflation outcome on expectations will obviously help sentiment, but it could be a case of buy the rumour, sell the fact, unless it comes in even lower," one trader said.
Median expectations centre on a 0.1 percent fall for the quarter for headline CPI, although estimates range from a 0.3 percent rise to a 0.3 percent fall, according to a Reuters survey of economists.
Underlying inflation is seen rising 0.4 percent, giving an annual rate of 1.7 percent and well below the Reserve Bank's 2.0-3.0 percent target, and would raise expectation for a monetary policy easing.  
But the market will also have to negotiate Thursday's second quarter average weekly ordinary time earnings before it goes on full alert for a cut in the 5.5 percent official interest rate.
Forecasts here centre on a 0.8 percent rise for an annual growth rate of 4.1 percent, within the RBA's comfort zone.
HSBC Markets' latest Wages Report showed major enterprise bargaining deals averaging 4.9 percent in the June quarter, up from an estimated 4.0 percent in the March quarter.
HSBC chief economist John Edwards said this was not enough to prevent a rate cut, but it will give the RBA cause for concern over wages pressure in coming months.
