headline: Former PNG government expected to regain power.
text:
Papua New Guinea's former coalition government looked likely to be returned to power as part of a new alliance on Tuesday after unexpectedly winning the support of political opponents.
In the first parliamentary sitting since the June elections, a member of the former ruling Pangu party, John Pundari, was elected parliamentary speaker, defeating a group of parties and independents headed by former premier Sir Michael Somare.
Rival parties have now retired to select prime ministerial candidates with the victor chosen in an open parliamentary vote later on Tuesday and a government formed.
Former deputy prime minister Chris Haiveta, who was criticised by a judicial inquiry into a failed mercenary deal, and the mayor of Port Moresby Bill Skate were expected to contest the top job for the former government coalition.
Skate was sitting in the prime minister's chair during the vote for speaker, indicating that he was the chosen candidate within the coalition.
If either Skate or Haiveta is successful they will be the first ethnic Papuans to serve as prime minister since independence in 1975 -- a move which will be widely welcomed.
Papua is a region in the south of the mainland.
Somare, a highlander, was also expected to be nominated, but unless the voting pattern which elected the speaker in the 109-seat parliament changed he was unlikely to win.
Somare, the country's first prime minister, seemed to have secured enough votes to form a new government until late on Monday when two minor parties joined the old government.
Skate's People's National Congress and the People's Democratic Movement had both sided with Somare in the early rounds of horse-trading traditional after the elections.
The former coalition government of Sir Julius Chan suffered a major defeat in last month's elections, with 15 ministers losing their seats in a voter backlash against alleged political corruption and the mercenary plan.
Chan, who lost his seat after 29 years in parliament, hired British-led African mercenaries in a US$36 million deal to try to end the nine-year seccessionist revolt on resource-rich Bougainville island.

headline: Australia coal strike end opens way for shipments.
text:
The end of a bitter six week strike at Coal and Allied Ltd's Hunter Valley No.1 mine will allow first shipments to leave Newcastle port in a couple of days, Allan Davies, the colliery's general manager, told Reuters on Tuesday.
The first shipment will be for South Korea in the Ocean Korea carrier, to be followed by the Vine, bound for Italy, he said.  
Davies, who said that the striking workers had returned to work on exactly the same conditions as they left, had cost the company, a unit of the Rio Tinto Ltd group, A$40 million in lost sales revenue, he said.
This had occurred through lost production of about one million tonnes of coal, or 40 days worth of production at about 25,000 tonnes a day, he said.
As miners voted to end the strike at the mine north of Sydney, about 37 ships were queued at the port waiting to be loaded with Coal and Allied coal.  
The ships, bound for Japan, Korea and Italy, varied greatly in size but were of an average of about 70,000 tonnes.
Coal and Allied's A$40 million loss of revenue from the strike had occurred through the company not adding to the Hunter Valley No.1 stockpile, Davies said.
Coal and Allied customers also had been disadvantaged by the inconvenience of rescheduled shipments or through being supplied with coal from other Hunter Valley mines, he said.
However, the company's customers had been supplied with coal throughout the dispute, other sources said.  
Coal and Allied had continued to ship during the strike using stockpiled coal at the port, Davies said. Where appropriate the company also had rescheduled shipments or filled in with production from the company's sister mine at Mount Thorley, which was not affected by the strike.
Other company sources told Reuters that while Coal and Allied had generally loaded all vessels during the strike, some vessels had withdrawn and switched to other shippers in the port.
Coal and Allied also had a fair stock of coal to start with, the sources said.  
"We've managed to muddle through," one said.
The company did not expect to lose long-term customers because of the strike, he said.
"After the six week strike they (the striking union workers) got precisely nothing," Davies told Reuters. "They're returning to work on the same terms as they left and they've gained nothing."
Officials of the union involved, the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union, were not immediately available for comment.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Australia handed new headaches in South Pacific.
text:
Australia's South Pacific woes mounted on Tuesday when a Papua New Guinea politician criticised in a secret report returned unexpectedly to power and Fiji promised a grilling at a forthcoming regional summit.
As the diplomatic fall-out spread over the publication of a confidential Australian briefing paper, former PNG deputy prime minister Chris Haiveta emerged a winner from a surprise deal on a new government in Port Moresby.
Haiveta was dismissed as an ambitious underperformer in the Australian report, one of a number of regional leaders criticised either personally or professionally.
The report -- marked 'AUSTEO', or Australian Eyes Only -- said Haiveta was an ambitious, arrogant and self-confident man whose prospects were damaged by his involvement in a scandal over plans to hire mercenaries to quell an island rebellion.
The 93-page document has sparked angry reactions in the region for its scathing portrayal of mismanagement, corruption and even drunkenness among South Pacific politicians.
Fiji Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka, head of one of the biggest and best economies in the South Pacific, condemned the report as disrespectful and said Australia could be taken to task at September's South Pacific Forum leaders' summit.
"We have our forum, we have our own ways of talking to them, and for that report to be made the way it was, I believe, is a show of disrespect," Rabuka was quoted as saying in the Fiji Times newspaper on Tuesday.
The briefing paper was prepared for Treasurer Peter Costello ahead of a meeting of economic ministers from the 16-member Forum in the Australian resort of Cairns earlier this month.
It was left on a table in a public area at a Cairns hotel, where it was picked up by Reuters.
The secret briefing questioned Haiveta's judgement as finance minister and said he had said he had not lived up to hopes that he represented a new era in the political life of Papua New Guinea, which won independence from Australia in 1975.
"Despite his strong background in policy and administration, he has not shown sound political instincts and good judgment as finance minister and Pangu Party leader," the report said.
Haiveta, who has not commented on the report, had appeared to be heading into opposition after PNG voters turned against his Pangu party and the People's Progress Party of former prime minister Sir Julius Chan. The Australian report described Haiveta as "Chan's lickspittle".
But in a deal engineered by Chan, who lost his seat in the elections, the two parties were returned to power in a coalition of former rivals headed by Port Moresby governor Bill Skate.
Skate was elected prime minister on Tuesday as Haiveta sat at his right hand in the chair reserved for the deputy prime minister, although this position and the other ministries has yet to be announced.
Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer congratulated Skate on his election, urging him to "respond to the message for change delivered by the electorate".

headline: Australia welcomes PNG govt, urges reforms.
text:
Australia on Tuesday welcomed Papua New Guinea's new government and urged the impoverished South Pacific nation to press on with crucial economic reforms.
Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said in a statement he would visit Port Moresby soon for talks with new Prime Minister Bill Skate, elected by parliament on Tuesday.
"Australia recognises that the new government faces considerable challenges in the months ahead to continue the important economic reform agenda, search for a peaceful resolution to the Bougainville conflict and respond to the message for change delivered by the electorate," he said.
Australia, PNG's former colonial master and biggest aid donor, has consistently urged economic reform, an end to the separatist rebellion on Bougainville and increased government transparency.
But relations between the two countries were soured earlier this year when former PNG prime minister Sir Julius Chan hired a group of African mercenaries to quell the Bougainville revolt. The mercenary plan was called off after an army revolt and civil protests.

headline: South Australian grains said reeling from drought.
text:
Wheat and barley production in South Australia is expected to be down by about 40 percent in the 1997/98 (April/March) season because of severe drought, a state farmers conference was told on Tuesday.
South Australian farmers have already incurred a 40 percent yield loss on 1997/98 grains crops because of effects of the El Nino weather effect, John Lush, chairman of the grains committee of the the South Australian Farmers Federation, told Reuters from the organisation's annual conference in Adelaide.  
Severe losses had already been incurred, regardless of whether the drought broke, with losses likely to escalate as warmer weather approached, he said.
"It is one of the driest periods grain farmers have ever experienced. It doesn't look promising," Lush said.
South Australia normally produces an annual winter grains harvest worth about A$1 billion.
Existing effects of the drought would have wiped about A$400 million from normal farm revenue returns, he said.
The state's 1997/98 wheat production could be down by 50 percent on a tonnage basis, Lush said.  
"Wheat and barley will suffer and ... peas and beans will suffer even more," he said.
"This situation will (worsen) as we go into spring, given (indications) that we will not be getting another big rain," Lush said. "There are areas in South Australia that look like they're not even going to get a crop in the ground," he said. In 1996/97 South Australia produced about 2.85 million tonnes of wheat and 2.04 million tonnes of barley.
Total Australian production in that year was 23.5 million tonnes of wheat and 6.6 million tonnes of barley.  
Latest forecasts are for Australia's 1997/98 wheat production to decline to about 16 million tonnes, with barley production to fall to about 6.0 million tonnes.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Indonesia extends Lone Star mine period.
text:
Lone Star Exploration NL said on Tuesday it now had until at least October 2000 to build a mine at its Awak Mas gold project after receiving a two-year work extension from the Indonesian government.
Lone Star had previously been given until October 1998 to build a mine after an initial feasibility study period expired in April last year.
Spokesman Bill Crossley said the Indonesian government had agreed to extend the study period until October 1998 and had pushed the date for construction of a mine back to October 2000.  
"We are very pleased with the outcome and grateful to the Indonesian government," Crossley said.
Lone Star said last Friday it had significant gold and base metal results from its Tarra prospect north of Awak Mas, on the island of Sulawesi. It has four other target sites in the area.
Awak Mas has an estimated resource of 35 million tonnes of ore grading 1.7 grams of gold per tonne for 1.95 million contained ounces.
Lone Star shares were unchanged at 20 cents at the close of trade on Tuesday.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Australian stocks close touch higher, eyes on Fed.
text:
Australian shares firmed from their lows on Tuesday to close slightly stronger as bank shares in particular rose in sympathy with a mild bond market recovery.
But volumes were slight as traders remained on the sidelines ahead of key local inflation data on Wednesday and U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's appearance before a House of Representatives banking sub-committee.
Volumes and volatility are seen remaining low until the U.S. and Australian interest rate pictures have cleared.
The All Ordinaries index closed up 3.0 points at 2,656.4.
Many investors remained wary of taking any positions ahead of Greenspan's Humphrey-Hawkins testimony at 1800 GMT (6.00 a.m. Eastern Australia time on Wednesday), particularly in the wake of his "irrational exuberance" comments in December.
"If he was worried back then, he's got to be alarmed at these levels," said one Sydney dealer.
Gold stocks and some resource stocks were the weakest on the day after the gold price fell more than US$3.00 an ounce overnight, capping its recent bounce-back.
The Gold index closed down 1.33 percent, with Normandy Mining Ltd down four cents at A$1.54 (US$1.14).
Some bank and other interest rate sensitive stocks firmed in afternoon trade as the bond market recovered somewhat from its morning sell-off on speculation inflation data due on Wednesday would trigger a rate cut. Commonwealth Bank of Australia was the best performer, rising 20 cents to A$16.42.
In other events, Boral Ltd rose six cents to A$4.01 after its gas spinoff, Envestra Ltd, said it would raise A$910 million through combined debt and equity issues.
Boral would receive A$889 million from Envestra for its South Australian and Queensland gas distribution assets which are to be put into the float. Boral also said it would pay A$33 million to move to 100 percent of U.S.-based Monex Resources, a processor of coal combustion by-products.
Macquarie Bank Ltd jumped 29 cents or over two percent to A$13.05, matching its all-time high of A$13.10 in intra-day trade, on a newspaper report that it would announce plans for a share buy-back at its annual meeting on Wednesday.
Cultus Petroleum rose 15 cents to A$3.65 on renewed speculation on a takeover. Bellwether BHP fell 16 cents to A$17.94, with some citing talk that BHP had been dropped from a model portfolio by U.S. investment house Goldman Sachs.
(A$1=US$0.74)

headline: RTRS-FAI sale to MMI terminated.
text:
A deal which would have seen insurer MMI Ltd buy the general insurance operations of FAI Insurances Ltd in New Zealand, Fiji and Papua New Guinea has been terminated, the companies said on Tuesday.  
A statement to the Australian Stock Exchange said the sale had been terminated by mutual agreement because the two companies could not agree on a final sale price.
The proposed sale had been announced on July 7 and conditional contracts had been exchanged.
FAI later said the sale of its New Zealand and Pacific Island insurance operations would raise A$50 million and deliver a profit above carrying value.

headline: Fraud hits half of Australia's businesses - survey.
text:
About half of Australia's companies experienced significant fraud within their organisation over the past two years, according to the latest KPMG Australia Fraud Survey released on Tuesday.
Patria Mann, KPMG co-ordinator of the Forensic Accounting Fraud unit, said this was likely to be the tip of the iceberg as organisations were frequently unaware of fraud, unable to quantify their experience or reluctant to discuss fraud losses.
"It is impossible to give an accurate figure on the cost of fraud to business, but there is no doubt that it is increasing," Mann said in a statement.  
Mann said of the companies surveyed there was an average fraud cost per organisation of A$450,000 or a total of A$104 million with the mining, communications and manufacturing industries suffering the highest average cost of fraud.
She said most frauds were by employees with about 52 percent of the total while management accounted for 25 percent. The rest of the frauds were by people outside the organisation.
"The survey suggests that the perpetrators of fraud are becoming more sophisticated," Mann said. "In fact, most frauds occur because of poor internal controls and management override of controls," she said.  
KPMG said the survey showed 60 percent of companies believe fraud will increase due to the availability of more sophisticated fraud techniques.
A survey questionnaire was sent to over 1,800 companies with a response rate of 27 percent.
-- Sydney newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Macmin says to defer Sinivit gold project.
text:
Junior miner Macmin NL said on Tuesday it had decided to defer further mine development at Sinivit in Papua New Guinea due to the decline in the gold price.
Macmin said the project was uneconomic, or at best marginally economic, at a gold price of US$320 an ounce.
The deferment is subject to approval by the Papua New Guinea Department of Mining and Petroleum.
The Sinivit project, formerly known as Wild Dog, lies south of Rabaul in East New Britain province.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Australian dlr sweats out inflation countdown.
text:
The Australian dollar clung to 74 cents in jittery trade Tuesday as the market counted down the hours to data which could well trigger a cut in interest rates.
It suffered an early wobble when its New Zealand neighbour was hammered by heavy selling in a very thin market but steadied at 74 cents on exporter and options-related bids. A rush of funds out of the mark also provided a cushion on the crosses.
But dealers felt the market mood remained bearish in expectation inflation figures Wednesday would prove so benign the Reserve Bank would have little choice but to ease policy, so taking official rates here below those in the U.S.  
By 5.00 pm (0700 GMT) the local currency was calm for the moment at US$0.7400/10 having edged up from a US$0.7390 low, but remained short of the US$0.7415/20 seen late here Monday.
Dealers said offers were crowded around US$0.7440 and chart resistance lay thick in the US$0.7475/80 area.
Support was put at US$0.7385 and US$0.7340, while a break of last week's US$0.7310 trough was needed to signal yet another phase of the four month-old, five cent-wide downtrend.
The New Zealand dollar was down at US$0.6490/95 having crumbled from US$0.6540 during the selling burst, while on the crosses the A$ was up at NZ$1.1393/18 from NZ$0.1321/30.  
Against the yen the local dollar nudged up to 86.09/19 from 85.75/85 late Monday while in trade weighted terms it firmed to 57.4 from 57.3.
Dealers said the dollar was going nowhere ahead of the long-anticipated inflation numbers, although it was harder to predict the market's likely reaction than the data themselves.
The median forecast for the underlying measure, which the RBA is pledged to keep in a 2-3 percent band over an economic cycle, favours a 0.4 percent rise for the quarter. That would see annual growth slow to 1.7 percent from 2.1 in Q1, the lowest reading since the series began in 1971.  
The consumer price index was seen actually falling by 0.1 percent, the first drop since June 1992, which would leave annual growth at just 0.5 percent from 1.3 percent.
Many analysts figured the RBA would be hard pressed not to ease in response to what was, after all, deflation and could move as soon as Friday morning.
Much depended, however, on what the volatile measure of average weekly ordinary time earnings (AWOTE) for Q2 had to say about wages growth when released on Thursday.
The market has been sanguine about the release up to now, a risky attitude given it has a habit of non-conformism.  
The original Q1 release, for instance, showed a much stronger than expected rise in growth to 4.6 percent which had been taken as lessening the chance of a rate cut. The final figures, however, were revised to show a rise of only 4.3 percent and the day after their release the RBA cut rates.
Median forecasts for Q2 are for earnings to rise 0.8 percent in Q2, which would see annual growth slow to 4.1 percent from 4.3 percent in Q1 and thus be no impediment to a move.
Die-hard A$ bulls found some comfort in wages data from HSBC Markets which showed major enterprise deals in the June quarter were up at 4.9 percent, well above the 4.0 percent seen in Q1.  
The HSBC report on wages stirred some speculation the weekly earnings data might not be as subdued as the market currently expected. However, analysts noted enterprise deals made up only about 1/3 of all settlements and it was still likely award payments were depressed enough to drag down AWOTE.
Offshore markets, however, would be more concerned with what Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan had to say at his Humphrey Hawkins testimony on the U.S. economy to Congress today. These events in the past have often shaken markets both in the U.S. and around the world.
-- Wayne Cole 61-2 9373 1800

headline: Bougainville raises Panguna re-open costs.
text:
Bougainville Copper Ltd said on Tuesday it had revised up estimates of the cost of reopening the vast but idle Panguna copper mine on Papua New Guinea's Bougainville island to up to 600 million kina (A$580 million).
The copper/gold mine was closed in May 1989 after attacks on workers by seccessionist rebels on the island.
Bougainville said in its half-year results statement that the accepted cost since 1991 of reopening the mine was 300 million to 450 million kina (A$291 million to A$437 million).  
"Following the change in the kina values relative to other currencies after its floating by the government late in 1994, and an allowance for inflated prices, the revised range is now estimated at the upper end of K400-K600 million, spread over a number of years," Bougainville said.
"Whilst these estimates assume no major damage to production facilities through vandalism or militant action, they do allow for the increased level of deterioration likely because of the prolonged closure, and for vandalism to and pilferage from infrastructure and accommodation facilities," the company said.  
Bougainville said access to the mine was still not possible so a reliable estimate of restoration costs could not be made.
The economic viability of the mine after reopening would depend on a number of factors, including the cost of recommissioning, likely future operating costs and government and community requirements, the company said.
The mine this year became the focus of a failed plan to hire mercenaries to end the nine-year civil war on Bougainville, a plan which was largely responsible for the downfall of then prime minister Sir Julius Chan in the PNG recent elections.
The mercenaries had offered to recapture the mine.  
Bougainville Copper chairman David Karpin said in April the PNG government had not followed up on a declaration that it would buy out the mine.
Bougainville Copper is a subsidiary of Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto Plc/Ltd.

headline: CBA/BII j/v wins Indonesia banking licence.
text:
The Commonwealth Bank of Australia said on Tuesday its PT Bank BII Commonwealth (BIICom) joint venture with BII, Indonesia's third largest private bank, had been granted an Indonesian operating licence to offer a full range of banking services.
BII is Indonesia's third largest bank.
The Jakarta-based joint venture is capitalised at 150 billion rupiah or about A$83 million, Commonwealth Bank said.
It said its initial customers would be Indonesian, Australian and multinational corporate and commercial clients.
--Sydney newsroom 61-2 9373 1800

headline: W. Australia says gold royalty may be deferred.
text:
Western Australian state premier Richard Court confirmed on Tuesday his government was prepared to defer the introduction of its planned gold royalty.
He said a deferral was one option put to the industry to soften the impact of the new revenue raising measure in light of the effect on the industry of the recent drop in the gold price.
"We've made it clear we are going to introduce a royalty," he told reporters.
"One of the proposals is that we defer it for six months but it would certainly come in even if it was deferred for six months at that 1.25 (percent, the proposed introductory rate).  
"But the main part of our negotiations cover the floor price we would put in in the second phase of the royalty (when it would rise to 2.5 percent) and the minimum requirements, the minimum levels, of deductions for a mine to make sure the small operators are definitely excluded," Court said.
Court announced the royalty in his 1997/98 budget speech in March. At the time he said the industry would be consulted on its features but the government's plan was to phase it in in two stages, commencing at 1.25 percent from January 1, 1998, and rising to 2.5 percent by July 1999.  
The measure was designed to raise A$19 million in 1997/98 and A$70 million annually at the 2.5 percent rate.
But last week Resources Minister Colin Barnett said the recent fall in the gold price had prompted the government to propose delaying the January 1 introduction of the first stage.
He also said the government was prepared to negotiate further on "having a second component to the royalty to be tied to the price of gold".
On Tuesday, Court said he believed the royalty negotiations will be completed within a fortnight.  
"It (the deferral proposal) will involve the government having to defer some of the dates in relation to its application but in the past we have made it very clear that whenever a mining company has difficulty with royalties we are prepared to assist them in the short term over that difficult period," Court said.
"We've made a commitment that we were going to introduce a gold royalty but at the same time we made an announcement that we would negotiate with the industry as to how it would be introduced.  
"(In relation to) the second phase of the royalty, we also had it in mind to put a floor price on so that would not come into being if it fell below a certain price, and that is one of the areas that we are currently negotiating with the industry.
"The talks are going well and I hope we can reach an amicable agreement," Court said.
Western Australia, Australia's leading gold producing state, has not previously imposed a royalty on gold production, unlike the other Australian states, although other minerals are subject to royalties.
-- Sydney newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: S.Australia sees Australian National sale on track.
text:
The Australian government's timetable to sell the Australian National (AN) rail network remains on track despite the threat of an Opposition delay in South Australia, a state government spokesman said on Tuesday.
The South Australian Parliament must pass enabling legislation before the sale of AN, which operates freight services and workshops in South Australia and Tasmania plus three interstate passenger services, can go ahead.  
The state Opposition said on Tuesday it remained concerned about four main issues affecting AN workers' entitlements and would not make a final decision on supporting the legislation until it had received a satisfactory answer from the government.
A spokesman for Transport Minister Diana Laidlaw told Reuters similar concerns had been raised by the Australian Democrats, which hold the balance of power in the state's upper house, and the government would work to address them.  
"We are still on track to get (the legislation) through," he said, adding the minister intended to move for a vote on the legislation before the current parliamentary session, due to end this week, closed. He warned there was an enormous risk to AN jobs and the sale process if the bill was defeated.
"But at the end of the day we would not expect that to be the case," he said. Final bids for AN, which has attracted international interest, are due at the end of this month.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: RTRS-Placer raises Porgera reserves 11 pct.
text: Placer Dome Inc, operator of the Porgera gold mine in Papua New Guinea, said on Tuesday it had increased reserves at the mine by about 11 percent to 11.6 million ounces.

headline: Grenfell gets Gawler Craton go-ahead.
text:
Gold explorer Grenfell Resources NL said on Tuesday that it had successfuly concluded an agreement with various Aboriginal parties over its exploration programme in the Gawler Craton region in South Australia.
Grenfell said the agreement gave it clearance to carry out all types of exploration under a two year programme.
The only restrictions were in areas not critical to its programme, the company said.
The Gawler Craton shot to prominence as a gold region late in 1996 on the back of impressive drilling results in the area.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373 1800

headline: Sausage said 96/97 trading result in line.
text:
Australian Internet software company Sausage Software Ltd said on Tuesday its unaudited trading result was in line with the forecast loss of about A$2.8 million for the year ended June 30, 1997.
Sausage said the result was after abnormal items but before amortisation of intangible assets.
It said reported revenues are expected to be about 11 percent below forecast, operating costs were kept under tight control and adjusted accordingly, and therefore were substantially below forecast levels.  
"Contributing to the variance in revenues were unanticipated delays in finalising various software bundling agreements," Sausage said.
Sausage also said it had formed an agreement with MindSpring Enterprises Inc, one of the largest Internet Service Providers (ISPs) in the United States, for MindSpring to use its HotDog Express software.
"We hope to announce more of these agreements in the future. The support of a fast growing company like MindSpring gives HotDog Express substantial leverage into the biggest ISP market in the world," it said.
-- Sydney newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Australia's AMP says fund nets 18.9 pct return.
text:
Australia's largest fund manager, AMP Investments, said on Tuesday the diversified growth option of its investment linked superannuation fund had posted an after-tax return of 18.9 percent for the year to June 30, 1997.
Fourth quarter after-tax returns were 9.5 percent.
The diversified growth option fund accounts for about A$1.5 billion of the fund, which has over A$10 billion in total funds under management.
However, AMP said that while it was pleased with the results, it was taking a cautious tack, with real returns in excess of 10 percent unlikely to be sustainable.  
"We recognise that a number of financial market risks are emerging," AMP Investments director Rob Eastcourt said in a statement, signalling a shift to direct investment.
"We believe much of the good news is already priced into financial markets. AMP Investments recognises that growth opportunities for funds are in the direct investment area, such as direct property, infrastructure and development capital."
In terms of outlook, the manager said it was maintaining an underweight exposure to Australian and international bond markets and had adopted a more defensive position by reducing exposure to Australian and international shares in favour of short dated fixed interest and listed property trusts.
AMP Investments is part of financial services group, the Australian Mutual Provident Society (AMP), which has assets of over A$90 billion and plans to list on the Australian Stock Exchange after mid-1998 if policyholders agree to demutualise.
It is expected to rank among the top 10 companies.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373 1800

headline: RTRS-Australian Treasury offers A$1.1 bln of notes.
text:
The Australian Treasury will offer a total of A$1.1 billion of Treasury notes for tender on Wednesday, the Reserve Bank of Australia said on Tuesday.  
The tender comprises A$300 million of five-week notes, A$400 million of 13-week notes and A$400 million of 26-week notes.
The Treasury last week offered a total of A$1.2 billion of notes, comprising A$400 million of five-week notes, A$500 million of 13-week notes and A$300 million of 26-week notes.
There are A$456 million of non-official holdings of T-notes maturing in the week ending July 24.
-- Sydney newsroom 61-2 373-1800

headline: CBA to offer A$505 mln Envestra debt soon.
text:
Commonwealth Bank of Australia's syndicated debt unit said on Tuesday it expected to syndicate the A$505 million of term debt being raised by Boral Ltd's gas spin-off Envestra Ltd within the next few weeks.
Envestra said earlier on Tuesday it planned to raise A$345 million in term debt as part of its plan to raise A$910 million through a combination of stapled securities, indexed bonds and term bank debt to pay for Boral's gas distribution assets.
Envestra will also raise A$160 million through a term debt facility underwritten by CBA to fund capital expenditure, taking the total syndicated bank debt to A$505 million.  
"We'll be coming to the market in the next few weeks to syndicate," CBA Vice President of Syndicated Debt Janet Pennington told Reuters. She said she could not say exactly when the debt would be syndicated or how it would be priced as these details would be released closer to the syndication.
Envestra's prospectus said the A$345 million facility to fund the acquisition of the networks would have a five year term, while the A$160 million facility to fund capital expenditure would have a six year term.
Interest on the term debt facility would be payable either quarterly or semi-annually in arrears.  
Envestra said it had entered into a series of swap arrangements whereby its interest expense on the term debt facility was fixed on A$200 million of the debt in the first four years, on A$145 million for five years and on A$154 million of the capital spending tranche for six years.
On maturity the full amount of the term debt facility would be refinanced on a similar basis.
Envestra also announced earlier it would issue A$215 million of capital indexed bonds underwritten by Macquarie Bank Ltd and the Australian Mutual Provident Society.  
The bonds would rank equally with the bank debt, with A$160 million of the bonds maturing in 2007 and the remaining A$55 million due in 2012.
The principal outstanding would be refinanced on a similar basis.
The interest rate on the first A$160 million had been fixed for 10 years and the rate on the rest had been fixed for 15 years.
The principal component of the bonds would be indexed by the quarterly change in the Consumer Price Index.  
"Envestra's cash flows are well suited to borrowings where the debt service obligations are linked to the general level of inflation because the Access Charges that the regulator allows Envestra are likely to reflect changes in costs that are likely to be linked to movements in the CPI," Envestra said in its prospectus.
A spokesman for Macquarie was not immediately available for comment.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: BHP announces copper/minerals appointments.
text:
The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd said on Tuesday it had made three group general manager appointments to its copper and minerals units.
BHP said John Grubb was appointed senior vice president of BHP Minerals Zimbabwe, Colin Palethorpe senior vice president, BHP Copper, San Francisco, and Roger Higgins senior vice president of BHP Copper Pacific and managing director, OK Tedi Mining Ltd.
Higgins, formerly general mine manager at Minera Escondida takes on Grubb's previous role while Grubb takes on Palethorp's former position.  
"These changes will occur progressively over the next few months ahead to allow the necessary time for an effective transition and hand-over of responsibilities," the company said.
BHP said Palethorpe, who joined BHP in 1972, was returning to San Francisco to join the growth and technology team of BHP Copper after leaving in 1994 to take up his position in Zimbabwe.
-- Melbourne Bureau 61-3 9286-1435

headline: Qn Charlotte sets purchase, shares deal.
text:
New Zealand holding company Queen Charlotte Holdings Limited said on Tuesday it had entered into a conditional agreement to purchase the development rights to a 10,000 square metre themed aquarium in Shanghai.
The planned deal involves taking over the Chang Feng Park project from interests associated with leisure and property developer Ken Wikeley, who recently took a call option over a 53 percent stake in Queen Charlotte.
In a statement Queen Charlotte said it planned to issue an initial 40 million shares on settling the deal and would also seek to raised further capital through a private placement.  
The agreement is conditional on a number of matters, the company said, noting that holders of the company's existing 57 million shares would be entitled to one free option for every two shares they hold in Queen Charlotte.
"Shareholders on the register in March 1998 will receive this option entitlement to purchase one fuly paid ordinary Queen Charlotte share for 20 cents in June 1999," it added.
A special meeting is due to be held in October.
--Wellington newsroom +64 4 471 4273
e-mail wellington.newsroom@reuters.com

headline: Power NZ delays AGM amid legal wrangling.
text:
Power New Zealand Limited, currently subject to a joint takeover plan by U.S.-controlled Utilicorp NZ and local company Mercury, said on Tuesday it would postpone an annual shareholders meeting until September 11 due to pending legal procedures related to its ownership.
Several legal initiatives have been started by Power NZ's independent directors, relating to a cornerstone agreement between PNZ and Utilicorp, and because of these, and the need to keep shareholders informed of such issues, the company said in a statement it was delaying its planned meeting.
--Wellington newsroom +64 4 471 4273  
e-mail wellington.newsroom@reuters.com

headline: RTRS-Aristocrat share trading suspended.
text: Trading in shares of gaming machine maker Aristocrat Leisure Ltd have been suspended pending an announcement on an application for a gaming licence in the United States, the Australian Stock Exchange said on Tuesday.

headline: RTRS-Westpac Australia May leading index rises.
text:
The Westpac-Melbourne Institute Leading Index of Australian economic activity, which indicates where activity will be in six to nine months, rose by 1.3 percent in May and the annual growth rate rose to 8.2 percent.
The Coincident Index, which provides a broad measure of the current state of economic activity, rose 0.1 percent, but the annual growth rate remained negative at minus 0.5 percent.
The Leading Index of Inflation fell to 4.2 percent in May from 4.4 percent in April.  
"The clear implication from the Leading Index is that better times are ahead for the economy," said Nigel Stapledon, chief economist at Westpac.
"The annual growth rate of the Index at 8.2 percent, and averaging a more indicative 6.1 percent over the past three months, compares favourably with long term growth of 2.7 percent," he said.
He said activity will certainly be stronger in 1998 and expects some improvement to be emerging through the course of the second half of 1997.  
"The strength of the Leading Index is not sufficient to dissuade the Reserve Bank from mandating another cut in interest rates either before or at its next board meeting on August 5," Stapledon said.
"While the economy is set to improve, given the degree of slack in the economy, there is ample room for further stimulus without posing risk to inflation," he said.
On the Coincident Index, Stapledon said that it continues to run well below the trend, reflecting the weak state of the economy in the first half of 1997.
"That is now history," he added.  
"The Leading Index of Inflation declined in May and has been in a steady trend decline since mid 1995, indicating inflation pressures will continue to be absent for some time to come," Stapledon said.
The absence of inflationary pressures is expected to be confirmed this week with the release of the Consumer Price Index and wages data for the second quarter due on Wednesday and Thursday.  
The headline CPI is set to fall well below 1.0 percent, helped by falling mortgage rates, and more significantly the Treasury underlying measure is set to fall below 2.0 percent, which will be below the bottom of the RBA's target range of 2.0-3.0 percent, he added.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Australian wheat outlook remains uncertain - AWB.
text:
The outlook for Australia's 1997/98 wheat crop remained uncertain, Trevor Flugge, chairman of the Australian Wheat Board (AWB), said on Tuesday.
Current crop projections were based on the assumption that the area sown to wheat would be similar to last year, at about 11 million hectares, despite the threat of drought, he said.
The Bureau of Meteorology's confirmation of the return of the El Nino weather effect indicated that drier than average conditions would persist over the next 12 to 15 months, he told the New South Wales Farmers' Association annual conference in Tamworth.  
"It must be stressed at this point that El Nino is only affecting a small part of Australia. Opening rains have been very favourable across much of New South Wales (NSW), Queensland and Western Australia," Flugge said in a speech released here.
The timing and distribution of further rainfall during winter would determine the scope for Australia's wheat production in 1997/8, he said.
"It is always difficult to give any forecast of the Australian wheat crop this early in the season and the El Nino phenomenon makes it particularly difficult this year," he said.  
Flugge said the AWB had recently revised its national wheat crop estimate to 15 to 16 million tonnes from 18 million tonnes.
The AWB chief's view of prospects for Australia's 1997/98 wheat crop was echoed by other grains industry leaders at the conference.
Xavier Martin, chairman of NSW Farmers' grains committee, said the 1997/98 crop "stands on a knife-edge".
"In much of the state (of NSW) rain is desperately needed," he said.  
"At the same time, prices are looking relatively lacklustre and we need a significant lift in prices. I am slightly more optimistic about that than I am about all regions receiving timely rains," he said.
Traders believed international wheat prices had hit bottom, Flugge told the conference.
AWB estimated increasing demand for 1997/98, he said. "Stronger world wheat demand should continue to keep pace with increasing wheat supplies, however it is unlikely that world stocks will be drawn down in 1997/98," Flugge said.  
"World ending stocks are likely to build by around five million tonnes, easing further the tightness that characterised the wheat balance sheet in early 1996/97."
Flugge said the AWB believed 1997/98 export availability from the five major wheat exporters was likely to decline by 17-18 million tonnes from 1996/97, with Australia, Argentina and Canada to experience lower wheat production.
Larger production from former Soviet Union republics and Eastern Europe was likely to produce significantly higher wheat exports from these countries, making up some of the shortfall, he said.  
Overall import demand in 1997/98 was expected to increase by about two million tonnes, with stronger import demand in western and southern Asia and northern Africa, he said.
China was likely to import only 3.5 million tonnes of wheat in 1997/98, slightly more than in 1996/97 but well down from the 12 million tonnes imported in 1995/96, he said. This followed steadily increasing Chinese self-sufficiency, he said.
The prospect of a re-emergence of European Union (EU) wheat export subsidies was a market focus as the EU 1997/98 wheat marketing campaign neared, Flugge said.  
"However, the risk of overheating EU domestic wheat prices as well as budgetary concerns should see the EU avoiding such aggressive tactics if possible, at least in the near term," he said.
The U.S. was similarly likely to wish to avoid the use of subsidies in the absence of competitor subsidies, he said.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Davids says Shane Allan is finance officer.
text:
Food wholesaler and retailer Davids Ltd said on Tuesday that former Telstra Corp executive Shane Allan has been appointed as its chief finance officer.
Davids said in a statement that Allan, who had fomerly been director of corporate services and finance at the government-owned telecommunications group, would start on September 1.
"His appointment further strengthens the revised management team we have put in place at Davids to lead the business into the future," executive chairman John David said in a statement.  
Joint managing director John Patten resigned last month due to ill health.
Patten's resignation prompted a number of management and organisational changes, with Jeff David appointed managing director.
That reorganisation included the temporary appointment of Don Bourke as chief financial officer while a permament candidate was sought.
Bourke joined Davids to assist in the rationalistion and integration of Davids' recent acquisitions.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Complaint against NZ MP Kopu sent to committee.
text:
The New Zealand parliament's speaker Doug Kidd on Tuesday referred a complaint by the opposition Alliance against its former MP Alamein Kopu to the powerful privileges committee.
Kopu resigned from the Alliance last week and its leader Jim Anderton asked the Speaker to rule on whether she had resigned from parliament by leaving the Alliance.
The Alliance said it had legal advice that Kopu effectively resigned from Parliament because she signed an agreement on July 12 that she would resign if she left the Alliance.  
Kidd said he would refer the matter to the committee, but was making no judgment on the complaint other than that it was not a trivial matter.
"(The validity of the complaint) is not a matter for the speaker to determine. That is a matter for the House.
"Therefore until the House or a court has decided to the contrary she will continue to be treated in all respects as a member of parliament," Kidd said.
The Privileges Committee can make a recommendation to the House which then has the final say.  
The Alliance has said that by leaving the group Kopu had disturbed the proportionality of the House determined by the party vote under the mixed member proportional system adopted for the 1996 election.
-- Wellington newsroom 64 4 473 4746
e-mail - wellington.newsroom@reuters.com

headline: Australia launches A$125 million ocean clean-up.
text:
The Australian government said on Tuesday it would spend A$125 million (US$92.5 million) over the next five years on a new environmental strategy to clean up seas and beaches and protect endangered marine species.
The Coasts and Clean Seas Strategy was the latest initiative in a A$1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust and would help protect the island nation's vast coastline and surrounding seas, deputy prime minister Tim Fischer said.
"The government is committed to protecting marine species like whales, fish, sharks, seabirds and turtles, while promoting job-creating ocean industries in a way which does not threaten our marine environment," Fischer said in a statement.
The strategy, to be funded by the partial sale of state-owned telephone company Telstra Corp Ltd, comprises 15 separate projects.
Among them, A$51 million will be spent reducing pollution from sewage and storm water and another A$8 million on the protection of endangered marine life.
About A$4 million will also be spent on the eradication of marine pests brought to Australia by ships and which threaten the survival of native Australian fish, animals and plants.
Oil spills, the promotion of sustainable fishing practices and greener coastal development will also be targetted.
Fischer said a A$1.5 million oceans policy would include the monitoring and control of illegal fishing of species such as the Patagonian toothfish in the Antarctic and Australian waters.
Almost A$8 million will be spent on establishing more protected marine parks such as the Great Barrier Reef off northern Queensland state.
Australia's coastline stretches 36,735 km (22,776 miles) and is bordered by the South Pacific Ocean in the east and the Indian Ocean in the west. Australia also administers eight external territories, including the Australian Antarctic territory and the McDonald Islands in the sub-Antarctic.
(A$1 = US$0.74)

headline: Australia succeeds on inflation, now jobs wanted.
text:
Consumer price figures for the June quarter on Wednesday are confidently expected to confirm that Australia has won its battle with inflation in emphatic style.
The underlying measure of inflation could well be at its lowest level in 27 years while the Consumer Price Index should show a fall in the quarter.
The last time that happened was in 1992 when the economy was just emerging from recession.  
But the victory has been tarnished by stubbornly high unemployment, leaving some analysts wondering if the Reserve Bank was not in danger of being too successful.
"Underlying inflation at the lowest level on record is a fantastic result," said Tony Meer, an economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "But any lower would be an over-achievement."
Defeating inflation may be an end in itself for bond markets, but some more tangible advantage must be shown if public support for the battle is to be maintained.
The most meaningful benefit to the public was jobs and interest rates, and there was room for improvement on both.  
"If you have unemployment stuck above eight percent you risk losing the support of the broader community," said Meer.
"That would be a tragedy because when the next supply side shock comes and inflation threatens once more, the RBA will need the community behind it," he said.
Stephen Koukoulas, chief economist at Citibank Australia, also argued that curbing inflation was not the real objective.
"The whole point of low inflation is that you can have low interest rates so investment is biased toward productive ends rather than mere asset price speculation," he said.  
"The nation deserves a reward for this inflation performance which is why, if these figures are as good as we think they'll be, the RBA should get on with the job and cut," he said.
The median forecast for the underlying measure favours a 0.4 percent rise for the quarter which would take the annual rate to 1.7 percent from 2.1 in Q1, the lowest reading since the series began in 1971.
The consumer price index was expected to actually fall by 0.1 percent taking annual growth to just 0.5 percent from 1.3 percent. The highest estimate was a modest 0.2 percent and a handful reckoned the fall could be as large as 0.3 percent.  
The improvement has largely been driven by falling mortgage charges which reflects both increased competition amongst lenders and past cuts in official interest rates.
All analysts agreed the achievement was an impressive one.
When the heady pace of economic growth in 1994 looked to be stoking inflation and threatening the RBA's 2-3 percent target the bank hiked rates three times in five months.
The pre-emptive strike ensured the underyling rate peaked at just 3.3 percent in Q1 1996, compared to a high in the previous cycle of 9.9 percent in 1986 and a sky-high peak for the series of 21.9 percent during the oil price shock of the early 1970s.  
The resulting slowdown of price growth has also been brisk compared to the glacial pace of past improvements, giving rise to much speculation that a new, low inflation era had dawned.
"Looking from here, it stretches as far as the eye can see," said Koukoulas. "Our model for underlying inflation shows it not moving above two percent until next year and not troubling three percent until 1999," he said.
There was a caveat, however, in that this assumed no lasting weakness in the Australian dollar.
But DMG's Meer reckoned the depreciation in the currency so far -- around six percent this year -- was not yet a threat.  
"Industry has no pricing power at the moment so even if import prices rise they can't pass it on to the consumer," he said.
-- Sydney newsroom 61-2 9373 1800

headline: Australia's Costello in Melbourne for CPI data.
text:
Australian Treasurer Peter Costello will hold a news conference on Wednesday in Melbourne at 0200 GMT (12.00 p.m.), his office said on Tuesday.
Costello will comment on the June quarter inflation figures and announce the 1996/97 preliminary budget outcome.
The inflation data will be released at 11.30 a.m. (0130 GMT) by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
-- Canberra Bureau 61-6 273-2730

headline: SFE wheat rises strongly again in market squeeze.
text:
Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) wheat futures continued to rise strongly on good volume on Tuesday.
A total of 46 contracts changed hands, with traded prices rising by between A$4.00 and A$7.50 a tonne.
November 1997 added A$4.00 to A$192.00 a tonne, January 1998 jumped by A$7.50 to A$194.00 while March 1998 traded A$5.50 higher at A$195.00 a tonne.
Settlement prices in untraded contracts rose by similar amounts.

headline: Cultus shares climb in choppy trade.
text:
Shares in second tier oil firm Cultus Petroleum NL climbed 5.7 percent to A$3.70 by midday on Tuesday as long running takeover speculation sparked again in an otherwise lacklustre market, traders said.
The A$3.70 level reached today is equal to a seven week high. Since January 1 the shares have nearly tripled in value from A$1.26 to today's high, touching an all time peak on May 29 of A$4.05.
Sentiment about the stock has been boosted by its interests in significant finds such as the Cornea field offshore Western Australia and in Victoria's Otway Basin.  
"There has been nothing new around the traps today but people think these smaller oil stocks will all be taken over anyway," said a dealer at a Sydney brokerage, noting the longer term view of many in the market.
The dealer pointed to patchy trade which saw two parcels of 500,000 shares each dominate otherwise ordinary turnover.
"There is two lines of half a million but the rest is all bits and pieces."
Analysts noted the presence of giant global oil operators in joint ventures with the company, suggesting that it would not surprise to see a bid eventuate in the future.  
"With the areas it has, it would make it simpler for one of the big players to take it out," said a Sydney resource analyst.
Cultus's partners in the Cornea find are Royal Dutch/Shell Group whose Australian unit operates the WA-241-P permit joint venture and holds 50 percent. Chevron Corp unit Chevron Asiatic Ltd and Cultus each hold 25 percent of the permit. The company is due to report its fourth financial quarter activities report by the end of July.
By 1.25 p.m. (0325 GMT), Cultus shares were just off day highs, up 19 cents at A$3.19, on turnover of 1.3 million shares.
-- Walter Watson, Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373 1810

headline: Australia's Fischer says rate cuts help dlr.
text:
Australian deputy prime minister Tim Fischer said on Tuesday that local interest rate cuts had boosted economic activity and this was flowing through to a more realistic value for the Australian dollar.
"It is starting to build the confidence and the burst of activity for the economy we much need and with that I have got to say it also helps engender a more realistic value for the Australian dollar," Fischer said after a meeting of the national government's Cabinet here.  
Asked if another rate cut was possible if the second quarter consumer price index to be released on Wednesday showed zero inflation, he said;
"I would simply allow that the disciplines of our budget has facilitated a lower interest rate structure here in Australia and I hope that is going to continue ...," he said.
Based on a poll of economists, the median forecast for the underlying measure is an 0.4 percent rise for the quarter which would take the annual rate to 1.7 percent from 2.1 in the firs quarter.  
The consumer price index was expected to actually fall by 0.1 percent taking annual growth to just 0.5 percent from 1.3 percent. The highest estimate was a modest 0.2 percent and a handful reckoned the fall could be as large as 0.3 percent.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Pacific Retail sees NZ$6 mln pre-tax in H1.
text:
Appliance and computer retailer Pacific Retail Group on Tuesday reaffirmed that it was on track to post a NZ$6 million operating profit before tax in the six months ending September 30.
In the annual report, managing director Greg Lancaster said directors had been encouraged by the improved profit streams generated by the group since January.
"The appliance retail market is likely to remain difficult this year, but the benefits of the Bond & Bond merger and the hire purchase securitisation are coming to account," he said.  
"Based on current pre-tax operating profits of $1 million a month and given no market deterioration -- pre-tax earnings for the six months ending September 30 are likely to be about $6 million."
Pacific Retail posted a $3.8 million pre-tax profit in the year ending March 31. Its $2.3 million tax paid annual profit compared with a $2.1 million profit the previous year.
Pacific Retail chairman Roger Bhatnagar also confirmed he will step down later this year. He will remain on the board as an executive director.  
Bhatnagar and Lancaster bought the company, formerly Noel Leeming, in 1991 before spearheading a public share float in 1993. In that time, the company's annualised turnover has increased to over $300 million from $90 million, Pacific Retail said.
--Wellington Newsroom +64 4 4714 272
e-mail wellington.newsroom@reuters.com

headline: Bill Skate elected Papua New Guinea prime minister.
text:
Bill Skate, the mayor of Port Moresby, was elected prime minister of Papua New Guinea on Tuesday in a parliamentary vote.
Skate will head a coalition of former ruling parties decimated at the June election, opposition parties including his own People's National Congress, and independents. He beat former prime minister Sir Michael Somare by 71 votes to 35 in a vote in the South Pacific nation's new parliament.  
Ironically, Skate had campaigned strongly against the former government of Sir Julius Chan, charging it with corruption and speaking out against a plan to use mercenaries against separatists on Bougainville island.
Former deputy prime minister Chris Haiveta, who was criticised by a judicial inquiry into the failed mercenary plan, was expected to be a contender for the number two job.
Chan's coalition suffered a major defeat in last month's elections, with 15 ministers losing their seats in a voter backlash against alleged political corruption and the mercenary plan.
Chan, who lost his seat after 29 years in parliament, hired African mercenaries in a US$36 million deal to try to end the nine-year seccessionist revolt on resource-rich Bougainville island. The plan was foiled by an army and civil uprising.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: UBS and Babcock Brown to bid for AIDC.
text:
A consortium made up of U.S.-owned financial group Babcock and Brown Pty Ltd and Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS) had been granted an exclusive period to finalise its offer for finance and infrastructure investment group AIDC Ltd, the Australian government said on Tuesday.  
Subject to confirmation of the offer, contacts for the sale of AIDC should be exchanged by the end of August, Finance Minister John Fahey said in a statement.
The government said in a statement that Babcock and Brown was a subsidiary of U.S. financial institution Babcock and Brown Inc, which specialised in the arrangement of structural finance and project finance transactions.
UBS was a major global bank with a strong presence in the wholesale banking financial markets in Australia.

headline: UBS and Babcock to bid for AIDC.
text: A consortium made up of Babcock and Brown Pty Ltd and Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS) had been granted an exclusive period to finalise its offer for finance and infrastructure investment group AIDC Ltd, the Australian government said on Tuesday.

headline: Reduced Australia industry protection needed - ABARE.
text:
Reductions in industry protection were necessary if the potential for growth in aggregate income in the Australian economy were to be realised, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) said.
Protection for specific industries may sustain those industries but at a cost to others and reduced income for the nation overall, senior economist Ivan Roberts said in releasing ABARE's latest study, Advantages of Trade Reform for Australia.
"Gains to aggregate incomes can be achieved through reducing industry protection irrespective of whether other countries do likewise," he said in a statement.  
"Nevertheless, the greatest gains arise if reductions occur elsewhere as well as in Australia," Roberts said.
Assistance to Australian manufacturing had been declining and was now much the same as for agriculture, he said.
However, within manufacturing and agriculture there remained activities which were heavily assisted, including textiles, clothing and footwear, motor vehicles and parts and milk, he said.
"There is room for greater efficiency of resource use within the economy and associated increases in aggregate incomes through more liberal trade policies," he said.  
Industry protection could not provide a basis for increasing aggregate income and may not increase employment, Roberts said.
It supported some groups at the expense of others and reduced aggregate national income, he said.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Sons of Gwalia posts record production.
text:
Gold miner Sons of Gwalia Ltd said on Tuesday it produced a record 509,654 ounces of gold in 1996/97 (July/June), up from 303,115 ounces the previous year.
Production for the quarter ended June 30 was 134,726 ounces at an average cash cost of A$400 per ounce.
Managing director Peter Lalor said the company was reviewing its assets in order to achieve optimum results at the current gold price.
However he said the company's future was sound given its "large reserve and resource base, our prospective ground position and a significant and valuable hedge book".  
The company's hedge book totalled 4.9 million ounces, with a market value of A$353 million at the July 8 spot price of A$429 an ounce.
Sons of Gwalia said it had also boosted its reserves by 7.5 percent to about 3.29 million ounces of gold. Its operations are based in Western Australia.
Lalor said the review of operations was due as much to the change in sentiment towards gold and reduced hedging opportunities as the fall in the gold price.  
"The reality is we are in a different period," Lalor told Reuters. "The economics of the gold industry have changed."
Lalor said all the company's producing assets would come under review, although it would not focus solely on mines with higher operations costs, such as Bullfinch and Laverton.
The review would also consider holdings in various regions, exploration potential, and the potential to reduce costs and optimise mine plans, he said.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: NAB says sector reform to save A$4 bln/yr.
text:
National Australia Bank Ltd managing director Don Argus said on Tuesday that the reform of Australia's finance sector could save the country A$4 billion a year through improved efficiencies.
Argus, in notes released before a speech to the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Melbourne, restated criticism that reform of the Australian finance industry had been stalled by the national government and the industry itself.  
"Our banking and financial services system is estimated to cost Australia A$40 billion to run. Even a modest saving of 10 percent a year through improved efficiencies would provide benefits of A$4 billion a year," Argus said.
The potential savings were much more than could be achieved through reform of the waterfront or other microeconomic initiatives.
It was imperative the government moved quickly to implement changes advocated by the Wallis inquiry into Australia's finance system, Argus said.  
Earlier this month Argus criticised the government's block on big bank mergers, saying it was a myopic and farcical attempt to hold off industry rationalisation.
Argus said the current period of uncertainty for Australian industry required leaders of government and industry to clearly and forcefully articulate their policies and positions.
"What we (Australia) appear to lack is the desire to collectively address issues..be clear in our policy prescriptions..and then put these openly to our various stakeholders," he said.  
Argus said there was no doubt Australia's finance sector was more open and competitive than most Asian nations but argued that the appetite was lacking for the type of reforms which would take the industry as a global leader in the next century.
"When I talk of reform, I have in mind an integrated package of government policy, regulation and corporate initiatives designed to ensure Australia reflects..and does not deflect, global realities," Argus said.
NAB has disagreed with Australia's three other major banks, ANZ Banking Group Ltd, Westpac Banking Corp and Commonwealth Bank of Australia over prudential and systemic reform.
NAB has argued for a more deregulated environment which opens up the market to competition from non-banks and allows big bank mergers.
The other three want the Reserve Bank to keep its prudential power and have not argued so strongly for big-bank mergers.
NAB is seen the most likely predator if big-bank mergers are allowed by the government, which said in April when it released the Wallis report it wanted to see more competition develop before releasing the shackles.
-- Melbourne Bureau 61-3 9286-1435

headline: Australia's Optus appoints Gillespie as CFO.
text:
Australian telecommunications group Optus Communications Pty Ltd said on Tuesday that it had appointed former Cable and Wireless Plc executive Norman Gillespie as its chief financial officer.
Gillespie follows a string of C&W executives who have joined Optus since the appointment of Peter Howell-Davies as chief executive officer last month. C&W also has financial control of Optus after it doubled its stake to 49 percent on July 1.
Optus said Michael Stefanovski, who acted as chief financial officer in recent months will return to his position of director, finance.  
Howell-Davies said in a statement that Stefanovski will be discussing future roles within Optus or the C&W group.
On his appointment Gillespie said: "I am committed to help build the long term financial strength of Optus through the relentless pursuit of delivering on tough targets, underpinned by uncomprising determination to please customers."
Prior to joining Optus, Gillespie was director of group planning and accounting for C&W in London.
-- Sydney newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Australian wage deals average 4.9 pct in Q2 - HSBC.
text:
Major Australian wage deals under the enterprise bargaining system produced average increases of around 4.9 percent in the June quarter, the HSBC Markets Wages Report said.
This is a marked increase on both the 4.0 percent estimated in the March quarter and 4.2 percent for the December quarter.
"It is not enough to prevent a fifth rate cut, but the trend of enterprise bargaining outcomes in the June quarter will give Reserve Bank Governor Ian Macfarlane cause for concern over wages pressure in coming months," said John Edwards, chief economist at HSBC Markets.  
The increase in average wage payments comes at the same time as annual inflation is rapidly falling.
HSBC expect Wednesday's release of the second quarter annual headline Consumer Price Index to rise only 0.4 percent and 1.8 percent for the Treasury underlying rate.
"Real earnings are thus rising at the quite rapid rate of over 3.0 percent in large sections of industry, despite high unemployment and only moderate output growth," Edwards said.  
"This is a much higher increase than the current overall rate of productivity growth, which is nearly flat. It is also likely to be higher than average productivity growth in many of the industries concerned," he added.
HSBC's preliminary survey of upcoming agreements for the September quarter shows there are a number of quite high settlements likely in construction and in retail banks.
"The trend to increased outcomes is more likely to speed up than slow down," Edwards said.  
In the June quarter major private sector agreements recorded an increase of 5.1 percent per employee, outpacing public sector bargains at an average 4.8 percent, HSBC said.

headline: Australian coal union says retains strike option.
text:
Striking miners at Coal and Allied Ltd's Hunter Valley No.1 mine would return to work from midnight Tuesday but would continue to negotiate with the company, said Ross Peters, union president at the mine north of Sydney.
The prospect remained of the the union striking again if it did not achieve a satisfactory workplace agreement in negotiations with the company, Peters told Reuters.
"If the negotiations fall down, protected action is still available to us. It's an option that we would look seriously at," he said.  
Negotiations would start on Wednesday and pickets would remain in place during the 21 day negotiating period.
The talks would be betweene the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union (CFMEU) and Coal and Allied. The Industrial Relations Commission had offered any assistance necessary or requested by the parties, Peters said.
A train being loaded by union labour on Tuesday morning would move around noon (0200 GMT), he said.
Work had resumed on terms recommended by the Australian Industrial Commission, he said. Union members had always offered to return to work to negotiate on these terms, he said.  
The company had removed staff workers at the mine, he added.
As earlier reported, Allan Davies, Coal and Allied's general manager at the Hunter Valley No 1 mine, told Reuters on Tuesday morning that the unionists were returning to work on the same terms as they began the strike. "They've gained nothing," he said.
Coal and Allied is 71 percent-owned by Anglo-Australian mining house Rio Tinto Ltd.  
The company's attempt to negotiate more flexible enterprise bargains with its workers, the main reason for the bitter six-week strike, is seen as a key battle in the Australian coal industry's efforts to improve profitability.
-- Michael Byrnes, Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Memtec appoints new Florida boss.
text:
Water filtration group Memtec Ltd said on Tuesday that production manager Tom Carroll would move to Florida to head the company's troubled Fluid Dynamics plant.
Carroll would move from his current position as Memtec's production manager in Timonium, Maryland, to take over in Florida, Memtec chairman Dennis Hanley said in a statement.
In what it described as an unrelated event, Memtec said Tom Hagen would step down from his post as president of Memtec America and Fluid Dynamics to take a "well earned vacation".
Hagen was expected to rejoin the company's senior management team later this year, the statement said.  
The group's senior management in Florida, including Carroll, would report to Memtec president and chief operating officer Andrew Denver for the time being.
A delay in expanding capacity at the Fluid Dynamics plant led to a sharp fall in that division's second quarter profits and was also responsible for a sharp fall in Memtec's share price this year.
Memtec reported sales in the first half of the year to June 30, 1997 of A$147.68 million.
Memtec is also listed in the United States on NASDAQ.  
Memtec's shares were up five cents at A$36.75 at 11.10 a.m. (0110 GMT) on insignificant trade.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Sydney Olympics awards radio rights to 2UE, ABC.
text:
The Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG) said on Tuesday it had awarded the Australian radio rights to the 2000 Olympics to the Australian Broadcasting Corp (ABC) and a commercial network led by Sydney's 2UE.
A bid by the Australian Radio Network, jointly owned by Australian Provincial News Ltd and the U.S. based Clear Channel Communications, was unsuccessful.
The privately-owned 2UE consortium is called Talk Australia and includes 3AW in Melbourne, 4BC in Brisbane, 5AA in Adelaide, 6PR in Perth and a group of almost 200 regional stations.  
The government-owned ABC planned to spread its Olympic coverage across all its networks, SOCOG said.
"It's great to have Australia's two most powerful broadcasters involved in the Sydney Games," SOCOG President Michael Knight said in a statement.
SOCOG said it would not disclose the value of rights.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Australian P-Notes - No Tenders.
text:
There were no promissory note tenders reported on Tuesday on the Australian commercial paper market after Monday's vibrant start to the week.
Traders said the absence of maturing issues and some caution ahead of a series of key events over the next couple of days, both locally and in the United States, kept fresh supply on the sidelines.
Australia releases its second quarter inflation report on Wednesday and quarterly average weekly ordinary time earnings on Thursday, while Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan delivers his semi-annual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony in the U.S. over the next two days.
