headline: Former PNG government set to form new coalition.
text:
Papua New Guinea's former coalition government looked likely to be returned to power as part of a new alliance on Tuesday after winning support of former political opponents.
In the first parliamentary sitting since last month's elections, a member of the former ruling Pangu party, John Pundari, was elected parliamentary speaker, defeating a group of parties and independents headed by former premier Sir Michael Somare.  
Rival parties then retired to select prime ministerial candidates with the victor chosen in an open parliamentary vote later on Tuesday and a government formed.
Former deputy prime minister Chris Haiveta, who was criticised by a judicial inquiry into a failed mercenary deal, and the mayor of Port Moresby Bill Skate were expected to contest the top job, although Somare could not be ruled out.
The former coalition government of Sir Julius Chan suffered a major defeat in last month's elections, with 15 ministers losing their seats in a voter backlash against alleged political corruption and the mercenary plan.
Chan, who lost his seat after 29 years in parliament, hired British-led African mercenaries in a US$36 million deal to try to end the nine-year seccessionist revolt on resource-rich Bougainville island.

headline: Ashton says slower diamond sales to persist.
text:
Ashton Mining Ltd on Tuesday said its diamond sales slowed in the June quarter and that weaker Asian demand would persist for the rest of 1997.  
Sales dipped in the June quarter, after a seasonally strong March quarter on the back of restocking by retailers after the Christmas period, Ashton said.
"This (drop) mainly reflects slack demand in the Japanese market and lower demand in Hong Kong and other parts of the Asian region," it said.
"These conditions are expected to persist in the second half."
Ashton markets its diamonds directly through its office in the world diamond trading centre of Antwerp. It left the De Beers-run Central Selling Organisation (CSO) in 1996.
Ashton reported total diamond production from its 40.1-percent-owned Argyle diamond mine in northwest Australia rose to 9.399 million carats for the June quarter, Ashton said.
This brings half-year production to June 30 to 16.44 million carats, down on 21.3 million carats a year ago, it said.
But Ashton said it was on track to achieve full-year production of at least 36 million carats, it said.  
In 1996, a total of 42 million carats were produced from Argyle, the world's biggest diamond mine.
The Argyle production figures include joint venture partner and mine manager Rio Tinto Ltd's share of output.
Ashton said a squeeze on margins was continuing, with weaker Asian demand offsetting strong demand from the polished market in the United States.
Ashton has already said it expects second-half earnings to be lower than in the same 1996 period, but has not lost hope of exceeding last year's net profit of A$20.57 million in 1997.  
Ashton on Tuesday noted CSO's recent statement that the cartel would report a fall in sales for the second half-year of calendar 1997. "At this stage (the CSO) appears to be set for a US$5 billion result for calendar year 1997," Ashton said.
Ashton on Tuesday highlighted the discovery during the June quarter of four new kimberlite pipes in the Buffalo Hills prospect in northern Alberta, Canada, as well as three new kimberlite pipes in Mali.
A total of 15 such pipes have been found in the Buffalo Hills area, Ashton Canada announced on Monday.
-- Melbourne bureau 613-9286-1421

headline: Australian stocks mark time at open.
text:
The Australian share market opened a touch lower on Tuesday as traders marked time ahead of Wednesday's key local inflation data and testimony from U.S. Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan later on Tuesday.
The All Ordinaries index shed 3.6 points to 2,649.8.
Trade was restrained with most preferring to sit on the sidelines ahead of the two events, which could both give indications on future interest rate movements.
"(Inflation) numbers tomorrow and Greenspan tonight, that's what everyone is watching," said a dealer from a Sydney-based investment bank, who thought the market would remain reluctant to move either way for the rest of the day.
"I think there will only be five to six points in it."
In a mixed and patchy market, building materials and energy group Boral was two cents higher at A$3.97 (US$2.94) after it detailed the A$910 million capital raising involved in the spinoff of gas distribution arm, Envestra. Boral also said it was to pay A$33 million to move to 100 percent of U.S.-based Monex Resources, a processor of coal combustion by-products.
Elsewhere, the gold sector remained under pressure with heavyweight Normandy Mining dropping two percent to A$1.55. Newcrest Mining was also down two percent at A$2.66.
Rises outnumbered falls by a ratio of about six to five, while about 46 percent of stocks traded remained steady.
(A$1=US$0.74)

headline: Ports of Auck volumes up 15 pct in June yr.
text:
Ports of Auckland said on Tuesday container volumes grew nearly 15 percent to over 464,000 TEU's (twenty-foot equivalent units) in the year to June 30, 1997.
This compared with 405,000 TEU's for the previous year.
"Nearly 3.9 million tonnes of non-containerised cargo were moved through the port, an increase of eight percent over the previous year," Ports of Auckland said in a statement.
"In total, Ports of Auckland handled more than 11.3 million tonnes, compared to 10.1 million tonnes in 1996. This is an increase of more than 12 percent."  
The port had 2,381 ship calls, an increase of four percent over the previous year. Only ships over 500 gross tonnes were included in this count.
Ports of Auckland Chief Executive, Geoff Vazey, said the continued strong growth in container trade through Auckland reflected the number of services which use Auckland as a hub port.
"A growing number of containers are trans-shipped through Auckland. These containers come in and out of Auckland on major international lines and then are transported to other New Zealand centres by road, rail or on coastal shipping services."  
Vazey said there was strong growth in volumes in the second half of the financial year. Container throughput between January and June 1997 was 245,000 TEU's compared to 219,000 TEU's between June and December 1996.
"We enjoyed very strong growth in the second half year because there were high volumes of containerised exports, particularly dairy products."
Vazey said the port had achieved excellent volume growth in spite of mixed economic conditions through the year, largely because of its investments made to attract hub services.  
More than 50 percent of New Zealand's total container trade comes through Auckland. In order to accommodate the continuing growth in the container trade through Auckland, the company plans to upgrade and extend Fergusson Container Terminal.
It has also invested $35 million to develop Bledisloe Container Terminal as a specialised container facility. This included the construction of a new container crane, the relocation of an existing crane and the introduction of a straddle carrier operation.
Ports of Auckland will announce its annual financial results for the year to June 30 on August 19.  
--Wellington Newsroom +64 4 4714 272
e-mail wellington.newsroom@reuters.com

headline: AGL backs Australian natgas deregulation.
text:
The Australian Gas Light Co (AGL) said on Tuesday that it welcomed the New South Wales state government's move to open the first stage of the deregulation of Australia's natural gas market from August 1.
The NSW Independent Pricing and Regulatory Tribunal (IPART) has approved AGL Gas Networks Ltd's Access Undertaking report on the deregulation of the Australian natural gas market.
"New South Wales and AGL have led the field in the introduction of the new competitive gas market," AGL managing director Len Bleasel said in a statement.  
"It's time all other states followed. True competition will only occur with a competitively open national market," he said.
Bleasel predicted national demand for natural gas would increase from its current level of 18 percent of primary energy share to more than 20 percent by the year 2000.
NSW acting energy minister John Aquilina said in a statement the opening of a competitive gas market would save consumers up to A$60 million a year.  
"According to the IPART this will result in around A$60 million a year being slashed from the gas bills of NSW customers by 1999/2000, on transportation costs alone, and these savings could increase in future years," Aquilina said.
He added industral and commercial gas consumers who use more than 100 terajoules or A$600,000 of gas a year would be the first to choose their suppliers and enter contracts with pipeline owners for delivery.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: NZ 77-day T-bills yield 8.486 pct at tender.
text:
The weighted average yield for NZ$75 million of 77-day treasury bills at Tuesday's tender was 8.486 percent versus 7.251 percent for a similar maturity at last week's tender, the Reserve Bank said.
Bids totalled NZ$272 million.
The weighted average yield for NZ$75 million of 168-day treasury bills was 7.995 percent versus 7.009 percent for a similar maturity at last week's tender.
Bids totalled $115 million.  
The weighted average yield for the NZ$50 million of 329-day treasury bills was 7.72 percent versus 6.942 percent for a similar maturity at last week's tender.
Bids totalled $62 million.
-- Wellington newsroom 64 4 4734 746

headline: Unions lose in coal strike - Australian govt says.
text:
Australian Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith on Tuesday welcomed the end of the six-week Hunter Valley coal dispute, but said the strike had failed to achieve anything for the unions.
"It is hard to see what the coalminers' union has obtained for its rank and file members as a result of industrial action in the last five or six weeks," Reith told reporters.
"I think it's been at a very great cost to individual miners as well as to the industry," he said.
Coal miners voted earlier on Tuesday to return to work from midnight on Tuesday at Rio Tinto Ltd unit Coal and Allied Ltd's Hunter Valley mine north of Sydney.
The workers, part of the Construction, Forestry Mining and Energy Union (CFMEU), voted to end a six-week strike which Coal and Allied estimated cost the company A$1 million a day in lost revenue.
"There's certainly been a very significant cost to the rank and file membership of the CFMEU but without any obvious benefit," Reith said before attending a cabinet meeting.
-- Canberra Bureau 61-6 273-2730

headline: NZ fund managers report a bumper June qtr - W.Mercer.
text:
New Zealand investment managers had a bumper June quarter thanks to a stunning return in overseas shares and good performances in New Zealand shares and property, William Mercer reported on Tuesday.
Rates of return before tax and expenses ranged from 6.6 percent (Colonial Investment Management) to 11.0 percent (AMP Investments) with a the median return being 9.2 percent.
It said superannuation funds with a June year should be able to report very strong returns -- ranging from 15.5 percent (Colonial Investment Management) to 23.9 percent (ANZFM).  
W.Mercer expects over half of all funds have earned a gross rate of return of over 20 percent for the year.

headline: Australia's ABA backs digital TV introduction.
text:
The Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) said on Tuesday it has recommended the government support the early introduction of digital terrestrial television (DTTB) broadcasting to Australia.
"DTTB will provide the foundation for television of the 21st century," ABA chairman Peter Webb said in a statement.
"The present analog system will not meet the expectations and needs of viewers in the next century while cable and satellite television systems that use digital transmission are restricted by the lack of digital receivers in the home."  
The ABA has recommended that DTTB be introduced as a high definition television (HDTV) system because this will ensure that all receivers are able to receive all types of future transmissions, Webb said.
"Already we see, both here and overseas, growing demand for larger screen home theatre style receivers.
"This demand will accelerate as large flat wall hanging television receivers become affordable," he said.  
Webb said the next step is the choice of DTTB transmission systems to use in Australia.
"The introduction of DTTB into Australia will require an enormous investment by the industry and to assist in encouraging this investment the ABA has recommended that existing broadcasters be given access to the technology in exchange for the eventual return of their analog channels when DTTB is fully establised," Webb said.
Digital terrestrial television is the transmission of digital signals from land-based transmitters to standard roof-top aerials.  
Australia has two state owned television broadcasters -- Australian Broadcasting Corp (ABC), Special Broadcasting Services (SBS) -- and three main commercial networks.
The private groups are the Nine Network, owned by Kerry Packer's Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd, Seven Network Ltd and Ten Network, which is controlled by Canada's Canwest Global Communications Corp.
-- Sydney newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: NZ's CentralPower doubles Q1 profit to NZ$2.1 mln.
text:
Manawatu power company CentralPower said on Tuesday it had doubled its first-quarter after-tax profit to NZ$2.1 million.
Chairman Allan Lockie told the company's annual meeting that the unaudited result was three percent ahead of plan and twice that achieved for the same period last year.
"The increased profit reflected the larger scale of the company following the merger with Electro Power and the subsequent cost savings that had been achieved," Lockie said.  
Palmerston North City power supplier Electro Power agreed to merge with its CentralPower neighbour in December. CentralPower said at the time it expected the deal would save about $3.0 million a year.
--Wellington Newsroom +64 4 4714 272
e-mail wellington.newsroom@reuters.com

headline: Coal & Allied says coal strike over.
text:
Striking coal miners voted on Tuesday morning to return to work at Rio Tinto Ltd unit Coal and Allied Ltd's Hunter Valley mine north of Sydney.
The decision ended a six-week strike which Coal and Allied estimated had cost the company A$1 million a day in lost revenue.
The workers, members of the Construction, Forestry Mining and Energy Union, voted 80 opercent to 20 percent to return to work from midnight on Tuesday, Allan Davies, general manager of the Hunter Valley Number One coal mine, told Reuters.  
The first train was expected to be moving with coal by about 10.45 am (2445 GMT) Tuesday. First shipments are expected to leave the port in about two days time.
Early shipments are scheduled for Korea and Italy.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Australian Stocks to Watch Today - July 22.
text:
Some Australian stocks to watch this morning:
* Australis Media Ltd A$0.215 (steady)
* News Corp Ltd A$6.16 (-0.098)
Australis is reported to still be in merger talks with fellow pay TV group Foxtel, which is jointly owned by News Corp and Telstra. Australis held a board meeting on Friday and an announcement is expected this week.
* Boral Ltd A$3.95 (-.22)
Boral's gas distribution business, Envestra, said before Tuesday's market open that it plans to raise A$910 million in debt and equity. On July 1, Boral said it would be paid A$889 million by Envestra. The difference between these figures are made up of transaction costs and stamp duty. The company also said in a separate statement that it would pay A$33 million to take full control of U.S. fly ash producer Monex Resources.

Aberfoyle to go ahead with A$125 million expansion of Gunpowder copper mine in northwest Queensland.

Burns Philp settled its long-running Estate Mortgage legal dispute with Meridian Investment by paying the trust A$90 million in cash and 12 million convertible notes at A$2.20 each.
-- Sydney newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Boral to boost Monex ownership to 100 pct.
text:
Boral Ltd said on Tuesday it would pay A$33 million to increase its ownership of Monex Resources Inc (Monex) to 100 percent from 34.5 percent.  
Boral said Monex, based in San Antonio, Texas, was the leading manager, processor and marketer of coal combustion by-products, or flyash, in the southeastern and south central United States.
Boral's Western Ash subsidiary had a similar leading position in the western United States, it said.
"This transaction will position Boral as the leader in the flyash resale market in the United States with annual sales in excess of A$100 million," Boral managing director Tony Berg said in a statement.  
"Together with our Australian flyash technology (the transaction) positions us well as a world leader in this field," he said.
Monex and Western Ash would operate under the name Boral Material Technologies Inc.
The deal was expected to be completed in late July.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800

headline: Bougainville rebels agree to release hostages.
text:
Bougainvillean rebels plan to release five Papua New Guinea soldiers held hostage since September 1996 as a sign of goodwill, according to a statement released on Tuesday.
"After exhaustive consultation amongst our leaders and my delegation, we are now, as our goodwill to the people of Papua New Guinea, agreed to release the five POWs held in South Bougainville," the statement, dated July 18 but released by New Zealand Foreign Affairs Minister Don McKinnon's office on Tuesday, said.
The statement was signed by Bougainville Revolutionary Army (BRA) Commander General Sam Kauona, BRA chief of operations Ishmael Toroama and Southern Commander Peter Naguou.
It said the hostages would be handed over to New Zealand government representatives on board the frigate Canterbury on Wednesday.
The place of the handover would be settled by negotiation between New Zealand and the BRA.
McKinnon welcomed the announcement.
"The decision reflects the unity which has emerged at Burnham and underpins a widespread desire for peace between all parties to the conflict. It is a very promising development," McKinnon said.
Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Saturday called on the rebels to release the five, and welcomed the signing of a peace declaration by BRA and PNG-backed Bougainville officials on Friday after two weeks of talks at the Burnham military camp near Christchurch.
Officials from the BRA and its political wing and the Bougainville Transitional Government (BTG) signed a declaration pledging to negotiate with the government, which was not a party to the talks, starting in September.
They also agreed to work towards a ceasefire, the demilitarisation of Bougainville and for an international peacekeeping force.
Thousands have died in the Bougainville conflict since landowners revolted in 1988 over damage caused by the huge Panguna copper mine, and the royalties they received from it.
The mine is owned by a unit of the Anglo-Australian giant Rio Tinto Ltd.
Pacific affairs commentator David Robie told Radio New Zealand from Port Moresby the release of the hostages could act as a kind of circuit-breaker.
"The new government tomorrow could certainly take this to good advantage to move steadily and strongly towards peace," he said.

headline: Asian crude - Heavy crudes poised to fall.
text:
The strength in Asia's heavy crude market was waning Tuesday as buyers took a step back and amid signs of weaker premiums.
But Minas could remain supported, as smaller export volumes leave limited spot supplies available for August, they added.  
Only 300,000 barrels of August Minas was heard on offer by two shosha, with most August volumes now committed.
There were rumours of 200,000 barrels of August Minas sold by a western trader to a shosha at ICP +70 cents per barrel.
But the trade was denied by the shosha.
Chinese Daqing crude was sold to a Japanese refiner around OSP +75, although the firm premium surprised many traders who saw the heavy crude market weaker.
But a small top-up parcel of August Duri was confirmed sold by a South Korean refiner at ICP +45 cents per barrel, a sharp fall from trades done at over ICP +$1.00.  
Cinta and Widuri crude trading was thin, with very few buyers heard.
The large Widuri and Cinta volumes allocated by Indonesia for August were expected to also put pressure on prices of these grades.
Light Asian crudes were marginally stronger, with a Belida trade heard done by an equity producer at ICP +18, although this deal probably had guaranteed dates, traders said.
The last Belida trade was to a U.S. major at ICP +12.
New Zealand Maui condensate loading 10-15 August was likely sold to a European major, although details were not confirmed.

headline: S.Korean yield closes higher on Ssangyong rumour.
text:
South Korean three-year corporate yields rose on Tuesday following rumours South Korea's sixth largest Ssangyong Group faced financial troubles, dealers said.
The group strongly denied cash-flow trouble rumours.
But dealers said Ssangyong's rumoured woes would continue to affect the debt market, pushing the corporate yields up to the 12.20 percent level.
* 3-yr corporates close up at 12.16 pct vs 12.13
* 3-mth CDs end flat at 12.20
* Overnight average same as Monday 11.55 pct  
The Bank of Korea stepped into the won/dollar market to chill speculative dollar buying interest by currency traders concerned about the nation's economy after financial troubles in the Kia Group and possible chain of defaults on debts by big conglomerates.
Dealers said the bank redeemed 150 billion won in Repurchase Agreements before maturity to ease liquidity in the market but they said the market was unmoved.
-- Jane Lee (822) 727 5648

headline: Southeast Asian currencies fragile despite lull.
text:
Southeast Asian currencies showed signs of succumbing to renewed pressure in late Tuesday trade after making a brief recovery earlier in the day.
Dealers said the dollar's surge to a 71-month high of 1.8071 marks in afternoon trade also weighed on Asian currencies.
They said early gains in the Malaysian ringgit and Singapore dollar were driven by funds cashing in on the dollar's sharp rise, but did not reflect a change in sentiment.
"People who were long were just taking profit. I believe this regional currency weakness is not over yet," said a U.S. bank dealer in Singapore.
The market is awaiting the results of an Asian central bankers meeting in Shanghai later this week.
"This wave of contagion hitting the regional currencies will be a relatively long running affair," said Desmond Supple, head of Asian currency research at BZW Asia.
Supple said the central bankers meeting could yield strong verbal support for the region's currencies, but added that he did not expect it to result in actual coordinated intervention.
"There's a broad-based reassessment of risk-reward valuations in the region. Given that genuine funds are leaving as well as speculators, that significantly increases the cost to the real economy of any intervention," he said.
The Indonesian rupiah bounced back as offshore players triggered stop-loss dollar sales below the 2,600 level in afternoon trade, dealers said.
The rupiah was quoted at about 2,590 to the dollar at 0920 GMT after rising as high as 2,5670 against 2,600 around midday.
"We didn't hear of any intervention today. The dollar was trading near the high of the band so people just got cautious," the Singapore dealer said.
The Indonesian central bank raised its intervention band by one point to 2,378/2,682 after the rupiah became the latest victim of a speculative attack on Monday. It plunged about 150 points to a historic 2,665 low against the dollar before staging a marginal recovery on central bank intervention.
But dealers said the dollar was likely to encounter strong buying interest on any moves towards the 2,550 level.
In Malaysia, the ringgit slipped back a notch to 2.6230 to the dollar against 2.6200 earlier.
Dealers said a further drop towards 2.65 was likely despite expectations Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad would intensify his criticism of speculative attacks on the ringgit.
News reports quoted Mahathir, due to return to Malaysia on Tuesday after a two-month absence, as saying there may have been a political agenda behind recent attacks on regional currencies.
Bank Negara Malaysia said its reserves had fallen to 61.9 billion ringgit as at July 15 against 70.7 billion a fortnight earlier, reflecting its recent efforts to defend the ringgit.
The Singapore dollar slipped back beyond the 1.46 level against the U.S. dollar in line with weakness in the ringgit.
Dealers said the currency was likely to head for 1.47/1.48 to the U.S. dollar despite positive export data and optimistic comments about the economy from government officials on Monday.
"In the short term, this is not so much about Sing dollar weakness as it is U.S. dollar strength," a dealer said.
The Thai baht weakened, partly due to rumours that Thai opposition parties were planning to bring a no-confidence motion against the government, dealers said.
"It's just natural for the opposition to create trouble with the current financial crisis in Thailand," said one.
The Philippine peso ended weaker at 28.15 to the dollar from 28 previously despite central bank sales of about $5.5 million during the day, Manila traders said.

headline: Tokyo stocks end lower as euphoria wanes.
text:
Tokyo stocks closed moderately lower on Tuesday as recent euphoria was watered down by a pull-back in Wall Street high-technology stocks, brokers said.
They also said the market awaited testimony by U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan starting later in the day, drawing energy out of the market.
"Investors flocked to adjust their positions in technology shares, but it doesn't mean the investment trend has changed," said Kokusai Securities Co senior trader Kaoru Ichikawa.
The 225-share Nikkei average closed down 92.30 points or 0.46 percent at 20,157.02.
September Nikkei futures slipped 100 points to close at 20,180. "There was no sign of a sell-off in U.S. stocks, so the Nikkei 225 will revive after a round of profit-taking," said Seiki Orimi, manager of the stock information service office at Dai-Ichi Securities Co Ltd.
On the Tokyo Stock Exchange's first section, turnover dwindled to 280 million shares on Tuesday, from 376 million on Friday. Japanese markets were closed on Monday for a holiday.
Losers outstripped winners 713 to 360, while 168 issues were unchanged. The broader-based TOPIX index gave up 7.76 points or 0.50 percent to end at 1,531.60. The Nikkei 300 was down 1.29 points or 0.43 percent at 298.09.
Market participants were keen to see if any comments from Greenspan affect Wall Street stocks.
But most brokers in Tokyo said there would be no major change in U.S. monetary policy amid tamed inflation.
"Some investors paused in the Tokyo market today, as they wanted to wait for further data about the state of the Japanese economy in the later half of this business year," Dai-Ichi's Orimi said.
An Economic Planning Agency (EPA) official said on Tuesday that Japan's diffusion index of leading economic indicators for June was likely to be below the "boom-or-bust" figure of 50.
Earlier on Tuesday, the EPA announced that the index for leading indicators in May was 33.3.
the official said the fact that the index has been below 50 for several months does not necessarily mean Japan's economy is going to slow down in the near future. Among high-tech shares, Hitachi Ltd fell 30 yen to 1,280 on trade of 4.018 million shares, the third-most actively traded issue on the first section.
Fujitsu Ltd also lost 30 yen to end at 1,660. Turnover was 4.01 million shares, the fourth-heaviest volume on the first section.
Some semiconductor-related issues also fell. Shares of Advantest Corp fell 380 yen to 9,820. Tokyo Electron Ltd slid 490 yen to end at 6,820. "High-tech shares such as Advantest and Tokyo Electron had been surging in recent sessions and were ready for a break," said Harushige Kobayashi, Yamaichi Securities deputy general manager. Shares of Honda Motor Co Ltd recovered. They rose 80 yen to close at 3,470. Honda was sold heavily on Friday due to a report that U.S. car dealers were asking a judge to grant class-action status for lawsuits against Honda following a kickback scandal.
A federal judge in Baltimore said on Friday he would most likely deny the bid for class-action status. By sector, decliners were led by securities, trading houses, oil, electrical equipment and precision instruments. The major gainers were air transport, credit/lease and electric power shares. The second section index was down 11.45 points at 1,799.32, with 5.74 million shares traded. The over-the-counter (OTC) index was down 8.76 points at 1,158.09.
-- Hiroko Nakata, Tokyo Equities Desk +81-3-3432-8027

headline: ASIAN EXOTICS - Currencies stable in late trade.
text:
Southeast Asian currencies recovered some of their recent losses on Tuesday as operators took profit on the dollar's recent sharp rise.
Dealers and economists said there was growing caution ahead of an Asian central bankers meeting at the end of the week but that the risk to the downside still loomed large for most of the region's currencies.
"This wave of contagion hitting the regional currencies will be a relatively long running affair. The danger is that this is a temporary calm we're seeing," said Desmond Supple, head of Asian currency research at BZW Asia.
Supple said the central bankers meeting could yield strong verbal support for the region's currencies but added that he did not expect it to result in actual coordinated intervention.
"There's a broad-based reassessment of risk-reward valuations in the region. Given that genuine funds are leaving as well as speculators, that significantly increases the cost to the real economy of any intervention," he said.
In Malaysia, the ringgit also received a boost from Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's comments expressing displeasure with the recent speculative assault on the currency.
Press reports quoted Mahathir, due to return to Malaysia after a two-month absence on Tuesday, as saying there may have been a political agenda behind the recent moves in regional currency markets.
"That's a very strong statement from him. So those funds which were very long (dollars) below the 2.60 level started to take profit," a European bank dealer in Singapore said.
He said the ringgit had already depreciated by over five percent from a recent high of 2.49 and operators were reluctant to push it towards a low of 2.65 to the dollar.
The ringgit hit a 38-month low of 2.6450 in London markets on Friday.
"The moves have been on very thin volume. It's been purely a speculative attack and the market will see that Malaysia's not as bad as perceived," he said.
But he added that domestic dollar demand from corporate parties caught out by the dollar's sharp run-up would limit the ringgit's upside and the dollar should find good support at the psychological 2.60 ringgit level for the time being.
The ringgit was quoted at 2.6170/200 to the dollar at 0415 GMT against 2.6250/300 at its Kuala Lumpur close on Monday.
Further south, the Singapore dollar firmed above the 1.46 level against its U.S. counterpart as players turned less bearish after the release of positive trade data on Monday.
Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose a nominal 8.8 percent year-on-year in June against forecasts of a 6.3 percent nominal rise after May's 1.0 percent fall.
Comments by government officials predicting a turnaround in global electronics demand in the coming months also supported sentiment, dealers said.
Electronic exports account for about 70 percent of Singapore's non-oil domestic exports.
The dealer said wariness of possible central bank resistance was also preventing operators from pushing the Singapore dollar down towards 1.47 to the U.S. dollar.
He said local corporates had sold about $100 million from the 1.4630/40 levels but the U.S. dollar was likely to meet fresh buying interest around 1.4550.
In Indonesia, the rupiah hovered around the 2,600 to the dollar level after falling prey to an aggressive attack on Monday.
"It's a fight to break the 2,600 resistance level for the rupiah. Singapore players are defending the resistance. We are waiting to see who has more bullets," a U.S. bank dealer in Jakarta said. He added that local operators were steadily unloading dollars.
"If the 2,600 level is broken, the dollar can fall all the way down to as low as 2,570," a local bank dealer said.
He said many operators could be forced to cut losses in the afternoon when London markets open if the rupiah broke the 2,600 resistance level.
The rupiah became the latest victim of a speculative attack on Monday, plunging about 150 points to a historic 2,665 low against the dollar before staging a marginal recovery on central bank intervention.
Indonesian Finance Minister Mar'ie Muhammad said on Tuesday the attack on the rupiah was not related to fundamentals and that the government had no plans to change its monetary policy.
The Thai baht lost ground in domestic markets, where players returned from a long weekend and fretted about the impending release of data on financial institutions' non-performing loans. The baht was quoted at 30.880/30.980 to the dollar in the local market versus 30.42/30.47 baht late Friday.
"The baht was fluctuating quite a bit this morning. But the market was thin, so even a small transaction could move the market," a U.S. bank dealer in Bangkok said.
-- Syed Azman in Kuala Lumpur (603-206 2323), Mantik Kusjanto in Jakarta (6221 384-6364), Anchalee Koetsawang in Bangkok (662) 652-0642, Lilian Karunungan in Manila (632-841-8937) and Sonali Desai in Singapore (65-8703090)

headline: Asian dollar deposits little changed in late trade.
text:
Asian dollar deposit rates were little changed in moderate trade on Tuesday, dealers said.
Most traders were sidelined ahead of the outcome of U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's semi-annual Humphrey-Hawkins speech to a House of Representatives subcommittee at around 1800 GMT today, they said.
"The market was quiet and featureless in the morning due mainly to an absence of fresh incentives. All eyes are on monetary policy and everyone is waiting to see what Alan Greenspan says in his speech later tonight," a dealer said.  
"I guess we will have to wait and see what happens later tonight," he said.
In day-to-day rates, Tuesday/Wednesday and Wednesday/Thursday were unchanged from Monday's common 5-9/16 5-7/16 percent, respectively.
Week-fixed was unchanged at 5-5/8 5-1/2 percent.
Among longer dates, two-months was unchanged at 5-11/16 5-9/16 percent, four-months unchanged at 5-3/4 5-5/8, six-months unchanged at 5-13/16 5-11/16 and twelve-months unchanged at 6-1/16 5-15/16 percent.
- P. Theseira (65-870-3085)

TIFFE Euroyen ends firmer in light Tokyo trade.
text:
July 22 settlement  prev settlement
 TIFFE Euroyen 3M (H)     99.02		   99.00
---------------------------------------------------------------
The key March three-month Euroyen contract on TIFFE ended the day session firmer in light, listless trading on Tuesday, traders said.
Amid a dearth of fresh factors, traders were waiting for the Bank of Japan's quarterly economic outlook on Thursday.
In its last outlook issued in April, the BOJ said the Japanese economy remained on a recovery trend despite fluctuations caused by a consumption tax increase on April 1.  
The central bank also said in April that Japan's net exports were likely to continue rising, partly due to the yen's depreciation since mid-1995.
"If the central bank presents a slightly positive outlook for the economy (in its quarterly report), the Euroyen might ease to around 98.95," said a city bank trader.
The Euroyen market, however, has recently been slow to respond to negative factors, so any possible dip on the BOJ report might be temporary, traders said.
March Euroyen ended on Tuesday at 99.02, the top of the day's 98.99-to-99.02 range, on turnover of 14,156 contracts.  
In the interest rate swap (IRS) market, a few Japanese banks paid one-year fixed interest rates in an otherwise quiet market, traders said. The one-year IRS was quoted at 0.79/0.83 percent at 0630 GMT, down from Friday's 0.80/0.84 percent.
The BOJ left the market with a 200 billion yen surplus in its regular money market operation on Tuesday, in order to fend off upward pressure on rates in the short end of the market.
The call rate firmed slightly, however, to 0.50-0.51 percent from Friday's 0.49 percent. Traders expect accomodative operations by the BOJ to continue on Wednesday.
--- Yoshiko Mori, Tokyo Treasury Desk +81-3-3432-8676

headline: Villagers see missing SIA jet, Thais searching.
text:
The Royal Thai Navy has sent a rescue team to southern Thailand to investigate reports that villagers have spotted the wreckage of a Singapore Airlines (SIA) training plane, Navy officials said on Tuesday.
SIA said in a statement issued in Singapore late on Monday that the Learjet 31 light training aircraft had gone missing with two people on board.
It left the Thai resort island of Phuket for Ranong, 170 km (106 miles) further north, in the afternoon but air traffic controllers lost contact with it.
A trainee and an instructor were on board, the statement said.
A Thai navy search and rescue team was forced to halt its efforts after three hours of searching on Monday due to heavy rain and poor visibility, a navy officer said.
"We received a report from a volunteer radio team that people have spotted the wreckage of the plane but have no further details," a navy spokesman said.
He said a volunteer radio team claimed that some villagers had seen the wreckage of the plane in the coastal jungle area in Naka village of Kapoe district of Phangnga province about 700 km (420 miles) south of Bangkok.
The fate of the two people on board was still unknown, he said.
The missing aircraft was operated by the Singapore Flying College, a subsidiary of SIA.

headline: Ringgit recovers, trading seen volatile.
text:
Previous	Forecast	Resistance    Support
    2.6050/6420   2.6150/350    2.6050	  2.6450
-------------------------------------------------
* Ringgit recovers on profit-taking of dollar positions
* Dollar's easiness against other regional currencies helping ringgit
* Trading seen volatile due to thin volumes and wide spreads
The ringgit recovered against the dollar in early Asian trading as players continued to take profits from the dollar's recent climb, dealers said.  
At 0300 GMT, the ringgit was at 2.6115/65 to a dollar. It closed at 2.6250/300 in Kuala Lumpur on Monday.
"There's still some selling of dollar due to profit-taking from both local and offshore," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank. "Dollar/ringgit appears to be consolidating and we should see further gains in ringgit."
Dealers said a softer dollar trend against other regional currencies also helped the ringgit.
Some dealers also attributed the ringgit's firmness to the return of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad from a two-month absence later on Tuesday.
Dealers said dollar gains were likely to be capped at 2.6450, the level it hit in London markets on Friday.
They expected dollar/ringgit trading to remain volatile due to thin volumes and wide spreads.
-- Syed Azman (603-201 4813)

headline: Search on for missing SIA training jet in Thailand.
text:
Search and rescue operations were under way again on Tuesday for a Singapore Airlines (SIA) training jet missing in Thailand, a source close to the operations in Singapore said.
"A team has left for the site in Ranong. We have still no information this morning," the source told Reuters.
He said Thai authorities who had conducted searches on Monday were renewing their efforts.
SIA said in a statement late on Monday that the Learjet 31 light training aircraft had gone missing with two people on board.
The jet left the Thai resort island of Phuket for Ranong, 170 km (106 miles) further north, in the afternoon but had not arrived after air traffic controllers lost contact with it.
A trainee and an instructor were on board, the statement said.
SIA said it was liaising with the authorities in Thailand as they searched for the aircraft in a forested area south of Ranong.
The missing aircraft was operated by the Singapore Flying College, a subsidiary of SIA.
An SIA spokesman said it has four Learjet aircraft and that the college has been operating pilot training for six years.
"This is the first incident involving such a training flight," the spokesman said.

-- Ekran Bhd and ABB Asea Brown Boveri will meet on Thursday to resolve a dispute over major terms of a contract to build the $6.18 billion Bakun hydroelectric power project, Acting Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said. Ekran Bhd which was awarded the project, has handed a $5.5 billion contract to ABB to construct the dam.
-- Malaysia remains committed to achieving a surplus budget by keeping a tight rein on spending, Acting Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said at a dialogue with industry in Malacca.
-- Cambodia is considering compensation for foreign firms affected by violent clashes between rival factions in the government, second Prime Minister Hun Sen said in a televised address. Hun Sen has ousted first Prime Minister Prince Norodom Ranariddh in a bloody battle two weeks ago, taking the country to the brink of civil war. Hun Sen estimated total damages to foreign property in the region of $10 million.

BUSINESS TIMES
-- Metroplex Bhd is planning to invest $10 million in a South African casino.

headline: Mahathir arrives in Kuala Lumpur at 0945 GMT.
text:
Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is scheduled to arrive in Kuala Lumpur from a two-month work-and-holiday break at 1745 local time (0945 GMT) on Tuesday, officials said.
"It's 5.45 p.m. (0945 GMT)," an aide at the Prime Minister's Office said when asked about the arrival time of the premier. She declined to give further comments.
Mahathir was earlier scheduled to arrive in Kuala Lumpur at around 1930 hours (1130 GMT).
An official at the Information Services Department of the Ministry of Information said the premier is scheduled to hold a news conference at the Kuala Lumpur airport on his arrival.
Market players are on high alert for any comments from the straight-talking prime minister following the recent speculative attack on the ringgit and other Southeast Asian currencies.
The attacks had negatively affected regional stock markets and boosted interest rates.
Mahathir, speaking in Okayama, Japan, on Monday said there may be a political agenda behind the attacks, which he said was led by "a certain powerful American financier".
The official at the Information Services Department said Mahathir's airport news conference, according to convention, is open only to domestic media reporters.
-- Kuala Lumpur newsroom (603-201 4813)

headline: Asia Naphtha/Mogas - Naphtha's bull run falters.
text:
The backwardation seen in the Asian naphtha market since July 10 disappeared on Tuesday, amid slack regional demand, traders said.
"If you look at the factors, there are no bullish factors but so many bearish ones," said a trader with a major oil company.
Traders said Thai buyers who emerged two weeks ago and soaked up a lot of the length depressing the prompt market, were silent due to a four-day Thai holiday which ends on Tuesday.  
Demand from North Asian endusers was also thin with high domestic naphtha production. Weak ethylene prices are also threatening petrochemical production, a Japanese trader said.
Only Taiwan was seeking a full range naphtha cargo for September delivery, in a tender which closes on July 23 and is valid for two days.
"Naphtha was being driven up by the open-spec buyers," a trader said. "There may have been some prompt demand, but how long can that last, is anyone's guess."  
Japan's forward open-spec contracts for second-half September/first-half October were talked at par at $207/$208 per tonne, compared to a 50-cent backwardation on Monday.
In Singapore, August swaps were just two cents per barrel higher than September, compared to the 10-cent backwardation on Monday, traders said.
August swaps traded at $21.45, down from Monday's quotes at $21.55/$21.75.
Traders said naphtha's fall may widen the spread with gasoline, which held steady in lacklustre activity.  
Gasoline traders were sidelined amid ample supplies and thin regional demand from India and Taiwan.
Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp (CPC) emerged with its usual bi-monthly tender to buy 250,000 barrels of 95-octane unleaded reformate for delivery September 1-15, a company official said.
The tender closes on July 29 and is valid for two days.
CPC bought three cargoes in total for August from a Dutch trader -- the last at $23.30 per barrel, cost-and-freight Taiwan for August 11-20, and the first two for August 1-10 at $24.60 and $24.76.

headline: El Nino unlikely to hit Philippine power supply.
text:
State-owned National Power Corp (Napocor) said on Tuesday there will be enough power supply despite the El Nino weather phenomenon expected this year.
El Nino, which is Spanish for the Christ Child, forms when waters in the tropical Pacific ocean turn warmer, changing wind and other global patterns.
"We have a strategy trying to prepare for this El Nino. We have been conserving water in our reservoirs. We can assure you there will be no power disruption," Napocor president Guido Delgado told Reuters.
In the main Luzon grid, recently commissioned coal-fired power plants like the 700-mw Pagbilao plant in Quezon province will help beef up electricity supply, the official said.
Delgado said there will be no power shortages even in the southern Mindanao island which is most susceptible to El Nino since hydroelectric power makes up 85 percent of the region's power generation mix.
The Napocor official said 300-megawatts of power barges are now deployed in Mindanao and another 100-mw will be operational before the year-end. An additional 50-mw barge will be put on stream next year.
In the early 1990s, Mindanao suffered power shortages of 250-mw to 350-mw brought on by El Nino.
-- Manila newsroom (63 2) 8418939 Fax 8176267

headline: China B shares down amid bad sentiment, A shares up.
text:
China's hard currency B share indices closed down in both Shanghai and Shenzhen on Tuesday amid poor sentiment, while the A share markets rose after fears eased over Shenzhen Development Bank.
Shanghai's foreign currency B shares closed slightly lower on Tuesday amid uncertainty ahead of interim results, but the index pared early losses after the domestic currency A share market staged a rebound, brokers said.
The B index fell 0.441 points or 0.59 percent to 74.839 points on volume of 6.954 shares worth $3.316 million.
Volume was relatively thin on Tuesday since many B share investors remained on the sidelines awaiting interim results or had turned to Hong Kong to buy China plays, they said.
"Most B share companies have not issued their interim results, and the uncertainty caused many investors to stay on the sidelines," said a broker with a local securities firm.
Of 45 Shanghai B shares, 40 traded with 23 down, nine up and eight flat.
Investors sold shares of property developers with ties to Shanghai's Pudong New Area, the city's premier development zone, because of expectations these companies would report poor results, brokers said.
Pudong developer Shanghai Jinqiao Export Processing Zone Development Co was the most actively traded, falling $0.010 or 1.43 percent to $0.690 on volume of 743,843 shares.
The Shanghai A index rebounded on talk that Shenzhen-listed A share Shenzhen Development Bank would not change its 1996 dividend plan, they said.
Shenzhen Development Bank left its 1996 plan unchanged following a vote by shareholders on Tuesday after the markets closed.
The Shanghai A share index gained 16.007 points or 1.28 percent to 1,264.561 points on volume of 439.883 million shares worth 5.417 billion yuan after the market shrugged off fears over Shenzhen Development Bank.
The SSE30 blue chip index rose 41.972 points or 1.10 percent to 3,857.493 points.
Shenzhen's hard currency B share index closed down 0.47 points or 0.36 percent to 132.10 points on light turnover of HK$35.6 million, slightly up from Monday's HK$28 million.
Shenzhen's A share index reversed morning losses to close higher on Tuesday, as investors shrugged off concerns market leader Shenzhen Development Bank would change its 1996 dividend plan, brokers said.
The A index gained 6.92 points or 1.66 percent to 422.40 points on turnover of 5.4 billion yuan, compared with 7.4 billion on Monday.
Trading in Shenzhen Bank's A shares was suspended on Tuesday as the bank was due to hold a shareholders' meeting to discuss its 1996 dividend plan, which consisted of a five-for-10 bonus share issue plus a cash payout of 0.2 yuan per share.
Brokers said the Shenzhen A share market should move higher on Wednesday after the bank left its plan unchanged.
"I think the A share market is going to trend higher on Wednesday as investors laud the bank's dividend," said Xu Yinhui, an analyst at China Guotai Securities.
($1=8.3 yuan, $1=HK$7.8)

headline: China auctions U.S.-made warship for 2.01 mln yuan.
text:
A World War Two-vintage warship, originally presented to China's Nationalist navy in 1942, was auctioned off in Shanghai on Tuesday for 2.01 million yuan ($242,169), the Shanghai International Auction Co said.
The ship, built in New York in 1942, was ordered auctioned by a local court because its owner, a Shenzhen company, could not afford to renovate it, the official Xinhua news agency said.
The new owner was a joint venture company, the Hongchang Ship Salvage Steel Co, which beat four other bidders to the hammer, the auctioneers said in a statement.
Bidding opened at 1.2 million yuan and was pushed up in 33 bids to the final price, they said.
After China's 1949 revolution, in which the communists beat the Nationalists, the ship passed to the ownership of the People's Liberation Army, Xinhua said.
It was decommissioned to the Shenzhen company two years ago, Xinhua said.
The auctioneers were appointed by Shanghai's Number One Intermediate People's Court, Xinhua said without further detail.
($1=8.3 yuan)
-- Shanghai Newsroom (8621) 6279-7004

headline: Malaysia Mahathir declines comment on ringgit.
text:
Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad on Tuesday declined to comment on the speculation in the ringgit saying he will have to study the situation first.
"I will get information from the Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister to see if I can help in any way. If not, I will follow," he told reporters on his return from a two-month work-and-holiday break overseas.
He did not elaborate.  
Mahathir said while he supported freedom of trade, he was uncomfortable with the power wielded by speculators.
"There is freedom in speculation which has become an important weapon. You give power to someone because he's rich ... to force other countries to bow to him," Mahathir said speaking in his native Bahasa Malaysia language.
The prime minister had been asked to comment on remarks he had made on Monday in Japan that a "certain powerful American financier" was behind the attack on Southeast Asian currencies.
"We believe in freedom of trade .... but it could be misused," Mahathir said.
He said the American financier, whom he has not named, was on a "crusade for charity". "It means he robbed from the poor to show he's charitable," Mahathir said.
The ringgit has fallen nearly five percent in the last 10 days and remains volatile as speculators, widely believed to be U.S. hedge funds continue to sell the local unit.
Dealers in Singapore and London have named George Soros and his quantum group as one of those leading the attack on Southeast Asian currencies. Soros also sponsors The Open Society international humanitarian foundation.
In early July, Soros declined comment when asked if he was linked to attacks on the Thai baht.
Mahathir also declined comment on the fall in Bank Negara Malaysia's foreign exchange reserves in the fortnight to July 15, saying he wanted to study the issue.
Bank Negara announced on Tuesday that its foreign exchange, gold and other reserves fell to 61.9 billion ringgit by July 15, from 70.71 billion a fortnight earlier.
-- Kuala Lumpur newsroom (603-201 4813)

headline: Malaysian corn prices stable, stocks manageable.
text:
Malaysian corn prices were stable this week, with traders reporting more manageable stock levels in local warehouses after steady consumption in recent weeks.
Stocks of maize in Malaysia's central region totalled about 80,000 to 100,000 tonnes this week, traders said.
They expected inventories to remain around that level for about a month. No new consignments of corn are expected to arrive in the period.
"Our consumption is about 80,000 tonnes a month and it'll be just nice," said a trader. "But if another few Panamax vessels come in, then we're going to have another glut."
A Panamax vessel carries around 50,000 tonnes of maize.
Traders said although prices were holding, they were still not reflective of the current high international rates set by the Chicago Board of Trade.
"Technically, we should be on par with the world prices, but there's demand here for the moment to quote higher," said a dealer with a Malaysian flour mill.
On Tuesday, bulk corn of Chinese origin in Malaysia's central region was quoted in a wider range of 360-375 ringgit ($137-$143) a tonne C and F, compared to 360-365 a week ago.
Bulk Argentine maize, ex-factories/godowns in the central region, was also trading in a band of 360-370 ringgit from 365-370 last week.
"A" grade wheat in Malaysia was lower at 650 ringgit a bag from 690 a week ago. "B" grade wheat was down to 350 ringgit from 390.
Soymeal prices were also slightly higher, at 865 ringgit for the imported material, compared to 850 ringgit previously, and 855 ringgit for the local stuff, from 860 last week.
-- K. Baranee Krishnaan (603-2307509) ($1=2.6250 ringgit)
-- Kuala Lumpur newsroom (603-206 2323)

headline: Government, analysts split on Taiwan's GDP growth.
text:
Taiwan's economics minister said on Tuesday the island would have no trouble reaching its target for gross domestic product (GDP) growth in 1997.
But private economists were less optimistic, citing troubling factors that could emerge later in the year to thwart Taiwan's economic recovery.
Minister Wang Chih-kang told a news conference that the GDP target of 6.24 percent was easily attainable.
"With investment increasing and industrial output stably rising to support the recovery, I am confident that our GDP growth can reach the forecast 6.24 percent or even better," Wang said.
He said private investment in the first quarter rose 8.95 percent year-on-year and was expected to reach 11.54 percent for the whole of 1997, Taiwan's best performance in five years.
On Tuesday, the economics ministry said industrial output rose 5.28 percent in June from a year earlier, and export orders were up 6.01 percent year-on-year.
However, private economists said recent good figures were no guarantee for a continued economic boom, and Taiwan's dependence on the electronics industry could jeopardise the economy's overall health.
"So far, except for the electronics industry, most economic indicators have shown medium or slow growth, making me wonder if the GDP target can be reached," said HSBC James Capel economist Stephen Wang.
HSBC forecasts 5.9-percent GDP growth for 1997, and several other institutions' forecasts range between 5.9 and 6.3 percent.
Economists said political factors -- such as the ruling Nationalist Party congress in August, President Lee Teng-hui's September visit to Central America and December's local government elections -- could bring trouble to the economy.
"Investment is likely to slow in the second half on worries over (mainland China's) likely tough reaction to President Lee's Central America visit as well as the party congress and local elections," HSBC's Wang said.
Economists said they expected the electronics industry to continue its strong performance -- a performance that has helped launch a bull run in the stock market's electronics sector and the overall index since the beginning of the year.
Taiwan's electronics sector index had leapt 111 percent while the overall index had gained 42 percent this year before the latter fell by 2.88 percent on profit-taking on Tuesday.
But recoveries in other sectors have not shown similar strength, officials and economists said.
"The economy, except for the electronics sector, has not fully recovered yet," central bank governor Sheu Yuan-dong said recently.
Analysts interpreted Sheu's comments as meaning that despite the red-hot stock market the central bank would not tighten its monetary policy for fear of stalling Taiwan's economic recovery.
"There is little room for the central bank to tighten policy if it wants to keep on boosting the slowly recovering economy," said Grand Cathay Securities economist Chang Jui-hsing.
"The central bank is in a dilemma on deciding its policy: looser to boost the economy or tightening to control the stock and foreign exchange markets."
The central bank has in recent weeks repeatedly issued negotiable certificates of deposit to mop up liquidity in the banking system.
Analysts say the move was aimed at cooling the stock market and inducing investors to sell U.S. dollars for Taiwan dollars to prevent the local currency from falling sharply.
Sheu said last week that Taiwan's huge reserves and trade surplus would help to insulate its currency from speculative attacks like those that have undermined currencies in Southeast Asia.
The Taiwan dollar has fallen mildly in July on what dealers see as overseas speculation in the form of non-delivery forward trading.

headline: Indonesian growth seen slowing on rupiah crisis.
text:
The fall in the value of Indonesia's rupiah may slow economic growth as interest rates will have to remain high to counter a likely rise in inflation, economists said on Tuesday.
They also said the country's debt burden, estimated at around $110 billion, could increase if the rupiah remained weak, although parts of the export sector could benefit from more competitive prices.
The rupiah on Monday came under fierce speculative attack which beat it down about five percent to a historic low of 2,665 against the dollar before central bank intervention brought about a marginal recovery.
On Tuesday, the currency was volatile but had strengthened to about 2,585 against the dollar in the late afternoon.
Nevertheless, the rate was sharply down from the 2,430 level that prevailed two weeks ago.
"Curbing inflation in the last eight to nine months has been very helpful in the central bank lowering interest rates," said a Singapore-based regional economist.
"Now with inflation likely to pick up (after the currency depreciation), this is put into question."
Alex Erskine, regional market strategist with Citibank Corp in Singapore, agreed.
"Interest rates are up just now, which will take the edge off growth," he told Reuters Financial Television. "That is a challenge to the longer term."
"I think we are beginning to see a weaker rupiah," Erskine added. "Corporates next week will try to cover some of their foreign exchange exposures, so I think more weakness lies ahead."
Finance Minister Mar'ie Muhammad  told reporters on Tuesday that monetary policies would not be altered in the wake of the speculative attack on the rupiah.
But economists said continued weakness in the local currency and resulting inflationary pressures could force authorities to revisit their policy of allowing interest rates to decline.
The I.D.E.A. consultancy said a weaker rupiah could add to the foreign debt burden.
"Local corporates and institutions with unhedged exposure would suffer by way of higher debt servicing costs," it said in a report.
"A sustained weakened rupiah will also threaten to derail the government's plans to prepay debt," the consultancy added.
However, Asian Development Bank president Mitsuo Sato said during a visit to Jakarta that the country's debt levels were not a matter of concern.
"Let me again stress at this moment I don't have any concern about the level of (Indonesia's) foreign debt," he told reporters after a meeting with President Suharto on Tuesday.
I.D.E.A. said the rupiah depreciation could help boost lower value-added exports, although higher value-added goods would suffer from increased costs due to higher import content.
"It (the depreciation) is going to make Indonesian exporters more competitive vis-a-vis other exporters," said the regional economist.
"But bear in mind that a lot of regional currencies have also weakened and these are also competitiors. So the overall trade picture is hazy," I.D.E.A. said.
"But certainly vis-a-vis the major industrialised countries, Indonesian exports to Europe and the United States will be cheaper. On a net basis, I would say it would help the export sector."

headline: Singapore investors focus on core stocks, OTCs sag.
text:
Singapore blue chips stocks won some favour on Tuesday with investors looking to accumulate bargains while Malaysian over-the-counter (OTC) issues were sold off.
Dealers said local and foreign funds were selectively buying core stocks, due to a brighter second half economic outlook.
"They think it's fair value now. Foreign funds are lining up orders for blue chips," said one foreign brokerage dealer.
She said Singapore stocks were seen a better bet than other markets due to its weaker but more stable currency.
The Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) closed down 0.24 points at 1,950.51 on active volume of 179 million shares.
The UOB OTC index, which tracks Malaysian stocks, slipped 4.71 points to 1,083.92, partly on currency fears.
News that Malaysia' reserves fell to 61.9 billion ringgit at July 15 against 70.7 billion a fortnight ago, hurt sentiment.
"It confirmed what everybody knows but it contributes to the bearish mentality," another broker said,
In the broader market, gainers trailed losers, 172 to 185.
The index was hit by falls in Cerebos Pacific, down Singapore 25 cents to a fresh low of S$5.55.
Keppel Corp also dampened the STII, easing 15 cents to S$6.65. The actives were led by small capitalisation stocks such as Asia Food & Properties, which rebounded from a new low of US$1.00 to close up one cent at US$1.09.
Retailer Heshe saw 10 million shares crossed at 33 cents. The issue rose one cent to S$0.33.
Dealers said early married trades on Flextech, with 20,000 shares executed at S$0.83, were done outside the market and was a "keying in mistake". It closed two cents lower at S$1.75.

headline: Macau Airport June cargo falls.
text:
Latest monthly figures published by Macau International Airport Company (CAM) show 3,155 tonnes of cargo was handled during June, slightly down from May's total of 3,342 tonnes but still well above the level's of a year ago.
The number of passengers passing through the Portuguese enclave's airport in June was 175,402, down by more than 14,500 on May's total but like cargo at the higher levels reached this summer following the airports November 1995 opening.
Mike Hanley, manager of the airport's cargo centre operated by MASC Ogden Aviation Services said business during June had been good and he was confident of another busy month during July with increased freighter frequencies from Scandinavian Airline Systems and Asiana Airlines.

headline: Thailand to grow more fragrant rice as prices soar.
text:
Thailand plans to turn one of the country's largest wastelands into a fragrant rice basket as the price of the top grade rice has soared to an all-time high, government and industry sources said on Tuesday.
Ananta Dalodom, deputy permanent secretary of agriculture, told Reuters the government aimed to more than double fragrant rice yields in the northeastern Tung Kula-ronghai wasteland by the year 2001.
"The concrete plan is up and we will start implementing from next year," he said.
Tung Kula-ronghai, meaning "field of crying women", is one of the areas of Thailand most prone to natural disasters, hit by drought in the dry season and flooded during the rainy season.
Despite its shortcomings, Tung Kula-ronghai, which occupies 336,000 hectares (830,000 acres) covering five provinces in the northeast, produces some of the best long-grain fragrant rice, although in limited quantities.
Thailand, the world's biggest rice exporter, has tried to boost exports of high-quality rice as its market share in lower-quality rice is being taken by low-cost producers such as Vietnam and India.
Thai rice exports in 1996 exceeded 5.0 million tonnes, 60 percent of which were high-quality grades, and the percentage is expected to rise further, according to Somboon Pataichant, manager of the Thai Rice Exporters Association.
Demand for fragrant rice alone rose to 1.4 million tonnes in 1996 from 1.2 million in 1995 and 1.0 million in 1994, Somboon said.
Demand for fragrant rice comes mainly from Asian countries like Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia and China. The United States is also a big market, trade sources said.
The price of grade A fragrant rice was quoted recently at around $750 per tonne FOB Bangkok, while grade B fragrant rice was quoted around $730 per tonne on the same basis -- an all-time high.
Supplies have barely risen fast enough to catch up with rising demand due to the low-yield nature of the crop and the limited area where it can be grown.
The current yield of fragrant rice in Tung Kula-ronghai, for example, is only 1.59 tonnes per hectare.
The agriculture ministry's Ananda said the ministry plans to boost fragrant rice yields in the wasteland to 5.15 tonnes per hectare in future.
Ananda said that out of 336,000 hetares of land in Tung Kula-ronghai only 64,000 hectares had been prepared by the government to allow fragrant rice cultivation.
"By 2001, we aimed to boost such an area to 240,000 hectares, using a remodelling method and organic fertilisers to improve the soil quality," he said.
Ananda said the ministry was improving  fragrant rice strains and would make them available to more farmers in the area.
"We have every reason to believe that the plan will produce positive results and Thailand will have more fragrant rice supplies by the year 2001," he said.

headline: Indonesia late rubber stable, concern over rupiah.
text:
Indonesian tyre-grade SIR20 prices were stable in late trading on Tuesday, with foreign buyers putting pressure on values following the rupiah's decline against the U.S. dollar, traders said.
"Buyers are already trying to squeeze prices because they think we are getting more rupiah for dollars now," one trader said. "The market outlook is bearish and I think prices will go lower because of the poor buying interest and weak rupiah."
Another trader said there were some enquiries from Singapore-based dealers but there had been no deals.
"INRO showed no interest when prices were at the 'may-buy' level and buyers know that INRO will not come into the market until prices go down much more," he said.
"They (buyers) are making the most of the situation by putting in very low bids," he added.
The traders said SIR20 offer prices were quoted at 43.50-43.75 cents/lb fob Medan, 43.25 cents fob Palembang, 43.625 cents fob Surabaya, 42.75 cents fob Jambi.
-- Jakarta newsroom + 6221 384-6364

headline: Ringgit slips back on fund buying of dollar.
text:
The ringgit gave back most of its gains on Tuesday as offshore funds bought back the dollar after taking profit early in the day, dealers said.
"Players are buying back the dollar and the pressure on ringgit is not over yet," said a European bank dealer in Singapore. He believed the dollar/ringgit has not seen the last of further upside moves.
"We could still see a test of 2.65," he said.
But funds were wary about pushing the dollar up quickly ahead of the return of Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad from a two-month absence later on Tuesday.  
Dealers said there was also some caution ahead of an Asian central bankers meeting in Shanghai at the end of the week.
At 0930 GMT, the ringgit was at 2.6250/80 to a dollar. It rose to a high of 2.6105 in the morning.
The ringgit hit a low of 2.6450 a dollar on Friday.
Wide spreads of 20 to 30 points continued to exaggerate currency movements, dealers said.
The ringgit had earlier received a boost from Mahathir's comments expressing displeasure with the recent speculative attack on the currency.
Press reports quoted Mahathir as saying there may have been a political agenda behind the recent moves in regional currency markets. Dealers have said that U.S. hedge funds were responsible for the attack on the regional currencies.
The market was bracing itself for more comments from Mahathir against currency speculators on Tuesday, dealers said.
Dealers said the ringgit will remain under speculative pressure amid perception that the central Bank Negara will not intervene aggressively to defend the currency to prevent further depletion of its reserves.
Bank Negara said on Tuesday its foreign exchange reserves fell by 12.5 percent in the fortnight to July 15, confirming market estimates of the size of central bank's recent interventions to defend the ringgit.
It said its reserves fell to 61.9 billion ringgit as at July 15, compared to 70.71 billion ringgit at June 30.
-- Syed Azman (603-201 4813)

headline: Indonesia exports tea to Iraq under U.N. deal.
text:
Indonesian companies have exported 3,000 tonnes of tea to Iraq under a scheme to allow Baghdad to import food and are confident of more sales if the U.N. programme is extended, industry sources said on Tuesday.
The sources said the United Nations had given approval for the export of 4,000 tonnes of Indonesian tea, 3,000 tonnes of which had been shipped over the past two months. The rest was expected to be sent in early August.
The exports are estimated to be worth between $8 million and $10 million.
Iraq has been allowed by the United Nations to sell $2 billion worth of oil over six months and spend the proceeds on food and medicine. The United Nations must approve all such purchases.
The industry sources said the companies were awaiting U.N. approval for the export of another 2,000 tonnes of tea to Iraq.
Another industry source said another 4,000 tonnes of tea had been shipped to Iraq through Jordan under private deals not covered by the U.N. oil-for-food deal.
All transactions call for cash on delivery, sources said.
The Iraqi ambassador to Indonesia, Sa'doon J. al-Zubaydi, confirmed that Indonesian tea had been exported to Iraq, but did not have details.
He said Iraq favoured doing business with friendly countries such as Indonesia. Both countries are predominantly Moslem
"Our psychological stature, if you like, is more geared towards countries that have been friendly with us. Indonesia is one of those countries," he told Reuters.
He said Indonesian businesses held a pharmaceutical and medical equipment exhibition in Baghdad recently and that the Iraqi market was ready to import such items from Indonesia.
The tea exports to Iraq were the first from Indonesia since the United Nations imposed trade sanctions on Iraq after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990.
"We (Indonesia) were always one of the big suppliers of tea to Iraq before 1991," one industry source said.
"The volume ranged from 12,000 to 20,000 tonnes a year, compared with total imports of about 40,000 tonnes from all over the world."
He said Iraq had also been buying tea from China and Vietnam through private transactions.
"Indonesia will continue to be one of Iraq's big suppliers of tea if the United Nations renews the oil-for-food deal," he said. "The Iraqis like Indonesian tea and our prices are also more competitive compared to Sri Lanka and India."
Industry sources said Indonesia's tea production was expected to fall by 10-12 percent in 1997 from an estimated 130,000 tonnes last year.
"State plantations posted a 15 percent shortfall in the first five months of this year because of bad weather," one source said. "With the seasonal drought expected to last until October, we will see production fall by at least 10 percent."
The sources said the weakening of the Indonesian currency against the U.S. dollar would have no impact on the tea trade as local purchases were done in dollars.

headline: Indonesia late palm olein stable in quiet trade.
text:
Indonesian palm olein prices were generally stable in late trading on Tuesday, with sharp declines in Malaysia dampening demand, traders said.
They said palm olein was quoted at 1,440-50 rupiah/kg in Jakarta, unchanged from the opening. Crude palm oil was on offer at 1,200 rupiah/kg in the north Sumatran city of Medan.
"The market was slow because of the falls in Malaysia coupled with the sudden rise in local prices due to the weakening of the rupiah against the U.S. dollar," one said.
"Sellers are trying to hold on to their prices, but I think prices will ease tomorrow because of ample supply and weak demand. Players will also be watching the rupiah closely to see how prices should adjust if the currency weakens further."
The rupiah regained some strength on Tuesday, one day after it fell to a historic low on offshore speculative attacks.
Data from Belawan Port showed that the MT Bunga Anggrek will leave for Dumai on Tuesday with 5,540 tonnes of palm oil, while the MT Victory Ocean will leave for Rotterdam on Wednesday with 9,550 tonnes of palm oil.
-- K.T. Arasu, Jakarta newsroom + 6221 384-6364

headline: Philippine onshore NDF ban has no impact on market.
text:
News that onshore banks in the Philippines will be barred from selling non-deliverable forwards (NDF) has little or no significance for the NDF market as a whole, traders said on Tuesday.
The Philippine central bank said on Tuesday that onshore banks cannot sell non-deliverable forward dollars to offshore counterparties for the next three months.
Central Bank governor Gabriel Singson said the suspension was to allow the central bank to review the legality and practice of the derivative instrument.  
"This will make no difference to the market as it is now," said one Singapore NDF trader.
He said when some Philippine banks received licenses to trade derivatives around two months ago, a few took it to mean they could quote NDFs.
However, it is widely believed that when the peso fluctuation band was widened earlier this month the central bank called in banks and told them to stick more to the spirit of the forex regulations rather than interpret them exactly.  
It was then the onshore banks stopped quoting NDFs and the ban announced on Tuesday was simply a formality which shows that the central bank is not clear whether it is legal for onshore banks to quote NDFs, traders said.
They said even when onshore banks started quoted NDFs, when markets were a lot more stable, it never made a material difference to the offshore market.
As investment flows entered the Philippines via the NDF route, spreads and liquidity offshore were always better than onshore.  
"If anything, for me, it's good news because I'm an offshore business and I like to keep the onshore business out," said the Singapore based trader.
-- Phil Smith, Singapore newsroom (+65-870-3046)
