headline: Macau to increase tax on casino monopoly.
text:
The Macau government and the territory's casino monopoly company will sign a revised agreement on Wednesday increasing its franchise tax, a government spokesman said.
Under the deal, Sociedade de Turismo e Diversoes de Macau (STDM) will pay 31.8 percent of its gross takings in tax, up from 30 percent.
The Portuguese-run government also forecast STDM will pay about 5.2 billion patacas (US$650 million) in taxes this year.
The agreement was approved in June by a joint Sino-Portuguese body working on details of Macau's sovereignty changeover in 1999.
STDM said earlier this month said it had net profit of 4.6 billion patacas in 1996, the first time the monopoly reported its earnings.
-- Hong Kong Newsroom (852) 28436441

headline: Students on hunger strike against ASEAN on Burma.
text:
Seven Burmese students-in-exile on Tuesday launched a hunger strike outside the Malaysian embassy in Bangkok to protest against ASEAN's decision to admit Burma.
The students vowed to continue their action until the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN), which this week admits Burma as a member, reversed its decision.
They demanded that ASEAN consult the Burmese opposition National League for Democracy (NLD) party led by Aung San Suu Kyi and negotiated the release of political prisoners with Burma's ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC).
The students wanted ASEAN to oversee the transfer of power from the military to the NLD, which swept the 1990 general election in Burma but whose victory was not recognised by the military.
Each student wore a placard bearing the name of an ASEAN member country around his neck.
"In order to draw world-wide attention to the shame of ASEAN's acceptance of the SLORC, we, a coalition of Thai and Burmese student organisations, have decided to stage a hunger strike," a statement from the students said.
"We will continue to protest against Burma's relationship with ASEAN until our demands have been met," it added.
ASEAN now groups Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines, Brunei and Vietnam.

headline: Thai stocks end up, discount poor finance results.
text:
Retail buying of finance stocks and foreign investors reluctance to sell ahead of any possible IMF bailout helped Thai stocks post modest gains by the close on Tuesday despite poor half year earnings results, traders said.
The SET Index pared earlier losses to end 6.41 points or 0.98 percent higher at 659.78. The SET 50 added 0.59 points or 1.19 percent to 49.97 in trade worth 5.47 billion baht.
"Foreigners are still being very selective but the local punters are trying to drag it out in the finance sector even though the fundamentals don't really support it," said a trader at Phatra Thanakit.  
Half year results from commercial banks and finance and securities firms were sharply down almost across the board but foreign investors were reluctant to sell on the figures ahead of a possible IMF package which could spike prices, traders said.
Analysts believe that Thailand might seek an IMF package to put its economy on an even keel although the authorities have discounted the idea so far.
The downside was limited as most investors had been bracing for a poor set of results, analysts said.
"Though the results exceeded most scenarios I think expectations were pretty low anyway," said a foreign analyst.  
Thai Farmers Bank Plc gained four baht to 118, Siam Commercial Bank Plc added seven to 130 and Dhana Siam Plc ended up 2.75 to 42.75.
The finance sector's 3.46 percent gain was sentiment driven by local retailers who were playing low-priced stocks on sentiment against prevailing fundamentals, traders said.
"Some local investors think they can push these shares under 10 baht to 20 or 30 and think these stocks have a lot of room to go even though the fundamentals don't support it at all," said the trader.
--James Mclean (662) 652-0642

headline: Shanghai copper ends mostly down on correction.
text:
Shanghai copper futures ended mostly down on Tuesday on a technical correction after sharp gains over the past two days, traders said.
The most actively traded November 1997 contract ended at 20,700 yuan ($2,496) per tonne, losing 250 yuan. It opened at an intraday high of 21,200 yuan and hit a low of 20,580 yuan per tonne.
August fell 40 to 20,500, September 220 to 20,450, October 220 to 20,700, December 240 to 20,700 and the January 1997 contract rose 350 to 20,730 yuan per tonne.
Combined volume fell to 91,280 tonnes from 113,680 tonnes.  
Copper opened mixed but at intraday highs only to fall sharply due to heavy long liquidation, traders said.
Traders said many investors were eager to liquidate their long positions on Friday for good profits, preferring to reduce their exposure while they waited for fresh market-moving news.
"Some investors took advantage of the overnight LME (London Metal Exchange) gains to liquidate their long positions after past two days of heavy gains," a trader said.  
"Investors were also afraid of sharp fluctuations over coming days as there has been no change in market fundamentals despite the two days of rises," he said.
Three months copper on the LME ended Monday's afternoon kerb at $2,319 a tonne but looked at the upside in late inter-office trading and was indicated at 1800 GMT at $2,326/30.
London analysts saw resistance at $2,340, a level likely to be tested on Wednesday amid a lack of upside momentum.  
"LME copper will continue to be an important factor influencing Shanghai copper in the absence of domestic market-moving news," a second trader said.
Physical copper prices in the Shanghai area were stable at around 20,700 yuan per tonne due to the prevailing steadiness on the futures market, traders said.
Traders said they expected copper futures to move in a wide range in the next few days.  
Aluminium ended mostly up.
August fell 20 to 13,750. September rose 100 to 13,00o, October 480 to 13,680 and November 450 to 13,650 yuan per tonne.
Combined volume rose to 2,840 tonnes from 190 tonnes.
($1=8.3 yuan)
-- Shanghai Newsroom (8621) 6279-7004

headline: Toyota sees gradual rise in US car sales in Japan.
text:
Toyota Motor Corp said on Tuesday it expects to see gradual progress in car sales in Japan by the "Big Three" U.S. car makers.
"American cars are not common in Japan yet. It is difficult to have a rapid increase (in sales) in any country. We also spent several years (building up overseas sales). I think their sales are likely to increase gradually," Toyota president Hiroshi Okuda told reporters.
Last Thursday, Andrew Card, president and CEO of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association (AAMA), criticised Japan for the country's slow progress in opening up its automobile market and its growing trade surplus.
Japanese sales of American-made cars excluding Japanese makers' U.S. unit-made cars, totalled 20,643 units in the January to June period, down 19.8 percent from 25,749 a year earlier, mainly due to the impact of the increase in Japan's sales tax in April, according to industry data.
Sales of Cavalier cars, made by General Motors Corp and sold by Toyota's domestic dealers, rose to more than 1,000 units in June as a result of the launch of a new version, Okuda said.
Toyota's Cavalier sales rose to 1,236 units in June, after 598 in May, 419 in April and 966 in March, a Toyota spokeswoman said.

headline: China's spring silk output at 187,500 tonnes.
text:
China's spring silk cocoon output reached 187,500 tonnes this year, down eight percent from the year ago period, an official of the China National Silk Import and Export Corporation said on Tuesday.
Total cocoon output in 1997 was expected to be little changed from last year, the official said without giving further details.
Silk cocoon output plunged 38 percent in 1996 to about 420,000 tonnes, earlier figures showed.
In 1996, 80 percent of China's silk enterprises were losing money and frustrated silkworm growers chopped down about 30 percent of their mulberry trees.
-- Beijing Newsroom (8610) 6532 1921

headline: Singapore bunker levels quoted slightly higher.
text:
Singapore bunkers were quoted slightly higher on Tuesday in line with a supported cargo market but may ease later amid moderate enquiries, traders said.
Bunker 380-cst supplies were quoted at $101/$102 per tonne and the 180-cst grade was about $3/$4 per tonne higher. However, traders said traded levels later in the day for the 380-cst grade would be at around $100 per tonne as most suppliers, eager to grab business, might lower their offers.
MDO and gas oil stabilised at around $160 and $173 per tonne respectively.
--Singapore Newsroom (65-870 3571)

headline: Hong Kong stocks close lower ahead of Greenspan.
text:
Hong Kong stocks deepened losses to close Tuesday lower as selling in the banking sector increased in late afternoon ahead of U.S. Fed chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony to Congress, brokers said.
The Hang Seng Index fell 89.52 points, or 0.58 percent, to 15,446.78 but was off its low of 15,397.71. Turnover was HK$14.12 billion, down from Monday's HK$17.64 billion.
"Some investors used Greenspan's testimony as an excuse to sell. Since trading was thin, the blue chip index was easily moved in late trade," said Henry Lui, research analyst at Mansion House Research.
Market senitment was a bit cautious and many investors perferred to stay on the sidelines despite the general feeling that Greenspan would not give any clear trend on U.S. interest rates during his testimony, Lui said.
Banks ended lower after a short-lived rebound in mid-morning brought the Hang Seng to its intra-day high of 15,602.87.
"The banking counters are undergoing a consolidation, and they could stage another rally next week ahead of their interim result announcements," said Charles Cheung, executive director at J & A Securities.
HSBC Holdings eased HK$3.00 to HK$259.00.
Hang Seng Bank fell HK$0.50 to HK$114.50 and Bank of East Asia lost HK$0.40 to HK$32.50.
Brokers said utilities, which still lagged behind the market, attracked bargain hunters.
China Gas added HK$0.50 to HK$16.90 on talk that a brokerage planned a covered warrant issue on the stock.
Hongkong Electric surged HK$0.90 to HK$31.60 on speculation that Chinese companies might be interested in buying a stake in the company.
Will Beck, an analyst at SocGen-Crosby, said the speculation was not justified.
"Li Ka-shing is well connected so I don't see why you would need a strategic shareholder in this case. It is more likely that PRC (China) projects would go through CKI," Beck said.
Tycoon Li Ka-shing is head of the Cheung Kong group, which includes Cheung Kong, Hutchison, Cheung Kong Infrastructure (CKI) and Hongkong Electric.
Profit-taking hit China-backed H-shares and red-chips, with the Hang Seng Chinese Enterprises Index easing 21.33 points, or 1.88 percent to 1,112.08 and the Hang Seng red-chip index also down 30.08 points, or 0.90 percent, to 3,321.98.
July index futures fell 155 points to finish at 15,455.

headline: Singapore government securities end narrowly mixed.
text:
Singapore government securities ended narrowly mixed on Tuesday in moderate trade on retail and interbank interest, dealers said.
"Government securities were narrowly mixed today amid continued uncertainty over market direction. Treasury bill yields were narrowly mixed but bond prices were slightly higher. Volume was moderate," a local dealer said.
In treasury bills, three-months closed at a yield of 3.60/3.55 percent compared with Monday's yield of 3.55/3.50 percent and one-year at a yield of 3.00/2.95 percent against 3.25/3.20 percent.  
Among bonds, April 1999 ended at S$98.15/98.20 from Monday's close of S$98.02/98.07, May 2002 at S$99.15/99.20 versus S$98.88/98.93 and June 2003 at S$94.15/94.20 against S$93.88/93.93.
The overnight interbank offered rate rose to 4-5/8 4-1/2 percent from Monday's 4-1/4 4 percent.
-- Singapore newsroom (65-870-3080)

headline: AIDS campaigner urges China boost sex education.
text:
A Canadian cycling round the world to promote awareness of AIDS said on Tuesday China appeared determined to combat the spread of the disease but urged Beijing to boost sex education in schools.
China had almost certainly underestimated the number of its people infected with HIV, the virus that can lead to AIDS, Bertrand Boudreau told a news conference in Beijing on his Save Our Children From Aids round-the-world tour.
"If everyone was tested tomorrow I would not be surprised if the figure was as high as one million," he said.
The official number of HIV cases in the world's most populous nation was 5,157 people at the end of October 1996.
However Western health experts put the number at 50,000-100,000 people and the figure could be up to 10 times higher because most cases went unreported, Boudreau said.
Boudreau cited increased population mobility within China and travel overseas, as well as widespread prostitution, as factors behind the spread of HIV, or Human Immunodeficiency Virus, in China.
He voiced concern that too few people, especially prostitutes, were using condoms. "Prostitutes don't carry condoms in their purses because if they're caught with them, that provides evidence against them," he said.
Boudreau urged China to make education on sexually transmitted diseases compulsory in all schools to prevent the spread of AIDS, or Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome.
"Young people are having sex younger and younger," he said. "It's a must to talk about condoms."
A meeting with the China AIDS Prevention Association had left him convinced that health officials realised the need for action to prevent the spread of HIV.
Boudreau, 42, will leave Beijing on Thursday to cycle to Shanghai for the China leg of his tour that has taken him over 72,000 km (44,740 miles) and through 61 different countries since he left Canada in August 1994.
China has been grappling with growing prostitution and narcotics abuse as market-oriented economic reforms weaken puritan communist morality and social controls.
State media have reported a total of 133 AIDS cases in China.

headline: FOCUS-Bank Negara reserves fall after intervention.
text:
Bank Negara Malaysia's foreign exchange reserves fell by 12.5 percent in the fortnight to July 15, confirming market estimates of the size of central bank's recent interventions to defend the ringgit.
Malaysia's central bank announced on Tuesday that its foreign exchange, gold and other reserves fell to 61.9 billion ringgit as at July 15, 1997, compared to 70.71 billion ringgit a fortnight earlier.
Bank Negara is estimated to have spent over $2.0 billion in defending the ringgit in the last few weeks against speculators who have been selling down all currencies in Southeast Asia.
"This just proves what the market has been believing. In U.S. dollar terms two to three billion is what they (Bank Negara) have spent in the last few weeks, from mid-May to second week of July," said Daniel Lian, regional economist with NatWest Markets in Singapore.
The pressure on the ringgit increased over the last two weeks after Thailand allowed the baht to float and the Philippines widened the peso's trading band, both effectively devaluing their currencies.
On July 8, Bank Negara struck heavily against speculators, selling between $1 billion to $2 billion to prop up the ringgit.
After an initial defence, Bank Negara since last week has allowed the ringgit to fall against the dollar. The Malaysian unit fell to a 38-month low of 2.6450 to a dollar on Friday, or over 5.5 percent lower than the 2.5050 level two weeks ago.
At 0900 GMT on Tuesday, the ringgit was at 2.6225/45 to a dollar.
Economists said the fall in reserves will not have any impact on the economy as Malaysia's reserves were more than adequate to provide it a comfortable import cover.
"It is not a shocking number. It will not have very much impact on the economy," said Lian.
"Normally a decline in reserves means a decline in money supply. That can be offset by more generous injections of liquidity into the system," he said.
With the decline of nearly nine billion ringgit ($3.46 billion) in its foreign exchange reserves, "it (the intervention) could not have gone on for too long," said Eddie Lee, chief economist at Vickers Ballas in Singapore.
Foreign exchange reserves as at July 15, 1996 amounted to 66.68 billion ringgit, showing a fall of 4.78 billion ringgit on a year-on-year basis.
Total assets stood at 96.82 billion ringgit on July 15 against 100.99 billion ringgit on June 30, but were slightly higher than 95.72 billion ringgit a year ago.
Currency in circulation stood at 22.07 billion ringgit, compared to 21.95 billion ringgit in June.
"It actually does not mean the country is any poorer, if the ringgit recovers, they (Bank Negara) could recoup the losses," said Lian.
Economists said they applauded Bank Negara's policy of not defending the ringgit further.
"In the past week Bank Negara has let the ringgit float more freely. Already they have chosen the wiser path," said Lee at Vickers Ballas.
-- Kuala Lumpur newsroom (603-206 2323)

headline: Jakarta exchange suspends Langgeng.
text:
The Jakarta stock exchange suspended trading in small-sized plastics manufacturer PT Langgeng Makmur Plastic Industry just before the close on Tuesday after a sharp rise in the firm's stock, an exchange official said.
"The rise was too sharp and too fast. We are conducting a standard procedure and expect the stock to resume trading by tommorow (Wednesday) afternoon after getting all the required information," said the exchange official.
Langgeng Makmur was up 325 rupiah, or 31.71 percent, at 1,350 rupiah in thin trading, with only 72,500 shares traded before it was suspended at around 0850 GMT, ten minutes before the end of trading, the official said.
Brokers said they were surprised at the sharp rise and added they did not know the reasons behind it.
-- Jakarta newsroom +6221 384-6364

headline: Thai H1 finance results offer bleak outlook.
text:
Disappointing half-year earnings from leading Thai financial institutions on Tuesday points to a further fall in asset quality in the nation's ailing financial system, analysts said on Tuesday.
Results of finance and securities companies were almost universally disappointing and worse than already bearish estimates, they told Reuters.
Among banks, the country's largest lender Bangkok Bank Plc reported a 16 percent decline in profits during the first six months and bank executives sounded a profit warning for the second half.
The bank reported that its unaudited six-month profits slipped to 8.63 billion baht ($287 million) from 10.24 billion for the same period in 1996.
"I don't think in the second half the results will be much better than this," the bank's executive vice-chairman Pithi Siti-Amnuai told Reuters.
The first-half decline in profitability was due to the bank's continuing policy of extensive provisioning for bad loans, he said.
Finance One Plc, once Thailand's top finance company, posted a mammoth 1997 half-year unaudited loss of 5.23 billion baht versus a profit of 850.31 million baht in the same period last year.
Finance One's creditors are getting increasingly nervous about their money after Thai Danu Bank Plc pulled out of a proposed merger between the two in which Thai Danu was to act as rescuer, analysts said.
The earnings figures paint a bleak picture for the industry as it struggles to cope with an economic downturn that is crippling Thailand, analysts said.
Moreover, the economic slump -- Thailand's worst in more than a decade -- the baht's recent flotation, and a decline in foreign creditor confidence are likely to cause industry funding costs to rise in the coming months, Pithi said.
The slowing economic growth, tight liquidity, deteriorating asset quality and a property slump have added to systemic risk in the Thai financial system, analysts said.
The industry's woes have prompted the government to attempt to revamp the sector by encouraging Thai financial institutions, many of which are overexposed to the cash-strapped and depressed property sector, to consolidate to prevent them going under.
"BBL's (Bangkok Bank's) net profits are substantially below expectations," said a senior foreign bank analyst.
"I'm told there are some chunky provisions in here ... but I think you have to be careful about what the implication is for conditions generally. If Bangkok Bank is 25 percent of the banking industry and if they are feeling the pain as they clearly are, it doesn't bode well for everybody else," he said.
The profit results may now unnerve investors who were greeted by healthy-looking earnings figures from smaller banks last week, analysts said.
Some commercial lenders were yet to make the fullest possible preparations to ride out the downturn in the economic cycle, Pithi said.
"I don't think some of us have actually faced reality and admitted that we have problems. The thing to do is admit your problems and provide a suitable remedy to the situation," Pithi said.
Interest rates might now rise in the short term and analysts said banks' decision to raise deposit rates last week signalled intensifying competition for deposits which could further squeeze bank profits this year.
"It suggests the banks are not entirely confident themselves of the extent of foreign capital inflows so the knock-on affect is a squeeze on domestic funding costs," said the analyst.
"Can you pass that on to your borrowers? Probably not at the moment because they are struggling already," he said. ($1 = 30 baht)

headline: Shenzhen Development Bank 1996 dividend unchanged.
text:
Shenzhen Development Bank on Tuesday left its 1996 dividend plan unchanged following a vote by shareholders at an annual general meeting.
Investors had feared the bank would change its dividend plan after the Shenzhen-listed domestic currency A share firm was punished by regulators for illegally trading its own shares.  
Investors were worried about a possible dividend adjustment after Beijing seized more than 90 million yuan in profits from the bank's illegal share activity.
The bank would make a five-for-10 bonus issue plus a cash payment of 0.2 yuan per share based on 1996 profits, it announced at the shareholders' meeting.
"I think the A share market is going to trend higher on Wednesday as investors laud the bank's dividend," said Xu Yinhui, an analyst at China Guotai Securities.
Trading in the bank's A shares was suspended on Tuesday pending the announcement and would resume on Wednesday afternoon, the Shenzhen Stock Exchange said.
The bank forecasts pre-tax profits would reach 1.0 billion yuan in 1997, up by 81.21 million yuan from last year, bank chairman Xu Jicai told shareholders.
He did not issue a net profit forecast.
Outstanding deposits would hit 30.6 billion yuan by the end of 1997, up 7.982 billion yuan or around 35 percent from end-1996, Xu said.
The company posted a net profit of 787.48 million yuan for 1996 against 435.13 million in 1995 under Chinese accounting standards.
The bank's earnings growth would slow in 1997 due to a rise in the business tax rate and lower income from securities business, Xu said, but did not give details.
Beijing last month ousted the bank's former president He Yun for the share trading scandal as part of a crackdown on stock-related irregularities.

headline: Toyota says looking at making vehicles in Russia.
text:
Toyota Motor Corp said on Tuesday it would send a delegation to Russia soon to look into the possibility of making commercial vehicles there.
"The mission, which will be sent soon, will look at the possibility of assembling vehicles in Russia. The type of vehicle is likely to be a commercial vehicle," Toyota executive vice president Akira Yokoi told Reuters.
Toyota president Hiroshi Okuda told a news conference on Tuesday that there was a possibility Toyota could begin assembling the vehicles in Russia in one or two years, although full production was unlikely in the near future.
Yokoi, who is in charge of overseas business for Toyota, also said no decision had been made yet on where and when it would begin making a small car in Europe.
Toyota said in March it was considering making small cars at a possible new plant in Europe for launch in 1999.
Toyota's European production activities are currently based in Britain. A second plant will be operational in Derbyshire, central England, from 1998.
Toyota officials said cars expected to be made at the new plant in Europe would go on sale in Japan first.
"Yes, we plan to produce and sell (the small cars) in Japan," said Akihiro Wada, a Toyota executive vice president in charge of car development.
Yokoi also said Toyota may apply to the Indian government within the next two weeks for permission to build cars there with its Indian joint venture partner.
He said the company was in the final stages of finalising details with its Indian partner.
Yokoi said its partner, the Kirloskar Group, may take a 26 percent stake in the venture, with the rest held by Toyota.
In late June, Vikram Kirloskar, chairman of Mysore Kirloskar Ltd, said Toyota planned to hold a 70 to 80 percent stake in the venture to produce a sports utility vehicle from 1999.

headline: RESEARCH ALERT - Singer Thai rated sell.
text:
Paribas Asia Equity Ltd on Tuesday rated Singer Thailand Plc a sell, saying the recent baht depreciation would hurt profitability, increase costs of imported parts and foreign funding, and dampen consumer demand for its products.
"All of the company's products are either imported or carry a large import content. The company can either raise prices and face lower demand, or keep prices stable but bear the higher costs of procurement," Paribas Asia said in a report.  
Thailand on July 2 let its baht loose on a managed float regime, a decision leading to its de factor depreciation of about 15 percent.
"With the depreciated baht, a large number of businesses and consumers will most likely curtail their spending due to wage restraints, higher financing costs and inflationary pressures. Singer's business unfortunately will be negatively affected both in terms of overall sales as well as an increase in delinquent hire purchase loans," Paribas Asia said.
It said Singer would also lose market share to competitors carrying domestically manufactured products.
Singer Thailand rose three baht to 119 at 0857 GMT on Tuesday.
-- Bangkok newsroom (662) 652-0642

headline: Informatics calls off Australian deals.
text:
Informatics Holdings Ltd said on Tuesday it decided not to go ahead with an acquisition in Australia as certain conditions were not met.
Informatics, which provides computer training services, had agreed to buy 30 percent of Education and Training Australia Pty Ltd for S$4.99 million by way of new shares earlier in March.
The transaction was due to be completed on July 21 but the vendors of the Australian firm had not been able to fulfill certain conditions, a company statement said.
Informatics did not say what these conditions were.
- Singapore Newsroom 65-8703080

headline: China passenger rail travel up 25 pct in June.
text:
The number of rail travellers in China soared in June, rising 25 percent compared with the year-ago month, the Xinhua news agency said on Tuesday.
China's railways carried a total of 2.22 million passengers last month, it said, quoting the Ministry of Railways.
"This is a considerable increase after years of sluggish rail transport service," Xinhua said, adding that in recent years more people had turned to road or air transport for faster or more comfortable service.
The railways, once the top transport choice of tens of millions of Chinese, have struggled to compete with long-distance buses and airlines in recent years. Last year, rail passenger traffic dropped 12.3 percent from the previous year while air travel boomed.

headline: Taiwan issues Sept 1-15 reformate import tender.
text:
Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp (CPC) has issued a tender to buy 250,000 barrels of 95-octane unleaded reformate for delivery between September 1-15, a company official said on Tuesday.
The tender which seeks the cargo for delivery to Keelung, Kaohsiung, Shalun or Taichung, closes July 29 and is valid for two days.
In its last reformate tender, CPC bought one cargo at $23.30 per barrel, cost-and-freight Taiwan for delivery August 11-20 from a Dutch trader, traders said.
The same trader had earlier sold to CPC two August 1-10 delivery cargoes at $24.60 and $24.76.
-- Singapore Newsroom (+65-870-3086)

headline: S.Korean won ends lower on Ssangyong Group rumours.
text:
The won closed lower on Tuesday as rumours of financial troubles in the nation's sixth largest Ssangyong Group sparked speculative dollar buying and dollar short-covering, dealers said.
A Ssangyong Group spokesman, denying talk of the group's troubles, said: "That's just a vicious, groundless rumour that is going around."
The won closed at 894.40, compared with Monday's close of 892.40. The won see-sawed at around the 892 won level on different views of the impact from depositary receipts by the Housing and Commercial Bank.  
The won fell to a daily low of 894.50 on short dollar covering as many banks went short on dollars on Monday when the central bank stepped into the makret five times.
Dealers said they were concerned about the impact on the Korean economy of Kia Group's troubles and a possible chain of defaults by big conglomerates.
But further falls on the won were limited on fears of the central bank's intervention. A Bank of Korea official said on Monday the bank wanted the dollar to move below 895 won.
Wednesday's mid-rate was expected to be fixed at 893.50 against 893.40 today. -- Yeom Yoon-jeong (822) 727 5647

headline: Taiwan tenders to buy jet fuel for Sep 1-20.
text:
Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp (CPC) has issued a tender to buy 32,000 tonnes of jet fuel for September 1-20 delivery, cost-and-freight (c-and-f) Keelung or Shenao, a CPC official said on Tuesday.
The tender closes on July 30 and offers should be valid for two days.
In its last tender, CPC purchased one 32,000-tonne cargo at around $197 per tonne for August 1-10 delivery, c-and-f basis.
-- Singapore Newsroom (+65 870 3093)

headline: KL overnight steady at 8.7 pct, Negara seen lending.
text:
The overnight interbank rate was steady at 8.7 percent on Tuesday with the central Bank Negara seen injecting fresh funds into the market, dealers said.
"Bank Negara is lending funds at 8.7 percent and this is capping the overnight at that level," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank.
Agent banks of Bank Negara were seen lending one-month funds in the morning, pulling interbank rates lower.
Earlier, one-month money was at 8.5 percent against 9.0/9.3 percent on Monday.
The three-month rate was at 8.0/8.3 percent against 8.0/9.0 percent.
Dealers said there was room for more downside.
"Rates should come off further but the fall is expected to be gradual," said another dealer.
He expects the one-month to stablise around 8.0 percent.
Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim said last week that Malaysia did not favour a high interest rate regime.
Dealers said direction of interbank rates would continue to be determined by the central bank's operations.
"It's a matter of how quickly Bank Negara wants rates to fall and to what level," one said.
Bank Negara was said to have injected funds over the past week to help ease market tightness.
Recent heavy buying of the ringgit by the central bank to defend the currency from speculative attack had caused a liquidity squeeze.
Bank Negara said on Tuesday its foreign exchange reserves fell to 61.9 billion ringgit as at July 15 against 70.71 billion a fortnight earlier, which confirmed market estimates of the size of its interventions.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were steady after recent gains.
At 0800 GMT, the three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was unchanged at 92.43, or an implied yield of 7.57 percent.
The December contract was also unchanged at 92.64, or 7.36 percent.
-- Syed Azman (603-201 4813) .

headline: China vigilant against separatism in Moslem region.
text:
Officials in China's restive Moslem region of Xinjiang have called for a people's war against separatists and illegal religious activities, saying anti-Chinese sentiment lingered after bloody riots this year.
"We must maintain sharp vigilance," the Xinjiang Daily quoted Amudun Niyaz, chairman of the Xinjiang People's Congress, or local parliament, as telling officials in the town of Yining where nine people were killed in anti-Chinese riots last February.
"(We) must motivate the masses to launch a people's war against ethnic separatists and illegal religious activities," he was quoted as saying in a report in the newspaper's July 17 edition, available in Beijing on Tuesday.
Although authorities had successfully suppressed the February riots, a handful of separatists had not resigned themselves to defeat, he told the officials in Yining, a town near the border with Kazakhstan.
"We must maintain high vigilance and be profoundly aware that the main dangers threatening Xinjiang's stability are ethnic splittism and illegal religious activities," Amudun Niyaz said.
The February riots, which began as a demonstration for Xinjiang independence, left nine people dead and 198 injured.
Three people were executed and 27 sentenced to prison terms ranging from seven years to life for their roles in the riots.
"Our struggle against national separatists is neither an ethnic nor a religious problem," Amudun Niyaz said. "It is a political struggle between those who safeguard the motherland's unification and security and those who split the motherland.
He accused foreign forces of providing support to the separatists in the mainly Moslem region of Xinjiang.
"It is a complete waste of time for a small handful of ethnic separatists to think they can realise their dream with the support of foreign anti-Chinese powers," he said.
"No power can separate Xinjiang from the motherland," he said.
Militants of Xinjiang's Uighur ethnic minority have said they want to set up an independent state of "East Turkestan" in Xinjiang, which borders Afghanistan, Pakistan and three mostly Moslem Central Asian states.
In May, eight people in Xinjiang were executed after being found guilty of involvement in crimes, including the planting of home-made bombs in the regional capital, Urumqi, that killed nine people.
The Urumqi bombings coincided with the funeral rites in Beijing of paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, who died on February 19.
Exiled ethnic Uighurs have claimed responsibility for the bombings and vowed to stage more attacks until they gain freedom for their Moslem homeland.
Last year, the region was rocked by several assassination attempts against government officials and religious leaders regarded as being pro-Beijing.

headline: Brent marked up on firmer NYMEX; watching Iraq.
text:
September Brent crude futures closed firmer on Tuesday in Asia in line with modest gains on NYMEX.
September Brent traded at $18.17, up eight cents from London, which had dropped three cents overnight to close at $18.09.
Brokers said news Iraq will take another step closer to resuming oil sales Tuesday, by formally presenting its aid distribution plan to the U.N., offered a bearish backdrop to the market.  
However, they did not expect any price fall out over the news, which was factored in on Monday and through last week.
Prices short term could face declines on headline trading though as more precise details emerge on Iraq's sales plans, especially given a time crunch for the first $1 billion worth.
NYMEX August crude, trading on the our-of-hours ACCESS system, was last traded at $19.27 per barrel, up nine cents from New York and little moved during the Asian day.
--Singapore Newsroom (+65 870 3081)

headline: China's Beijing Orient mulls A share IPO.
text:
Beijing Orient Electronics (Group) Co Ltd said on Tuesday it planned to make an initial public offering (IPO) of domestic currency A shares around the end of 1997.
The plan had yet to be approved by the China Securities Regulatory Commission, a company official told the Hong Kong-based newsletter China Securities Bulletin.
She did not give the size of the issue.
Proceeds from the proposed A share issue would be used to finance a new joint venture with a Taiwan-based firm to make colour television tubes, she said but gave no further details.
Beijing Orient, a maker of lamps and television components, listed 115 million hard currency B shares on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange last month.
"Our earnings in the first half were better than expected," she said by telephone from the company's headquarters in Beijing. But she declined to elaborate.
The company forecast 1997 net profits of at least 122.5 million yuan under international accounting standards.
Its 1996 net profit was 111 million yuan compared with 102 million yuan in 1995 under international standards.
($1=8.3 yuan)
